HEADLINE: Focus: Cleveland;
Looking to Score With a Sports Complex

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STOFFEL

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
A $2.7-MILLION excavation project for a new sports complex on 28 acres just south of the city's center marks the beginning of one of the largest downtown developments in recent history. It is also one of the few projects on schedule in what has become a near standstill in development.
The site, just three blocks from Public Square, is being cleared for the $361.7 million Gateway project, a combination open-air stadium and indoor arena. 
 The sports complex will create a strong southern anchor for the city. Not only will it help retain major league teams and provide space for national conventions, but it will also stretch the urban center southward to meet main highway interchanges.
There are long-term plans for museums and commercial developments on the Lake Erie waterfront several blocks north of the project, and they and Gateway are viewed as major elements in an effort to build an image for the city as a place to visit, not just as a center for business.
Gateway is "a very definite component in our downtown plan to concentrate attractions and create Cleveland as a destination center," said Hunter Morrison, the city planner.
Its completion in 1994 is also being counted on to spur additional redevelopment. Both the Cleveland Indians baseball team, already downtown, and the Cavaliers basketball team, now in an outlying suburb, have made commitments to the new complex and are expected to draw two to four million people a year into the city.
The open-air stadium will accommodate 43,000 Indians fans, and 29,000 additional seats can be built for football fans if the Browns are successfully wooed from their longtime home at the Municipal Stadium.
Cavaliers basketball games as well as hockey games, concerts and other events are slated for the 21,000-seat indoor arena. A total of 3,200 parking spaces will be provided on site initially, with more possible later.
The face of Public Square changed dramatically in the last decade with the completion of the $400 million renovation of the landmark 52-story Terminal Tower and the addition of the 57-story Society Center, now the city's tallest building. These days, however, the economic climate is being blamed for stalling several projects in the planning stages.
The Indians' co-owners, Richard E. and David Jacobs, fans and the American League have long considered the 61-year-old lakefront Municipal Stadium unsuitable for the team. Built for track and field events in an effort to attract the Olympics, it has since been modified for the Indians and the Cleveland Browns football team.
Momentum for a new ballpark began in the mid-80's, but voters defeated a 1984 referendum to raise property taxes to help finance a long-since-abandoned plan for a domed stadium. Still, planning continued. A $4 million loan (since forgiven) was granted in 1985 by the State of Ohio to help buy land. Two years later, demolition of warehouse buildings in the so-called Central Market district left room for a 3,000-space parking lot.
THE city and the county joined forces in 1990 to form Gateway Development Corporation, a nonprofit group charged with overseeing the project's development. Its nine-member panel is headed by James M. Biggar, chairman of the Glencairn Corporation, a local developer, and former chairman of Nestle Enterprises.
But the biggest boost came in 1990 when voters approved an excise tax on cigarettes and alcohol to pay for tax-exempt bonds, which will provide $153.8 million toward construction costs, meeting a Federal deadline for gaining tax-exempt status.
"Had the tax-free-bond provision been allowed to sunset and the bonds had not been sold, the project wouldn't have happened," said Mr. Morrison.
Since the bond offering began in September 1990, $18.8 million of $21.2 million expected has been raised from the sale of luxury seating. Short-term lease sales are to bring in an additional $25.3 million with arena luxury seating adding $4 million more. Twenty-four companies have paid $45,000 to $100,000 in advance for 10-year leases on private loge seating. Game tickets are not included.
"The unique thing about Cleveland is the commitment of the corporate community to the vitality of the city's downtown," said Harry C. Howell 3d, vice president for marketing for Gateway. "They didn't sign leases because they wanted the suite; they did it for the project."
Construction costs beyond money realized from the sale of bonds will be met by other state and Cuyahoga County sources.Parking revenues and the sale of the right to name the complex are being counted on for $21 million. In addition, a local development partnership formed by Cleveland Tommorrow, a civic group, has provided a $28 million loan and local charitable foundations have come up with $4 million.
The Cavaliers have a 30-year lease in which the rent is figured as a share of suite revenue and tickets sold; the Indians, who have a 20-year lease, have agreed to commit $20 million from their premium seating to the construction fund. Their rent will be based on attendance.
DESIGNED by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum of Kansas City, the firm responsible for the new Camden Yards ballpark opening this season for the Baltimore Orioles and the recently completed Comiskey Park for the White Sox in Chicago, the Indians' stadium at Gateway will give fans a full view of downtown.
Arena designs, completed by Ellerbe Becket of Kansas City, also include two restaurants, a food court, a Cavaliers team retail store and practice courts. Construction is expected to begin later this spring, with completion planned for August 1994.
Both sports facilities will be owned by Cuyahoga County once the debt is retired.
There are divergent views on whether having a major league team in a new ballpark will position the city nationally to attract visitors and conventions. Successful convention and tourist towns, such as San Diego, San Francisco and Chicago, for example, have either better weather or more attractions than Cleveland.
"There are upper limits on the number of conventions out there and other cities possess natural attributes over Cleveland," said Norman Krumholz, a former city planning director who is now an urban affairs specialist at Cleveland State University. "Are we going to compete with San Francisco? I don't think so. The whole point of the stadium is to hold on to the Indians. If we lost them, we wouldn't be a big-league town anymore and that would be disastrous to the morale and pride of the city."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Architect's rendering of the new stadium in Cleveland. (Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum)

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Looking to Score With a Sports Complex

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STOFFEL

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
A $2.7 million excavation project for a new sports complex on 28 acres just south of the city's center marks the beginning of one of the largest downtown developments in recent history. It is also one of the few projects on schedule in what has become a near standstill in development.
The site, just three blocks from Public Square, is being cleared for the $361.7 million Gateway project, a combination open-air stadium and indoor arena. 
 The sports complex will create a strong southern anchor for the city. Not only will it help retain major league teams and provide space for national conventions, but it will also stretch the urban center southward to meet main highway interchanges.
There are long-term plans for museums and commercial developments on the Lake Erie waterfront several blocks north of the project, and they and Gateway are viewed as major elements in an effort to build an image for the city as a place to visit, not just as a center for business.
Gateway is "a very definite component in our downtown plan to concentrate attractions and create Cleveland as a destination center," said Hunter Morrison, the city planner.
Its completion in 1994 is also being counted on to spur additional redevelopment. Both the Cleveland Indians baseball team, already downtown, and the Cavaliers basketball team, now in an outlying suburb, have made commitments to the new complex and are expected to draw two to four million people a year into the city.
The open-air stadium will accommodate 43,000 Indians fans, and 29,000 additional seats can be built for football fans if the Browns are successfully wooed from their longtime home at the Municipal Stadium.
Cavaliers basketball games as well as hockey games, concerts and other events are slated for the 21,000-seat indoor arena. A total of 3,200 parking spaces will be provided on site initially, with more possible later.
The face of Public Square changed dramatically in the last decade with the $400 million renovation of the landmark 52-story Terminal Tower and the addition of the 57-story Society Center, now the city's tallest building. These days, however, the economic climate is being blamed for stalling several projects in the planning stages.
The Indians' co-owners, Richard E. and David Jacobs, the team's fans and the American League have long considered the 61-year-old lakefront Municipal Stadium unsuitable. Built for track and field events in an effort to attract the Olympics, it has since been modified for the Indians and the Cleveland Browns football team.
Momentum for a new ballpark began to build in the mid-80's, but voters in 1984 turned down raising property taxes to help finance a long-since-abandoned plan for a domed stadium. Still, planning continued. A $4 million loan (since forgiven) was granted in 1985 by the State of Ohio to help buy land. Two years later, demolition of warehouse buildings in the so-called Central Market district left room for a 3,000-space parking lot.
The city and the county joined forces in 1990 to form Gateway Development Corporation, a nonprofit group charged with overseeing the project's development. Its nine-member panel is headed by James M. Biggar, chairman of the Glencairn Corporation, a local developer, and former chairman of Nestle Enterprises.
But the biggest boost came in 1990 when voters approved an excise tax on cigarettes and alcohol to pay for tax-exempt bonds, which will provide $153.8 million toward construction costs, meeting a Federal deadline for gaining tax-exempt status.
"Had the tax-free-bond provision been allowed to sunset and the bonds had not been sold, the project wouldn't have happened," said Mr. Morrison.
Since the bond offering began in September 1990, $18.8 million of $21.2 million expected has been raised from the sale of luxury seating. Short-term lease sales are to bring in an additional $25.3 million with arena luxury seating adding $4 million more. Twenty-four companies have paid $45,000 to $100,000 in advance for 10-year leases on private loge seating. Game tickets are not included.
"The unique thing about Cleveland is the commitment of the corporate community to the vitality of the city's downtown," said Harry C. Howell 3d, vice president for marketing for Gateway. "They didn't sign leases because they wanted the suite; they did it for the project."
Construction costs beyond money realized from the sale of bonds will be met by an expected state capital budget appropriation of $25 million; $12 million in state loans, $6 million pending from highway funds, $5.1 million in interest on bond investments and $2.5 million on other investments. Cuyahoga County is also being asked for a $75 million loan. Parking revenues and the sale of the right to name the complex are being counted on for $21 million.
In addition, a local development partnership formed by Cleveland Tommorrow, a civic group, has provided a $28 million loan and local charitable foundations have come up with $4 million.
Late last year, the state approved a property-tax cap providing that the development be taxed only on the current value of the land and not on its improvements. To compensate the city's schools and public entities, a $1 million pool was earmarked in the bill to come from city income taxes on Gateway workers.
The Cavaliers have a 30-year lease in which the rent is figured as a share of suite revenue and tickets sold; the Indians, who have a 20-year lease, have agreed to commit $20 million from their premium seating to the construction fund. Their rent will be based on attendance.
Designed by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum of Kansas City, the firm responsible for the new Camden Yards ballpark opening this season for the Baltimore Orioles and the recently completed Comiskey Park for the White Sox in Chicago, the Indians' stadium at Gateway will give fans a full view of downtown.
Three levels of luxury loges will create private seating for up to 1,416 and semiprivate club seating for 2,140 more. Loge owners will have access to free parking and a separate entrance and walkway to the park.
Private loge and club seating will be offered in the arena as well, along with a separate entrance and free private parking.
Arena designs, completed by Ellerbe Becket of Kansas City, also include two restaurants, a food court, a Cavaliers team retail store and practice courts. Construction is expected to begin later this spring, with completion planned for August 1994.
Designs for the project also include a 90,000-square-foot underground truck garage and several pedestrian plazas.
Huber Hunt & Nichols of Indianapolis last year was awarded a $5.1 million contract to manage the stadium construction; Turner Construction of New York was awarded a $5.5 million contract to oversee construction of the arena.
Both sports facilities will be owned by Cuyahoga County once the debt is retired.
There are divergent views on whether having a major league team in a new ballpark will position the city nationally to attract visitors and conventions. Successful convention and tourist towns, such as San Diego, San Francisco and Chicago, for example, have either better weather or more attractions than Cleveland.
"There are upper limits on the number of conventions out there and other cities possess natural attributes over Cleveland," said Norman Krumholz, a former city planning director who is now an urban affairs specialist at Cleveland State University. "Are we going to compete with San Francisco? I don't think so. The whole point of the stadium is to hold on to the Indians. If we lost them, we wouldn't be a big-league town anymore and that would be disastrous to the morale and pride of the city."

LENGTH: 1195 words

HEADLINE: Convention Bureau Is Wooing Bus Tours

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
IN the latest attempt to bring an influx of new dollars to Westchester hotels and tourist attractions, a marketing campaign is under way to turn the county into what is known in the travel industry as a hub and spoke destination for bus tours.
"It's a concept that has worked very well in generating additional revenues for the hospitality industry in other parts of the country," said Richard Eisley, president of the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau. "The plan is to get motor-coach companies to hub their coaches and passengers at Westchester hotels and spoke out every day, so to speak, to attractions in surrounding areas." 
 The concept would work particularly well for Westchester, he said, because of its proximity to Manhattan and the Hudson River Valley, both top destinations for passengers on organized bus tours.
 
High Expectations
 "We expect to draw visitors from as far away as the West Coast, the Midwest, the Sun Belt and Europe," he said. "What we are selling is location and hotels by making the point that by staying in Westchester, visitors will not only have easy access to all the attractions in New York City, which is the mecca for tourists, but they will also have the nature preserves and historical landmarks in New York State and Connecticut."
He added that despite a hotel tax of 3 percent in Westchester, room rates here are lower than those in New York City, whose hotels have a 5 percent room tax and a higher sales tax.
Even overnight stops would give local hotels and attractions a boost, Mr. Eisley said. According to a travel research company in New Bedford, Mass., "the average expenditure for a motor coach with 48 passengers is $4,695 spent locally overnight for lodging, meals and attractions," he said.
 
Visiting the Trade Shows
 In order to woo major tour companies, the bureau has embarked on a vigorous marketing program that includes participation in trade shows, including one in Kingston, N.Y., this month that is expected to attract 1,000 tour operators. The bureau is also expecting 50 tour-company representatives for a three-day familiarization tour of the county in May.
"We're having a mini-trade show on one of the days for the motor-coach people to talk to everyone here, from hotel reps to shopping-mall people, on a one-to-one basis," Mr. Eisley said.
David Thornton, a tour-operator marketing specialist who is acting as an adviser to the bureau, said the county's chances of success were good.
"Not only does Westchester have the scenic attractions and historic restorations that attract foreign and domestic visitors," Mr. Thornton said, "but Westchester is a crossroads that everyone has to go through to get to New England and west of the Hudson. And hordes of Canadians come through the county on their way to Manhattan.
"It's time for Westchester to capitalize on getting all those motor coaches to stop overnight in the county," he added.
 
Hotels Say They Need Help
 "Our hotels need all the help they can get," said Bruce Gorelick, president of the Westchester Hotel Association and general manager of the 443-room Westchester Marriott Hotel in Tarrytown.
"During a recession as deep as this one, fewer meetings and conventions are being held," he said. "Hotel business is down. It's an uphill fight for our hotels to keep in the black. We need something to stop the bleeding."
Hotels need a 66 percent occupancy rate just to break even, Mr. Gorelick said, but the average occupancy rates for hotels in Westchester this year have been between 58 and 60 percent.
The 3 percent hotel room tax levied by the county was bitterly fought by the industry, and Mr. Gorelick blamed it on a weak economy worsened by giving hotels in Connecticut and northern New Jersey a price advantage.
"When identical rooms in the same hotel chain cost $15 to $20 less in Stamford than in Westchester, you can see what we are up against," he said.
 
Hard Times for Hotels
 Mr. Gorelick gave a litany of examples to illustrate the difficult times hotels are facing: "Although they are still operating, Days Inn in Elmsford is in receivership. Some other hotels in the county are experiencing such difficulties that they have been lowering their rates to dangerous levels. Some are offering rates as low as $75, even $50, just to cover fixed costs. But hotels can't continue to operate that way for very long."
Taking what Mr. Gorelick calls a defensive action, the hoteliers are meeting with county and state legislators this month.
"We want to discuss the impact the hotel tax has had on our business," he said. "Most urgently, we hope to quash the specter of a possible increase in the hotel tax to 5 percent, which we hear is favored by some officials. Given the hard facts that we're doing everything just to survive, the thought of a tax increase is ludicrous."
To make the hotel tax more palatable when it was enacted, 15 percent, or $282,000, of the tax revenue of $1.88 million in the latest figures, was earmarked for financing the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau.
 
Association Contributes $8,000
 "Eighty-five percent of the money collected from the hotel room tax goes into the county general fund for other uses," Mr. Gorelick said. "We, as an association, want to go on record that we are so anxious to bring business into the county that with money out of our own pockets we have contributed $8,000 to the convention bureau to help put another salesperson on the staff. And we expect great things."
This year, Mr. Eisley said, in addition to the $8,000 in cooperative funds from the hotels, the Yonkers Raceway and Playland, the convention bureau received its 15 percent share of the hotel tax, or $282,000, and $32,000 from the state, bringing its total yearly budget to $322,000.
"Our bus-familiarization trip is in May," he said, "but because bus people don't buy overnight stays until at least six months after, we can only look for day trips beginning in November." He said that the revenue from day trips is hard to quantify, but he added that the National Tour Association estimates that a busload of passengers spends $2,199 in meals, attractions, transportation and passenger incidentals in one day.
 
And Don't Forget Conventions
 The bureau has also been promoting Westchester's convention and meeting possibilities. "Our first trade show in Albany drew executives from 22 different associations in the Capital Region and resulted in the sale of 1,200 hotel rooms," Mr. Eisley said.
Mr. Eisley estimated that the bureau's marketing efforts directed at bringing conventions to the county will fill 2,415 more hotel rooms, generating $274,706 in business and taxes.
The county also participated in a recent trade show at the New York Hilton in Manhattan. "Representatives from 30 large organizations circulated through the exhibition area, stopping to discuss prices with a sales team from 12 Westchester hotels, Playland and Yonkers Raceway," Mr. Eisley said.
"The hotels said they got a lot of good leads that they would follow up on," he added. "We're satisfied with the turnout. Now we'll wait and see."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A recent trade show at the Hilton in Manhattan, one of several the Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau attended to provide information about county tourist attractions. (Westchester Convention and Visitors Bureau)

HEADLINE: Minnesota Death Trip

BYLINE: By Caleb Carr; Caleb Carr's most recent book is "The Devil Soldier: The Story of Frederick Townsend Ward."

 BODY:

OVER THE EARTH I COME
The Great Sioux Uprising of 1862.
By Duane Schultz.
Illustrated. 307 pp. New York:
A Thomas Dunne Book/
St. Martin's Press. $21.95. 
 FROM the early 17th century to the late 19th century, the behavior of white settlers in America toward the native American tribes they encountered, as well as toward the land they expropriated from those tribes, was conditioned by one overriding factor: settlement was generally their last hope. Propelled by experiences of religious, ethnic and economic turmoil, the settlers had staked not only their fortunes but also their very lives on the hope of building new lives in untried country.
For the Indians the settlers displaced, the terms of the conflict were, in the beginning, slightly less mortal, but that mortality grew as the tribes saw their lands shrink drastically with the passing of generations. These circumstances alone would suffice to explain the extraordinary savagery that generally marked hostilities between the settlers and the native Americans; when we add the fact that both sides had made important cultural rituals out of heinous violence long before they ever encountered each other, it becomes clear that an almost unlimited potential for nightmarish behavior existed.
Duane Schultz's capably researched and tautly written "Over the Earth I Come" reminds us that responsibility for the abominable events that occurred during the Indian wars cut across ethnic boundaries. Mr. Schultz successfully resists the pressures of political correctness that reached their apogee with the release of the movie "Dances With Wolves" and offers vivid evidence that barbarity and treachery are qualities that characterize all groups, tribes and nations.
Mr. Schultz -- the author of several books on the Second World War, including "The Doolittle Raid," as well as "Month of the Freezing Moon: The Sand Creek Massacre, November 1864" -- uses a journalistic narrative style to bring to life the great Sioux uprising of 1862 in Minnesota, an event that cost the lives of hundreds of white settlers and eventually led to the largest mass execution in American history (38 Indians were hanged simultaneously), as well as to the expulsion of nearly all native Americans -- not just the guilty Sioux -- from their lands in that state.
Clearly, this was not a situation similar to the enslavement of black Africans or the genocidal extermination of Jews in Nazi Germany, two false analogies often cited in studies of American expansion. Rather, Mr. Schultz paints the Minnesota encounter as what it was: a war, a total war between rival nations for control of territory both groups were willing to die for.
Each side receives Mr. Schultz's muted disapproval: the whites for the way they forced and finally resolved the conflict, the Indians for the way they conducted it. Without overstating his case, he cites the causes of Sioux dissatisfaction, which are all familiar: "the broken treaties, the routine cheating by traders, the near-starvation conditions." By midsummer 1862 the Sioux living on their tribe's principal reservation were desperate, and some were turning to violence. But their chief, Little Crow, resisted calls for an armed insurrection. He confronted Tom Galbraith, the reservation's new Indian agent, and a collection of traders, notably the exploitative and successful Andrew Myrick, with his people's plight. Little Crow demanded food. The essential white reaction was summed up by Myrick: "So far as I am concerned, if they are hungry, let them eat grass or their own dung." As Mr. Schultz comments with typical and admirable understatement, "Andrew Myrick would pay for that remark."
Unfortunately, not only Myrick but scores of innocent white men, women and especially children paid as well. Throughout the summer, Sioux warriors engaged in atrocious behavior that often had little to do with righting wrongs or even with ritualized violence: it was simple sadism and blood lust, usually aggravated by whisky. The settlers were most often done in not by their hatred of the Indians but by the seeming friendships they had formed with them: approached by old Sioux acquaintances they had befriended with food and shelter, many settlers were murdered in the coldest of blood, the native Americans exhibiting a particular penchant for torturing infants and children.
Mr. Schultz does not fail to find individual as well as general parallels between the white and Indian sides: both Little Crow, the leader of the uprising, and Henry Sibley, the popular former Governor of Minnesota who eventually put it down (he was chosen to lead the campaign against the Sioux because of his extensive personal dealings with them), are drawn as three-dimensional, deeply flawed characters, each of whom pursued his appointed task reluctantly but relentlessly. In the fall of 1862, having lost a string of battles, Little Crow led most of his "hostiles" out of Minnesota, leaving behind a large group of white hostages and many "friendlies," Sioux who had opposed the uprising but who were punished by the whites anyway. Hundreds of Indians were sentenced to death that winter, though President Abraham Lincoln approved the execution of only 38 of them. At least some of those 38 were not guilty of any crimes; one had even saved a white woman and her family at great personal risk. But the innocent had made the terrible mistake of throwing themselves on the mercy of the revenge-obsessed whites.
Historically, the uprising represented the overture to the Plains Wars, during which the Sioux would fight the whites far more skillfully and with far greater success. Yet the essential terms and tone of the conflict, judiciously brought to life by Duane Schultz in "Over the Earth I Come," were set in 1862. If it is a less than inspiring story, it is certainly necessary to any balanced understanding of our nation's expansion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The hanging of 38 Sioux Indians at Mankato, Minn., on Dec. 26, 1862. (Minnesota Historical Society/From "Over The Earth I Come")

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: OVER THE EARTH I COME (BOOK)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%); GERMANY (51%);

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
In the Case of a Missing Publisher, All the Cards Are Now on the Table

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Should anyone make a movie about Domer Ringuette, it would probably be called "Domer, Run," in tribute to John Updike's Rabbit. And behind the opening credits, a gleeful Mr. Ringuette would be humming "On The Road Again," Willie Nelson's anthem to the exquisite joy of leaving it all behind.
On a Monday last August, Mr. Ringuette -- weekly newspaper owner, pillar of small business and local politician in Chicopee, Mass. -- abruptly disappeared without a word to employees, bankers, customers, newspaper readers or even the mayor. 
 When employees of his paper, The Chicopee Herald, went to his house to check on him, they found it empty, except for an ironing board.
 
'Walking Away From Assets
 Mr. Ringuette, at 53 years old, had done what many dream of doing: he had simply driven away from position, responsibility and assets that he estimates -- rather optimistically -- to be worth as much as $750,000, after his debts were settled.
"I had made up my mind to be free, so I became free," said Mr. Ringuette, who was located five months after he disappeared by The Transcript-Telegram, a daily paper in neighboring Holyoke that received an anonymous tip.
Mr. Ringuette, it turned out, had abandoned his publisher's life to fulfill a dream of becoming a poker dealer. He now deals seven-card stud and Texas hold 'em on the noon-to-8 shift at the Poker Palace in North Las Vegas, Nev., for minimum wage plus tips.
As for the confusion, perplexity and corporate mess he left behind in Chicopee, Mr. Ringuette's position is unequivocal indifference.
"In plain English, if anybody over there has problems, they can go to hell," he said last week.
Now that the shock has worn off somewhat in Chicopee, people seem to view Mr. Ringuette's flight philosophically.
"He was unhappy here and he left," said Dr. John E. Maslar, a chiropractor and local entrepreneur who essentially rescued The Chicopee Herald by hiring Mr. Ringuette's staff and starting a new paper he called The Herald-American.
But Dr. Maslar added, in a sentiment that seems to sum up Chicopee's view of Mr. Ringuette's curious behavior, "It's the weirdest thing in the world."
In the weeks following Mr. Ringuette's disappearance, rumors flew through Chicopee, a blue-collar town of about 57,000 between Springfield and Holyoke in western Massachusetts. Most of the population in Chicopee is of Polish or, like Mr. Ringuette, French-Canadian heritage.
Mr. Ringuette, who spent his entire life in Chicopee, said several rumors had reached him in Las Vegas. One theory was that he had fled to escape huge gambling debts; another had him deep in debt to loan sharks, and it was whispered in Chicopee that he was last seen getting into a sinister-looking black limousine. It was also said that he sometimes quoted poetry to his newspaper employees, though how this was linked to his disappearance was unclear.
 
Afraid of a Change of Mind
 Mr. Ringuette said the rumors about gambling and loan sharks were nonsense. He said he left the way he did because he was afraid he might change his mind if he took the time to sell everything and settle his affairs.
And he said he was fed up with 18-hour workdays, a recession-racked economy that had made money very scarce and the day-to-day frustrations of operating his newspaper, rental property and the Green Valley Country Store and Gas, the convenience store and gas station that he opened every day at 5 A.M. He had been divorced for more than 20 years and his only child, a daughter who lives in Texas, was not interested in publishing.
Under Mr. Ringuette, The Herald shifted from a paid-circulation weekly of about 5,000 to a free-circulation paper of about 25,000 that was distributed in neighboring towns. It had gross revenues of $250,000 to $500,000, the former publisher said.
Most of The Herald's articles were provided by freelance writers or sent in unsolicited. Mayor Joseph J. Chessey Jr. of Chicopee described the paper as a "hometown-type newspaper" with lots of "Girl Scout cookie drive pictures" and such.
"I like working," said Mr. Ringuette, who rejects the idea that he was motivated by laziness. "And I'm a little old for a middle-age crisis."
Indeed, Mayor Chessey and others who knew Mr. Ringuette remember him as hard-working and politically ambitious. A year ago, he had asked Mayor Chessey to appoint him to the Sewer Commission, which sets sewer rates. When Mr. Ringuette left, he was in the midst of an election campaign to become an alderman.
Even so, the Friday before he left, he called a friend and told her she could have his furniture if she would come get it. She came with a truck and removed everything but the ironing board.
On Monday, Aug. 19, he woke as usual at 4:30 A.M., threw some suitcases into his Lincoln Town Car, and left town.
 
Barely Breaking Even
 He said he took what cash he had, but there was not much as his businesses were barely breaking even. Mr. Ringuette declined to provide details, but estimated his debts -- including mortgages, printing bills and about $20,000 that The Herald owed to the Internal Revenue Service -- to be about $1.25 million.
Had he waited until the economy improved and sold out, he roughly estimates his holdings would have brought $2 million, though he declines to explain how he arrived at that figure.
When Mr. Ringuette did not open the convenience store as usual, word spread through Chicopee quickly.
The Chicopee Chief of Police, Joseph J. Wilk, said he never suspected foul play because an officer found no evidence of a break-in at Mr. Ringuette's home. "Everything was safe and sound and gone," he recalled.
When Mr. Ringuette's brothers and sisters, who also live in Chicopee, did not file a missing person's report, everyone concluded that Mr. Ringuette had bolted of his own free will.
At The Herald, Chicopee's only paper, the abandoned staff began a frantic search for a rescuer.
Mr. Ringuette had acquired The Herald in 1983 as a business investment and in hopes that it would eventually help him become mayor.
Though he dropped out of high school, Mr. Ringuette had earned a high school equivalency degree in the Marine Corps and, upon returning to Chicopee, gradually demonstrated acumen as a small-business man. In 1968, he acquired a small variety store, then expanded it to include a laundry and a restaurant he called Domer's Deli. Eventually, he sold that business and bought the convenience store and gas station, as well as real estate and The Herald.
 
Competition Emerges
 But a year ago, the two daily papers in neighboring Springfield and Holyoke had started free-circulation weeklies of their own.
When Mr. Ringuette left, The Herald's employees scrambled to publish that Wednesday's issue and frantically tried to find a backer.
Dr. Maslar, who operates three chiropractic clinics in the area, decided to give it a try, in part to give his son a part-time job as an advertising salesmen. His daughter, who is attending college, writes a column called "The Student's Viewpoint."
"If I had to make a living off this paper, I'd be on a soup line," Dr. Maslar said, though he added that he was making a small profit.
Dr. Maslar's approach was to declare that he was starting a new paper. Whereas Mr. Ringuette's paper had been The Chicopee Herald, the new paper was called The Herald, and quickly changed again to The Herald-American.
The convenience store remains shuttered.
 
Liquidation Likely
 Thomas L. Howard, a tax lawyer at Baker, Worthington, Crossley, Stansberry & Woolf in Washington, said Mr. Ringuette's creditors would liquidate his property, probably for no more than what is owed on them.
Mr. Ringuette says that when he receives letters from the Internal Revenue Service, or from lawyers or the Chicopee Savings Bank -- his main lender -- or the Massachusetts Department of Labor about unpaid wages, he just throws them away.
"If anybody is concerned and wants to put me in jail, they're welcome to," he said. "I don't give a damn; I'm free."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Domer Ringuette fulfilled a dream and mystified most people in Chicopee, Mass., when he suddenly gave up his life as publisher of the local weekly newspaper to deal cards at the Poker Palace in North Las Vegas, Nev. (Jim Laurie for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cut in Road Budget Imperils New York Drivers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's plan to slash highway spending in the New York City Department of Transportation's capital budget embodies the worst of bureaucratic decision making (news article, March 4). The Dinkins administration has moved not only to make the life of a car owner even more precarious, but also to threaten the long-term economic well-being of the future of our city. 
 These shortsighted people proposed cutting the Department of Transportation's capital highway budget by an unbelievable 98 percent: slashing an already inadequate $224 million to just over $4 million. This means, for example, that instead of 15 road crews, only one crew will serve all five boroughs.
I fully understand the need to reorder our priorities in fiscally difficult times, but this plan is irrational. Not only will it mean more pothole damage to front-end alignment, suspensions and tires, but it will also most assuredly lead to an increase in accidents and fatalities on our roads.
This City Hall scheme also threatens the long-term economic recovery of our city. There is little incentive for companies to stay in New York -- let alone invest to expand their job base -- when important deliveries can't be made on schedule and employees can't get to work on time or travel the city streets in safety.
And although I don't own a car, few issues have so direct an impact on our day-to-day life as the condition of our infrastructure.
This City Hall budget proposal is a prescription for disaster; it must be changed.
 
JONI A. YOSWEIN
Assemblywoman, 44th Dist., Bklyn.
Albany, March 11, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2367 words

HEADLINE: Hidden Lives: New York's Poorest Immigrants -- A special report;
Crammed in Tiny, Illegal Rooms, Tenants of the Margins of Survival

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

 BODY:
Up three flights of broken stairs in a garment factory building on the western edge of Chinatown was the windowless 8-by-10-foot cell that Abdulaye Kamara, an immigrant from Senegal, was happy to call home.
His neighbors were mostly people like himself, resourceful immigrants from China, Vietnam, Mexico and a few other countries, living quietly in a warren of 16 cubicles constructed illegally, with no apparent regard for building codes. 
 They had one working toilet, out in the narrow hallway, and no bath or kitchen. The air they breathed was thick with particles of dust and lint, wafting from three other floors where hundreds of Chinese women work at sewing machines from morning till night. They paid $200 to $350 a month and considered it a bargain.
 
Reduced to Rubble
 "I thought, 'This is lucky for me,' " Mr. Kamara said, recalling the day he moved in four years ago. "Manhattan is very high."
This most rudimentary of dwellings is nothing but rubble now, courtesy of four men with sledgehammers who showed up one morning in the wake of a landlord-tenant dispute. Since then, eight tenants have managed to get rooms at a single-room-occupancy hotel on East 28th Street -- a brief respite in the ceaseless search for that rarest of New York commodities: a decent and affordable place for a poor person to live.
But while the fourth floor is no more, the story of 372 Broadway in its hardscrabble heyday -- and of the lives that brought its tenants together there -- is the story of tens of thousands of marginal people who live packed together in similarly subdivided illegal encampments all over New York City.
These are the people who find jobs where there aren't supposed to be any, who manage to survive in New York -- and feed and shelter their families back home. They are the people who sell flowers at highway exits and watches on Fifth Avenue, who drive gypsy cabs in neighborhoods where yellow cabs won't go, who bus tables in Chinatown and deliver takeout at 2 A.M.
They are from China, the Dominican Republic, Colombia, Haiti, Senegal, Mexico and a lot of other places where freedom or work or both are in short supply.
At night here in America, they crowd 10 or more to a basement in East Flatbush, the East Bronx and Washington Heights, or five to a subdivided room in Harlem, Brighton Beach and Elmhurst. In Chinatown, some people sleep in shifts on bunks in barracks-style rooms.
 
More Than 60,000
 They are all citizens of an illegal underground network that has been expanding since the 1970's, as the city's single-room-occupancy hotels have been swallowed by real-estate development. It is impossible to know just how many of these dwellings there are, but urban planners, tenant lawyers, social workers and community organizers, based on their work with the tenants and on reports of evictions from the Fire Department, estimate there are more than 60,000.
The encampment at 372 Broadway was certainly not the worst -- there were sprinklers and fire alarms, and the walls were Sheetrock, not plywood and chicken wire.
"This was actually palatial compared to the standards by which a lot of people are living," said City Councilwoman Kathryn Freed, who is trying to help the tenants.
And Mr. Kamara's cell was palatial compared to where he spent his first six months at 372 Broadway. He is 5-foot-9 and thin, but in the circuit-breaker closet, there was barely space for him to curl up on a narrow mattress on the floor. Mr. Kamara, who is 31 years old, came to America 10 years ago to provide for his mother and nine brothers and sisters back in Dakar. For the last four years, he has done it on a meager $4.25 an hour as a stockboy. The circuit-breaker closet cost $35 a week, cash.
Like Mr. Kamara, the other residents of 372 Broadway, devoted to work and saving money for families back home, led lives as circumscribed as their tiny rooms.
In their two years in America, Fan Yong Guang, 35, and his brother, Fan Yong Yuan, 30, returned every night from the garment factory where they sew zippers to eat rice and vegetables cooked on a hot plate in their room. They have never been to a restaurant, or a movie. Central Park? Fifth Avenue? They had never heard of them.
"I don't know what is in America," the older brother said.
On one of his last nights at 372 Broadway, Mr. Kamara wore a secondhand winter coat as he huddled in his cold cubicle, with only a candle for light. He had just started a new job, as a $5.50-an-hour security guard, and his uniform hung from a hook on the wall. Displayed on a dented metal desk was a Christmas card from his family 4,000 miles away.
On his small tape player, his famous countryman, Youssou N'Dour, sang Mr. Kamara's favorite song, "Immigres," about Senagalese like him who have gone abroad in search of work.
"Every night before I go to sleep I'm thinking about the future," Mr. Kamara said, in the smooth English he says he has taught himself here. His smile was luminous.
"I want to build my mom a house in my country. Not a big house, just four rooms, including the bathroom and kitchen. Mango trees out front. Sometimes I dream I'm sitting under the mango trees with my mom and my brothers and sisters. Then I wake up, and look around, and I'm here."
"This was Frankie's room. Frankie was Spanish. Frankie was a nice guy." Mr. Kamara, the historian of the fourth floor, was giving a tour of a disaster area. Frankie's room was one of those demolished by the sledgehammers, and Frankie had vanished.
So had several Korean peddlers. And Sebastian. "Sebastian was Mexican," Mr. Kamara said. "He sold stuff on the street, sweaters, scarves, everything."
Anyone who was desperate enough to find the way to the fourth floor, and who had cash for rent, could get in. Mr. Kamara arrived after he lost the apartment he shared with five people in the Bronx. Near the electronics store on Canal Street where he was a stockboy, he had spotted the sign: "Room for Rent -- 372 Broadway."
Mee Ying Chan was a mystery tenant. She owns an apartment building in Queens. Still, she insists that she is poor. Last year, she declared herself an Independent candidate for the City Council but then dropped out. Ms. Chan's neighbors enjoyed watching Chinese movies on her VCR, before it was stolen.
In two rooms down the hall lived Gina Doss and Harry Fromer, both from New York. "Gina's in the hospital," Mr. Kamara said.
Mr. Fromer had returned to 372 Broadway after a month's absence -- he had also been in the hospital, he said -- and, before he could reach his door, Mr. Kamara gently broke the news. His room was no more.
"At least we're not on the street," said Mr. Fromer, whose last job was passing out fliers for the Plum Blossom restaurant in Chinatown.
 
Mystery Landlord
Space Leased 'For Storage'
 No one knows who put up the cubicles, though the tenants paid their rent to Javier Arana, who runs a small retail fabric store on the building's ground floor.
City records list the owner of 372 Broadway as the Broadway-White Realty Corporation. Besides that building, the company, which has had many addresses through the years but is not listed in the phone book, owns six apartment buildings in the Bronx. A man involved in the operation of the building, Zalman Deitsch, said he did not know that people were living in the building, which is zoned for commercial use only.
Until recently, Mr. Deitsch said, Mr. Arana leased the fourth floor. He said Mr. Arana told him he was using it for storage. Reached at the fabric store, Mr. Arana said he had nothing to do with the fourth floor and refused to comment further.
For the tenants of the fourth floor, the end may have begun when Ms. Doss, apparently unaware that her room was illegal, took Mr. Arana to housing court last October, demanding repairs. On Feb. 10, a judge fined Mr. Arana $3,500. On Feb. 11, the men with sledgehammers went to work.
 
No Strangers to Trouble
 "Look what they did to the Old Man's home." Mr. Kamara pointed to Room 408, where the front wall had been knocked in. The Old Man, as Mr. Kamara refers respectfully to 78-year-old Tsang Kok Wah, stood there in a soiled raincoat and knit cap.
The tenants were stoic. This disaster was not their first. In the village where he grew up, Mr. Kamara saw other children swallow stones because there wasn't enough food. "For a long time it didn't rain," Mr. Kamara said. "For lunch, we ate a little rice and drank a lot of water. For dinner we had bread and water with sugar. Then everyone moved to the city."
To build his mother's house, Mr. Kamara says he needs $12,000 -- an enormous sum of money in Dakar. After several years of nonstop labor -- peddling umbrellas, icing cookies in a baking factory in the Bronx, making plastic hangers in a factory in Brooklyn -- he had saved $6,000 in a bank in Senegal, he said.
"A few years ago my mom called," he said. "She told me the bank had gone out of business. My money was just gone. I was discouraged. My mom said, 'It happened, it's life. You have to encourage yourself.' So I started over." But he gave up peddling -- it was too risky, he said -- and it is hard just to keep sending money home, let alone to save.
Mr. Tsang wept as he talked through a translator about his losses. His family in China was denounced for owning land when the Communists seized power in 1949.
"The Communists killed my parents," he said. "They executed my brother, and they banged my wife's head on the wall until she died."
Mr. Tsang escaped to Hong Kong. Ten years ago, he came to New York. Here, he said, he is safe from Communists. Though he owns property in Florida, Mr. Tsang said, he can't live anywhere very far from Chinatown. He speaks no English.
On the fourth floor, the only running water was from a small sink in the hallway. How, then, did Mr. Kamara manage to stay so clean?
Mr. Kamara pulled from his pocket the membership card that, for $25 a year, admits him to the Carmine Street city pool, two subway stops and a short walk from his old building. "I love to swim," he said. "I swim half a mile. And I take a shower."
 
Work, Hope, Work
A Better Future For Someone Else?
 On the morning of their last Sunday at 372 Broadway, no tenants were home. Mr. Kamara, dignified in his uniform, was at his security guard post -- at the luxury high-rise next door.
Mr. Tsang was at his job, in Atlantic City, where he trades in cut-rate casino coupons for a modest profit, $4 a ticket. Seven days a week, he commutes by van from Chinatown.
On Canal Street, Fan Yong Guang and his brother were peddling men's dress socks from a cardboard box. "Four for 5 dollar," the older brother said to a couple who stopped only to look. His sales pitch is the only English he knows.
The brothers peddle socks on their days off from the factory in Brooklyn. Some days they sew 200 zippers each; their hands get sore, they said. Other days there is no work.
They each earn about $900 a month, they said. They send $100 a month to their wives in China and put away a few hundred dollars for the day when their families will join them. Food for both of them costs less than $10 a day. They have one luxury -- 10 unfiltered cigarettes apiece a day.
"I'm going to make money for my son," the older brother said. "He's going to go to school, and he's going to learn English. Then, when I'm old, he'll take care of me."
Mr. Kamara is eager to experience the city. "A few years ago, I rented shoes at Rockefeller Center for $10," he said. "I was falling. My friend took my picture. I sent it to my family."
 
The Only Worker
 Ice skating was one evening out of 10 years. Mr. Kamara can't afford small pleasures. "I'm the only one working in my family," he said. "It is very hard to find a job in my country." The only one he could find was pouring nail polish into bottles at a factory for $3.50 a day -- when he could get it.
His mother, Ramatoulaye Diop, speaking in French from the home of a friend in Dakar with a telephone, said the rent on her four-room house is $345 a month. Abdulaye is the one who pays it, she said. She is proud of her second eldest son.
Mr. Kamara gladly put in 11-hour days, seven days a week, as a stockboy at the electronics store. For $45 a day. "I asked the boss for a raise," Mr. Kamara said. "He told me, 'I can get two Mexicans for $45 a day.' "
Mr. Kamara, who has been searching the classifieds for a second job, recently invested $3 in a red tie. He was wearing it with his white shirt the other evening as he walked along bustling Canal Street. "You never know when you could get a job interview," he said. "They won't hire you if you don't look nice."
 
In 'Heaven'
Companionship At an S.R.O.
 At the Latham Hotel, 4 East 28th Street, the eight former tenants of 372 Broadway meet often in one another's rooms after work. "Now we have a lot of problems," Mr. Kamara said. "We talk a lot."
It takes some improvising. Mr. Tsang speaks Cantonese, the brothers Mandarin. Everyone's favorite tenant, Mr. Kamara, makes a point of greeting his Chinese neighbors in their own language: "Ni hao ma?"
Holding tightly to Mr. Kamara's hand, the Chinese brothers repeated their one-word assessment -- in English -- of their sparsely furnished hotel room: "Heaven, heaven!"
After an telephone call from Councilwoman Freed's staff 18 days ago, the Fire Department vacated the tenants, making them the responsibility of the city. If they qualify, they will eventually move to housing projects or city-owned apartments.
 
After All, Hope Flutters
 Mr. Kamara is thinking of the house he wants to build his mother. His dream, he said, seems distant.
"If I had a dream that this was going to be my life in New York," he said, "I would just have stayed in my country and been poor."
But New York is where he is. And, he said, "I have to be hopeful." A few days ago, hope was rising. "I got more hours on my job!" he said. "Double shifts!"
Mr. Kamara heard recently from his 27-year-old brother, Doudou. He can't find a job. "He wants me to send him a plane ticket," Mr. Kamara said. "He wants to come to New York."

HEADLINE: Worries Persisting At the Fed

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Federal Reserve officials say recent data indicate that the economy is picking up steam, but they remain worried that the incipient recovery could peter out.
In interviews last week, two Federal Reserve governors who agreed to speak on the record said that recent reports showing upturns in retail sales and housing starts were the most convincing evidence so far that the stubbornly persistent downturn was ending. But they also said that the manufacturing sector remained subdued and that employment growth was likely to lag. 
 "Taken together, the picture is pretty encouraging, but it is not definitive yet," said David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. "There are still concerns about sustainability."
 
'Positive' First Quarter
 Mr. Mullins said that a few weeks ago, many economists were expecting a flat first quarter, but he said recent data suggested that first-quarter growth "would squarely be in positive territory," although it would still be slow.
He said "the pattern of data bodes well for a stronger second quarter and a return to moderate growth by midyear."
Many analysts say the recent positive data make it unlikely that Fed officials would cut interest rates in the near future because they think the Fed no longer believes that additional monetary easing is necessary to insure recovery. Some Fed officials have said they worry that the markets might view any additional cuts as inflationary.
In an interview today on the ABC News program "This Week With David Brinkley," Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, agreed that the economy was recovering.
"We in the Administration are assuming each quarter throughout this year will be slightly better than the one before," he said, referring to the growth rate of the economy. "I think we can get 3 percent by the third and fourth quarter."
 
Lower Unemployment
 Mr. Darman added that at such a rate "we could have the good fortune of unemployment coming down" from its current level of 7.3 percent. He did not specify a level it might decline to.
The central bank governors pointed to numerous factors that could weaken or reverse the recent upturns. They said the rise in long-term interest rates since January could undermine the momentum in housing sales and residential construction, and they still worried about the persistent low levels of consumer confidence.
They added that the dollar's recent rise could hurt exports by making them more expensive.
"If you think of the two prime engines of the recovery -- the housing market and exports -- rates shoot at one and the dollar shoots at the other," said Mr. Mullins, who is considered the most influential member of the Federal Reserve Board after its chairman, Alan Greenspan.
Echoing what Mr. Greenspan told a Congressional committee early this month, the governors said the slowdowns in Japan and Germany could hamper American growth by hurting the nation's exports and slowing the world economy. Nevertheless, Mr. Greenspan said he expected American exports to continue to grow because of the strong economic gains of Mexico, the rest of Latin America and the newly industrialized countries of Asia.
Some Fed officials also worried that the positive news on housing starts and other areas could be exaggerated because of the unusually warm winter temperatures. For example, warm weather might have spurred a larger-than-normal amount of home construction in January and February.
The governors also said this economic rebound would probably not be as robust as past recoveries, partly because consumers and businesses were still struggling to pare the large debt they accumulated in the 1980's. This, they said, was holding back spending and consumer confidence.
 
Uneven Performances
 Another governor, Wayne D. Angell, said the lack of economic synchronization among the states would help prevent a robust recovery.
"We've had many quarters of recovery in Colorado, but I don't know if we have had recovery yet in New England," he said. "California is kind of a soft spot, with the cuts in defense."
Echoing Mr. Greenspan's Congressional testimony, the two governors said that consumer confidence appeared to be lower than recent economic reports would warrant. The governors said economic growth over the last three quarters had been so weak, after two quarters of decline, that it was depressing consumer confidence, as were fears about the nation's long-term economic prospects.
 
Anemic Growth Rates
 Mr. Mullins noted that consumer sentiment was subdued partly because the economy has not grown at even a modest 2 percent rate since the first quarter of 1989.
"The concern is not going into a double dip, but staying in this anemic growth range, which tends to reinforce fears," Mr. Mullins said. "There is power in negative thinking. That keeps people from spending and making the sort of commitments to keep the economy going again."
The Fed governors would not tip their hand about whether they were leaning toward lowering or raising rates, but Mr. Angell indicated that the central bankers were keeping their options open.
"There are some circumstances out there where we might have to raise interest rates, and some where we might have to decrease them," he said.

HEADLINE: Bush-Kohl Talks Stalled on Farm Trade

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
A weekend of talks between President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, leaders of the two biggest exporting nations, ended today with no suggestion of progress on a dispute over farm goods that is blocking a global agreement to lower trade barriers.
At a news conference at the White House, the two leaders expressed optimism that the proposed trade accord among 108 nations can be completed in mid-April, as negotiators have pledged. 
 But Administration officials have long said that the agreement hangs in part on the ability of Germany, the dominant force in the European Community, to persuade France and its other neighbors to break down a network of subsidies and trade barriers that protect farmers.
 
'Both Sides Have to Move'
 Mr. Kohl indicated today that his talks with Mr. Bush had produced no breakthrough. He also appeared to call for the United States to drop its demands for a more open European market, something Mr. Bush can ill afford in an election year in which he will depend on the farm vote. Canada and Australia have supported the United States in making these demands on Europe.
After two days of talks with Mr. Bush at Camp David, Md., Mr. Kohl said, "We still have some questions to solve before we can reach agreement. When we talk about compromise, it means that both sides have to move."
The talks also covered aid to the former Soviet republics and emerging democracies in eastern Europe, world environmental problems and preparations for a summit meeting of the seven largest industrial nations, scheduled for July 6 in Munich.
Both leaders consider the trade agreement crucial both to promoting growth in developing nations and to preventing the world from breaking into warring economic camps now that the United States-Soviet rivalry no longer dominates international affairs.
But Europe, led by France, has resisted demands by the United States, Canada and Australia that it open its borders more to farm imports and that it stop subsidizing exports like wheat.
 
Eyes on Europe and U.S.
 Other nations are refusing to negotiate lower trade barriers in other areas, like manufactured goods, until the United States and Europe solve their differences.
Administration officials expressed frustration with Mr. Kohl last week, saying that he had promised two years ago to press the French for concessions on trade but had failed to deliver.
Mr. Kohl said today that he "will give a full report of these two days of talks" to other European leaders, "and we will once again try to find out where there is further room for negotiations."
The two leaders also agreed to work with other Western nations at the Munich summit talks toward what Mr. Kohl called a "help for self-help" for Russia and the other former Soviet republics: technical assistance on problems ranging from unproductive farms to antiquated transportation networks to nuclear-reactor safety.
That advice would supplement the international financial aid now being assembled to stabilize Russia's currency and finance new development, he said. And both aid packages would replace the hastily organized relief missions and injections of money that have kept the former Soviet states from collapsing further this winter.
Mr. Kohl also said that he and Mr. Bush agree on the importance of the summit meeting on environmental problems scheduled for June in Rio de Janiero. At the meeting, developing nations are expected to resist requests by the West to curb industrial pollution and to take other costly steps to combat global warming and depletion of the Earth's protective ozone layer.
The Administration had sought until recently to discount the need for the session. Mr. Bush's first chief of staff, John Sununu, was openly skeptical of claims that some environmental problems were reaching a crisis, and the White House had reduced Mr. Bush's public involvement in foreign affairs after charges that he was paying too little attention to domestic issues.

HEADLINE: White House Sees a Mission to Cut Business Rules

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Saying that the tax-cut measures passed by Congress will not revive economic growth, the Bush Administration has aggressively turned to measures that would lighten the Government's regulatory burden, an area where it has considerable ability to act on its own.
It is not clear whether deregulation, an idea held in some disrepute as a result of the 1980's disaster in the savings and loan industry, has broad political appeal. But the Administration seems to have decided that at minimum it can be used to portray President Bush as a man with a domestic, perhaps even an ideological, program. 
 The drive began in earnest in late January when the President announced in his State of the Union Message a 90-day moratorium on new regulations and a "top-to-bottom review of all regulations, old and new, to stop the ones that will hurt growth and speed up those that will help growth."
 
Cost of Regulation
 There is no doubt that Administration policy makers have begun a concerted drive on what they regard as the over-regulation of American business. Federal regulation alone is estimated to cost as much as $400 billion a year, one-quarter of this for paperwork by large and small businesses.
In the process, a novel theory is being advanced that could vastly expand the scope of cost-benefit analysis, a component of the regulatory process first required by an executive order of President Gerald R. Ford and later strengthened by Presidents Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan.
But the task is complicated by Mr. Bush's own recent record. Though as Vice President in the 1980's he promoted deregulation, as President he supported many of the laws under which the current explosion of new rules is being carried out.
And not even the White House says that the effort will have more than a negligible effect on the economy in the short term, probably nothing even measurable in national output during 1992.
 
'Just the Beginning'
 Yet early results of these reviews are now tumbling from departments and agencies and the pains the Administration is taking to spread and promote them shows that the White House sees deregulation as important.
"This is just the beginning," C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel and a longtime Bush aide, said Thursday in helping unveil the Agriculture Department's list of 13 initiatives that range from a one-year postponement of nutrition-labeling requirements for meat and poultry to the announced intention to limit appeals of resource-management decisions by the Forest Service.
The Administration regards allowing flexibility in implementing and meeting regulations as important as deregulation itself. Some measures taken or proposed recently are:
*A set of initiatives in transportation that includes creation of a cash-for-clunkers program under which businesses and state and local governments can comply with clean-air standards by buying and scrapping old motor vehicles that cause the most pollution.
*A package of measures announced by Mr. Bush in Oklahoma City designed to aid the depressed natural gas industry.
*Proposals by the Securities and Exchange Commission to make it easier for small companies to sell stock and to make it easier for mutual funds to invest in new companies.
One of the most important actions, though not so clearly deregulatory since it involved a choice between two methods of controlling pollution during refueling, was the Administration's decision announced four days before the Michigan primary that requires special gasoline pumps rather than the installation of additional equipment on new cars.
The biggest potential challenge to the current regulatory system is one that questions the very basis on which rules are constructed. One of the most influential Administration policy makers, James B. MacRae Jr., Acting Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, now contends that the assessment of any new rule must consider compliance costs for workers as well as employers.
In suspending his consideration of air contaminant standards proposed by the Labor Department, Mr. MacRae said it was well established that poor people are less healthy than rich people. Thus, he said, if regulations impose such costs on employers that they reduce pay or jobs, workers might be worse off with the regulation than without it.
This proposition, reportedly to be applied to all Federal agencies, prompted immediate protest among Congressional Democrats, with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, calling it "deregulation ideology run amok."
 
Industry Wish Lists
 Meanwhile, as agencies debate which pending regulations might be exempt from the moratorium because they involving health and safety or are subject to legislated deadlines or court orders, business groups have responded to the renewed opportunity to make the case against proposals they believe ill-conceived.
The Aerospace Industries Association, for example, sent to the Federal Aviation Administration a list of scores of issues that it said would save airplane makers $43.1 billion over 10 years if properly addressed.
One proposal to which it objected would require airframes to be strong enough to withstand the strike of an eight-pound bird instead of a four-pound bird, a requirement it said was not supported by experience.
 
Admission of Error?
 The National Federation of Independent Business, meanwhile, was busy campaigning against another Government proposal to make employers liable for accidents in which their employees failed to buckle seat belts.
In addition to complaints from liberals, the Administration faces skeptics among conservatives.
William A. Niskanen, a Reagan Administration official who now heads the Cato Institute, a conservative research and advocacy group in Washington, said he questioned whether there would be any lasting benefit from the moratorium because Mr. Bush had endorsed much of the environmental, personal disability and other legislation that gave rise to fresh batches of rules.
To be credible, Mr. Niskanen said, the President "has to acknowledge publicly that at least some segments of laws he's endorsed might require amendment," an admission or error similar to one he made about raising taxes.

HEADLINE: SALE OF PLUTONIUM BY RUSSIA TO U.S. FACES UNSEEN SNAG

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
A $6 million deal is being blocked within the United States Government, in which the Energy Department would buy plutonium 238 from Russia and fashion it into nuclear batteries for American deep-space probes and other purposes, Federal and industry experts say.
American stocks of plutonium 238 are running low. If no other supply is found, a prohibition of the purchase could in time derail plans for a new fleet of American spacecraft to explore the heavens. 
 The plutonium sale is one of a number of deals that have been blocked by the Administration in attempts to prevent Russia's military-industrial complex from posing any future threat to the United States, in this case by starving it of revenue. Other blocked sales involve Russian rocket engines, space reactors and other aerospace items.
 
Stabilizing Effect of Sales
 Critics say import restrictions should be lessened or ended to help stabilize the Russian economy, prevent a relapse of totalitarianism and discourage Russian scientists, engineers and technicians from leaving for jobs in the third world.
The White House is said to be considering an increase in aid to Russia and a relaxation of some East-West trade restrictions, under which import curbs might eventually be eased.
The case of the plutonium 238 has a human dimension, as well. Russian officials and workers, desperate for hard currency, quickly went to work and made the material even before a contract was signed, experts said. To date, they have not been paid.
Negotiations for the $6 million deal got under way in 1989 and were all but completed in 1991 when they were suddenly halted, Federal experts said. For nearly a year, the deal has been in bureaucratic limbo.
The Energy Department's current budget request to Congress says the "analysis of this purchase is completed and is currently under active review within the Administration."
In an interview, William H. Young, Assistant Secretary for Nuclear Energy, declined to say where in the Government the deal was being scrutinized. "I can't get into some things," he said. "There are various parts of the Government that are involved and have an interest."
He insisted that there had been no breakdown in negotiations, adding, "We're still considering the possibility."
But Ned S. Rasor, an industry consultant in Cupertino, Calif., who helped advance the plutonium 238 negotiations with the Russians, recently wrote to Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia and chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, complaining that the deal was "being blocked" by the Administration.
The purchase, Dr. Rasor said, would be of "great fiscal advantage to the U.S." and "immediately assist stabilization of a democratic Russia."
 
'Moving Slowly'
 A Federal official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the purchase has been reviewed by various Government agencies -- including the National Security Agency, the Central Intelligence Agency and the National Security Council at the White House. "It's moving slowly," he said. "But I'm still hopeful it will take place."
All such deals have hit a roadblock, leading some experts outside government to speculate that a secret directive may ban such trade. Publicly, the Defense and State Departments have warned that American purchases of Russian high-technology goods could strengthen the military muscle of a former adversary.
John P. Boright, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Scientific Affairs, said at a Congressional hearing on Feb. 21 that the United States had to be "cautious not to inadvertently support organizations and capabilities that could represent a future threat."
The plutonium 238 for sale by the Russians is a radioactive isotope that naturally emits heat, which can be turned into electrical power. A different isotope, plutonium 239, is used to build nuclear bombs. Neither substance is found in nature. Both are produced in nuclear reactors, though by different means.
 
Major Space-Project Uses
 Compact power sources made with plutonium 238 are often called nuclear batteries, or, technically, radio-isotope thermoelectric generators. By whatever name, dozens of them have used in the nation's space program over the decades. They have powered lunar and Martian probes as well as the current Galileo mission to Jupiter.
Nuclear batteries are seen as essential to making electricity in the far reaches of the solar system, where sunlight is too dim to activate solar-power panels.
American supplies of plutonium 238 for such batteries are running low because of safety and environmental problems with the Federal Government's aging nuclear reactors, which have been shut down for years.
Plutonium 238 was last made in 1984. Since 1989, reactors at the Energy Department's Savannah River plant in South Carolina that could make more have been under repair. The K-Reactor there, when it is started back up again, perhaps next year, is scheduled to make tritium for nuclear weapons.
 
Alternatives Would Take Time
 Mr. Young of the Energy Department said it had no plans to make plutonium at Savannah River, and that the only domestic alternatives for plutonium 238 production were modifying a reactor in Idaho or refurbishing one in Washington state, neither of which could be accomplished before the turn of the century.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration needs nuclear batteries made of plutonium 238 for future projects like the Cassini mission to Saturn, a Neptune probe, a Pluto fly-by, a comet sampling mission, a Mars lander and a Mars sampling mission, agency officials said.
In addition to such uses, intelligence agencies need nuclear batteries for spying. In the 1960's, the batteries powered electronic listening devices atop the Himalayas aimed at China. Today, the Navy is said to use them for undersea eavesdropping.
The United States now has about 130 pounds of plutonium 238 on hand and needs about 300 pounds through 1999, according to Energy Department documents. Needs will rise dramatically if proposed NASA missions are approved by Congress.
"Things are building toward a crisis or a collapse," said Steven Aftergood, a plutonium 238 expert at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington.
 
Soviet Security Concerns, Too
 With shortages threatened, Energy Department officials in 1989 began looking into the purchase of plutonium 238 from the Soviet Union, Federal and industry experts said.
A Soviet nuclear expert, meeting in August of that year with an Energy Department official in Washington, was skeptical, saying such a deal was probably doomed because of the plutonium's potential use in espionage. But by October, the Soviets had relented and given their tentative approval.
At a May 1990 meeting in Moscow at the Ministry of Atomic Power and Industry, Energy Department experts, including one from its laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., said the United States was initially interested in 11 pounds. They asked for a free sample first to vnalyze the plutonium's purity.
The Soviets agreed. They also said that as much as 44 pounds of plutonium 238 could be produced for sale to the United States each year.
A free sample of 20 grams -- less than an ounce and valued at about $24,000 -- was delivered to Los Alamos in 1991 and found to be of high quality.
 
Change of Signals
 The deal went sour in April 1991. At a Washington meeting, Robert G. Lange, head of the Energy Department's nuclear battery program, told startled Soviet officials that the department was no longer authorized to negotiate the purchase.
A Soviet official paused.
"I want you to understand that the people who produced this in the Soviet Union have not been paid, and will not be paid, until we receive payment from you," the official said, according to American participants at the meeting.
Later, the Soviets lowered their price to just over $545,000 a pound. The initial 11 pounds would sell for $6 million.
Since then, Energy Department officials have conducted no more negotiations while saying that they are still considering the purchase. Mr. Lange, in a talk in Albuquerque in January, outlined planned space missions, the impending shortage and the possibility of the United States' buying plutonium from Russia.
 
U.S. Officials Uncommunicative
 "As long as man has the desire and the will to explore the solar system," he said, "plutonium 238 power systems must be used."
No Administration official has publicly stated the specific objections to the deal. One may be that money paid to Russia could be used to rebuild the military complex there.
Dr. Rasor, the American consulting negotiator, said in his letter to Senator Nunn that the Russians have been willing to consider safeguards to insure that the American purchase "will not support capabilities that could represent a future threat."
He added, though, that he had been unable to "present the availability of such safeguards to the blocking policy makers, since it has been impossible to identify them."
