HEADLINE: Trenton Moves to Reclaim Old Factories Left for Dead

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 22

 BODY:
They can be seen on the outskirts of any city from Baltimore to Boston, the acres of jumbled brick and cinder-block factory buildings, industrial ghost towns as much as any abandoned Rocky Mountain mining camp, their windows broken and dark, smokestacks cold, loading yards choked with weeds.
Some of them, favored by location or architectural detail, have been converted into glossy upscale shopping arcades, like Oil City, the once dingy refinery on the Onandaga waterfront in Syracuse. Others, like the former American Bank Note Company in the South Bronx, have been recycled into industrial incubators for small businesses. 
 But most remain empty hulks, abandoned by their owners and so contaminated by industrial pollutants that cities decline even to foreclose on them for fear of being burdened with responsibility for cleaning them up.
Now the City of Trenton has begun a pioneering effort to conduct a formal inventory of the dozens of old factories where the city's famous steel and ceramics were once produced. The program is being watched by other cities in the state, both because of Trenton's move to determine the environmental risks of reopening some of the sites, and because the initiative represents a break with the traditional reliance on private real-estate brokers to find occupants for the old buildings.
The recession in manufacturing jobs in Trenton is testimony to slow results of waiting for the private market to act. In Trenton, lighted letters on the old U.S. Highway 1 bridge across the Delaware River still boast, "Trenton Makes The World Takes," but even the mighty Roebling Works, where the cables for the Brooklyn Bridge were spun, is mostly silent, its head office building taken over by the Mercer County administration.
 
Similar Studies
 "It's time to stop talking about how awful this is," said James T. Harveson, the Trenton director of economic development. "We have to get going and find out what we have, because the market is so uncertain that private investors don't even want to put any money in to find out what's here."
The Northeast/Midwest Institute, a research organization sponsored by members of Congress from 18 states in those regions, has also begun a study on the re-use of old factory buildings, while the recently enacted Federal Surface Transportation Act includes a small fund to help similar studies.
The Trenton initiative aims to address one of the most vexing obstacles to recycling old factories: the extent of pollution at sites that may have been used for numerous industrial processes, under several owners, since being built at the turn of the century.
New Jersey's Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act, which is regarded as the toughest state pollution cleanup law in the country, requires the owner of an industrial site to rid it of any contamination before selling it or shutting down operations. When it was enacted in 1986, the law was expected to make it easier to recycle old factories into new ones by assuring buyers that they would not get stuck with an expensive cleanup.
But the costs of removing tons of contaminated material have proven to be so high, and the market for old buildings so slow, that Mayor Douglas H. Palmer of Trenton told a state Senate hearing this week that the law was having the opposite effect.
"In the last five years, we have had less than 10 sales of industrial properties in the city of Trenton," he told the Senate Environmental Committee on Thursday. Moreover, he said, 80 percent of the land in the city's industrial zone, along Highway 1, "isn't worth a dime."
"It has been rendered valueless because cleanup costs are more than the property is worth," he said. There is even a handful of abandoned buildings, their last owners long since vanished in a fog of succeeding mergers and bankruptcies, that the city has refused to take back for taxes out of concern for its own liability.
 
Liability Concerns
 "We don't want them," Mr. Harveson said. "We won't touch them until we have some sense of what we're getting into."
Mayor Palmer urged the Legislature to modify the law by, among other things, creating a fund to help cities clean up properties, and protecting them from the law's penalties.
New York does not have a similar cleanup responsibility law, said Madeline Gallo, a spokeswoman for the New York Department of Environmental Conservation. Connecticut requires disclosure of the presence of contamination when an industrial site is sold, but no cleanup is required.
Alfred I. Faiella, head of the Newark economic development office, cited the old Arkansas Chemical Company building on Foundry Street as an example of a property abandoned because of the potential cost of cleaning it up. "They just walked away," he said. "We took it for taxes."
One of Newark's finest old factories, the Murphy Varnish Company building in the Ironbound section, looms like an abandoned Georgian country mansion over the industrial landscape. Signs on its boarded-up exterior seem to anticipate the end of the still privately owned building: they alert firefighters to flammable materials on each floor.
The old factories do have one advantage that economic development officials stress: because they are located in old industrial zones, they are away from housing areas whose residents may raise objections to a new factory as a neighbor. But they also suffer defects besides the potential environmental problems.
"The ceilings are too low, there are too many columns, there are multiple floors instead of having everything on one level," said Stephen M. Segal, a Trenton broker of industrial real estate. "And typically, they have been added on to many times, with the oldest and most obsolete and most difficult to use section in front, and the newer parts in the back."
That is why, Mr. Segal and others pointed out, it has been easier for economic development officials to work with big, single-ownership industrial sites than the patchwork of numerous separate properties of the kind that face Trenton officials.
Thus, the New Haven Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit city-sponsored concern, started in the early 1980's a public-private effort to turn the old Winchester rifle works into the million-square-foot Science Park, where 100 small companies employ 1,200 workers.
Mr. Harveson says he thinks the same approach, attracting many small companies employing a handful of employees each, instead of trying to snare one big corporation to move into town, is wisest for Trenton.
"That's not how America works anymore," he said. "The new jobs are in small businesses."

HEADLINE: Courthouse Is a Citadel No Longer: U.S. Judges Curb Environmentalists

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
In the two decades since a burst of legislation to protect natural resources and wild habitats, environmental groups have often turned to the Federal courts to force the Government to comply with the laws or to expand the reach of regulations.
But environmentalists no longer consider the Federal courthouse a friendly citadel. In case after case, judges are deciding to throw out environmental and safety regulations or limit the effect of Federal laws. 
 The judges have ruled on grounds both substantive and procedural: that a law requires that regulations be cost-efficient; that an agency did not have authority to impose a regulation, or had not established adequate scientific basis for it, or that the plaintiffs simply had no standing to sue. Federal judges are also interpreting traditional doctrines on standing and jurisdiction to make it more difficult for environmental groups to sue in the first place.
Supporters of the new direction say they are pleased that Federal judges are finally listening to their argument that too many of the Government's environmental rules are based on insufficient scientific evidence and that their costs far outweigh the benefits.
 
Harm With the Good?
 "What the White House and the courts are now deciding is that regulations not only have potential to do good, they have the potential to do harm, and not just economic harm but actual harm to public health and the environment," said Fred L. Smith Jr., the president of the Competitive Enterprise Institute in Washington.
Last month, the institute won one of the cases cited as part of the new trend -- a case against the Transportation Department in which the institute showed that lighter and smaller vehicles designed to comply with rules for making cars more fuel-efficient resulted in 2,000 to 4,000 more highway deaths every year.
But environmentalists see the rulings as closing the door to one of the most important Government forums for advancing their cause. Albert H. Meyerhoff, a senior lawyer in San Francisco for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said: "The courts traditionally have been the last refuge where we could seek relief from environmental pollution and for health protections. More and more, we're seeing the courts are unavailable for us.
There have been five major rulings in the past year, on regulations affecting such issues as water pollution, asbestos and conservation, that point to the courts' new direction.
 
Weeding Out the Rules
 The rulings are coming as President Bush is mounting a coordinated attack on environmental and health regulations that he says are smothering innovation and hampering the creation of new jobs. In January, the President announced that his Administration would temporarily bar new regulations and conduct a 90-day review intended to eliminate or weaken existing rules. Unable for the most part to afford public works projects and other election-year gifts, the President has made eliminating the rules a centerpiece of his economic policy.
In the last three weeks, the Administration has eliminated a proposal that would have required automobile manufacturers to install new air pollution-control devices. It blocked a Labor Department proposal to reduce exposure to toxic chemicals in the workplace, and it sided with the coal industry in a suit the industry hopes will weaken strip mining regulations.
An Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity described the White House's efforts as a reasonable and intelligent response to a troubled economy. "What's driving this is simply that too much regulation does have the effect of decreasing economic growth and lowering the number of jobs," the official said.
 
Sharp Words From Reilly
 William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, who is often at odds with some members of the Administration, was more critical. He said the courts were "second-guessing" regulations that protect environment and health.
"If this second-guessing becomes a trend in judicial decisions, the upshot may well be to reinforce Congress's temptation to prohibit any calculation of cost, no matter how small the risk or how great the expense," he said.
Both critics and supporters of the rulings say the judicial record being established by the Federal courts is an inevitable result of a decade of appointments of conservatives. Presidents Bush and Ronald Reagan made the selection of judges one of their most important tasks. Of the 714 district, appellate and Supreme Court judges now on the Federal bench, more than half were appointed by the two Presidents, according to the Alliance for Justice, a liberal legal group in Washington. There are 123 vacancies, and 30 to 40 judges are expected to retire soon.
Many judges say that a better solution to environmental and health problems is economic policies that encourage industrial modernization. Conservative economic theorists say greater wealth is the key to improving a nation's environment and health of its people. Two Supreme Court Justices, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, back this view. Other judges who have become advocates of less regulation are Alex Kozinski of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, in California, and Frank H. Easterbrook of the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals, in Illinois.
 
Some Victories Recorded
 By no means are the courts sweeping all environmentalists out the door. In the Northwest, environmentalists have been successful in persuading two District Court judges to halt the cutting of stands of ancient forests of spruce and Douglas fir. And District Courts around the country have backed suits by the Natural Resources Defense Council and other groups demanding that the Energy Department obey Federal environmental and safety laws at its nuclear weapons plants.
"You don't get ideologues everywhere across the country," said Brian O'Neill, a lawyer in Minneapolis who works for Defenders of Wildlife, which has a case pending in the Supreme Court that tests whether the Endangered Species Act applies to Government actions overseas. "In our circuit, the Eighth Circuit, environmental groups get a fair shake even with conservative panels. That's why we bring cases here, because we think we get a fairer hearing than we would on the East and West coasts."
But environmental lawyers say they are nevertheless very concerned about the trends. Earlier this month, the Supreme Court decided in favor of Arkansas's right to set weaker water pollution-control standards than Oklahoma. Oklahoma had sued, arguing that water flowing into the state from Arkansas violated Oklahoma's stricter pollution standards. Arkansas argued successfully that its standards, the minimum allowed by the environmental agency, were valid.
Last month, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled that the 1990 Federal fuel economy standard for automobiles needed to be reconsidered. The Competitive Enterprise Institute and Consumer Alert, two free market groups here, argued successfully that in forcing automakers to design lighter, smaller, fuel-efficient cars, the Department of Transportation must take into account the broader safety effects of the rules. The groups expect that a new standard will allow bigger, less fuel-efficient cars.
 
Better 'Balance' Is Seen
 "If a corporation caused 20 deaths a year there would be outcry, Congressional hearings, front-page stories blasting the fact that private self interests had endangered public health," said Fred Smith, the institute's president. "But when a Government action results in 2,000 deaths per year, we have no hearings, no comment and a passive reaction. There is a lack of balance here that is not producing an honest debate on regulation. Finally, the debate that has been in intellectual forums for 20 years is now moving into the courts."
In December, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit threw out 12-year-old regulations set by the E.P.A. to control disposal of some wastes the Government considered hazardous. Shell Oil and more than a dozen other companies argued that most of the debris covered by the rules was ash or mill wastes that were not dangerous.
But in classifying them as hazardous the Government was forcing companies to spend hundreds of millions of dollars for disposal in special landfills where space for truly dangerous hazardous wastes was running out. In vacating the regulations, the Appeals Court said the environmental agency had not given industries a chance to comment before they were issued.
In October, the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, overturned a 1989 rule by the environmental agency that banned almost all products containing asbestos, a known carcinogen. The court said the agency had not considered the safety consequences of banning asbestos from such products as brake lining. Nor, the court said, had the agency considered less costly changes in the regulations. The court also criticized the cost of the ban. It said that for every theoretical case of cancer the agency thought it was preventing, the country would spent $2.2 million to $5.4 million.
 
Dismay and Elation
 The ruling dismayed Mr. Reilly of the environmental agency. "The decision to overturn a rule based on 10 years of very careful research and analysis is at odds with my concept of judicial restraint," Mr. Reilly said in an interview.
But William Laffer, a lawyer and regulatory expert for the Heritage Foundation, a public policy research group in Washington, hailed the rulings as "a splendid thing."
"What we have developed is a bizarre, amazingly complex web of Federal regulations which don't deal with protection of property or lives, but are concerned with making people and businesses jump through hoops," he said.
Philip M. Hocker, president of the Mineral Policy Center, a Washington environmental group, differed: "John Kenneth Galbraith once said, 'People always want what they don't have.' People wanted environmental protection but did not fully realize that could only be achieved by stopping the damage. That is painful because the damage was created for business profit."

HEADLINE: Albany Talks Still Clogged Over Budget

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 22

 BODY:
Although state leaders worked feverishly through the weekend, the prospects for a timely budget remained highly uncertain today because of a continuing impasse over how to wring more than $1 billion in savings from New York's Medicaid and welfare programs.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the state's legislative leaders met here this afternoon for the eighth consecutive day, with only nine days separating them from the start of the fiscal year on April 1. But they again failed to strike an accord on the complex and politically charged issues of Medicaid and welfare, which they have been debating since November. 
 While Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders sometimes emerge from their private negotiating sessions with reassuring pronouncements, there were no signs of optimism today.
"The Legislature, despite the lateness of the hour, has no real sense of urgency," Mr. Cuomo lamented. "They're having difficulty making even the simplest decisions."
Edward Martin, an aide to the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., said, "There seemed to be a little backward movement today on Medicaid."
The Democrats who control the Assembly and the Republicans who hold a majority in the Senate have yet to announce agreement on any of a wide variety of measures being considered to produce savings from Medicaid and welfare.
They include limiting the menu of health-care services covered by Medicaid for the able-bodied poor and restricting the number of hours that Medicaid would pay for personal-care attendants who cook, clean and shop for homebound patients.
 
To Fight Welfare Fraud
 The negotiators are still arguing about measures aimed at deterring people from moving to New York to qualify for higher welfare benefits. They also are discussing a proposal to fight welfare fraud by fingerprinting and photographing recipients, an idea valued more for its symbolism than for its dollars.
The leaders continue to discuss whether Medicaid recipients should be charged nominal fees for medical services, whether they should increase taxes on the revenues of hospitals and nursing homes, and whether commercial insurers should have to pay higher reimbursement rates to health-care providers in order to improve the competitive position of the struggling Blue Cross-Blue Shield network.
In a reflection of the difficulty of doing business in a divided Legislature, there are real ideological differences on these issues between the Assembly Democrats and the Senate Republicans. And the differences have been reinforced this year by the uncertainties of a looming election in which welfare has become a defining national political issue.
The Assembly Democrats hope to minimize the pain inflicted on the state's welfare and Medicaid recipients, the bulk of whom live in New York City, the base of the Democrats' power. Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin's negotiating room is limited by political discord within his own house, where 31 of the 95 Assembly Democrats have called for higher income taxes on the wealthy as a way to offset cuts in social services. Mr. Weprin, Mr. Marino and Mr. Cuomo have pledged to avoid significant tax increases in an election year.
The Senate Republicans hope to protect nursing homes, hospitals and insurance companies, some of which are struggling to survive in a recessionary economy.
Mr. Cuomo, in trying to broker a compromise, has been criticized by both sides. The Democratic Governor has been assailed by Assembly Democrats for conceding too much to the Republicans because of his obsession with a timely budget. The Senate Republicans have complained that Mr. Cuomo has not done enough to bring his fellow Democrats along.
The Governor, who says he abandoned a Presidential campaign to stay in Albany and work on the budget, has pressured the Legislature to meet the April 1 date by describing the consequences of failure in near-apocalyptic terms. He has warned that Wall Street is likely to lower the state's credit rating for the second time this year, potentially to junk-bond status, and has said disgusted voters will hold incumbent legislators accountable in November.
Mr. Marino and Mr. Weprin also have stressed the importance of meeting the deadline after missing it for seven consecutive years. But as is customary in Albany, where political deadlines are used to extract concessions, it is clear that if an agreement is to be reached on time, it will be as the bells are tolling.
Medicaid and welfare are not the only issues keeping negotiators from closing the $4.8 billion gap in a projected $30 billion budget. Always mindful that it is an election year, Mr. Marino and Mr. Weprin still hope to soften the $240 million cut that Mr. Cuomo has proposed in the state's $8.5 billion education budget. They also hope to find money for pork-barrel "member's items" for legislators to take back to their districts.
They continue to examine new revenue proposals, like a video lottery game that none of the three leaders has either rejected or claimed as his proposal. They must also decide whether to raise the state's bonding authority for housing construction and they must shore up a transit financing plan whose political support has deteriorated in the week since it was disclosed.
But negotiators on all sides of the budget debate agree that if they can reach their goal of saving $1.1 billion from Medicaid and welfare, the other elements are most likely to fall into place.
 
Complex Discussion
 At the negotiating table, the ideological debate between the Senate and the Assembly has been translated into a complex policy discussion.
On the issue of whether Medicaid recipients should make co-payments for their health-care services, negotiators say they are stalled on the question of whether a patient should be required to pay $5 on each of the first five days of hospitalization, as the Assembly Democrats believe, or pay $25 on the first day, as the Senate Republicans and Mr. Cuomo believe.
In trying to keep people from moving to New York to collect higher welfare benefits, the Senate Republicans have proposed paying newcomers either 75 percent of New York's benefits or 100 percent of their prior state's benefits, whichever is lower, for their first year in New York. Mr. Cuomo has proposed paying 80 percent of New York's benefits or 100 percent of the prior state's benefits, whichever is higher, for the first six months. The Assembly Democrats do not like either plan.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Will Recovery Stumble Over Long-Term Rates?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Now that everyone agrees that the economy has made some recent gains, economists are arguing over whether long-term interest rates -- which determine how much it costs to build a factory or finance a three-bedroom ranch house -- will head higher or lower.
Take the spirited exchange recently at the World Economy Lab, a new forum in Cambridge, Mass., where executives from Wall Street, banking and industry can mingle with some of the brightest lights of the economics department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
 Rudiger Dornbusch, one of the department's international economists, set off sparks by confidently predicting that rates on long-term Government bonds would fall a percentage point or two.
That brought sharp responses. "I've been listening to guys like you, and now I've got egg all over my face," said Scott Pardee, co-chairman of Yamaichi International (America) Inc. Mr. Pardee, a former Federal Reserve official, had apparently predicted that bond yields would decline to 7 percent by year-end just weeks before they jumped from 7.5 percent to more than 8 percent.
But Mr. Dornbusch was not impressed. "The same people misread the rise of inflation in the early 1970's, seeing it as a little run-up in an overheated economy not a permanent change," he said.
 
Rates Seen as High
 Both sides of the debate agree that long-term rates are high by any measure, especially in relationship to short-term rates and to inflation, which has recently been around 3 percent. Long-term rates are even higher abroad, especially in Europe.
If investors do bid up rates in coming months, the higher borrowing costs could dampen the housing recovery, reduce public and private investment and productivity growth, and drag out the much-needed repair of business and consumer balance sheets.
Part of what makes rates notoriously difficult to forecast is that investors, not the Federal Reserve, control how much the United States Treasury, blue-chip companies or home buyers must pay to borrow. The Fed can manipulate short-term rates by adjusting bank reserves or the rates it charges member banks, but it can only influence rates at the long end indirectly.
Optimists base their expectations of declining rates chiefly on an optimistic outlook for inflation, a trend that one Federal Reserve governor recently called the "major unreported economic story."
Fixed-income investors like low inflation because they can earn a positive return. "Domestic inflation expectations are the primary determinant of long-term interest rates," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company.
 
Low Inflation Pressure
 Mr. Dornbusch asserts, "There are no signs anywhere of accelerating inflation." The idea is that when the truth finally dawns on investors, bonds will stage another rally and rates will drop again.
For starters, higher unemployment is reining in wage increases and productivity growth has picked up, offsetting part of the rise in wages and benefits with higher output per hour.
Commodity prices, including gold, remain weak and, given excess capacity, are apt to remain so. And oil prices are also likely to remain stable.
"For three years, gold prices have been trending down and the money supply has been growing, on average, 4 percent a year," Mr. Kudlow said. "That's not the stuff of rising inflation."
But the pessimists who foresee higher rates are not necessarily fretting about a resurgence of inflation. Instead, they worry that the demand for money to invest will strain the supply of savings, especially because the $400 billion Federal deficit is swallowing so much private saving.
"The fiscal deficit is very large and very punishing," Mr. Pardee said. "So the Treasury continues to dominate the market week in and week out."
Things are even worse than at the beginning of the 1980's, this camp contends. "The budget deficit is much bigger and the trade deficit is much smaller," said Rimmer DeVries, former chief economist at Morgan Guaranty. "So a much bigger share of the budget deficit must be financed domestically."
 
'A Weak Government'
 And most economists doubt that Washington has the will to bring the deficit to heel. "We have a weak Government, and any Government we are likely to get will be weak," said Charles Kindleberger, an emeritus professor of economics at M.I.T.
Demand for new credit is not just coming from Washington but also from corporations eager to refinance in order to enhance their credit ratings and households who wish to lower their monthly mortgage payments. The fact that a lot of potential borrowers are waiting in the wings is putting pressure on rates.
The pressure on a limited pool of savings is not limited to the United States. "Rates are increasingly driven by global investment opportunities and the overall willingness of nations to save," said Robert Barro, a Harvard economist.
Deficits are growing overseas as well, said David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass. Unification with the former East Germany has pushed Germany's budget deficit from a small surplus to a $30 billion deficit. Now German rates on 10-year bonds are slightly higher than American rates, 7.9 percent versus 7.6 percent.
On the other hand, demand for money to invest is likely to be greater than in the 1980's. "Tremendous demand is coming from outside the G-7 countries -- Mexico, Southeast Asia, East Germany and Kuwait, " Mr. Wyss said, referring to the Group of Seven leading industrial nations.
Mr. Dornbusch dismisses the notion of a capital shortage. "The investment opportunities are wonderful, but the investment isn't taking place," he said. "Russia needs lots of capital. So does Africa. Nobody is going to give it to them."

HEADLINE: Trade Mission of Sorts Finds Hartford Lawmakers Roughing It in Las Vegas

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 22

 BODY:
Would gambling in Hartford create a seedy environment rife with flesh peddling, debauchery and lawlessness? A group of Connecticut legislators decided it was their duty to come and take a close look.
"This may seem glamorous to some," said Reginald G. Beamon, a Democratic State Representative from Waterbury, who also attended a trade mission in Taipei last year. "But to me, it's just part of the job." 
 Mr. Beamon and four other Connecticut lawmakers came to the glitzy, neon-blazing strip at the invitation of Stephen A. Wynn, the president and chairman of Mirage Resorts, which owns the Mirage Casino Hotel and two Golden Nugget casinos here. He has proposed building a $350 million casino and convention center in Hartford.
The notion of a casino in Connecticut's capital has provoked some moral outrage in the state, where the economy has long flourished on building M-16 rifles, the Seawolf attack submarine and the Colt .45.
 
'Land of Steady Habits'
 In Connecticut, which calls itself the Land of Steady Habits, residents can already bet on the lottery, greyhounds and jai alai and at the new casino on the Mashantucket Pequot reservation in Ledyard. But Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has vowed to veto any bill that permits a casino off the reservation, even though promoters say it would create 4,000 jobs.
"It's the hypocrisy that bothers me most," said Mr. Wynn, a gregarious man with a gleaming smile, an even tan and a careful coiffure.
The delegation included State Representative Gabriel J. Biafore, a Democrat of Bridgeport; State Representative Richard Foley Jr., a Republican of Oxford; State Senator Louis C. DeLuca, a Republican of Woodbury; and State Senator Frank D. Barrows, a Democrat of Hartford. Except for Mr. Foley, who paid his way, the legislators were guests of the casino.
The tour was intended to show that gambling is only one part of a mix of wholesome entertainment. At the upscale Mirage, the legislators saw dolphins, tigers and a magic show by Siegfried and Roy.
 
Lurid as an Airport
 While a few patrons wore outfits skimpy enough to warrant arrest in parts of the country, the casino promoters pointed to the legions of ordinary-looking people, some of them pushing baby strollers.
Mr. Foley, who said he had never visited a casino but had heard lurid accounts about the byproducts of gambling, looked across a room of gamblers that came in every size, shade and age. He said it reminded him of a crowd at an airport.
"These people don't look particularly perverted to me," he said. A moment later, he stepped across a flier on a sidewalk opened to a picture of a woman with a whip.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Foley had noticed a group of "working girls" in a casino down the street from the Mirage. "Not exactly what you'd see in Oxford," he said, referring to his small hometown.
But prostitution and drugs are hardly foreign to Connecticut. Mr. Foley said an aide recently told him he had watched a heroin deal just a block from the State Capitol.
Among the legislators here, only Mr. Biafore had made a decision. He was in favor of gambling. "I'd love to see this in Bridgeport," he said, as he walked past the jingling of coins in slot machines.
Mr. Biafore took the tour with his son, Paul, who works for another casino in Las Vegas, and his son's girlfriend, Jennifer Keeney, who works for the Mirage.
Mr. DeLuca, who acknowledged a passing interest in craps, said he would not gamble at the Mirage. "Just my luck I'd hit it big, and people would say it was fixed."
 
A Fortunate Recovery
 It was a long day. During a session of tax policy, investment strategies and demographics, Mr. DeLuca leaned back in his chair and closed his eyes for a long time.
He revived later that night, and shook the dice at the Sands. "We're going to do it! We're going to do it!" he shouted. And he did. Mr. DeLuca walked away with $80 extra. At the blackjack tables, Mr. Foley was not so lucky. He lost $40.
The Mirage, a neon-less hotel known for its tropical rain forest, tiger habitat, dolphin pond and a simulated volcano that erupts every 15 minutes, has 3,000 rooms and 7,000 workers.
Mr. Wynn played host to the politicians at a breakfast in one of the extravagent villa apartments reserved for his "special, special friends."
 
Cagney Impression
 After a spread that included pancakes Oscar and Nova Scotia lox, Mr. Wynn talked bitterly with legislators about his experiences in Atlantic City, where he once owned a casino.
"Those suckers in Trenton," Mr. Wynn called the New Jersey politicians. "Those dirty rats."
At a dinner in the casino on Saturday night to honor donors to the University of Las Vegas, the legislators were treated to roast loin of veal with shrimp and lobster cordon rouge. A program lauded the contributors to the school, who included Adnan Khashoggi, the arms dealer, the foundation of Michael R. Milken, the imprisoned financier, and scores of others, including Mr. Wynn and his wife, Elaine. The keynote speaker was Elizabeth H. Dole, the former United States Secretary of Labor and Secretary of Transportation.
The workers wore nameplates with their hometowns. And when the legislators saw a woman from Hartford, they rushed to her side with questions.
"I left Hartford eight years ago because there was nothing for me anymore," said Janice Jones, who works as a cashier in the casino. "Connecticut had better wise up and produce some jobs."
One of the casino promoters smiled with satisfaction, and said with a whisper, "That's the next employee of the month; I guarantee you that."

Beamon, Representative Gabriel J. Biafore, Senator Frank D. Barrows and Senator Louis DeLuca. (Darrin Bush for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;
No More Summer Vacation for Networks

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Like millions of other hard-pressed Americans, most television programmers have come to the conclusion that they can't afford to take a summer vacation anymore.
And this summer, more new programs will be on television than ever before -- a radical change from the days when summer television was an unbroken line of reruns. 
 There was always a sound reason for a lack of originality in the summer. Reruns made -- and still make -- a lot of money for a network. The network pays producers for two runs of a series, sells commercials in each and usually covers the full cost of the show during the first run. That makes the rerun pure profit.
But too many reruns also tend to drive viewers away, and nobody can afford to do that anymore.
"We've been talking forever about getting new programs into the summer," said Perry Simon, NBC's executive vice president of programming.
Such talk has been generated by concerns about how many viewers have drifted away from the networks in previous summer months, both to cable channels and away from television entirely.
Two years ago, CBS made the first step toward making a stand by finding a way to acquire lower-cost programs as summer entries, in the hope that one might catch on and become successful all year round.
CBS actually doubled its expectations. Two summer series are now strong regular performers for the network, "Northern Exposure" and "Top Cops."
Last summer, however, proved how uncertain this process could be as CBS found no winners. But the network had already proved its point. Good programs could be broadcast for less money in the summer and then transplanted to the regular season. CBS pays only about two-thirds the standard license fee for a summer series, or about $700,000 an hour.
Summer shows are not necessarily cheaper to produce. The producers usually absorb more of a summer series' cost on the chance that they will create a show that will carry over to the regular season. The producers of "Northern Exposure," for example, cut every corner possible during the summer, but have since increased the production budget and the fees they charge CBS.
This summer, CBS plans to try at least five new series, and will also broadcast two original mini-series. Over all, CBS will spend an estimated $4 million to $5 million extra on its summer schedule.
"We view this as development money," said Steven Warner, the CBS vice president of programming who is charge of the summer projects. "We want the special attention that can be paid to a few new shows in the summer. We definitely do not go fishing in the summer."
Last summer, the Fox Broadcasting Company, which has always used the rerun season to draw attention to itself, decided to take its most promising new series, "Beverly Hills 90210," and start its new run in July rather than September.
The show's popularity has soared since then, and Fox executives believe the summer strategy was largely responsible. "We blazed a trail last summer," said Sandy Grushow, the executive vice president of the Fox Entertainment Group.
Fox argues that summer programs, especially those appealing to younger audiences, are economically sound because they can attract advertising that otherwise has nowhere to go. "There is a lot of advertising money out there," Mr. Grushow said. "The movie business is dying to reach young viewers in the summer."
Among Fox's goals this summer: adding a sixth night of programming.
One reason why this summer is certain to be the most heavily viewed in years is the presence of the huge attraction of the Summer Olympics on NBC the last week of July and the first week of August.
NBC will try to use the platform of the Olympics to pump up interest in two current comedies that the network believes have just started to catch on with viewers, "Seinfeld" and "Blossom."
Both shows will be heavily promoted during the Olympics and will come back on the air with new episodes the week after the games end.
NBC will also put on at least one and possibly two other new dramas immediately after the Olympics in the hope that they, too, will catch fire and can be extended directly into the fall.
Mr. Simon said NBC hoped to learn from the failure of CBS to transfer any of the huge audience it pulled in during the Winter Olympics to the new shows it promoted during the games. CBS mainly promoted two children's shows, "Scorch " and "Fish Police," which quickly proved to be dismal failures.
By concentrating on two series already on the air, NBC hopes that it will not be wasting a big promotional advantage as CBS did.
ABC plans a slightly different approach this summer. The network will mostly rely on a group of shows that it had initially intended to use for short runs in the spring. At least three of these will not be used by the time summer begins. So rather than hold onto them until the next television season, ABC will try to place them strategically this summer.
Just as the Winter Olympics on CBS in February helped drive up the overall viewing of the broadcast networks while pulling down viewing on cable channels for the first time, the Summer Olympics could help reverse the shift of summer viewers from the broadcast networks to cable channels, both network and cable executives believe.
"I think the networks will probably stop their summer slide this year," said Bob Maxwell, the vice president of research for Home Box Office."
That does not mean cable will concede to the networks, he said. Indeed, cable channels, who have come to regard summer as their strongest time of the year, plan special attractions of their own.
The pay cable channels, like HBO and Showtime, which have seen their base of subscribers erode significantly in the last several years, hope for a big turnaround this summer because so many recent hit movies including "Robin Hood" and "Terminator II" will come to cable, starting in June.
'It's going to be an unusual summer," Mr. Maxwell said. And Mr. Grushow added, "It's going to be interesting to see who does well and who gets hurt."

HEADLINE: City-Sized Trouble Sours Dairy-Town Life

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUSSEX, N.J., March 18

 BODY:
Years back, tiny Sussex was the bustling commercial hub of the dairy industry in surrounding Wantage Township. But the farms are fading and Sussex's good fortunes are ebbing. Now, deep in the countryside of northwestern New Jersey, far from any urban center, it is wrestling with its own version of big-city woes.
The state has ordered the town's aging sewer plant replaced at a potential cost of $10 million. Sussex has to build a $2 million water filtration plant. And it faces a $1 million bill to rebuild a rickety dam so that Clove Lake, now a marshy shadow of its old self, can be refilled and residents can fish, swim and boat in it again. 
 Such costs are nothing to big-city mayors. But they are overwhelming for Sussex, where the municipal budget is just $1.2 million and blue-collar workers and the elderly, who are dominant in the population of 2,200, already grumble about being overtaxed.
Sussex, only three-quarters of a square mile, has no room left for big new taxable developments that would ease the residential tax burden. The town has already foreclosed on a former halfway house for discharged psychiatric patients and the land under a closed lumber yard for nonpayment of taxes. A 40-unit town house project, only a quarter complete, sits mostly weed-filled and empty on a hilltop, a victim of financing troubles.
Then there is the crime. Burglaries rose to 22 in 1990 from 7 in 1989; car thefts jumped to 19 from 12, and larcencies rose to 42 from 32.
Minuscule figures, certainly, compared to inner-city crime. But they help give Sussex the highest crime rate in its county, also named Sussex.
Sussex's population fell to 2,201 in the 1980's, down by 217, while surrounding Wantage Township, 68 square miles of fields and woods, grew to nearly 9,500 from 7,268. With growth came two new strip malls on Route 23. They are less than five miles south of Sussex's old business center and compete for its customers.
Experts say Sussex is not alone.
"We have a number of market towns or market centers that in an agricultural economy had very significant roles," said James W. Hughes, professor of urban planning at Rutgers University and director of the Rutgers Regional Report, which studies housing, demographics and the economy. "As the agricultural economy has waned, their historical function declined. Pre World War II, they were affluent parents. Now they're sort of destitute relatives. The great construction wave of the 1980's, the office building boom, bypassed these older centers. This is prototypical of the economic change that has swept through the region during the past generation."
Hovering over everything else here now is the takeover of the four-man police department by the Sussex County Prosecutor, Dennis O'Leary, at 1 A.M. on Feb. 29. He suspended the chief, Mark Van Engelen, and his three officers with pay, replacing them with county detectives and sheriff's deputies. No charges have been filed, and Mr. O'Leary has declined to discuss the reasons for the takeover or his investigation of the department, which is continuing.
A day before the takeover, members of the department removed 34 items from the police evidence room and burned them, including a marijuana plant and some small amounts of marijuana, in a hole near the public works garage. Mr. O'Leary's investigators dug up the site of the fire on March 6. He declined to discuss what if anything was found.
Chief Van Engelen's lawyer, Kevin Kelly, said the items that were burned were all from cases completed long ago. "None of the items involved pending cases or investigations," he said.
Mr. Kelly said the burning was done during the day, was videotaped and involved evidence in non-indictable offenses, some dating from the late 1970's. He said Mr. O'Leary's office approved the burning.
Mr. O'Leary said the question of permission was "in dispute," but declined to make any other comment. Mayor Peter Horvath and other town officials have refused to discuss the investigation.
But many merchants say the police takeover has cleared Main Street of what they variously call loiterers, bums, riffraff and "biker types.
To an outsider, Main Street looks pleasant and relatively prosperous, with a Chinese restaurant, appliance store, pharmacy, bank, jeweler, hobby store, newsstand and vest-pocket park. A bagel shop has just opened, a new pizza parlor is going in, and negotiations have started about turning the old 5 & 10 building into professional offices and apartments for the elderly.
 
No Lack of Churches
 "We're still a viable town," Mayor Horvath said, pointing out that Sussex has seven churches, a volunteer fire department, and new offices and apartments in a converted creamery.
The trick now is finding the millions for better sewage treatment, water filtering and the Clove Lake dam.
"We don't have the ability to expand the tax base, and the municipal leaders recognize the limited ability of the people to pay more," said Charles M. Kuperus, president of the Town Council and owner of a plant nursery. "There's a commitment to improve. We're going after every grant we can get."

HEADLINE: Dollar Rallies, but Reasons Are Still to Be Determined

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Since early January the dollar has been rallying strongly, a move that caught many forecasters by surprise.
Behind the surge are some signs of economic recovery and a hint of higher interest rates later in the year. But there has also been a general scramble by investors and speculators to get ahead of the game, to buy the dollar early so that any rally will mean really nice profits. 
 "The market is largely speculative," said David Gilmore, senior foreign exchange economist at MCM Currency Watch in New York, "and you make money by getting on trends early on and promoting them as best you can."
But as with last winter's upturn, this rally was not really expected. And now, forecasters are wondering if this year's rally will last; last year's fizzled.
 
More Confirmation Is Needed
 "From a trading point of view, the dollar went pretty far pretty fast," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation in New York. "Now, this story has to be ratified by fundamental evidence."
Some of that evidence came in the retail sales and industrial production increases in February. But more confirmation is needed in the March and April economic reports to get the dollar moving higher.
Forecasters contend that as long as data support the expectation of an economic recovery, the dollar will remain in its current range of 1.64 to 1.68 against the German mark. It closed Friday at 1.6714 marks.
And the dollar could move to the 1.80 range as the recovery gains momentum and increases the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to keep inflation from reigniting. Such a jump would mean an increase of almost 19 percent from the end of 1991.
But some forecasters expect the dollar to fall later in the year to its current levels as the German and other European economies recover from their recessions or economic slowdowns.
If there are disappointments in the United States economy, the dollar will fall, as it did last year when the hoped-for recovery did not materialize. In that cycle, the dollar rose by 23 percent by the summer and then fell back to end the year up just 1.8 percent.
On the Japanese yen, views are more mixed. Some forecasters say it will fall. But some analysts say that although the dollar has risen against the yen to the 134 level in the last three months, they expect the yen to rally later in the year. On Friday, the dollar closed at 133.85 against the yen.
The late-year-rally view is based, in part, on the growing trade surplus that Japan has with the United States and the rest of the world. There is also a belief that a rising yen, by making Japanese exports more expensive, would help curb the surplus, which otherwise adds to trade frictions. A turnaround in the Japanese economy is also forecast to support the yen.
"We have a very aggressive forecast on the yen," said Geoffrey Dennis of James Capel Inc. in New York. The rise in the surplus, he added, is a "psychological thing" that should draw support to the yen.
The dollar rally this year is in part a result of the new suddenness in the dollar's ability to change direction. It is not that the dollar, during any day, cannot turn quickly. That kind of shift has always happened. But the dollar these days seems to move far ahead of the signs -- economic, technical and otherwise -- that forecasters have depended upon in the past.
The guideposts of forecasting -- interest rate differentials, central-bank policy, capital flows and others -- are not giving the early warnings of change that they are supposed to. They are, in fact, often too late.
"The speed of the move means that you do not have the luxury anymore of waiting for the data to make up your mind," said Nicholas Sargen, the managing director of Prudential's Global Fixed Income Advisers. "You have to be much quicker on your toes in catching these changes in market sentiment. You have to be more anticipatory."
 
A 7.7% Move in a Week
 This year, the sudden switch in direction came between Jan. 9 and Jan. 15, five trading days in which the dollar soared 7.7 percent against the German mark. And the move came at a time when the so-called signposts seemed to point to a weaker dollar.
Some analysts say that the rally this year, which has seen the dollar rise almost 10.2 percent against the mark and 7.3 percent against the yen, is being helped by a new reluctance in the Bush Administration to intervene in the foreign exchange market. They argue that in this election year a stronger dollar helps President Bush by lessening inflationary pressures and, in turn, easing the upward push on long-term interest rates that could threaten an election-year recovery.
Both these factors have made forecasting the path of the dollar more difficult this year and help explain why many analysts, who thought the dollar would remain weaker in the beginning of the year, were wrong. These same factors could also affect the dollar's course from here.
 
More Betting on Anticipation
 The reason the traditional signposts for following the dollar are less useful is that the foreign exchange market and the millions of investors and speculators in it are placing their bets more on anticipation than they have in the past. Instead of waiting for evidence of a change in the direction of the dollar, they are trying to get on the bandwagon in advance.
Even with short-term interest rates on the German mark five percentage points higher than those on the dollar, many investors are counting on better gains from a quick rally of the American currency. But to better their chances they have had to buy the dollar early. And it is these purchases that have pushed the dollar higher.
"The market has gotten more reactionary," said James T. McGroarty, senior vice president of Greenwich Capital Markets Inc. in Greenwich, Conn. "The discounting mechanism of the market has gotten much more sophisticated, and investors and speculators are positioned now well in advance."
Mr. Sargen, a former Salomon Brothers economist, offered a specific example of how the signposts had changed. He said that until recently the dollar had not made a major turn upward until it was quite clear that the Federal Reserve Board had changed its policy on interest rates from easing, which can undercut the dollar, to tightening, which can support the dollar.
But in the last two years this sequence has not been the case. In 1991, the dollar rallied from a post-World War II record low of 1.4475 marks in February to around 1.83 marks in July, even as the Federal Reserve was still easing interest rates in an effort to revive the economy.
The same has been true this year. For example, Salomon Brothers expected the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates one more time early in the year. Thus, it expected the dollar to remain weak. But the dollar defied the traditional signposts again by beginning to rise in January.
 
Evidence of Fed's Shift
 The apparent change in the Administration's position on intervention in the foreign currency market has also helped the dollar rally, said David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. Mr. McGroarty said he, too, had sensed a change in policy.
The change is apparent in the policy actions taken in January and since then. In January, the Federal Reserve, on the instructions of the Administration, intervened to sell dollars against the yen. This move was, at the time, a clear signal that both the Bush Administration and the Japanese Government wanted the dollar to fall against the yen.
But since then, although the dollar has risen almost 8 percent against the yen, there has been no further intervention.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Anxiety and Loss Shape the Mood in Connecticut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 22

 BODY:
Almost everyone in Connecticut these days seems able to name a seemingly unshakable institution that the recession and a changing world have diminished or erased.
Banks drenched in state history have closed. Insurance companies have laid off thousands of white-collar managers. Military contracts that once poured into the state to fight the cold war have shrunk. A state that once attracted wealthy people because it had no wage tax has imposed one for the first time to balance its budget. Home values that once looked like blue-chip stocks have dropped. 
 In such an environment, anxiety will be the real winner in Tuesday's Presidential primary. In dozens of interviews across the state in recent days, from the Navy yards of Groton, to the suburbs of Fairfield County, to the insurance heartland here in the capital, the themes of loss and uncertainty were echoed everywhere.
 
Panic in the Suburbs'
 "There's panic in the suburbs," said Ralph A. Greco, a vice president at PaineWebber Inc. in Fairfield.
"You've got defense workers who don't have work making helicopters or submarines or what have you, and white-collar workers who because of restructuring aren't needed either and they have to find new trades, or new skills, or new locations," he said.
But Mr. Greco said he thought President Bush would not be hurt by all that in the Republican primary -- to the contrary, he thinks voters may seek the known and familiar on Tuesday, and in the general election in November.
Sharon Bieu thinks the electoral dynamic in Connecticut may work exactly the opposite way; to the benefit of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic front-runner, or to the benefit of anyone not named George Bush.
Ms. Bieu, a bank administrator who has lived in Connecticut all her life, said that last year's struggles between Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and the State Legislature over whether to impose a tax on wages has changed the way people look at politicians and politics, and maybe authority in general.
"Everybody feels as if we're being ripped off," said Ms. Bieu, who intends to vote for Mr. Clinton on Tuesday. "I mean, they're taking from us, but they're not giving us anything."
 
Governor Rates Low in Polls
 Mr. Weicker, a third-party governor who pushed the wage tax through a Democratic-controlled Legislature, has one of the lowest approval ratings of any governor in the nation, according to poll-takers. In a survey taken last month by the University of Connecticut, 68 percent of the 500 respondents questioned said Mr. Weicker was doing a fair or poor job. The poll had a margin of error of 5 percentage points.
But some residents said they thought Mr. Weicker's demonstrated ability to galvanize public opinion in the state -- for better and worse -- has paved the way for a politician who, like Mr. Weicker, often says what he thinks regardless of the consequences. That could perhaps help Paul E. Tsongas, a former Massachusetts Senator who dropped out of the race last Thursday, but whose volunteer staff is still pushing residents to vote for him to send a message.
Mr. Tsongas created a stir last week, in his few days of campaigning in the state, when he said residents would have to face the fact that the Seawolf submarine program -- earmarked for elimination by the Bush Administration -- was probably doomed. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, has said he thinks the Seawolf may yet be saved.
"The Tsongas message was clearly based on what he believes, but also I think it was a calculated message that people are ready to hear the truth," said Howard G. Rifkin, an associate professor at the Institute of Public Service at the University of Connecticut.
 
Presidential Learning Curve
 Other people point to a sort of Presidential learning curve.
"I'm going for Bush," said Denise A. Dorr, a 32-year-old Lisbon resident who was interviewed while having her nails done at a beauty salon. "I figure we gave him four years to screw up -- let him have four more years to fix it. If we put someone else in we'll just be starting all over again."
In past recessions, some elements of the Connecticut economy have been relatively immune from hard times. Some residents find it especially troubling that in the last three years, almost every pillar industry in the state has been damaged.
"You look at the Connecticut economy and you don't see what is going to be the factor that's going to turn it around," said Lawrence D. Stillman, an insurance company investment officer who supports Mr. Bush. "You don't see any industry that's on the upswing. It's bad as I can remember it being -- especially the mood."
That mood was captured today at a rally in New Haven where both Mr. Clinton and his remaining Democratic rival, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, spoke at the Trinity Temple Church side by side with the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The meeting was dedicated to the memories of young men who have died by violence in New Haven's streets, and the candidates and Mr. Jackson all pledged to dedicate themselves to rejuvenating the troubled cities.
With a gospel choir at their backs and a crumbling, depressed neighborhood outside the door, Mr. Jackson urged the candidates to change "the equation."
"We're not in the equation," he said, glancing at Mr. Brown and Mr. Clinton on the dais. "We seek to be in the equation."
Many residents of the state may have simply opted out of the equation. Mr. Jackson, who sought the Democratic nomination for President in 1984 and 1988, said he had dedicated this election cycle to voter registration, and at his urging several dozen people stepped forward today to register right then and there in the church.
 
Low Voter Turnout
 But politicians fear there could be a historically low turnout in Tuesday's primary, even lower than in 1988 when only about 23 percent of the registered Republicans voted and only 36 percent of the Democrats came to the polls.
Some residents have given up not just on the election but on the state itself. Jeffrey Cameron, a 29-year-old West Hartford resident, counted off the people he knows who are leaving to seek work elsewhere, especially in the South.
And such anecdotal evidence is backed up by the numbers. In 1991, Connecticut was third in the nation in the number of people moving out of the state compared with those moving in, according to Allied Van Lines. Only in North Dakota and New York were the numbers higher.

I mean, they're taking from us, but they're not giving us anything." (Photographs by Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: Sleepers, Keepers and Weepers in the Senior Circuit;
Bashers of Rotisserie Leagues Aren't Worth a Thin Dime

BYLINE: By PAUL BELINKIE

 BODY:
While an estimated 2 million baseball fans find enjoyment in playing Rotisserie baseball, last year a small group of critics assumed the responsibility of telling the public exactly how they should be enjoying the national pastime.
They included: 
 *Sports columnists who possessed the vehicle to address major baseball issues but preferred to use their forum to chastise Rotisserie players for not following traditional methods of rooting for sports teams.
*A national magazine that gave a thumbs down to Rotisserie baseball but considers bathing suits a major event.
*So-called fans who disregarded the fact that teams such as the Dodgers, Giants and Athletics had changed their addresses, and players such as Bobby Bonilla, Jack Morris, Danny Tartabull and Frank Viola changed their uniforms, but condemned Rotisserie owners for focusing on various players' performances instead of team standings.
One article even theorized that Rotisserie players were not true baseball fans because of the passion and determination they displayed in attempting to find the results of the previous day's games at their local newsstands. How's that for twisted logic?
When did Rotisserie bashing become in vogue? Who says there is only one way to correctly follow baseball? Who among us is the first to throw a knockdown pitch?
And where will it end?
Will we ban golfers because they slice the ball instead of hitting it squarely? Will we stop quarterbacks from rolling out and force them to stay in the pocket? Should we outlaw the dunk shot, the jump shot, the bank shot, the slap shot?
What about the past-his-prime softball player who can barely hit the ball over an infielder's head but still enjoys the challenge of running the bases (even though it requires a triple for him to score from second). Must he now pack it in because he approaches the game differently than he did 20 years ago?
What is so wrong with Rotisserie players who support the economy by buying newspapers to study box scores and by calling sports phones for the latest updates? Isn't the business of America good for business?
The misconception among critics of Rotisserie baseball is that "owners" are less knowledgeable about the game than they used to be. This is completely contrary to the facts.
Rather, there has been an evolution in the way in which a fan roots. Instead of rooting for someone else's team, a Rotisserie owner roots for his own team. Now, instead of following the home team, a Rotisserie player follows every team and every player in either the National or American League, or both leagues.
The result is the formation of a grass-roots network of fans that is more sophisticated and better informed. Should ignorance be encouraged?
There are several reasons why new-age sports fans are more knowledgeable. The creation of radio talk shows geared entirely to a sports format have prospered in many cities, giving fans the opportunity to express their viewpoints. Sports coverage in many newspapers has increased, giving readers a wider variety of information to dissect.
But perhaps the most important development has been the emergence of cable television. No longer are fans relegated to only following their home teams. Now teams from Seattle to Atlanta can be seen by subscribers, giving players who were once merely names in a box score an entire personality.
The logical conclusion of this exposure has been a greater interest in the sports that are televised, which can be measured by the overall increase in total attendance and the additional revenues that have been reaped by team owners. And by watching players perform instead of only reading about their performance, fans are finally able to judge for themselves the relative merits and talents of the ballplayers.
Rotisserie baseball is one way for advanced students of the game to test their expertise. While winning often requires a certain amount of luck, the decisions made during the season about players and strategy must be built on a solid foundation of information.
Cynics, however, have invariably found reasons to criticize someone else's notion of how to have a good time. Aren't there enough negative thoughts floating around as it is without getting on the bandwagon to stop someone else's enjoyment of a recreational activity. Aren't there enough rules, enough restraints, enough bosses, enough people telling you what you should be doing?
Are you tired of your friends enjoying something you don't understand? Do you miss the excitement of seeing how your team, not the home team, is doing in the standings every week? Are you against people having a good time if it doesn't agree with the way you would do things?
If the answer to these questions is yes, it should be noted that if you don't know who the patsy is in a poker game after 30 minutes, then it's probably you.
 
The Basics
 Rotisserie baseball is a game in which groups of people form their own league, with each person selecting a team of real players from the active rosters of either the American League or National League teams. The selection is usually done by auctions at which team "owners" bid for players.
The performances of individual players throughout the season thus determines how well each Rotisserie league team does. Teams are ranked from first to last each week in eight categories -- four offensive and four pitching -- and the team with the most points in these categories at the end of the season is the winner.
The prices listed for each player on this page represent an estimate of what it will cost to purchase the player at auction.

HEADLINE: Squandering Leverage on China

 BODY:
America's China policy is locked in stalemate. President Bush refuses to demand much of anything from China's leaders. Congress insists that every issue be addressed before extending normal trade. These extreme positions cancel each other out, allowing Beijing to disregard American interests with impunity.
Last week the charade played itself out again. Congress had passed a bill attaching a wide variety of human rights, trade and anti-proliferation conditions to China's "most-favored-nation" privileges -- the basis for normal trade relations with the U.S. Mr. Bush vetoed it. The Senate failed to override the veto. 
 How different -- and more effective -- American policy would be if Washington could figure out how to exploit, in a calibrated way, its leverage. China's recent renewal of capitalist economic reforms only increases that leverage.
Without access to the vast American consumer market, China's development would be markedly slowed. Without American investors, Beijing would be thrown back onto an unwanted dependence on Japanese capital. Without prestige meetings with President Bush, General Scowcroft and Secretary of State Baker, China's hard-liners would be seen as pariahs, compromising their hopes to rule after the death of 87-year-old Deng Xiaoping.
Yet Beijing regularly thumbs its nose at American diplomacy on bilateral issues. From copyright infringements to missile sales, Mr. Bush's negotiators accept Beijing's assurances at face value, only to discover that their Chinese counterparts meant to convey something other than what the Americans understood. After every misunderstanding, the Administration's instinct has simply been to sit down and try again.
Most of the blame for American ineffectiveness lies with Mr. Bush. He proceeds with the optimistic outlook he formed as Richard Nixon's emissary in Beijing. But the bloody crushing of China's democracy movement raised doubts about how much evolution can be expected from the Communist regime. And the fall of Soviet Communism alters the strategic calculus that led Washington to wink at China's trampling of human rights.
Congress hasn't been any more effective. Year after year, it has sought to attach a laundry list of conditions to legislation renewing most-favored-nation privileges.
True, trade privileges constitute one of the few policy tools available to the legislative branch. But maintaining open trade is more than a favor to China's hard-liners. It's just as vital to China's important reform sectors: entrepreneurs in the south coast Special Economic Zones, Hong Kong democrats, intellectuals thirsty for the international news foreign business people bring.
If Washington attached a few modest humanitarian conditions to most-favored-nation rights, like release of the political prisoner Wei Jingsheng or medical treatment for the imprisoned democrat Wang Juntao, China would surely accede rather than lose billions of dollars. Compliance with more ambitious requests, like freedom for all Tiananmen prisoners, could be made subject to a Presidential judgment of "reasonable progress."
Issues like prison labor and copyright piracy are best linked not to overall trading rights but to specific sanctions already written into U.S. trade laws. And leverage over issues like nuclear technology transfers and missile sales is best exercised through special mechanisms governing sensitive exports. The Administration has, in fact, tried these more targeted approaches, but without consistency or conviction.
This year's Presidential candidates have shown little interest in discussing China or any other foreign policy issue. But it's surely worth debating how the U.S. can more effectively press its interests and values on the world's largest remaining Communist regime.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Times Sq. Deal Shows Where the Bargains Are
To the Editor:
The acquisition by Bertelsmann A.G., the international news media group, of a Times Square building at Broadway and 45th Street (news article, March 4) is a sign of the future strength of New York City and not, as you state, an "indication of the weakness of the city's real estate market."

 BODY:
 The agreement structured by Mayor David N. Dinkins's office shows 1992 is a good time for bargains.
Similar criticism was voiced in the 1970's, when New York Telephone and Teacher's Annuity bought 1166 Avenue of Americas for $30 million. A few years later, half the building was sold for $165 million. What was first seen as a sign of a weak economy was an appropriate business deal by the city and the two corporations. The same half of the building sold for $100 million more a few years later.
Bertelsmann understands the importance of New York City. It is time for others to take advantage of what New York City has to offer and come back.
 
LEWIS RUDIN
Chmn., Assn. for a Better New York
New York, March 11, 1992
