LENGTH: 1738 words

HEADLINE: WIDER U.S. DEFICITS ARE NOW FORECAST FOR THE MID-1990'S

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
A year after White House economists forecast that the Federal budget would have a surplus by the mid-1990's, they are now predicting a deficit of nearly $200 billion in fiscal 1996. And Congressional economists take an even dimmer view.
Projections released this month by the Congressional Budget Office said this year's deficit would be a record $368 billion and that after dropping in the next few years, deficits would soar in the second half of the decade. By 2002, the office said, the deficit could reach $423 billion. 
 Driving the deficit is the enormous and rapidly growing Federal spending on health care. Annual spending on health care is expected to rise from $196 billion this year to $481 billion in 2000. Mandatory programs like Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid now account for about half of all Federal spending.
 
Not a High Priority
 Yet President Bush and Congress have paid scant attention to paring the deficit. The budget accord between Congress and the White House in 1990 seemed to calm fears about the deficit and remove it as a high-priority item on the public agenda.
"This is the first time since the deficit became a problem 10 years ago that no one is even paying lip service to getting rid of it," said Charles E. Schultze, an economist at the Brookings Institution who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Jimmy Carter. "This is the first time we've given up."
But as expenditures have climbed and tax revenues have failed to keep up, many economists are sounding an alarm. They say the dismal deficit projections and the wrangling between Congress and the President over tax cuts have helped drive up long-term interest rates, which are having a negative effect on stock prices, housing sales, business investment and consumer confidence.
 
Draining Investment Dollars
 They also say the deficit hurts the nation's long-term competitive position by draining money from private savings that could be used to finance investment in machinery and factories that raise output and productivity.
In language considered highly alarmist for a chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan recently told Congress that these deficits were "unacceptably high."
In recent weeks, Mr. Greenspan has repeatedly noted with chagrin that last year the Administration forecast that the Federal budget would reach a surplus in fiscal 1996, but that in its budget this year, the Administration foresees a deficit of $180 billion in 1996, including the costs of the savings and loan rescue. Much of the difference is explained by lower-than-anticipated revenues caused by slower-than-expected growth and by the larger-than-anticipated expansion in Medicare and Medicaid costs.
"We have to go back to the drawing board," David W. Mullins Jr., the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, said in an interview last week. "We don't see anything that is going to restrain this deficit, and we're starting a bidding war over tax cuts with a deficit at nearly $400 billion, which isn't very encouraging."
The deficits began to balloon in the 1980's, but many economists did not worry much, believing the Reagan Administration's tax cuts would spur so much additional growth that tax revenues would increase and narrow the budget gap.
Through the 1980's -- and as recently as January 1991 -- the Federal Government predicted that the budget would have a surplus in five years' time. Not only has a surplus failed to materialize, but the deficit has ballooned.
The string of optimistic forecasts changed in January, when President Bush's budget message included a prediction by the White House Office of Management and Budget that envisioned large Federal budget deficits at least through 1997.
 
An Up-and-Down Path
 The O.M.B. forecast said the deficit would be $399 billion this year and would slide to $180 billion in fiscal 1996. Then, it said, the deficit would rise again, to $182 billion in 1997.
"Total U.S. public and private spending on health is literally on an unsustainable path -- threatening to consume an impossible proportion of G.D.P.," said Richard G. Darman, the office's director. He added, "Slowing the growth of 'mandatory' programs is the most important key to bringing the deficit under control," those programs being Medicaid, Medicare and Social Security.
In projections released this month, the Congressional Budget Office, a nonpartisan agency, estimated that the fiscal 1992 deficit would soar to $368 billion, the highest ever. That includes about $61 billion for the savings and loan bailout and the current surplus in the Social Security fund.
The underlying deficit -- without the bailout costs -- will drop from $307 billion this year to $219 billion in 1995, then curve steadily upward, reaching $432 billion in 2002, the budget office predicted. The budget office said the underlying deficit would fall from 5.3 percent of gross domestic product this year to 3.1 percent in 1995 and climb to 4.2 percent in 2002.
Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said that if "there is no substantial improvement in the underlying deficit over a five-year period, by the second year of the next century, we're in the soup."
At some point, the Federal savings and loan bailout program is expected to no longer require huge infusions of cash, as the industry returns to health and the Government receives income from the sale of assets that have become profitable. The budget office estimates that the bailout will cost and $69 billion next year, but by 1996, the sale of assets will contribute $45 billion to the budget. But even this contribution is not expected to be nearly enough to offset the spending on health care.
 
An Impediment to Growth
 A new study by economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York concluded that the budget deficits of the 1980's held the nation's economic growth about 3 percent below what it would have been without such deficits. The report added that if the deficit continued to depress private savings, it would hold down growth by about 6 percent by the year 2000.
Some economists say the size of the deficit is exaggerated, asserting that interest payments on the debt should not be factored into the balance because those payments just redistribute money from American taxpayers to holders of Treasury bonds, most of whom put the money back into savings. But looking at the steep upward curve of the deficit and the downward trend in savings, many economists say this criticism misses the point.
Economists and lawmakers who would like to bring the deficit down say it would be unwise to slash it this year because that could hamper an already sluggish recovery. They say it might even be wise to have some short-term stimulus, by increased public works spending, for instance, to speed the recovery.
 
Disappointment With Candidates
 But they say they are disappointed that the Presidential candidates are all but ignoring the long-term deficit problem and that when a candidate suggests a way to cut spending or raise taxes to narrow the deficit, his opponents jump on such proposals.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas attacked former Senator Paul E. Tsongas for proposing that gasoline taxes be increased by 5 cents a year for a decade, while Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican candidate, relentlessly condemned President Bush for agreeing to a tax increase in 1990.
"The problem in politics is that if you promise to do something about the deficit, it imposes pain in the short run and the rewards for doing something about it aren't felt for a long time," said Rudolph G. Penner, former director of the Congressional Budget Office. "The rewards will be felt by our children and grandchildren."
The Congressional budget forecast shows that barring changes in health-care programs, the cost of Medicare will soar from $128 billion this year to $301 billion in 2000. Medicaid costs will more than double, from $68 billion this year to $180 billion in 2000. Taken together, Medicare and Medicaid spending will jump from 3.4 percent of gross domestic product this year to 5.3 percent in 2000, larger than the 4.2 percent share consumed by the deficit in 2002 as projected by the Congressional Budget Office.
 
Using Borrowed Money
 Most economists say a budget deficit need not be bad if the money borrowed is used for investments that increase productivity, like improving airports or job training. That would produce a more efficient economy, which would help enable Americans in the future to repay the debt.
But Mr. Reischauer complained that the money in the deficit has not been used in this way.
"If the money were used for public infrastructure, that's O.K.," he said. "If it were used to fight a war or major social problems, that would be O.K., too. But to the extent it's been squandered on public consumption, you have increased the debt burden on our children without increasing their capacity to repay it."
He also complained that the deficits over the last decade have raised the ratio of public debt as a percentage of G.D.P. from 25 percent in the 1970's to more than 50 percent today and almost 60 percent at the end of the decade.
Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said: "I think the Congressional Budget Office has phrased it succinctly, that the deficit will cripple economic growth. That's what the huge deficit is doing and will continue to do."
 
Parting With the Leadership
 In the recent tax debate in Congress, Mr. Levin parted with the Democratic leadership to propose that the cost of the $300 tax credit per child proposed by Senate leaders -- $28 billion -- be applied instead to reducing the deficit.
"If we act to reduce the deficit, which will promote future growth, that is a more positive step for the middle class than any benefit from the tax cut," he said.
Senator Warren Rudman, a New Hampshire Republican who has long led the fight to hold down the deficit, observed despairingly: "The blame for this lies with the Congress and the President, with Democrats and Republicans alike, most all of whom have been unwilling to make the hard choices or to explain to the American people that there is no such thing as a free lunch.
"In a time when we are at war economically," he continued, "when the security of America is being drained drop by drop, we cannot seem to get it together."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 24, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about new forecasts of the Federal budget deficit referred incorrectly to a deficit-reduction proposal by Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan. In the recent Congressional tax debate, he proposed a bill that would have scrapped the $300 tax credit per child proposed by Senate leaders and instead used most, not all, of the $28 billion cost of the credits to reduce the deficit.

The Economy
A year after White House economists forecast that the Federal budget would have a surplus by the mid-1990's, they are now predicting a deficit of nearly $200 billion in fiscal 1996. Congressional economists take an even dimmer view. [Page A1.] 
 Federal Reserve officials say recent data indicate that the economy is picking up steam, but they remain worried that the incipient recovery could peter out. [D1.]
 
Markets
The dollar has rallied strongly since January, surprising many forecasters. Behind the surge are some signs of economic recovery and a hint of higher interest rates later this year. But there has also been a general speculative scramble to buy the dollar early so that any rally will mean really nice profits. [D1.]
In a bull market, few members of an exchange worry about who sits in the chairman's seat. But when Comex members elect a new chairman on Tuesday, amid a sagging market, they will look to the new leadership to turn things around. [D3.]
 
Companies
More than a dozen new hand-held computers based on "superchips" are due out this year. This new class of inexpensive machines, known in the industry as picocomputers, could transform the high-volume retail computer market. [D1.]
An F.D.A. official has told makers of medical equipment that the agency will follow up hearings on silicone-gel breast implants by initiating investigations of five other devices: artificial testicles, penis implants, breast implants filled with saline solutions, centrifugal pumps used in heart-bypass operations and electrical stimulators used to treat alcoholism and depression. [D1.]

PUB-DATE: March 24, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 2039 words

HEADLINE: U.S. ADDS PROGRAMS WITH LITTLE REVIEW OF LOCAL BURDENS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Against the background of a stubborn recession and mounting financial distress in the country, the Federal Government continues to create or expand domestic spending programs with little or no review of the financial burdens they will place on state and local governments, public policy analysts say.
In 1990 alone, the year the recession began, President Bush signed 20 bills into law, ordering programs that the National Conference of State Legislatures says will cost state and local governments billions of extra dollars, primarily for health care, the environment and Social Security payments for public employees. 
 Some mandates, like the Americans With Disabilities Act, were enacted without any reliable estimates of the cost to state and local governments. The legislation, which requires businesses and state and local governments to provide the disabled with equal access to services, employment, buildings and transportation systems, is now expected to cost them millions of dollars annually to comply.
 
Health and Environment
 The most expensive regulations for any state involve Medicaid, the Federally subsidized health-care program for low-income people that will cost $38.3 billion for the states to finance this year. The next most expensive mandates involve environmental laws, primarily water purification, which will cost state and local governments $32 billion a year by 1995.
And three new studies show that despite the publicized efforts of President Ronald Reagan and President Bush to decentralize government, both contributed to a proliferation of regulations that meant enormous costs to states and cities in the 1980's.
No one can reliably estimate the cost of complying with many such programs, and Congress is required to make only preliminary estimates on some of the bills it considers. But analysts say no Federal law provides for complete reimbursement of any mandated program, and some legislative analysts estimate the burden to local governments of such spending at scores of billions of dollars a year.
 
'Rock and a Hard Place'
 "We are between a rock and a hard place," said Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, a Democrat.
As part of a plan to pay for newly mandated Federal health benefits for children, pregnant women and the elderly, Governor Casey has proposed eliminating some medical benefits for disabled men who currently receive state welfare grants. The state raised taxes by a record $3.3 billion this fiscal year and still must reduce spending by $800 million to balance a $14.2 billion budget.
Pessimism is widespread. Three-quarters of the states and more than a third of the nation's cities report worsening fiscal problems this year, and many governors and mayors are saying the problems will linger or worsen over several years even if the economy recovers quickly.
"I think we're headed for a showdown," Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican, said in a recent interview in which he blamed Congress for "wrecking" state budgets. But analysts and other governors blame Mr. Bush. Last month, when the President met with the National Governors Association, their meeting turned into an arguing match.
At that meeting, on Feb. 3 in Washington, two Democratic governors, Roy Romer of Colorado and George Sinner of North Dakota, attacked the President, asserting that too much money was going to the military and too little to the states. "What bases do you want to close?" Mr. Bush asked testily.
Only a month earlier, Mr. Bush seemed sympathetic to the plight of the state and local governments. In January, in Mr. Bush's State of the Union Message, he sought to lay responsibility for mandates on Congress and advocated curbs on spending.
 
Bush on Mandates
 "We must put an end to unfinanced Federal Government mandates," Mr. Bush said. "These are the requirements Congress puts on our cities, counties and states without supplying the money. And if Congress passes a mandate, it should be forced to pay for it and balance the cost with savings elsewhere."
In an earlier effort to give the states more flexibility in administering Federal programs, Mr. Bush last year proposed to consolidate $15 billion in block grants and to leave the decision on how to spend the money up to the states. But many cities opposed the legislation and it died in Congress. Mr. Bush said last week that he planned to revive the proposal.
Nevertheless, analysts say the President has done little to curb the flow of Federal mandates. Nor, they assert, has he acted to provide more financing for those bills he has signed into law.
 
'Zero Leadership'
 "President Bush has provided zero leadership in this area of nation-state relationships," said Joseph F. Zimmerman, professor of political science at the State University of New York in Albany and the author of two new studies on the relationship between the states and the Federal Government.
"You can't point to a single bill where he took leadership to give states more freedom of action, or for that matter, where he sought to impose mandates on states," he said. "In a sense, it is as though President Bush has just been oblivious to this whole area until he mentioned it in the State of the Union Message."
Last January Mr. Bush ordered a 90-day moratorium on new regulations by Federal agencies and a review of existing rules to identify those that appear to do more economic harm than good. That proposal, modeled after a strategy that he carried out as Vice President in the Reagan Administration, was aimed mainly at lightening the burden for businesses.
But a new study says that whatever the impact on businesses, the deregulatory effort was "largely ineffective." It said the Government ultimately passed on more significant regulatory burdens to state and local governments during the 1980's than in almost any other decade, adding to their financial responsibilities.
The study, "Federal Regulation of State and Local Governments," is being prepared for publication later this year by the United States Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, a Federally chartered research organization in Washington.
 
No Change in Sight
 "Congress was the more active regulator than either the Reagan or Bush Administration, but none of the laws with mandates were enacted over Presidential veto," said Timothy J. Conlan, a professor of government and politics at George Mason University. Prof. Conlan and two colleagues, David R. Beam and Cynthia Colella, wrote the study.
Prof. Conlan and his colleagues said they foresee no lightening of this burden for state and local governments.
The candidates in the contests for the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominations have made Federally mandated programs an issue in their campaigns.
President Bush's challenger for the Republican nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan, has advocated a two-year moratorium on new mandates and a re-appraisal of existing ones.
The Democratic front-runner, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, says the Government is creating too many inflexible and costly programs that reduce the states' ability to cope with social and financial problems they consider more pressing.
 
More Legislation
 Of the 125 mandate-laden bills that have been introduced in Congress this session, more than half deal with health care and criminal justice, which are the two fastest growing segments of state budgets, said Martha A. Fabricius, a policy analyst with the National Association of State Budget Officers who has been monitoring this legislation. She said that more than 20 of the most expensive bills had been introduced by the Democratic leadership.
If enacted, the bills would force most states to raise taxes or reduce existing services, analysts said.
Under some of the bills, the states would be directed to pay all or some of the cost of new programs like insuring savings and loan associations, planting trees on state-owned land, operating mobile units to assist the mentally ill among the homeless and increasing prison terms for several categories of violent crimes.
The states would also be ordered to eliminate at least one revenue-producing program, a tax on certain retirement income, forcing them to find other ways to finance government.
While the Government has expanded Federally mandated programs and whittled away at state and local tax revenues, it simultaneously has reduced aid to the states.
In the 1980's, for example, overall Federal aid declined 10 percent, when adjusted for inflation, and grants that were not related to health care declined 23.6 percent, according to Government figures. There are no estimates on the loss in tax revenue to the states.
 
Historical Shift
 The expansion of Federal authority over state affairs represents an historic shift in American Government since the 1960's, according to Prof. Zimmerman
"Congress, with the acquiescence of the Supreme Court, is slowly usurping the sovereign powers of states and turning them into administrators of national policy," he said, summarizing a central conclusion in two studies he wrote for the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations. The studies, scheduled for publication this year, are entitled "Federal Pre-emption of State and Local Authority" and "Federally Induced State and Local Governmental Costs."
In all, there are estimated to be tens of thousands of Federal mandates and they touch nearly every aspect of government. There are mandates that instruct states or local governments on landfills, welfare benefits, speed limits, other traffic regulations and prison construction, among other things.
 
New York Stories
 Federally required health-care programs consumed 14 percent of all state budgets in 1990 and, with the cost of expanded programs and inflation in medical expenses, the Federal programs will devour 28 percent of the states' budgets by 1995, the National Governors Association estimates.
Examples of the costs that can result from these mandates are easily seen in populous states like New York. Stricter standards for drinking water may cost the city billions; a $600 million water filtration plant is under construction in the Bronx. School districts have spent tens of millions of dollars removing asbestos from school buildings. Congress, in passing the measure in 1986, never considered its cost to state and local governments; it is now projected at $3.1 billion over 30 years.
Members of Congress who develop mandatory programs acknowledge that the programs are a crushing burden for state and local governments. The legislators say there will be no alternative to this piecemeal approach until the President and Congress agree on national solutions to national problems like taxes, health care, welfare and environmental issues.
 
Federal Financing
 "It's incumbent on us to realize that the states can't continue to pay for Medicaid, which is a complicated, second-class health-care system for less than half of the poor people in the country," said Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Health and the Environment and the author of a number of Medicaid mandates.
"We need to have major reform in either Medicaid or in the whole system, but we simply can't let pregnant women, infants and children go without health care," said Mr. Waxman, who has said the Federal Government should be responsible for financing Medicaid.
Mario M. Cuomo of New York was the nation's only governor who supported the Medicaid mandates for new programs for poor children and pregnant women in the last two years.
Brad C. Johnson, Governor Cuomo's counsel in Washington, said that providing the additional medical care to women and children cost New York $3.8 million last year, and the state spent $828 million to put 100,000 newly eligible people into nursing homes.
 
'Good Investment'
 "He didn't go along with the other 49 governors because he said the mandates for women and children were a good investment," Mr. Johnson said.
Good investment or not, the state is now trying to decide how to cut $1 billion out of its Medicaid and welfare programs because of budget problems.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite cries about the growth of government and the financial burden it entails, the proliferation of regulations continues to flow from the Federal Government. At the Library of Congress in Washington, a volume from the Code of Federal Regulations is returned to the stacks. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times) (A14)
 
Graph: "Where Government Supersedes State Authority" shows number of Federal laws that pre-empt state authority each decade, 1900-1989. Nearly every one of the post-1960 laws contain mandates or restrictions that are expensive to state and local governments; earlier pre-emptions established such things as national standards for weights and measures, copyrighting, patents and railroad safety, and did not directly cost states much money. (Source: U.S. Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations 1992 estimate) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: U.S. Under Fire In Talks at U.N. On Environment

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 23

 BODY:
Rich and poor countries attending a five-week conference here say the United States is endangering prospects for the international environmental meeting planned for Rio de Janeiro next June.
These countries say that by refusing to promise more environmental aid to the third world or to set limits for emissions of gases that contribute to global warming, the United States threatens to sabotage the two most important agreements to be taken up at the Rio meeting. 
 The purpose of the Rio talks, which are expected to draw thousands of participants from more than 170 countries, is to plan for a world economy that can continue to grow without irreversible ecological damage.
 
Cleanup Plan Threated
 The American stand threatens Agenda 21, an ambitious, international environmental cleanup plan for the next century, because of third world requests for additional aid and new environmental technologies from industrialized northern countries.
The 12 European Community countries as well as Canada and Scandinavia are ready to give additional aid, but have not committed themselves to specific amounts.
There has been no visible result so far from a meeting last week of the conference's Secretary General, Maurice F. Strong of Canada, with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and the the White House chief of staff, Samuel P. Skinner, in an effort to change the American position.
Today Senator Al Gore, a Democrat from Tennessee who will lead the Senate contingent to the Rio meetings, told delegates that the United States must exercise leadership to insure their success, saying that at a minimum agreement must be reached on "new and additional" aid to the third world and on the stabilization of emissions.
"The United States must use its moral authority, its political and economic strength and its leadership skills to resolve the impasses that are frustrating progress," Senator Gore said.
America's reluctance to commit itself to freezing its emissions of "greenhouse" gases at 1990 levels by the year 2000 imperils agreement on the planned new international convention on stabilizing the global climate, which is supposed to be the centerpiece of the Rio agreement.
Last week the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, William K. Reilly, told the conference that the Administration planned no fundamental changes in its position on climate change, saying it would continue to resist "top down directives or commitments and targets, the costs and consequences of which we have not yet fully assessed."
While Washington opposes specific, binding commitments on cutting emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases, Mr. Reilly said that the United States was still committed to reducing these emissions through practical action.
 
'A Futile Exercise'
 In an effort to save the separate negotiations on the climate treaty, the United States and about 20 other countries have been invited to a meeting in Paris on April 15, Portugal, the current president of the European Community, announced today. The participants will try to resolve the standoff before the final round of negotiations opens in New York on April 30.
"It would be a pity if the convention had to be postponed until after Rio," Portugal's representative to the United Nations, Joao Pereira Bastos, said at a news conference, adding that Europe would find an American-style convention that did not require detailed commitments unacceptably weak. In a clear reference to the United States, Mr. Bastos said it would be "a futile exercise" for Europe to press ahead with its own climate stabilization plan unless "other regions" joined in.
Partly because of these disagreements, the conference of more than 170 countries meeting here to prepare the agenda for the Rio meeting has entered its fourth week with little progress to report.
But progress is also being slowed, delegates say, by the breadth and complexity of the agenda because it identifies poverty and its effects as a fundamental environmental threat and says that only when it has been abolished will the global environment be safe. As a result, the conference is bogged down in quarrels over economic and social issues that at first sight seem far removed from the environment, including debt relief, slum clearance, the Uruguay Round of trade talks and subsidies for northern farmers that block the agricultural exports of poor countries.
These issues complicate the negotiating process by taking up time and reopening old quarrels between the North and the South. The fact that many of these questions are the subject of continuing negotiations in other international forums makes the discussions here even more complex.
"With 60 percent of our time gone, we've only negotiated 5 to 10 percent of the output," Canada's chief delegate, John Bell, who is chairman of the group dealing with financial questions, said last week. "Increased funding for the developing world is absolutely central. It's frustrating we haven't even started negotiations."
Asked about America's reluctance to provide aid, Pakistan's United Nations representative, Jamsheed K. A. Marker, current president of the Group of 77, as the developing countries call themselves, said that he did not wish to single out the policies of any individual countries for public criticism. But in an interview he made clear that the developing world remained unhappy with Washington's stance, saying: "Without financial commitments it is difficult to know how this will all end. That's the biggest stumbling block for the developing world."
Chile's delegate, Vincent Sanchez, said: "This conference could fail. We've agreed absolutely nothing of real significance so far."
Already, an important attempt to draft a convention to save the world's rain forests has collapsed because mainly northern, industrial countries and southern, undeveloped countries cannot agree on who is to blame for their destruction.
 
Progress Is Expected
 While few delegates deny that the Rio preparatory conference has reached a critical phase, some say progress will pick up in the two remaining weeks as countries realize time is running out. "These big conferences usually reach a low point about now," said Britain's delegate, Fiona McConnell. "It's often darkest just before the dawn."
But increasingly participants here say that the Rio meetings must be judged less on concrete agreements than on broad global initiatives to make economic development environmentally sustainable.
"Rio must be seen as the start of a process, not the end," Mr. Strong, the conference's Secretary General, said today.
The last world environmental conference, held in Stockholm 20 years ago, resulted in most governments' creating environmental ministries.
Agenda 21, the 800-page global environmental action plan, lays down new goals in virtually every field.
To carry out their part of this agenda, developing countries say they will require $70 billion in additional aid each year over the $55 billion they now receive from northern industrialized countries.
 
Relations Embittered
 Most industrialized nations are ready to make firm pledges of new resources and access to technology that will allow developing countries to make a safe transition to industrialization. But the United States continues to resist even a general commitment, even though it recently made an additional $75 million available in environmental aid for developing countries.
The result, many delegates say, has been a general embittering of North-South relations at the conference, with the Group of 77 pushing a number of demands the northern countries consider extreme, politicized and unacceptable.
In Rio, heads of state hope to adopt what is being called an "earth charter," a document northern countries foresee as a relatively short statement committing everyone to taking greater care of the environment -- "the sort of thing you hang on a classroom wall," one diplomat said.
But the Group of 77 has submitted a long draft accusing northern countries of selfishly pushing the world toward ecological disaster through their greed. The draft demands sweeping changes in life styles and consumption patterns.

HEADLINE: Former Chase Manhattan Official Named Deputy Mayor by Dinkins

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
In a move to bolster his standing in the business community, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday appointed Barry F. Sullivan, a well-known banker and former chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, as New York City's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.
Mr. Sullivan, who is 61 years old and who became known in New York City's banking industry as an innovative executive at the Chase Manhattan Bank, will remain a consultant to First Chicago at a salary of $780,000 a year, which was negotiated as part of his retirement package in December before he discussed the city job. He said his consulting work with First Chicago would be minimal and would not interfere with his duties as a deputy mayor. 
 Mr. Sullivan said yesterday that he would give his $112,000 City Hall salary to charity after he pays taxes on it.
Dinkins administration officials said yesterday that Mr. Sullivan's unusual financial arrangement with the city was not unprecedented and that Mr. Sullivan had agreed to remove himself from any city decisions that might affect First Chicago, like the sale of city bonds.
 
Gesture to Business Sector
 The appointment of Mr. Sullivan, who was recruited by David Rockefeller, his former colleague at the Chase, is seen as an attempt by the Dinkins administration to get the business community more involved in developing plans to resolve the city's mounting fiscal problems and to bolster investors' confidence in how the city is run.
Dinkins administration officials noted that during the city's last fiscal crisis, the city hired a number of private finance experts who retained paid affiliations with their respective institutions, including John C. Burton, who was appointed Deputy Mayor for Finance in 1976 but remained an officer of a major bank.
"It's critically important for the city to be able to tap into the rich resources of the business community," said O. Peter Sherwood, the Corporation Counsel for the city. "While we are hiring people with remarkable talents, we are also protecting the public interest by making sure they do not use their position for the benefit of their outside employers."
Mr. Sullivan said that through his appointment, "the Mayor is saying that the private sector is important to the city and if I can get a business expert who also understands the city, I can get a bridge between the two that I don't have today." Mr. Sullivan added that he planned to concentrate on developing small and medium-size businesses in New York City and attracting more international businesses.
He said that while he had contemplated not accepting a salary from the city, he later decided that it was important that he be paid for the work he performed. The money, he said, will be donated to New York City's parochial and public schools, Columbia University and the United Way.
Mr. Sullivan, who strengthened First Chicago's bank's venture-capital and consumer divisions, takes over as the city's chief promoter of business and development at a time when the city is struggling to overcome its worst fiscal crisis since the 1970's.
Facing mounting budget deficits, Mayor Dinkins has been under pressure from business leaders to hold down taxes and avoid drastic service cuts. But as city services decline and with the high cost of doing business in New York, many companies and investors appear to have lost faith in New York City and have moved elsewhere.
 
To Forge New Ties
 Mr. Sullivan, who has broad experience in the private sector and in public sector jobs like helping Chicago's first black mayor, Harold Washington, build links to the business community, is being brought in to forge new ties between the Dinkins administration and the business community, whose relationship has been tenuous, aides to Mr. Dinkins said.
Perhaps the most difficult challenge facing Mr. Sullivan is building new confidence among the city's business leaders and attracting new business and investments through partnerships and other arrangements.
Mayor Dinkins announced Mr. Sullivan's appointment at a City Hall news conference yesterday attended by some of the city's top business leaders, including Mr. Rockefeller, the former chairman of Chase, and Robert Tisch, the chairman of the New York City Partnership. "Mr. Sullivan's ideals, combined with his hard work and dedication, will help the city of New York and will help this government better serve the people of New York," Mr. Dinkins said.
Mr. Rockefeller first approached Mr. Sullivan about the deputy mayor job in January when city officials put the word out that they were looking for a successor to Sally Hernandez-Pinero, who resigned last month to become chairwoman of the city's Housing Authority.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, who had indicated that she wanted a less demanding job so that she could spend more time with her young children, had earned the respect of many in the business world, though she was initially seen by some as inexperienced and weak.
Business and community leaders yesterday praised Mr. Sullivan's appointment, which has been expected for some time but was delayed because of negotiations over his affiliation with the bank. Mr. Sullivan is scheduled to begin his new job full time on May 1 after he completes a volunteer project in Chicago to involve business executives in reviewing the finances of the city's public schools.
"The business community would like to feel that the person in that job understands its problems and can offer some creative solutions," said Tony Terraccino, chairman and president of the First Fidelity Bank Corporation. "Barry Sullivan is just that person because he's knowledgeable about business and understands its needs."

HEADLINE: Friedrich von Hayek Dies at 92; An Early Free-Market Economist

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Friedrich von Hayek, a Nobel Prize-winning economist who was an intellectual forebear of libertarians and other advocates of free-market economics from Ronald Reagan to Margaret Thatcher to Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus of post-Communist Czechoslovakia, died yesterday. He was 92 years old.
Mr. Hayek's secretary, Charlotte E. Cubitt, confirmed his death in Freiburg, Germany, according to Edward Crane, president of the Cato Institute, a conservative American research and policy institute. 
 Mr. Hayek, a British citizen of Austrian birth who taught at the University of Chicago during the 1950's, had lived in Freiburg for nearly three decades and been ill for several years. The immediate cause of his death was not announced.
Mr. Hayek won the Nobel Prize in 1974 for his work in the 1920's and 1930's on money, prices and the causes of the business cycle. But his most famous work was a 1944 book, "The Road to Serfdom," which predicted that collectivism would fail and warned Western Europe and the United States of the dangers of socialism and big government.
 
'A Rallying Cry'
 "It provided a rallying cry for free-market intellectuals during what was for them the dark days of the 1940's," said Mr. Crane, president of the Cato Institute, said. "He proved to be very prescient."
Stephen Kresge, who is editing Mr. Hayek's collected works -- 18 books, 15 pamphlets and 142 articles -- added, "It was one of those ironies that he was widely read in Eastern Europe at a time when he wasn't being read in the West."
Mr. Hayek influenced virtually every prominent free-market economist, from Milton Friedman to George Stigler, as well as providing intellectual fodder for some of the Reagan Administration young turks, including Martin Anderson, the President's first chief domestic-policy adviser, and Paul Craig Roberts, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy.
An ardent opponent of most Government intervention in the economy, he was all but ignored by other economists for 30 years after World War II, although he was respected for early contributions to monetary theory.
This was a time when economic thought was most heavily influenced by John Maynard Keynes, an advocate of growth and prosperity with an important role to be played by government. Keynesianism became a dominant intellectual force, as the European social democracies boomed and the Soviet Union and other centrally planned economies scored impressive feats of industrialization.
Mr. Hayek, an extreme hawk on inflation, also laid the intellectual foundations for opposition to high taxes on inheritances or high incomes.
His following in the United States, even after he won the Nobel Prize, consisted mostly of a small band of monetary economists, including Milton Friedman of the University of Chicago, a fellow Nobelist in economics, who held that too-rapid growth of the money supply was the root of all outbreaks of inflation.
With the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, his constituency has widened. Mr. Hayek's views on the economic inadequacies and political ills of central planning are now regarded as in the mainstream.
 
Medal From Bush

Last November, President Bush awarded Professor Hayek (rhymes with kayak) the Medal of Freedom, the United States' highest civilian honor. His son, Laurence Hayek, accepted the award.
"More than almost anyone else in the 20th century, this guy was vindicated by the events in Eastern Europe," said Austin Furse, director of policy planning at the White House.
Once described as "articulate, austere and infinitely urbane," Mr. Hayek was born in 1899, into a Viennese family of academics and civil servants.
The tall, patrician Mr. Hayek served as a gunner in World War I before earning two doctorates, one in law and a second in economics. During the 1920's, he was a member of a small circle of brilliant young Austrian economsts, including Fritz Machlup, Oskar Morgenstern and Gottfried Haberler, all of whom, like Mr. Hayek, eventually ended up at prominent American univeristies.
On the eve of the Depression, he left for the London School of Economics, where he lectured in the 1930's and 40's. He won that post by creating a stir with a series of lectures on the causes of economic booms and busts.
 
Debate With Keynes
 Soon after arriving in England, Mr. Hayek threw down the gauntlet to John Maynard Keynes by delivering a blistering review of the Treatise on Money. According to Mark Blaug, a historian and professor emeritus at the University of London, the controversy engaged almost everyone who was anyone in monetary economics in that day and was only settled, in Keynes's favor, when Keynes published his "General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money" in 1936.
When Keynesian thought prevailed and his reputation went into eclipse, Mr. Hayek turned to philosophy and psychology, which he first taught at the University of Chicago, where he wrote what many consider to be a second masterpiece, "The Constitution of Liberty." He returned to Austria in the early 1960's and finally settled in Freiburg.
"He got the satisfaction, the enormous satisfaction, not only of recognition," said Mr. Kresge, "but of seeing what has happened in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union."
In addition to his son, Mr. Hayek is survived by his second wife, Helene, and a daughter, Christine.

HEADLINE: Polish Austerity Budget Threatens Medical Care

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, March 23

 BODY:
As Poland's leaders unveiled the Government's austerity budget, Dr. Piotr Zielinski was worrying today about matters less sweeping: how many doctors to dismiss and where he might finance next week's purchases of medicine.
Dr. Zielinski, director of the Bielinski Hospital on the outskirts of Warsaw, runs one of the thousands of agencies in Poland that are already hard up for resources and will have to make do this year with even less. He is planning to lay off 30 percent of his employees this year, close down most specialized wards, and continue asking patients for voluntary contributions, even though the Polish Constitution guarantees everyone free health care. 
 Poland's economic reform plans, regarded as the boldest in Eastern Europe for the last two years, have recently been the focus of concern among Western economists. The victory of parties opposed to the reform plans in last year's parliamentary elections stirred questions of whether Poland was losing its nerve just as the reforms entered their most painful phase.
"In order to avoid a financial crash, reform must involve austerity measures," Andrzej Olechowski, the Finance Minister, told reporters today as he described a budget aimed at restoring Poland's credibility in international financial markets.
Poland is under strong pressure from the International Monetary Fund to limit its deficit to 5 percent of gross national product, about $4.5 billion.
The I.M.F. suspended approval of Poland's economic program in September, after the budget deficit began to soar out of control. A tentative agreement to reduce Poland's $46 billion international debt is contingent on maintaining the fund's approval.
The budget Mr. Olechowski sent to the Parliament today hits the 5 percent deficit target by limiting spending on health and education and by proposing something few American politicians would dare try: cuts in social security.
Mr. Olechowski said Poland's retirement system, which guarantees a pension of about 70 percent of the average industrial wage, was more generous than the country could afford, and he said the 2.5 million people receiving disability payments was well above European standards.
At the squat, gray-concrete Bielinski Hospital, Dr. Zielinski has already learned much about pinching pennies. The hospital ran out of money in October, and survived only through a public fund-raising campaign that included strategically placed collection boxes and televised appeals for contributions.
In the final months of 1991, the 685-bed hospital created waiting lists for all non-emergency surgery. The typical patient needing a hernia operation or gall bladder removal waited four to six weeks. This year the hospital is temporarily resuming its normal schedule.
Dr. Zielinski insisted that the money allocated to him by the Health Ministry was less than the bare minimum. But he acknowledged that Poland's entire system of health care encouraged waste and needed drastic reform. "We've never had to calculate the cost of anything," he said.
Until recently, the doctors at Bielinski Hospital and the adjoining outpatient clinic made house calls, and whole wards of the hospital were kept open all night with doctors on duty in case any patients walked in. Since visits to the doctor were free, some elderly people treated the outpatient clinic as a "social club" and dropped by every day, according to Dr. Zielinski.
Officials at the Health Ministry hope to set up a system of health insurance in Poland. Meanwhile, they have already put into effect a plan in which patients have to make partial payments for some of the more expensive prescription medicines. In the case of some imported antibiotics, this can mean $15 per treatment, about 10 percent of the average monthly wage of an industrial worker in Poland.
Dr. Zielinski said that shortly after this system was announced, the number of patients seeking help at the hospital's clinic dropped sharply. He attributed this both to a reduction in frivolous visits and to a fear among sick people that they would be prescribed medicine they could not afford.
 
Few Alternatives Seen
 Senior Polish officials well understand the hardships these budget cuts are bringing, but see few alternatives. One factor influencing their thinking was a confidential World Bank study, circulated this year, that said Poland stood on the brink of hyper-inflation and must slash social spending, raise taxes and end the role of workers in managing state-owned factories that still employ millions of people.
The analysts argued that Poland could lose the benefits of two years of economic austerity if it failed to tighten control over its budget -- particularly pensions -- and speed up privatization with a "drastic approach."
"Poland faces grave problems that it must overcome," the World Bank said in the draft report. "The fiscal situation has worsened to the point where hyper-inflation is an immediate danger. Unemployment reached a level that cannot be tolerated for long, even if many unemployed find some work in the informal sector."
The World Bank analysts acknowledged that Government intervention was needed to end a recession that has pushed unemployment above 12 percent. According to the report, market forces alone have failed to transform the country's state-run industries, and must be supplemented by programs that force such factories to restructure or go bankrupt.

HEADLINE: Nunn Is Optimistic On Big Aid Package For Ex-Soviet Lands

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
After a meeting with President Bush, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said today that he was "cautiously optimistic" that the President would soon push for a major aid package to help Russia and other republics of the former Soviet Union.
Senator Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, and three other Senators who recently traveled with him to Moscow and Kiev, met with Mr. Bush to urge him to press ahead with aid for the republics and to tell him that he would have bipartisan support in the Senate for such a package. 
 "I am cautiously optimistic that the President is going to be more assertive and that we're going to see some kind of proposal forthcoming from the Administraton," Senator Nunn said.
The Senators said they had discussed a contribution to a multibillion-dollar fund to stabilize the ruble and the $12 billion contribution that the United States had pledged, but not approved, for the International Monetary Fund.
Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana and an influential member of the Foreign Relations Committee, said in a news briefing after the meeting, "We want him to lead and we want to support him, and we understand that a very difficult vote-getting operation will be required to get support" for such increased foreign aid.
 
Nunn Praises Russia
 The group of senators, which included John Warner, Republican of Virginia, and Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who attended the meeting, told them that "a large package is being examined."
Senator Nunn praised Russia for taking painful steps to build a market economy, but he said the republics were in great need of Western help to allow that transition to succeed.
"This is a critical time," he said. "My feeling is that we spend some dollars now in order to spend a whole lot less in the long run, perhaps expenditure of trillions if we have proliferation and ethnic conflict breaking out all over the former empire."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
On Reflection, Bush and Clinton Have Likenesses

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn., March 23

 BODY:
Moving from the hermetically sealed, high-security bubble of President Bush's entourage to Gov. Bill Clinton's campaign is a journey through the political looking glass. It is not hard to imagine the two candidates standing on opposite sides of the mirror, looking at reflections distorted by politics and circumstances but in many ways the same.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton are both graduates of the school of compromise, trying to get along with as many people as possible and building up networks of friends and allies through endless note-writing and constant telephoning. But the public perception could not differ more. 
 Voters rate Mr. Bush high on integrity and honesty and low on compassion and understanding of their problems. For Mr. Clinton, it is just the opposite. His just-plain-folksiness is as much a problem as Mr. Bush's aloofness, and that could drive a Bush-Clinton contest, if, as now seems likely, Mr. Clinton wins the Democratic nomination.
 
Different 'Family Values'
 If Mr. Bush has to decide how goofy is too goofy and when impressively Presidential becomes dangerously detached, then Mr. Clinton must ask: How slick is too slick? When do human flaws turn into fatal weaknesses?
The mirror images are reflected in their speeches, as Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton sound many of the same themes and make many of the same arguments, but salt them with social values that could not be more divergent. For Mr. Bush, "family values" means an anti-abortion amendment to the Constitution; for Mr. Clinton, the phrase means legalized abortion.
They even show in the atmosphere on the two men's campaign planes. Mr. Bush's is a war zone; his aides are convinced the press is out to get the candidate and at fault when the President's campaigning falls flat. Mr. Bush once courted reporters, especially when his popularity was high; but with times tougher, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, has called them "lazy bastards."
More thick-skinned, Mr. Clinton smiled through weeks of attacks, managing to keep his plane an oasis of congeniality. When a newcomer joined the flock of reporters last week, a regular tried to persuade him that Mr. Clinton was more worthy to be President than Mr. Bush.
 
Image-Building Time
 Other images seem the same. Both staffs are virtually all-white clubs, with a woman as rare a sight on Mr. Clinton's plane as it is in Mr. Bush's entourage. Criticism of the Arkansas Governor's playing golf at an all-white club has given him a taste of Mr. Bush's struggles with his patrician image.
Even the candidates' campaign strategies seem reflected in the same glass.
After defusing Pat Buchanan's challenge, Mr. Bush has put his Boeing 747 in the hangar for a while and retreated to the White House. There, he is busy trying to look tougher than Congress and paint himself as a chief executive burdened by the responsibility of governing and trying to get the Democrats to do the right thing.
After emerging with a seemingly unassailable lead in the Democratic race, Mr. Clinton will have to pick up the pace, his aides say, not just to keep winning primaries, but to elevate himself to Mr. Bush's level.
The President's fortunes rely heavily on his ability to use the power of incumbency. Mr. Clinton must build himself up by knocking Mr. Bush down.
Barnstorming through Connecticut and New York, the Arkansas Governor presented himself as a compassionate leader and Mr. Bush as a schoolyard bully who was blaming everyone else for his misdeeds and was in need of a visit to the woodshed.
"If I had behaved that way as a young boy, my Momma would have spanked me," Mr. Clinton said, letting his Arkansas drawl slide just a little deeper into the "aw-shucks" register.
Painfully aware that Mr. Bush can schedule nationally televised speeches and meet foreign leaders to remind everyone of his stature, Mr. Clinton is planning more major speeches.
But Mr. Clinton is having trouble finding areas of disagreement on military policy, apart from his desire to keep building a submarine that Mr. Bush is willing to forgo, and slight differences on helping workers at weapons plants that will soon close.
Mr. Clinton is forced by conviction and politics to support Mr. Bush on the Persian Gulf war. To show a difference, he can only rely on Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf's assertion that the war ended a bit too soon. Mr. Bush can bring the general on stage and then go to military bases to be cheered as Commander in Chief.
Mr. Bush has not seemed to be able to get his themes in focus, give speeches without mangling his lines or show he cares about regular people. Mr. Clinton, though a compelling orator, sometimes ends up looking just a bit too facile as he exercises his ability to sound as if he has been thinking all day about the particular problems of an audience.
While polls show that many voters wonder if Mr. Bush can be trusted to be an agent of social justice and economic equity, not just a globe-trotting diplomat and warrior chief, they also show that voters do not know if they can trust Mr. Clinton at all.
Mr. Bush's aides say they look forward to exploiting Mr. Clinton's inexperience on the national stage and his other weaknesses.
Mr. Clinton has said he looks forward to crossing speeches with an opponent who cannot speak well off the cuff.
The candidates try to please their audiences in their own ways. In anticipation of the New York primary on April 7, Mr. Clinton has made much of his opposition to Mr. Bush's Middle East policies. He has not mentioned that, like Mr. Bush, he opposes Israeli settlements on the West Bank.
Mr. Bush often announces some new Federal program to benefit the state in which he is campaigning and seems to know every local politician by name.
Mr. Bush believes he cannot win without the conservative vote and Patrick J. Buchanan's assaults have forced the President further to the right. Mr. Clinton, on the other hand, is striking toward the center and the near-right and so has been able to resist pressure from the left.
Still, on Sunday, he had to sit quietly, smiling wanly, as the Rev. Jesse Jackson lectured him on responsibility and compassion and then shamed him into joining a protest march through the streets of New Haven that the Governor had planned to skip.

HEADLINE: New Foe for Seoul Party in Vote Today

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, March 23

 BODY:
South Korea's stormy politics have long been shaped by the simple rule that the conservative forces of the military, the Government and big business are always united for the often violent struggle against their common foe, the left.
But as this young democracy prepares for its most important elections in four years on Tuesday, a new challenger is shaking the governing party more than street demonstrations ever did -- a powerful opponent on the right. 
 The 76-year-old Chung Ju Yung, founder of the Hyundai group, Korea's second largest industrial conglomerate, has formed a new conservative party and opened a bitter assault on the governing party of President Roh Tae Woo in the campaign for the National Assembly.
This independent-minded, self-made millionaire has pushed ideology aside and focused his harsh attacks on bread-and-butter economic issues and political corruption. What he is offering is not a new political order so much as what he says would be a more competent one. In doing so he is initiating a debate that is likely to persist even if his quixotic campaign fails -- a debate on what role the Government should play in the economy as South Korean democracy matures.
"His involvement has really given us a shock," said Suh Song Mok, a National Assembly member from the governing Democratic Liberal Party and one of its key election strategists. "The main issue in the election has turned out to be chairman Chung, and how many seats he will win. The question is whether he takes his seats from the ruling party or the opposition."
As Mr. Suh said, the new Unification National Party has also stolen attention if not some votes away from the main opposition party, the Democrats, led by Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's foremost dissident.
Mr. Chung's message is similar to that of Ronald Reagan in the American Presidential election of 1980: He wants to get the Government off the backs of businessmen, in this case by eliminating Government shakedowns and the heavy-handed way it controls everything from what some industries produce to who gets bank loans.
"What he is saying has some appeal to the business community because they don't want to be controlled by the Government any longer," said Yang Sung Chul, a professor of political science at Kyunghee University. "Under Roh Tae Woo we have all these highs: high real estate prices, high inflation, high trade deficit, high foreign debt. People are frustrated. That's why I wouldn't be surprised if there is a protest vote."
Few expect Mr. Chung's party to win a majority of the 299 seats in the Assembly, or even to deny the Democratic Liberals a majority. But he is putting the old military-dominated power structure through a test with longer-term significance: Is it ready for genuine political pluralism?
Over the weekend, a military officer said at a news conference that soldiers were being forced into filing their absentee ballots for the governing party. With about 560,000 soldiers who vote in this way, the news was enough to bring charges of vote-rigging from the opposition. The Defense Ministry denied the charges.
Suspicions that Government agencies have been performing dirty tricks were seemingly confirmed last week when four members of the Agency for National Security Planning, which used to be called the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, were caught handing out leaflets charging an opposition politician with carrying on affairs and fathering an illegitimate child. The Government has said the four were acting on their own.
 
Long Feud With Government
 Mr. Chung, who has officially resigned from the Hyundai group, has had a longstanding feud with the Government, culminating last year in the filing of a $181 million tax case against Hyundai.
Basic economic issues and questions of honesty have pushed aside most other policy debates in the election campaign including national security. Even with the concern over reports that North Korea is developing nuclear weapons, there is almost no discussion among the candidates of how far or how fast the South should go in pushing for reunification with the hard-line Communist Government in Pyongyang.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chung Ju Yung, left, has formed a new conservative party and opened a bitter assault on the governing party of President Roh Tae Woo in the campaign for the National Assembly. On Sunday, Mr. Chung introduced one of his party's candidates, Kim Dong Kil, right, at a rally in Seoul. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton's 2-Front Attack Is Slowed by More Defense of His Past

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GROTON, Conn., March 23

 BODY:
In a curious blend of defensive and offensive posturing on the day before the Connecticut primary, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas lobbed attacks at his two prime political competitors today and fended off new accusations that he used his office to benefit political supporters in his home state.
But one of those two rivals, President Bush, charged Mr. Clinton today with committing "the oldest, most crass political game in the world" by telling local shipbuilders that their project should be saved while at the same time calling for $100 billion in cuts in the military budget. 
 Mr. Clinton, traveling through the state by bus today, called the President a leader who would "do nothing" to stimulate the American economy.
"He told the American Congress to do nothing while American businesses, large, medium and small, are getting their brains beat out because we're the only country in the world without an economic strategy," Mr. Clinton said this morning at a plant gate here.
 
Much Ado About 'Do Nothing'
 Mr. Bush, at a news conference at the White House on Sunday, repeated his oft-stated pitch for Congress to cut the taxes on capital gains. He said he was "perfectly prepared to work with Congress" to stimulate the economy but would not agree to an approach that would harm more than help.
"The best thing would be to do something that would stimulate investment, but if that can't happen, then the next choice would be to do nothing and the worst choice would be to pass a tax-and-spend bill," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Clinton seized on the "do nothing" part of Mr. Bush's statement.
"I couldn't say it any better than George Bush has," Mr. Clinton said. "He has given us his platform for the 1992 election, and I hope the American people read his lips."
In an interview with WTNH-TV in New Haven, Mr. Bush took aim at Mr. Clinton, though he did not mention his name. "I want to cut the defense budget by $50 billion," he said. "And that's based on the recommendations of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Secretary of Defense. And yet, what you're hearing from the other side is: 'Well, 50 is not enough. Let's cut it 100. But when I go to some different area or some different plant, I'll tell them I'll keep theirs open.' That's the oldest, most crass political game in the world."
Mr. Clinton today visited the shipyard here that produces the Seawolf submarine and employs 17,000 people. Mr. Bush has recommended canceling production of the two Seawolfs yet to be built under the contract.
But Mr. Clinton's anti-Bush message was muddled somewhat today as he was forced to explain away more questions from his past.
The major distraction for Mr. Clinton today was an article in The Los Angeles Times that detailed his relationship with Dan R. Lasater, an Arkansas businessman who was awarded a state contract in 1985 for a police communications system.
The article said that Mr. Clinton personally lobbied state legislators, urging their support for a $30.2 million bond contract to finance the state radio system, and that three important Democrats dropped their opposition.
The contract was awarded to an alliance that included Mr. Lasater's company and was worth $750,000 to him and his partners. Governor Clinton in 1986 called Mr. Lasater "a substantial contributor and supporter of mine."
The unsuccessful competitor was Stephens Inc., a Little Rock, Ark., concern that the Times article said had received most of the state's bond business for years. It quoted an anonymous former state Democratic official as saying that Stephens had supported Mr. Clinton's Republican opponent in two elections.
 
Pardon for Contributor
 The article also told of Mr. Lasater's guilty plea and sentencing in 1986 to two and a half years in prison for cocaine possession. After Mr. Lasater finished his sentence, Mr. Clinton granted him a state pardon in 1990.
Mr. Clinton said today that any pressure by him for the communications system was to bring business to the state, not to steer it to a friend.
Responding to recent questions about his playing golf at an all-white club, Mr. Clinton said he had led an "integrated" life. He denied assertions that the club, the Country Club of Little Rock, discriminated, saying that it let non-members like himself play there. "They let people of different races play golf there, go to social events there," he said. "They always have."
Mr. Clinton sought instead today to focus on Mr. Bush and on Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former Governor of California, who attacked Mr. Clinton in New York on Sunday by calling him "Slick Willie" and who said the President would take "Bill Clinton and grind what's left" in the fall election.
"Governor Brown doesn't serve our party very well with those kinds of violent personal attacks," he said.

HEADLINE: Shamir Is Accusing the U.S. of Trying to Rearrange Israel's Borders

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 23

 BODY:
Signaling that he may run for re-election with a campaign against the Bush Administration, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir accused the United States today of trying to rearrange Israel's borders even before the Middle East peace talks have had a chance to get going.
Mr. Shamir said he could never accept President Bush's insistence on a freeze on Jewish settlements in the occupied territories as the price Israel must pay for $10 billion in American loan guarantees to resettle new immigrants from the former Soviet Union. 
 "There can be only one meaning to this demand," he told hundreds of evangelical Christian pilgrims in Jerusalem. "It is an attempt to determine Israel's borders and the ultimate status of the areas in question in advance of negotiations. We shall never agree to such a step."
Once more, the Prime Minister restated his determination to build settlements in the West Bank -- "areas that are the cradle of our civilization."
"This little country is all that we have, and it is ours," he said.
 
Defensible Borders Stressed
 Mr. Shamir did not go quite as far as several of his Cabinet ministers and aides who have accused the Administration of seeking to push Israel fully back to its borders before the war in 1967, when it emerged holding lands that had been part of Syria, Jordan and Egypt. Israel maintains that it cannot properly defend itself from its pre-1967 frontiers, which a senior official in the Prime Minister's office, Benjamin Netanyahu, recently described as "the borders of Auschwitz."
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has rejected all Israeli suggestions that the Administration, with its hard-nosed stand on settlements, was either siding with the Arabs in the peace process or interfering in Israel's parliamentary elections, scheduled for June 23.
In his speech, Mr. Shamir repeated his commitment to the peace negotiations. But it seemed from his remarks that he may now believe, as others in his Likud Party have already concluded, that there is political sense to making targets of Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker in the election campaign against the Labor Party, whose call for a one-year freeze on settlements is presumably more to the Administration's liking.
Any sort of anti-American campaign carries enormous risks, given the overwhelming importance of good relations with Washington for Israel's diplomatic and economic well-being. But feelings against the Administration are running high here these days, especially among political conservatives who tend to vote for Likud or for several small parties even further to the right.
The apparent death of the loan guarantees, the allegations in the United States that Israel had improperly re-sold American arms technology to other countries, the news reports (denied by the State Department) that Mr. Baker used a graphic Anglo-Saxon obscenity in talking about American Jews, and the fatal bombing of the Israeli Embassy in Buenos Aires last week -- all have combined to make many Israelis feel besieged and friendless.
"People are angry at the Bush Administration for what turned out to be an uncompromising stand on guarantees," said Ronald Kronish, head of the Israel office of the American Jewish Committee. "The feeling is that the Administration has been unduly harsh."
While it seemed likely that Labor's leaders would try to blame Mr. Shamir for the poor state of United States-Israeli relations, for in their view being the uncompromising one with his position on settlements, many Likud politicians say their own best bet is to capitalize on resentments here by running against Washington. Their argument is that they will do well by presenting themselves to voters as the ones who stood up for principle even in the face of considerable American pressure.
"The Administration is trying to destroy Israel's image in American public opinion," David Magen, Minister of Economic Planning, told the Israeli radio. There was, he said, a hostile effort to undermine Israel through a campaign of "instigation and incitement."
Apparently, Mr. Shamir is not fully comfortable with this sort of frontal assault, for at a meeting of his Cabinet on Sunday he called for restraint in dealings with the United States, this country's chief benefactor. But his speech before the Christian group today suggested that he was willing at least to test the water for such a campaign.
In his remarks, the Prime Minister said terrorism like the Buenos Aires bombing was "directed against our very existence as a state and as a people."
"The perpetrators of these dastardly crimes will fail," he said, "because they are rebelling against the march of history. They are rebelling against the will of God."
