HEADLINE: Slumping Real Estate Leaves Giant Reeling

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The real estate depression has backed another giant against the wall. In recent days, Olympia & York Developments Ltd., New York's largest commercial landlord and a financial powerhouse in its Canadian homeland and abroad, turned to its banks to ease a cash crisis and began negotiating to reorganize billions of dollars of debt in an attempt to retain its vast holdings.
Now, Paul Reichmann, the highly regarded head of Olympia, will negotiate with scores of bankers to get easier payment terms, forgiveness of debt and a capital structure that will allow the company the latitude to finish its huge Canary Wharf project in London and meet its debt obligations in North America. 
The troubles of this huge conglomerate, which owns the World Financial Center in New York and many other Manhattan office towers, underscore how heavy bank borrowing and falling commercial real estate values in the United States and London have devastated even the strongest property companies.
In London last week, Citibank foreclosed on Randsworth, a $425 million property investment by a group of pension funds in more than a million square feet of London office and retail space. And developers on both sides of the Atlantic have faced cash squeezes as rents and property values have fallen.
Besides its real estate holdings, Olympia & York owns most of the Gulf Canada oil company, most of Abitibi-Price, the world's largest maker of newsprint, and enormous property holdings in the United States and Europe. It is one of the world's largest private companies and its losses in property investments could yet have a devastating impact on many of the biggest banks in Canada, the United States, Europe and Japan that have lent more than $12 billion to the company. Rumors of the company's troubles have roiled the commercial paper markets for the last few weeks.
News of the Olympia cash crisis shook the Toronto Stock Exchange yesterday, causing real estate and banking issues to fall sharply and the Toronto Stock Exchange 300 to fall 26.28 points, to 3,443.67. The Financial Services Index plunged 67.97, to 2,689.18 as investors speculated on what effect Olympia's troubles may have on Canadian banks.
The exchange's real estate and construction index plunged 83.21, to 6,149.04. And the news brought swift Government action. Finance Minister Donald Mazankowski of Canada said that Ottawa was negotiating with banks to stabilize the company, but he said no bailout was being considered.
For Olympia, the task ahead is to reorganize its debt and try to wring as many concessions from its lenders as possible to protect the company's assets from foreclosure. The company raised more than $170 million in emergency cash last week to ease the crunch. "This will be an exercise in re-establishing the base in all his properties," a prominent real estate executive said.
"The banks are going to accept different terms and lesser debt in exchange for equity in the properties. And that is the game of convincing them that the equity is worth more than it is," the real estate executive said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "If you do that right, what you get is usually much more than you give." Referring to Mr. Reichmann, the executive said: "He gets lower debt and better cash flow and they get a future on the value of the equity. The only way he can lose is if they take the properties."
The restructuring of the Olympia & York empire is likely to prove one of the largest in history and will bring into the center of public attention the Reichmann family, the secretive Toronto billionaires who own the company, and the banks that lent them billions. Since 1990, when the family began quietly looking for a a buyer for 20 percent of its portfolio of American real estate, speculation has swirled that Olympia was squeezed for cash.
Some Wall Street real estate professionals estimated that Olympia had more than $12 billion of bank debt on its books. The company's cash problems have limited its ability to refinance the hundreds of millions of dollars of debt that matured regularly and to do other necessary things like pay for needed property improvements.
 
Huge Cash Drain
 Its 71-acre London project, known as Canary Wharf, is still an enormous cash drain and Olympia has had a hard time taking out the money it invested in development and construction of the project through bank refinancing and issuing public securities. The company's cash flow has shrunk as its non-real estate investments have suffered in the worldwide recession. The Reichmanns have been unable to sell off property to raise cash quickly because the real estate markets have been virtually frozen for more than a year now.
Olympia's troubles harbor huge potential losses for some banks. But because many of the loans are collateralized by individual properties, some banks may suffer only small losses. It is widely expected in the New York real estate market that the banks will take equity positions in some of the Olympia properties in exchanging for writing down the company's debt, reducing interest rates and extending loan maturities.
"The banks have few options in dealing with them now," said another real estate executive who also declined to be identified. "The banks have to provide liquidity or they have a huge problem. Reichmann can use this to his advantage because the banks' alternatives are limited and so they have to be very understanding and work this out."
But even if the banks are very cooperative with the Olympia executives, the restructuring of the company's billions in debt will likely be protracted because of the scale of the debt and the complexity of the company's capital structure.
J. P. Morgan & Company, which has about $50 million in unsecured loans to the company, is expected to serve as its adviser in the negotiations.
Yesterday, a spokesman for Olympia declined to comment on the focus of the talks with the company's banks and would say only that the current cash crisis was brought about because the speculation in the commercial-paper markets made it difficult for the company to raise money for the enormous refinancing needs it has each quarter and to refinance commercial paper debt.
"Speculation surrounding the commercial-paper program created a liquidity crisis, which delayed arrangements for other sources of finance," Peter Rosenthal, a spokesman for Olympia, said yesterday.
Commercial paper has long been one of Olympia's main source of financing because the rates are low. But few companies are able to retire all their commercial paper outstanding on short notice. Typically, Olympia would borrow short-term money that would mature every 30 to 90 days and would refinance that debt as it matured with more commercial-paper issues.
Although the recent market rumors and rating agency downgrades of Olympia & York commercial paper over the last several weeks forced the company to reduce its commercial-paper programs from about $800 million to $400 million in Canadian dollars recently, Olympia's problems are more fundamental to problems in the real estate industry.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Higher in Quiet Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices were mostly higher yesterday in quiet dealings that pushed yields lower.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond rose by 3/32 point, or 94 cents per $1,000 face amount. Its yield fell to 8.03 percent, from 8.04 percent late on Friday. 
 No economic reports were released by the Government that affected the bond market. Traders looked ahead to the auction of two-year and five-year notes later this week.
On Friday, Treasury prices fell because of several factors, traders said, including a report from a regional Federal Reserve bank that detected an economic upturn. Signs of economic improvement often depress bond prices because they make it less likely the Fed will lower interest rates.
 
Looking Ahead
 John Canavan, an analyst at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. in Princeton, N.J., said some market participants were looking ahead as far as April 3, when the Government releases March employment figures.
Today, the Treasury Department is scheduled to sell $14.75 billion in two-year notes, and $10.25 billion in five-year notes tomorrow. Both are record amounts.
In the weekly Treasury bill auction yesterday, the Government sold $11.5 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 4.08 percent, down from 4.09 percent last week. Another $11.5 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 4.27 percent, unchanged from last week.
Yields on the securities were 4.18 percent for the three-month bills and 4.43 percent for six-month bills.
 
Short-Term Maturities Up
 In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were unchanged to 3/32 point higher, intermediate maturities were up by 1/16 point to an eighth point, and long-term issues were unchanged to up by 3/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.81 point, to 1,207.35.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 4.17 percent, as the discount rose by 2 basis points, to 4.08 percent. Yields on six-month bills were unchanged at 4.37 percent, as the discount held at 4.23 percent. Yields on one-year bills held at 4.71 percent, as the discount was unchanged at 4.50 percent.
A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.
 
Federal Funds Rate Up
 The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 4 percent, up from 3 3/4 percent late on Friday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 94 1/4, down by 1/32 point. The average yield to maturity was 6.79 percent, unchanged from late on Friday.

HEADLINE: Another Texas Bank for Banc One

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Taking advantage of its high stock price, the Banc One Corporation announced an agreement yesterday to buy Team Bancshares of Dallas, the successor of a failed Texas bank, for $782 million of Banc One stock.
The acquisition of Team, which was created in 1988 by a private investor group to buy failed and weak Texas banks, will strengthen Banc One's grip as the second-largest banking company in the state and make it the leading bank in terms of branch offices in the Austin and Dallas/Fort Worth markets. Team has about $5.5 billion in assets.
 
Tripled Their Money
 
 Banc One completed its acquisition of most parts of the failed MCorp, a Texas banking company, last year, but it remains second in the state to Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., which bought the failed First Republicbank in 1988.
For investors who were brave enough to put money with Team in the late 1980's, the sale to Banc One will produce a profit equal to nearly three times their investment of $270 million. The gain is even greater for investors who were among the earliest buyers of Team shares, according to Ronald G. Steinhart, chairman of Team and a major investor in the company.
While Team benefited from the willingness of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to hold the bad loans of banks acquired by Team, the Government has never been a shareholder in the company. By concentrating on collecting low-cost deposits from consumers and making loans to individuals and local companies, Team was profitable in its first year, and in 1991 it earned about $35 million.
"That's not as much as we think this bank can earn when the economy comes back all the way," Mr. Steinhart added.
Team will be the sixth company with assets greater than $1 billion that Banc One has bought in the last year in exchange for new shares of stock. Banc One's stock, which closed unchanged yesterday at $46.625, has been trading at an unusually high price for a banking company relative to its profits.
Because of its high stock price, Banc One has been able to make the acquisitions by issuing fewer shares than would be required by other companies whose stock is not so highly esteemed. That has been a big advantage for the banking company, enabling it to offer prices for acquisitions that other companies could not match without issuing so many new shares that their earnings per share would fall. For example, the $82 worth of Banc One stock to be paid for each share of Team is equal to about 2.25 times Team's book value, the value of each share on Team's own books. Most bank acquisitions are done at two times book value, or less.
 
Helped Share Earnings
 Donald Kimble, an assistant vice president at Banc One, said that all of the banking company's acquisitions had increased, or are expected to increase, earnings per share in the first year after the purchase. By contrast, many other banking companies that have issued new shares for acquisitions say that the increase in the number of shares outstanding caused earnings per share to decline for a few years after the acquisition.
Banc One has issued or will issue 32.7 million new shares to pay for the 14 banking companies, with a total of $12 billion in assets, that it acquired last year. But analysts still expect Banc One to earn more per share in 1992 than the $3.16 it earned last year.

HEADLINE: Stocks Slip in Quiet Trading; Dow Off 4.25

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed slightly lower in quiet trading yesterday, giving back some of the gains made on Friday in the "triple witching" expiration of index futures, index options and equity options contracts.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 4.25 points, to 3,272.14. Other indexes also fell a bit. 
 A firming bond market helped stocks bounce back in the afternoon, but that was not enough to counter a negative tone established early in day. That tone was set by some sharp declines in European stock markets and investor concern over interest rates and the budget deficit.
And as if that were not enough, news that Citicorp would have a loss of about $120 million on a loan to a British property company also dampened the mood.
"This market has been in the same trading range for about 10 weeks, with no hint of direction," said Ricky Harrington, director of equity investments for Marion Bass Securities.
Analysts said investors were marking time awaiting the release of more economic data this week to see if there were further signs of a recovery. The durable goods numbers, due out tomorrow, "may turn out to be the most important of the week," Mr. Harrington noted.
Yesterday's New York Stock Exchange volume of 157.05 million shares was extremely light compared with the 246.9 million shares traded on Friday. Losing issues outnumbered gainers by 996 to 699.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.39 points, to 409.91, and the American Stock Exchange composite dropped 0.67 point, to 401.36. In Nasdaq trading, the decline was a little deeper, with the composite off 2.45 points, to 621.83, while the Russell 2,000 slid 0.61 point, to 207.76.
Rising interest rates were a concern, as mortgage rates inched higher and the Treasury's 30-year bond remained over 8 percent. The combination put some pressure on equities, traders said.
Reports that the Federal Reserve was worried about the recovery and that wide budget deficits are forecast for the mid-1990's also dampened market sentiment.
Elsewhere, traders said news of Citicorp's loan loss and reports that Olympia & York, the Canadian developer, was seeking to restructure its $20 billion of debt hurt the banking sector.
Citicorp fell 1/2, to 17 1/8; J. P. Morgan fell 1, to 58; Chemical Banking fell 5/8, to 34 3/4; Norwest dropped 5/8, to 35 1/8, and First Union lost 1 1/8, to 35 3/4.
Trading desks said shares of Intel fell 1 3/4, to 63 1/4, following an article in Barron's that investors faced earnings disappointments.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Lower As Trading Slows to Crawl

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower in slow trading today as dealers adjusted their positions in anticipation of new data on the United States economy.
Gold was unchanged in New York, closing at $338.20 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Later, the Republic National Bank quoted a price of $338.25, also unchanged from Friday. 
 "I can't emphasize how quiet it was today," said Kevin Lawrie, vice president for foreign exchange with the Bank of Boston. "There was nothing new to inspire people. I haven't seen it this quiet in a number of weeks."
Traders were waiting for new economic statistics that might give the dollar some direction, Mr. Lawrie said.
Tomorrow the Government is to release figures on February durable goods orders. On Thursday, figures for fourth-quarter gross domestic product and corporate profits will be announced, along with weekly jobless figures.
"We're not clear whether the dollar is still in its bullish uptrend," Mr. Lawrie said. "People are looking for anything positive to grab onto."
Traders say the market is cautious and needs extraordinary economic figures to move it.
The dollar ended the day in New York at 133.45 Japanese yen, down from Friday's 133.85. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 134.20 yen, up 1.65 yen from Thursday. Japanese markets were closed Friday for a national holiday.
In London yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 133.75 yen.
The dollar was also lower against the German mark, closing at 1.6665, down from 1.6730 late Friday. The mark closed in Europe at 1.6685 marks, down from 1.6785 Friday.
Against the British pound, the dollar fared no better, closing at $1.7190, compared with $1.7120 Friday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7170, from $1.7045 Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.5145 Swiss francs, down from 1.5190; 5.6515 French francs, down from 5.6755; 1,252.75 Italian lire, down from 1,257.00, and 1.19175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19825.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Europe Is Costly So Far for Delta

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas

 BODY:
FLY Delta Air Lines from Munich or Frankfurt to New York? It is not the first airline that Germans think of, for Delta has not been a household word in Europe. Since taking over most of Pan American World Airway's routes to Europe last summer, however, the carrier has spent heavily to become a competitor there, and industry experts are optimistic the investment will pay off over the long term.
"There's more to be done in terms of identity," said Harold Achtziger, the vice president of international operations at Delta. "Once we get the message out on how big our route structure is, then people will become enthused." 
 Delta began service to 21 former Pan Am trans-Atlantic destinations on Nov. 1, a time of year when international traffic normally falls. The recession has pushed traffic down even further. This combined with heavy spending on retraining employees, refurbishing terminals and other start-up costs put great pressure on earnings. Delta's operating loss for the quarter ended Dec. 31 totaled $236.8 million, and the net loss totaled $187.6 million.
"It's taken a lot to train people to our way of doing business," Mr. Achtziger said.
The situation has affected Delta's stock, which closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at $66.25, unchanged. That is on the low end of its range of $65.25 to $75.25 in the last year.
Since the start-up costs were higher than expected, the results were of concern to some analysts. For example, Rose Ann Tortora, an airline analyst at County NatWest, increased her estimate of Delta's losses for the fiscal year ending in June to $1.50 a share from $1.00. She added that since Delta's stock was at a high level, it was vulnerable if international operations did not improve.
So far, international bookings for all airlines have remained discouraging, with carriers, including Delta, offering a free companion ticket to those who travel to Europe. And some carriers cut fares by 10 percent this month to stimulate bookings.
Whether the resistance to travel will continue into the peak summer season is uncertain since many people book at the last minute.
There is little doubt that Delta's acquisition of the Pan Am routes will eventually prove to be highly profitable. Frankfurt is considered to be a desirable hub for service to other destinations in Europe and other parts of the world.
Delta has raised concern among carriers like Lufthansa and Alitalia, both because its strong domestic system in the United States gives it the ability to feed its international flights and because its healthy balance sheet enables it to expand.
For the time being, however, Delta's start-up costs will continue to take a bite out of earnings. During the quarter ending this month, its expenses to service passengers have risen 37 percent over the comparable period last year, Ms. Tortora said.
"If the implementation is successful," she added, "they will get the offsetting revenues, and they will make money."
She said that Delta had had a good record in developing new service. Also, Delta has an advantage over European carriers in that its cost of delivering service is lower.
Nevertheless, European carriers have also become aggressive in preparing for the greater competition in their market. They have ordered new airplanes, have started new routes and are upgrading what are considered some of the best in-flight services even further.
Most are also cutting back on their top-heavy management and getting cost savings from their unions, and many are no longer dependent on state subsidies. Some -- British Airways, for example -- have become privately owned carriers that are building global route networks.
Thus, Delta is taking over routes in markets where the competition is becoming keener.
Mr. Achtziger said his staff had been looking at the way Lufthansa serves its customers. But it has not been a one-way street, he added. "They are looking at their product, and they are copying some of the things we do," he said.
Delta has also formed a partnership with Swissair and Singapore Airlines under which they feed traffic to one another and do some joint marketing.
Delta and other American giants are not a great threat to the European carriers in the short term, but they cause concern over the long range. Delta, with its lower operating costs, modern fleet and strong financial resources, can gradually whittle away at the European airlines' market share and threaten even their strongest hubs.
Ms. Tortora added that operating under the pressure of deregulation, American carriers had learned to be fast to win new markets and had become determined to keep driving down costs.
"They have become very competitive on the cost side," she said.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Capital Spending Unlikely to Surge

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE incipient recovery, now evident in higher retail sales, should -- if it continues -- show up in another form by late summer: a rebound in capital spending as Corporate America re-equips to meet the growing demand for its wares. That was the pattern after other recessions. The problem is that capital spending lately has failed to perform according to script.
During the recession, it declined only mildly, avoiding the steep plunges of previous recessions. The concern is that the mild decline in capital spending will be followed, in the recovery, by an equally mild rebound in capital spending. But even if capital spending rebounds sharply, will it create thousands of new jobs, as it has in the past? The answer appears to be no, which means the recovery will be harder to sustain. 
 "The cost of employment is a much greater consideration than it was in the past," said Raymond E. Cartledge, chairman of the Union Camp Corporation, a paper company that invested $1.2 billion in 1990 and 1991, mostly for machinery to increase production capacity by one-quarter for its main products. But when the big spending was over, Union Camp had added no employees.
Similarly, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company invested $5.2 billion in 1990 and 1991 so that its long-distance network in the United States could handle 135 million business calls on an average weekday last year, up from 110 million in 1989. But as A.T.& T. installed the new automated gear, the number of workers operating the network sank to 11,600 in 1991 from 16,800 in 1989.
The cutbacks reflect what Eliot Janeway, an economic consultant, calls "the killer cost of job benefits." Health care and pensions, in particular, have become a larger share of labor costs.
Presumably, if the economy becomes strong enough, the concern over adding labor costs will fade. Union Camp might build an additional factory, requiring more workers, rather than cram new machinery into existing plants, so that existing workers can produce more. And A.T.& T., having just introduced a video telephone for the home, might find sales brisk enough to justify a separate plant to make the phones. Right now they are made as a sideline by existing workers at a factory in Shreveport, La., dedicated to other products.
Such decisions will not come easily. Corporations are wary. Demand for what they sell has suffered not only from the recession, which started in July 1990, but also from the minuscule growth that has stifled the economy since early 1989. "There is not a lot of new investment because there is not a boom or a great expectation of one," said Edward Denison, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
Reflecting the reluctance to expand employment while more production can be obtained from existing workers, the amount of capital equipment assigned to each worker has risen in value at an average annual rate of 1.5 percent since 1979. That is almost as much as Germany's 1.6 percent, the Labor Department reports. But with expansion no longer so popular, net new investment -- that is, capital outlays beyond the cost of replacing existing equipment -- declined in the late 1980's to less than 5 percent of gross domestic product, the G.D.P. being all the new wealth that a nation generates in a given period. Until the 1980's, the proportion rarely fell below 7 percent.
"Companies are content to seek higher profits from their existing operations rather than expand in the hope of gaining market share when the boom comes," said David Wyss, senior economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting service.
Aside from the aversion to labor costs and the skepticism about the future, economists cite other factors that have discouraged capital spending, both new and replacement. It totaled $1.06 trillion in 1990 and 1991, after adjustment for inflation, or roughly 11 percent of G.D.P. compared with nearly 16 percent a decade ago.
The still-heavy corporate debt load means revenue must be channeled into loan repayment rather than investment. Further, overbuilding of offices and stores has killed investment in commercial buildings. And foreigners are inhibiting investment on two counts. First, they are reducing their spending for new factories in the United States. Second, their array of modern plants abroad inhibits expansion by American companies. The latter have become fearful that consumers will buy imports rather than domestic products.
The bottom line is weak investment, endangering a recovery. Vigorous capital spending in the past has created new jobs not only to make new equipment and build new factories and stores, but also to man them. The new workers have then become bigger consumers, feeding the recovery.
"The hope is that companies whose products people buy will hire and then invest and expand and hire more people," Mr. Wyss said. "But right now executives are being cautious. And what scares us is that they won't shake their caution."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A.T.& T. Enters Card Venture

 BODY:
Taking aim at the largely untapped market of small-business customers, American Express and A.T.& T. said yesterday that they planned to offer a card combining features of American Express cards and A.T.& T.'s long-distance discount card.
The new program, called Corporate Link, offers teleconferencing and other communications services, language translation services, consolidated and detailed billing, as well as itemized expense-account and other reports. Customers will also receive 10 percent discounts on long-distance charges totaling $120 or more a year. 
 The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the American Express Company have both experienced sharp reverses in their core businesses in recent years, prompting both to work on strengthening their appeal to small-business customers. Providing services when a company is young is likely to build a loyal customer, executives from A.T.& T. and American Express say, an important consideration when every market-share point is sharply contested.
After intense competition by MCI and Sprint, A.T.& T. has stabilized a sharp drop in long-distance market share at about 67 percent. The white-collar recession hurt American Express's Optima, or revolving-credit operation, as well as the mainstay green charge-card operation, where bills are paid in full at the end of the month.

HEADLINE: Callousness at Colt's

 BODY:
Two years ago Colt Industries' faltering firearms manufacturing unit, based in Hartford, was saved by financing that included state pension funds as well as money from a union and private investors. But then the new company disappointed supporters of gun control by bringing out a new version of an assault rifle the old Colt had voluntarily withdrawn from the civilian market.
Last week, when the still-troubled firearms company filed for bankruptcy, the state again moved to prop it up, this time with a loan of $2 million from the Connecticut Development Authority. Yet doubts remain about the propriety of public support for a business with a history of indifference to valid public concern. 
 The company, founded in the 19th century by Samuel Colt, produces a variety of handguns along with the M-16 assault rifle for the military. In 1989 it withdrew its AR-15, a version of the M-16 sold in civilian gun shops, as a gesture to public concern about domestically produced assault rifles. Such weapons, prized by criminals, serve no compelling legitimate purpose in civilian hands.
The company's subsequent owners didn't inherit the capacity for corporate statesmanship. Shortly after they took over the business they now call Colt's Manufacturing, they began shipping a version of the AR-15 called the Sporter, modified to eliminate superficial assault weapon features like a bayonet mount. That dismayed Francisco Borges, the Connecticut State Treasurer, midwife of the deal two years ago in which public employee pension funds had put up $25 million to purchase 47 percent of the new company. He spoke of pressuring the company to withdraw the Sporter, to no avail.
Like other gun makers, Colt's finds that the recession and the end of the cold war have cut deeply into demand for its traditional lines of firearms. The criminal market, meanwhile, looks more and more robust.
Colt's won't say how much the Sporter contributes to sales and insists that most purchasers use it for target competition. State officials, public employees and taxpayers have a right to more precise reassurance that the rescue of a proud old company won't pose a new threat to public safety.

HEADLINE: A Military Force for the Americas

 BODY:
Right-wingers backed by the military have now thwarted an international peace plan for Haiti, forcing the Organization of American States to contemplate stronger approaches to restoring democratic rule. In Venezuela, military nationalists challenge democracy. And Shining Path guerrillas terrorize Peru.
The time has come to create a new inter-American military force that could intervene to protect democratic governments from hijacking by armed terrorists. 
 The vast majority of Haitians favored O.A.S. efforts to restore their ousted President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. But an armed minority of soldiers and political thugs intimidated enough legislators to block final approval.
Now O.A.S. members are likely to step up economic pressure. That will bring new suffering to impoverished Aristide supporters, but may not soften the hearts of soldiers who have profited handsomely from drugs and other illicit rackets.
Nor will embargoes alone provide an answer to serious problems elsewhere in the hemisphere. Last month rebel soldiers nearly overthrew Venezuela's democratic Government. And in Peru, the violent Shining Path insurgency continues to gain ground, threatening the democratic regime. Peru's own army, notorious for human rights abuses, has proved ineffective and a danger to democracy itself. Meanwhile the possibility of backdoor U.S. intervention through drug interdiction rightly alarms Congress.
The crises demand a Latin American version of the collective security arrangements now emerging in Europe, Africa and Asia.
European mediators backed by U.N. peacekeepers are trying to end the deadly war between Serbs and Croats. Soldiers from a West African regional organization have helped restrain Liberia's civil war. And Indonesian and Malaysian forces are now moving into Cambodia as part of a U.N. peacekeeping plan. Outside intervention is no longer tantamount to big-power bullying.
A hemispheric intervention force is more likely to be accepted if Washington maintains a low profile. The U.S., as the region's major military power, is uniquely suited to certain logistical and reconnaissance tasks. But political control of the force needs to be shared broadly.
Earlier in the Haitian crisis, Argentina and Costa Rica seemed favorable to creating an inter-American force. With the region's militaries again becoming restive and Shining Path on the march, there's little time to lose.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Tough Choice

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic front-runner, wants to spend $3.4 billion to build two Seawolf attack submarines that President Bush correctly canceled. For that Mr. Clinton has been accused of "pandering" to the voters in Connecticut, whose primary is today. But whatever his motives, the policy is wrong-headed.
Even Mr. Clinton concedes that America doesn't need another Seawolf. He simply wants to keep submarine production capacity afloat until the time comes for a new sub. 
 There's a better way to preserve vital defense industries as the Pentagon budget shrinks. Careful planning can choose exactly which skilled workers and plants are essential. The result is likely to be elimination of some facilities, such as the Connecticut shipyard that builds the Seawolf. But that's the sort of tough choice that will face any President in coming years.
The Seawolf was designed to counter a Soviet submarine threat that is unlikely to materialize. Mr. Clinton would buy a smaller, cheaper submarine, the Centurion, to replace older subs as they retire more than a decade from now. But the Centurion could not be procured until 1998 at the earliest.
Mr. Clinton rightly talks about needing "a plan for conversion" of defense industries to civilian projects. But nuclear submarine yards are not ideal candidates for conversion. There is no commercial need for nuclear subs. And many of the technical skills needed for constructing them can't be honed by building much else.
Even as part of America's defense industrial base, the nuclear submarine yard at General Dynamics's Electric Boat Division in Groton, Conn., may not be needed. The U.S. has another shipyard capable of building and repairing nuclear warships -- at Newport News, Va. When the Pentagon begins building Centurions, it won't be producing them at a fast enough pace to keep two shipyards going. And it doesn't need two fully capable shipyards to insure future competition in designing new nuclear subs.
Newport News says it can restart sub construction even after a hiatus -- if the yard can be put to work overhauling existing subs and building a new nuclear-powered aircraft carrier. A study of the nuclear warship construction industry could examine that claim. It could also examine which key subcontractors with necessary skills may need to be kept in business during the hiatus.
Closing Electric Boat will be painful for its employees and costly to Connecticut and Rhode Island, already suffering from prolonged recession. And resuming submarine production at Newport News after a long layoff would entail other costs.
But it would be cheaper than keeping Electric Boat at work building unneeded submarines. Mr. Clinton calls for change and recognizes that it begins with substantially larger cuts in the defense budget. But he has to accept the consequences of those cuts. Otherwise the more things change, the more they'll stay the same.

HEADLINE: When 'Fairness' Isn't Fair

BYLINE: By Clayton Yeutter; Clayton Yeutter is President Bush's counselor for domestic policy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Class warfare, discredited throughout the former Communist world, seems to have found new life in American political circles. A front-page article in the March 5 New York Times described one example: an allegation that the recovery of the 1980's -- and hence the conservative philosophy of the Bush Administration -- helped the rich and hurt the poor.
This analysis, a reprise of the so-called fairness argument, rests on a Congressional Budget Office study and an analysis by a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist, Paul Krugman. The C.B.O. and Mr. Krugman have played prominent roles in shaping the liberal version of the fairness debate, and their allegations have become a staple in the speeches of Democratic politicians. But the analysis suffers from grievous flaws. I will cite just a few. 
 First, the claim that the top 1 percent of taxpayers raked in 60 percent of the benefits of the Reagan-Bush boom rests on a statistical sleight of hand. The C.B.O.-Krugman analysis masks the progress of the Reagan-Bush expansion by throwing in data from the Carter era, when the poor got poorer and the rich got poorer. During the Reagan-Bush boom, by contrast, the rich paid more in taxes and the poor made more in income. Minorities enjoyed a greater leap in wealth, employment and mobility than whites. The middle class shrank because more people became "rich." That's the Reagan-Bush record.
Second, the analysis gives the impression that American society consists of stationary social classes -- a sort of human layer cake in which a haughty, unchanging upper class rests atop an oppressed, unchanging underclass. That is pure fiction: Our greatness as a nation arises from the fact that people rise and fall on the strength of their abilities. Many children of the rich fall below the national average income level in their lifetimes, and many poor children rise to riches.
Third, the C.B.O. study creates the impression of an increasingly divided America by overstating the "wealth" of the top 1 percent and understating the wealth of everyone else. It lumps retirees who have sold their homes into the ranks of tycoons. It overlooks the incredible increase in the values of investments in the Reagan-Bush years. At the same time, the study understates middle-class wealth by overlooking the value of unsold assets like homes, stocks and pension funds. If you count everybody's capital gains, you find that the poor and middle class got the vast majority of benefits of the Reagan-Bush expansion.
But the fairness story involves far more than statistics. It involves values. Many advocates of the "fairness" critique want to stoke middle-class resentment by implying that the rich take from the poor. They never seem to realize that a dynamic, entrepreneurial economy can create a bigger pie for everyone.
American workers understand how an economy works, however, and so do voters. They don't like the Robin Hood politics of class warfare, and never have. When societies exalt the corrosive instinct of envy they condemn themselves to a poverty of goods and spirit. Moses delivered a commandment that began: "Thou shalt not covet." He and his wanderers understood that an economy runs not just on profits, but on values.
The "fairness" argument ignores the way the market works. It twists the meaning to advocate a Government powerful enough to transfer money from rich to poor. But no one equates fairness with a Government that grows and raises taxes, regardless of its performance, or that transfers money from the rich and middle class into programs that lure the poor into permanent dependency.
Most Americans think about fairness in practical terms. You work hard, and you keep what you earn: That's fair. If you save and invest and take risks, and produce something that fulfills the needs of others, you make a profit. That's fair.
The politics of redistribution are as dead as Leninism. Today, people in former Communist lands beg for copies of the Federalist Papers and "The Wealth of Nations" -- not for "The Greening of America." They don't seek a sleeker socialism. They seek something like what President Bush calls the Good Society -- one built on hard work, decency, thrift, service, family -- one that places the individual before government.
The C.B.O.-Krugman assault on the Reagan-Bush recovery avoids all these factual and moral subtleties, and muddles a debate that matters to most of us. That's a shame because the fairness debate will shape our destiny. As we take on the tangled issues that arise from it, we will need all the facts and all the real fairness we can get.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

HEADLINE: Genetic Engineering Needs Strict Regulation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Bush to Ease Rules on Products Made by Altering Genes" (front page, Feb. 25) and "From Monsters to Mainstream" (editorial, March 1) both emphasize the economic benefits of the Administration's new biotechnology policy.
The National Audubon Society remains concerned about the environmental risks posed by genetically engineered organisms, such as plants, fish and microbes. We are not afraid of monsters, but Vice President Quayle and the Competitiveness Council are. Their monster is regulations designed to protect the environment. Undoubtedly, Competitiveness Council members will sleep better at night under their new policy. 
 This policy will not guide regulatory agencies; it will paralyze them. The first problem is the definition of biotechnology. According to the council, everything is biotechnology, and everything poses equal risk, including plants and animals produced by normal sexual reproduction. Basically, Federal agencies must regulate everything, or nothing.
Another problem with the new policy is that it prevents the regulatory agencies from doing anything until unreasonable risk is proved. Who would provide the proof? We cannot wait for industry to step forward. Government agencies must evaluate risks and make regulatory decisions.
The final problem is the unreasonable risk standard. This requires the value of environmental protection to be greater than the economic cost of regulation. An industry booster can add up dollars and jobs, while nobody can easily evaluate environmental quality in the same terms. This standard is a prescription for continued environmental degradation.
Consider the entrepreneur Leopold Trouvelot, who imported a few gypsy moth eggs from Europe in the late 1860's to raise in his home near Boston. His intent was to establish an American silk industry. His silk industry did not survive, but the moth did: somehow eggs, caterpillars or moths escaped from his house. Every spring, gypsy moth caterpillars now defoliate millions of acres of trees in Northeast and mid-Atlantic states.
If Trouvelot were alive today, he would dismiss our environmental concerns with the blessing of the Competitiveness Council. He would talk about the jobs his silk industry would create. He would point out the benefits to commerce resulting from a multimillion-dollar silk industry. He would boldly assert that his silk industry would enhance American competitiveness. Given all this, he would conclude, how could we worry about a little caterpillar?
For a 1992 example, consider genetically engineered fish. Scientists hope fish that contain new growth hormones will grow bigger and faster than normal fish. Other scientists are developing fish that could be introduced into cold, northern waters, where they cannot now survive. The intention is to boost fish production for food. The economic benefits may be obvious, but not the risks. Does this make the risks reasonable?
Our critics will argue that gypsy moths are different from genetically engineered fish. That is not the point. The point is it is easy to speculate about economic benefits of a new technology. But speculation is not fact. Sadly, the Competitiveness Council prefers to believe economic speculation and ignore the environment.
 
EDWARD BRUGGEMANN
Staff Scientist
National Audubon Society
Washington, March 2, 1992

HEADLINE: Right Time to Invest In Eastern Europe

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Articles like "Eastern Europe Foils All but the Hardiest of Western Investors" (front page, March 5) may discourage American business investment in Eastern Europe, which would be a big mistake. In the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic, for example, as of last July, investment by American companies made up only 10 percent of foreign investment.
With such low levels of investment, United States companies are losing out on what is sure to be one of the next economic miracles of this era. Remember, in the period before World War II, Czechoslovakia was one of the most developed countries in the world. Present frustrations not withstanding, the Czech and Slovak federation may be ready to take off economically as Germany did in 1950. 
 The United States Government recognizes the exciting and important opportunity presented, and is providing technical assistance and other foreign aid to Eastern Europe.
One of the most exciting programs is the one I work for, the Czech and Slovak American Enterprise Fund, a privately managed investment fund with an Agency for International Development grant (there are similar programs for Poland, Hungary and Bulgaria). We are committed to investing in viable small and medium-size businesses in the Czech and Slovak federation, with an emphasis on joint ventures with United States companies.
 
RICHARD DINE
Silver Spring, Md., March 11, 1992

HEADLINE: Why New York State's Independent Colleges Also Deserve Aid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that 250 professors and students at the City University of New York have sued the state, "contending that the way it finances public higher education is racially discriminatory" (news article, Feb. 27). While I take no position on the merits of the legal challenge, I believe you leave out a critical part of the story: the contribution of independent colleges and universities.
No matter whose statistics we accept, it is clear that New York State subsidizes each student in four-year, public colleges somewhere between $8,650 and $9,700 a year (these figures do not fully include capital expenditures). By contrast, direct state subsidies to the 398,000 students enrolled in independent colleges amount to only $1,025 a year per student. 
 Independent colleges produce fully 47 percent of all baccalaureate degrees awarded to African-American and Latino students in the state, more than either CUNY or the State University system. At the graduate level, 61 percent of all degrees awarded to African-Americans and Latinos come from independent institutions.
Yet direct state aid to independent institutions lost 25 percent to inflation between 1985 and 1990, while state aid to public institutions increased 30 percent in the same period. Since 1990, at Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's urging, direct state aid to independent institutions has been reduced three times, a total of 37 percent. All told, since 1985 the purchasing power of this aid has been cut by nearly half.
The 1992-93 executive budget recommendations contain a cut of 50 percent in direct aid. These reductions would greatly impair the capacity of independent colleges to serve poor students, including African-Americans and Latinos.
The state's policy of disinvestment in independent higher education over the last seven years ignores the cost-effectiveness of these institutions, as well as the long-range economic benefits deriving from the students they train.
 
JONATHAN F. FANTON
President, New School for Social Research
New York, March 3, 1992

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: TELEVISION;
New MSG President

 BODY:
DOUG MOSS has been named president of the Madison Square Garden Network, an appointment anticipated since December when his predecessor, BOB GUTKOWSKI, was elevated to the presidency of Madison Square Garden. Moss, who is 38 years old, had been the MSG Network's senior vice president of advertising sales since 1990.
In Gutkowski's six years at MSG, its subscription rolls swelled from 1.7 million to 4.6 million households, a performance achieved mainly through the acquisition of the rights to Yankees games. 
 Repeating that phenomenal growth will be virtually impossible, but Moss said: "That was such an evolutionary period for us. Now I have to maintain that standard of excellence and look at the business every day and do the best you can."
Despite the recession, he said advertising sales for New York Rangers and New York Knicks games have hit a network record, and early sales for Yankees games exceed last year's slow pace. Said Moss: "We've been very fortunate. The marketplace has improved a bit and the splash the Yankees made by getting Tartabull and hiring Buck Showalter has helped."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primary;
DEMOCRATS REBUFF CLINTON IN THE CONNECTICUT PRIMARY AS BROWN WINS A CLOSE VOTE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Democratic primary voters in Connecticut served notice yesterday that they were less than overwhelmed by their party's new front-runner, Gov. Bill Clinton, handing him an embarrassing second-place finish to former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
The voting was a jarring message for a man who was widely predicted to be on a clear path to the nomination after former Senator Paul E. Tsongas left the race last week. It heightens the importance of New York's primary on April 7, and it signals that Mr. Clinton still has considerable work to do to build and consolidate his support among Democratic primary voters. 
 It was also one more sign of the unpredictable mood of the voters in this season of economic anxiety and deep discontent with politics and politicians.
 
Outpouring of Anger?
 Mr. Brown, whose anti-establishment campaign has proved far more dangerous to Mr. Clinton than many had expected, asserted that the day's voting was an outpouring of anger at the powers that be. "It's not about me," he said, campaigning in New York. "It's about a process that hasn't been working."
Mr. Clinton told a rally last night that the outcome in Connecticut was a "small setback" but that he had only begun to fight. "Nobody's going to take this election for granted. We're going to work hard and we're going to win it," the Arkansas Governor declared. "I've always been told New Yorkers like a good fight."
With all of the vote counted, Mr. Brown had 37 percent, Mr. Clinton 36 percent and Mr. Tsongas 20 percent.
 
The Tsongas Effect
 Clinton campaign officials asserted that the Connecticut vote reflected lingering affection for Mr. Tsongas as well as a historical pattern in which voters have sought to slow a front-runner who was considered a presumed nominee.
"It's a long process, and I think people voted to keep the process going, to keep it open, and learn more about the candidates," said David Wilhelm, the Clinton campaign manager. "And that's all right."
On the Republican side, with 99 percent of the vote counted, President Bush had 67 percent to 22 percent for Patrick J. Buchanan, his conservative challenger. Nine percent of the voters backed an uncommitted slate of delegates and 2 percent supported David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klansman from Louisiana.
But it was Connecticut's Democrats who were heard most clearly. Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said last night that Mr. Clinton, who has a huge edge in delegates, continued to gain ground, and he argued, "I've never known a nominee who wins everywhere, every day."
For all the efforts at philosophy, the Connecticut primary set the stage for a new period of testing for Mr. Clinton. "You've got to be careful trying to translate Connecticut into New York," said John Marino, the chairman of the Democratic Party in New York. "But it's going to make New York as interesting as it's been in the past two cycles and as important as it's been in the past two cycles."
Other party leaders said the shock from Connecticut could turn out to be healthy for Mr. Clinton, saving him from the complacency that many Democrats saw in the campaign of Michael S. Dukakis after he wrapped up the Democratic nomination in the spring of 1988.
Phil Angelides, the chairman of the California Democratic Party, said, "Does it change the big picture? No. But it probably administers a shock that in the long term will have proven to be not unhealthy. This is a great reminder of how tough the road to November is going to be."
 
A Boon for Brown
 Surveys of voters leaving the polling places showed that Mr. Brown was the clear beneficiary of Mr. Tsongas's withdrawal last Thursday, just five days before a primary that he had long been expected to win. Four in 10 voters said they would have voted for the former Senator from Massachusetts if he had remained in the race. Moreover, 4 in 10 of those who ended up backing Mr. Brown said Mr. Tsongas was their first choice.
Just as telling, Mr. Brown was the favorite of those who said they made up their minds how to vote in the last four days. About a quarter of the registered Democrats voted in yesterday's primary, proof that the worries in the Clinton camp about a low turnout were well founded.
Some voters went to the polls and simply pretended that last Thursday's announcement never happened: the Tsongas faction in Connecticut refused to die. Saying they hoped ultimately to draft Mr. Tsongas as the Democratic nominee, local organizers said they mounted a considerable effort to remind voters that Mr. Tsongas was still on the ballot and thus still an option.
And Clinton aides asserted that the remaining sentiment for Mr. Tsongas had a major influence on yesterday's results.
In a statement, Mr. Tsongas said the results in Connecticut showed that "the voters believe that we need an economic policy that works." He added, "I am gratified that the message continues to have the power to move people."
Still, his campaign manager, Dennis Kanin, said Mr. Tsongas was not encouraging the draft movement. "He has suspended his campaign," Mr. Kanin said.
 
Ignoring the Trend
 The troubles for Mr. Clinton are in keeping with a history of the voters making life difficult for Democratic front-runners. In 1976, Mr. Brown made a late entrance in the campaign against Jimmy Carter and won contests in California, Maryland and Nevada. Connecticut, moreover, has resisted the trend before. In 1980 its voters backed Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and in 1984, Gary Hart.
Still, Republicans were gloating last night. "What it says is there's a lot of ground to cover before the Democratic convention," said Torie Clarke, press secretary for the Bush campaign.
Mr. Clinton entered this phase of the campaign with a seven-to-one edge in national convention delegates, and under the party's strict rules of proportional representation, Mr. Brown will be hard put to overtake him.
In Connecticut, Mr. Brown and Mr. Clinton each won 21 of the 53 delegates at stake and Mr. Tsongas gained 11.
A tally compiled by The New York Times now shows Mr. Clinton with 1,012 delegates, nearly half of the 2,145 needed to win the nomination. Mr. Tsongas has 434 delegates, Mr. Brown has 164 and 566 delegates are either backing other candidates or uncommitted. The tally includes the preferences of "super delegates," who are members of Congress, Democratic National Committee members, governors or former elected officials.
Mr. Bush won all 35 of the Republican delegates at stake, bringing his total to 764, roughly two-thirds of the 1,105 he needs to win the nomination.
The significance of the Connecticut voting for the Democrats was not so much in the delegates to be won, but in the psychological impact on both campaigns and the party.
Mr. Clinton has primaries and caucuses in 20 states ahead against a candidate who has made a series of personal attacks. Mr. Clinton is expected to keep up his own assault on Mr. Brown, centering on his support for a flat income tax and his shifting positions over the years.
Last night, Mr. Clinton declared, "Mr. Brown's major proposal -- Jerry's tax -- declares war on New York, war on the middle class, war on the poor."
 
Bush's 'Tough Call'
 The Bush campaign, meanwhile, had a few worries of its own in yesterday's voting.
Ms. Clarke, from the Bush campaign organization, said the President's allies felt "pretty good, given the fact that Connecticut was hit hard by the recession, and given the fact that the President recently had to announce some tough spending cuts for the state."
Mr. Bush himself thanked Connecticut's voters tonight, saying it showed they understood that a President sometimes has to make "tough calls," as he did on canceling the Seawolf submarine.
Still, there were warning signals for the general election. In the survey, Mr. Bush got about half of the Republican primary voters who considered themselves liberal; a fifth of those voted uncommitted and a quarter voted for Mr. Buchanan. This suggests that Mr. Bush's continued efforts to protect his right flank, in the midst of a primary challenge from Mr. Buchanan, may have cost him.
Almost two-fifths of the Republican primary voters said they disapproved of Mr. Bush's performance in office. More than 8 in 10 said they considered the national economy to be "not so good" or in "poor" condition.

HEADLINE: In Every Category, Crime Reports Fell Last Year in New York City

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
Reported crime in New York City fell modestly last year in every major category, the Police Department said yesterday. It was the first such across-the-board decline in 36 years.
The total number of crimes reported to the police, based on the crime figures provided to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, dropped for a third year in a row from 710,221 in 1990 to 678,855 in 1991, a decrease of 4.4 percent. Total crimes fell three-tenths of 1 percent in 1990 and eight-tenths of 1 percent in 1989. Decreases in total felonies were registered in 54 of 75 precincts, while there was no change in 2 precincts.
 
A Number of Factors
 The rise and fall of crime is a result of a number of factors not readily discernible, including reported versus actual crime, shifts in demographics and personal habits, and police strength, visibility and strategy. 
 Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said he felt that the increases could be attributed to an increased police presence in the streets and the taking hold of his community policing strategy. Outside the department, some criminologists adhered to that view, while others questioned whether the statistics were accurate reflections of crime.
Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, an independent agency monitoring crime, said it was difficult to assign a specific cause for the decrease. "Can we link changes in police strength and operational methods to a decline in crime? I think they should not be dismissed as explanatory factors."
Homicide, which surged 17.8 percent from 1989 to 1990, dropped 4.1 percent in 1991, from 2,245 in 1990, when the deaths of 87 people in the Happy Land Social Club fire in the Bronx pushed the total to a record number, to 2,154. If the Happy Land deaths were eliminated, homicide figures between 1990 and 1991 would be about even and the decrease statistically insignificant. Robberies, considered a barometer of violent street crime, fell 1.8 percent; aggravated assault dropped 3 percent, and rape declined 7.5 percent. Burglaries fell 6.6 percent, larceny theft 4.5 percent and motor vehicle theft 4.9 percent.
The figures run counter to a national trend. While other cities with a population of one million or more are showing half the percentage decrease in total crimes compared with New York, they are showing a 4 percent increase in violent crime. In major categories of murder and robbery, a number of major cities are showing double-digit percentage increases.
Mayor David N. Dinkins was briefed on the crime figures yesterday morning shortly before Mr. Brown testified before a joint council committee hearing on the "Safe Streets/Safe City" program, which was created several years ago to add more police officers to the streets after a crime wave resulted in intense pressure on City Hall to act.
Mr. Dinkins's spokesman, Leland T. Jones, said yesterday that "Safe Streets" was beginning to pay off in lower crime figures. "I think he was cautiously pleased, pleased that the numbers were down but cautious in knowing there was a lot more work to be done and we have to move forward with the staffing increases and redeployments called for in his 'Safe Streets/Safe City' program to make sure the downward trend continues."
In New York, 1991 was a year in which it was not uncommon for two parties in a dispute, often over drugs, to spray a street with bullets, wounding and killing bystanders; or for teen-agers to carry guns into schools as casually as they would pens, as was the case in late November when a student shot and killed another and wounded a teacher at Thomas Jefferson High School. Two other students were killed in a separate shooting there this year.
 
Handguns and Homicides
 Deputy Chief Michael A. Markman, commanding officer of the Office of Management Analysis and Planning, which prepared the report, said that 73 percent of homicides last year involved the use of handguns, compared with 69 percent in 1990, 56 percent in 1980, 48 percent in 1970 and 19 percent in 1960.
He said that 15- to 19-year-olds were more likely to be arrested for murder than members of any other age group. Twenty-nine bystanders were killed, compared with 22 in 1990.
Mr. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, whom Mr. Brown credited with tracking the across-the-board-decline to 1955, said that "while crime remained unacceptably high, clearly the indicator arrows are pointing the right way: downward."
Commissioner Brown said, "As we began implementation of the Mayor's 'Safe Streets Safe City' program, we placed a special emphasis on increased visibility at the precinct level. For example, the number of uniformed personnel assigned to patrol in the police precincts of the five boroughs has increased by 22 percent over 1990. Where we had only 786 beat officers in August 1990, we now have over 3,000 beat officers, an increase of 290 percent."
While some have speculated that an aging or shrinking population might lead to a decrease in crime, Mr. Repetto and others dismissed demographic change and other large social factors as an explanation for the drop in New York City.
"It can't do it in a year," Mr. Repetto said. "Changes in population, changes in reporting crime, great social and economic changes, those don't happen in a year." According to the Census Bureau, the population of New York City increased during the 1980's, and many claim that the true population is underreported.
But Dr. Lawrence W. Sherman, a criminology professor at the University of Maryland and president of the Crime Control Institute, a national, nonprofit research organization, saw the figures as inconclusive, saying that, statistically speaking, this year's decline "could be a down-blip followed by an up-blip next year."
Small percentage changes, as in the aggravated assault and robbery categories, could be meaningless statistical fluctuations, Dr. Sherman said. He added that if the 87 deaths in the Happy Land Social Club fire were subtracted from that year's record-breaking murder figure of 2,245, the number of murders in 1991 would have decreased by 4.
The decrease in New York appears significant when compared with statistics in other cities.
According to F.B.I. figures for the first six months of 1991, the key barometers of homicide and robberies were up 2 percent, and 6 percent for cities.
The increase in homicide in San Antonio was 60 percent, in San Jose 58.3 percent, in Dallas 30.2 percent and in San Diego 19.7 percent. Robbery rose in San Jose by 33.5 percent, in San Antonio by 31.8 percent, in San Diego by 30.9 percent and in Chicago by 30 percent.

HEADLINE: Births Beyond Hospitals Fill an Urban Need

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
Shortly after midnight on a recent Sunday, in one of New York City's poorest neighborhoods, 20-year-old Yesenia Rice gave birth in a clinic several miles from the nearest hospital.
Her mother-in-law and aunt sat behind her on the thick double bed, one advising her to "yell and scream" and the other urging her to "breathe, breathe, breathe." Her mother stood behind the bathroom door, glad to be near her daughter but unable to watch the unmedicated pain. 
 When the boy was finally born, after 33 hours of labor, the midwife cradled him briefly while his father, Kyle Rice, cut the umbilical cord. Then the midwife placed the glistening infant on his mother's belly. Fewer than eight hours later, far sooner than a hospital would have allowed, Ms. Rice was home with her husband and son in their apartment in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx.
The birth of Stefen Marc Rice at the Childbearing Center of Morris Heights last month is part of the search for cheaper and better health care for poor urban women.
The solution, many health-care experts say, may be centers where prenatal care, labor, delivery and follow-up care are all given outside the hospital. The centers serve women with no health problems and no reason to believe they will have a complicated pregnancy, and hospitals are used as backup if complications occur.
The experiment is based on two encouraging facts, one economic, one medical. Births outside of a hospital cost about $3,300 in the New York area, 60 percent less than traditional hospital care. This is largely a result of the lower salaries paid to midwives and the fact that there is no hospital stay.
In addition, at least one study, reported in The New England Journal of Medicine four years ago, found that birthing centers have half the newborn mortality rate of hospitals. Center administrators say this is because the centers are smaller than hospitals and can provide more personalized care.
Still unanswered, however, is a question of culture: Can these centers be made attractive to women who have come to shun what they see as old-fashioned ways and who believe that expensive, modern technology is better?
"They're in the United States now," said Jennifer Dohrn, director of the center in Morris Heights, an area where many families come from countries where midwives and home births were the norm. "They want access to the hospitals and the machines. It's an extra challenge to explain what we're all about. When it works, it's spectacular."
Although there are a handful of similar centers serving migrant women in rural Texas, the four-year-old Morris Heights center was the first in the country intended for a poor urban neighborhood.
The center was established by the Maternity Center Association, which also runs a center on the Upper East Side. Its success, in turn, has led to the creation of a center in the East New York area of Brooklyn, near Kings County Hospital, scheduled to open this fall. If that works, the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which will run the East New York clinic and which runs the city's 11 municipal hospitals, has expressed interest in opening other centers citywide.
 
Relaxing Before Birth
 The history of the centers began less than 20 years ago in response to the demands of middle-class women who viewed childbirth as a natural experience, not an illness, and who wanted more control over how and where they gave birth.
Many obstetricians were, and still are, critical of the decision to give birth outside a hospital, citing the small but existing risk of complications needing immediate, high-tech care. But most states now license birthing centers and 135 such centers have opened in the United States since 1975. Until the Morris Heights center opened, almost all were in middle- and upper-middle-class areas.
At these centers, birth occurs in bedroom-like rooms, without medication, monitors or doctors. Women can use the Jacuzzi to help them relax or the kitchen if they feel hungry. Family and friends gather around to coach and watch. Often children are invited. After the birth, new mothers rest for no more than 12 hours and then go home.
"At the hospital they would have attached me to a monitor and not let me move around," said Ms. Rice, who spent much of her labor circling a large flower pot in the center's waiting area, oblivious to the sympathetic stares of other patients.
"There would have been drugs and they would have taken the baby away to the nursery," she said, as her son slept by her side. "This way is more natural."
 
Attracted by Convenience
 So far, 410 babies have been born at the Morris Heights center. The Bronx Lebanon Hospital provides backup services, and the center accepts both Medicaid and private insurance.
Midwives in Morris Heights say that the prenatal care they offer is what attracts women in this poor, violent, medically underserved neighborhood. At a recent orientation session for prospective patients, for instance, only two of the seven women who attended were attracted to the center's philosophy. Others said they came because "I just live right up the block" or "My friend came here and said it was nice."
Out in the waiting room, 21-year-old Eva Licona, who is seven months pregnant, sat with her 9-month-old son and 3-year-old daughter, both of whom were born in area hospitals.
 
'Better Than the Hospital'
 She had planned to have this child at Union Hospital in the Bronx but had to cancel a prenatal check-up because her son was sick. When she tried to reschedule, she said, she was told the next available opening was three months later.
Her mother passed the Morris Heights center every day and suggested that her daughter find out what it was. Her first appointment was the following week. "This is better than the hospital," she said. "It's right around the corner and I don't have to take the bus or the train with these kids."
Aware that their approach may be surprising to some patients, Ms. Dohrn and the three staff midwives try to make the center a reassuring place. Other centers, which often feature a decor of chintz and antiques, have found that they intimidated many poor women who assumed they were not welcome.
The Morris Heights center is bright and cheerful, with a children's play area and bold African prints on the walls. The bulletin boards hold schedules of support groups that have developed over the years -- for single mothers, for breast-feeding mothers, for teen-age mothers.
The fact that this is a different kind of clinic is apparent from the first appointment when women are taught to weigh themselves, test their urine for sugar and protein, then enter the results on their charts. Women accepted into the center record these numbers at every visit, as a way of keeping them aware of the changes in their body.
 
Invitation to a Birth
 Women embrace the center's philosophy to varying degrees. Most are attracted to the policy that allows a woman to invite as many relatives and friends to the birth as can reasonably fit into the room. Sometimes, that involves a lot of people. One patient, active in her church, invited the gospel choir to sing in celebration while she gave birth. They stayed in the waiting room and sang loudly.
More usual is the presence of children. When 27-year-old Shari Anderson gave birth to her son, Glenn Jr., early this month, her 10-year-old daughter, Shaniqua, was there to watch. When the worst of the pain began, Ms. Anderson worried that she had been wrong to bring Shaniqua and tried to coax the girl into waiting outside with an older cousin. The child would not leave.
"I'm glad she stayed," Mrs. Anderson said, a week after the birth. "She's proud of him. She's telling her friends 'I seen my brother be born.' "
Also popular among patients is the center's policy of sending women home between 5 and 12 hours after they give birth. They are visited at home the following day by a nurse from the center who checks both mother and baby. That schedule is sharply different from most hospitals, which require a two or three day stay and do not arrange home visits.
The concept the center backs that meets the most resistance from new mothers is breast-feeding. Most of the women will not try it, the midwives say. There are posters on the walls advocating the practice and several women who have breast-fed have been trained by the staff to counsel others. But the number of interested women is not high. Lack of time, fear of difficulty and mistrust of anything but modern formula are the reasons most often given.
"I think this place is great but I won't do the breast-feeding," said Ms. Rice, who said she was not willing to change her fast-food diet to provide nutrients for her son.
Looking down at the baby, who was sucking hungrily on a bottle of formula, she said, "I love him to death but I won't put a piece of broccoli in my mouth."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Car Sales Fell in Mid-March; Trucks Rose

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 24

 BODY:
Sales of North American-built vehicles fell 2.7 percent in mid-March, as auto makers continued to feel the decline in fleet sales of cars to rental companies. Light-truck sales were higher.
Sales of cars fell 6.9 percent in the period to 167,708, from 180,195 a year earlier, while sales of light trucks rose 4.7 percent. Total vehicle sales fell to 276,889, from 284,482 in the comparable period of last year. 
 In the absence of other economic news, some traders on Wall Street cited the decline in vehicle sales as one reason for an 11.18-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of domestic car sales was 5.8 million for the March 11-20 period. That compared with 6.0 million in early March and 6.2 million a year earlier. The number of selling days was the same in each period.
Although sales were sluggish, dealers seemed optimistic, based on the number of prospective customers visiting their showrooms. "Showroom traffic has increased," said David Cooksey, general manager of Jerry's Chevrolet in Weatherford, Tex. But he said customers were having difficulties qualifying for loans.
Stan Ennis, general sales manager of Saccucci Lincoln Mercury Honda, in Middletown, R.I., said: "Lending requirements are tougher than they've ever been. And some people, because of the difficulties in the economy, are having things -- maybe a late payment on a credit card -- show up on their report."
The General Motors Corporation posted a 6.1 percent drop in car sales, to 77,954, and the Ford Motor Company's car sales fell 5.4 percent, to 46,573. A trade publication, Ward's Automotive Reports, estimated that the Chrysler Corporation's car sales dropped 26.4 percent, to 14,350. Chrysler reports sales once a month.
Ford said its sales of cars to retail customers rose 10 percent, while sales to daily-rental fleets were down an amount the company declined to specify. This year, Ford increased to six months, from four, the period that rental fleets must keep cars before selling them back to Ford.
Wendy Needham, automotive analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham in New York, said, "Clearly, fleet sales are giving way to retail sales, and that's going to help profitability."
 
 
Truck Sales Rise First
 G.M.'s light-truck sales were off 12.6 percent, to 38,305. Ford sold 13.6 percent more light trucks, at 38,389. Ward's estimated Chrysler's light-truck sales at 26,850, a 22.6 percent increase from a year earlier.
Some dealers took heart from the fact that over all, light-truck sales have been stronger than a year ago. Truck sales typically jump during the first stage of an economic recovery, followed by an increase for cars. Mr. Cooksey, the manager of the Chevrolet dealership, said, "We're selling new Chevy Suburbans as fast as we can." The Suburban is a large station wagon-style utility vehicle on a light-truck chassis.
 
'A Disappointment'
 Of the Japanese companies that build domestic cars -- which are considered for reporting purposes those built in the United States, Canada and Mexico -- the Honda Motor Company suffered a 3.5 percent decline in car sales, to 10,814, and the Nissan Motor Corporation posted a 38.8 percent drop, to 2,289. But the Toyota Motor Corporation reported a robust 38.8 percent increase in car sales, to 10,421. Sales were up 44.4 percent for Toyota's redesigned Camry model, built in Georgetown, Ky.
 Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said: "Except for Toyota, these numbers are a disappointment. They are not a real setback, but a clear indication that the recovery is having a hard time getting out of first gear."
The Big Three continued to lose their share of the domestic car market to Japanese companies. G.M., Ford and Chrysler together captured 82.8 percent of domestic car sales, down from 84.2 percent a year earlier. Japanese makers captured a 17.2 share, up from 15.8 percent.
The Big Three consolidated their overwhelming lead in the light-truck market. G.M., Ford and Chrysler sold 95.7 percent of all North American-made light trucks, up from 95.5 percent. The Japanese share was 4.3 percent, down from 4.5 percent.
