HEADLINE: At East-West Crossroads, Western Europe Hesitates

SERIES: After the Cold War -- First article in a series: Western European Views

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 24

 BODY:
While the Berlin wall was still standing, Western Europe enjoyed a pretty good deal: It bowed to American leadership on East-West security issues and quietly got on with turning the European Community into a world economic power that had minimal international political obligations.
In theory, the region lived under constant threat from the East, but by the mid-1980's few Western Europeans believed that a Soviet attack was possible. They felt secure because the future seemed predictable: Washington would control Moscow, Europe would remain divided and they both would flourish. 
 But with the end of the cold war, Western European governments have been suddenly confronted with the unknown, and anxiety is setting in. Not only can they no longer ignore the problems to the East, but their established relationships and carefully drafted plans have also been thrown into question.
 
Uncertainty Eastward
 "In the past, we lived between the Atlantic and the wall," said Simone Veil, a French member of the European Parliament. "We would shed a tear for the misery of those in the East, but the situation was frozen. Now we have uncertainty and we don't know where we're going."
Western Europe's immediate goal is self-evident: to deal with the new threats -- less extreme but more immediate -- posed by the post-Communist East without sacrificing its own economic prosperity and political harmony. But as it sets out to build the new Europe, it feels besieged.
Looking at the East, Western Europe knows that chaos in the former Soviet bloc will bring a flood of immigrants and refugees. It worries that Yugoslav-style civil wars could be repeated elsewhere. It is scrambling to avert a new Chernobyl disaster in antiquated Soviet-made nuclear reactors. It fears dispersal of the nuclear arsenal once controlled by Moscow. And it wonders if it has the time and money necessary to bring free-market democracies to the East.
 
Uncertainty Westward
 Looking at the West has hardly proved reassuring. Paris and London are nervous about Germany's new power, Bonn has been stunned by the cost of developing eastern Germany and economic growth is slowing throughout the region. The European Community also seems unsure of its next step, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has lost its traditional role and Western Europe's relations with Washington are strained by new trade disputes.
In both halves of Europe, the shadow of the 19th century has also reappeared.
"We knew the transition would be difficult," said Simon Lunn, an official at the North Atlantic Assembly, a parliamentary body linked to NATO. "What we didn't see was that as soon as Communism disappeared, old resentments would bubble up and create potential problems throughout the area."
Above all, the rise of a united Germany is stirring long-dormant fears of German might, albeit of its economic and political influence rather than of its military ambitions.
 
Xenophobia Resurgent
 The surge of ethnic disputes across Eastern Europe is also awakening grim memories of the past.
Further, this coincides with rising xenophobia in the West. In practice, France, Italy and Spain are more worried about immigration from North Africa, but Germany already feels swamped by new arrivals from Poland, Russia, Ukraine, Yugoslavia and Romania, and the German public is demanding tighter border controls.
"Suddenly the West is confronted by its own past rhetoric when it complained, 'How evil the Communists are for not letting their people go,' " a senior European Community official said. "Easterners would hear the community boasting about its virtues so that's where they want to be -- either through membership or immigration."
Even Berlin, a proud symbol of liberty throughout the cold war, now feels battered as the problems of the poor East spill into the rich West. The wall itself has now largely disappeared, replaced by what the German writer Gunter Grass has called a "social abyss." Yet a good many West Berliners think life would be a lot easier if the wall were still in place.
"There's a sort of unexpressed feeling that we'd be better off if we could ignore Eastern Europe's problems," former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said.
 
Balance of Power
When Bonn Speaks, Everyone Listens
 The search for a new role for the former Soviet bloc might seem almost simple were it not accompanied by a fundamental change in the balance of power in Western Europe, brought on by the uniting of Germany and the reduction of the American military presence.
But the end of the cold war has disrupted relationships that assured stability in Western Europe for more than 40 years. And as the United States pulls back from Europe to address its domestic problems, France and Britain have had to adjust to Germany's growing domination of the region.
"You feel it in daily events," a Western European ambassador said, insisting that he not be identified. "New weight is given to German views. The way Germany views things is formative in how decisions are taken. I'm not saying this with hostility. It's a fact of life and we have to adjust to it."
Last December, the European Community did just that, bending to strong German pressure and agreeing to recognize the former Yugoslav republics of Slovenia and Croatia even though several governments were not eager to do so. A few days later, in another example of muscle-flexing, Germany raised bank interest rates without consulting its European partners.
 
'Myth of French Grandeur'
 France is finding it specially painful to accept Germany's new profile. For 35 years, France enjoyed political leadership of the community, thanks to its alliance with Germany's economic power, but theirs is no longer a partnership of equals.
"The myth of French grandeur is disintegrating and this is creating a deep crisis of confidence in France," a German official said.
In 1990, President Francois Mitterrand even went as far as trying to slow the pace of German unification. More recently, senior French officials have complained that Germany is working to rebuild its traditional sphere of influence in Central Europe.
France's insecurity may even have contributed to the drubbing that the governing Socialist Party suffered in regional elections last Sunday.
But Mr. Giscard d'Estaing, the former President, is more sanguine.
"It's not true that we're seeing the rebirth of German imperialism," he said in an interview. "The objective fact is that their power has grown and this brings consequences. France should now redefine its role. It must step out of its defensive posture."
 
Britain Turns East
 Britain, in contrast, traditionally gave precedence to its "special relationship" with Washington over political ties to Western Europe. It was therefore a blow to former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher when the Bush Administration anointed Germany its new "partner in leadership" in May 1989, six months before the Berlin wall came down.
But her successor, John Major, has brought Britain closer to Europe and established a good personal rapport with the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl. If the April 9 general elections bring the Labor Party leader, Neil Kinnock, to power, Britain may become still more "European."
 
Role of the U.S.
Stay on Board; We Need the Ballast
 An important variable in the balance of power is whether -- or rather how much -- the United States will disengage from Europe. Although Washington plans to cut its troops in Europe from 325,000 in 1989 to 150,000 in 1994, President Bush has pledged that the United States will remain a European power.
Most governments in Western and Eastern Europe welcome this commitment, viewing Washington's presence in NATO as an essential counterweight to Russia as well as to Germany. Yet they are also alarmed by the isolationism emerging in the United States and by Canada's recent decision to withdraw its last 1,100 soldiers in Europe.
"It's normal for the United States to pass responsibilities to Western Europe, but we're not fully ready, so there is a risk of a vacuum," noted Andre Glucksman, a French philosopher. "The risk posed by the United States is not intervention but isolation."
 
Alternatives to U.S. Power
 Two debates with potential for conflict are taking place. France, which in 1966 withdrew its forces from NATO's integrated military command, is convinced that the United States will soon pull all its troops out of Europe. And it believes Western Europe should prepare for this by establishing an independent defense capability.
Specifically, France envisions transforming a moribund nine-nation regional defense group called the Western European Union into the security arm of the European Community. It has also persuaded Germany to beef up an existing joint military brigade in the hope that in time it will form the core of a new European army.
But Germany as well as Britain and others are equally determined not to weaken NATO, which has long given Washington a voice in European affairs. Thus, to avoid provoking an American pullout, they want the European defense "pillar" to come under NATO; and to give the alliance a new role, they favor expanding its mission to include "out of area" threats in, say, the Middle East.
NATO's principal function, though, would be to maintain an American presence in Europe. "The only element of stability and predictability in this world in transition is the trans-Atlantic axis," NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, said. "If the United States disengages, I foresee a certain temptation for Western European nations to revert to past patterns of power politics."
Peter Schneider, a Berlin writer, was more specific: "If the United States leaves, Germany will be the dominant European power. No one likes the idea; many Germans don't want it. But it will happen anyway."
 
NATO and Community
Fear of Expansion: Big May Be Bad
 While Western Europe anguishes over its future, the countries of the East look for a place to belong.
As far back as 1988, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, then the Soviet President, spoke of a "common European home." President Mitterrand later called for a European confederation embracing East and West. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has imagined a "Euro-Atlantic community" stretching from Vancouver to Vladivostok.
The first attempt to design an umbrella, however, involved the Conference for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which includes the United States and Canada. It played a major role in promoting human rights and democracy in the Soviet bloc during the cold war. But so far it has not demonstrated the authority to manage urgent security and development problems, and now, with 51 members, it is probably too cumbersome.
In reality, with the collapse of the Warsaw Pact and Comecon, the Moscow-led trade bloc, the only regional groupings still exercising power are NATO, with 16 members, and the European Community, with 12. And unsurprisingly, the former Soviet-bloc countries rushed to seek their aid and protection with a view to eventual membership.
At NATO headquarters in Brussels, officials usually occupied with endlessly revising military strategies were suddenly busy receiving top-level delegations from the East, including President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia and President Lech Walesa of Poland. While not ready to take in new members, the alliance also created a North Atlantic Cooperation Council as a forum for discussing security, disarmament and political questions; the membership so far includes 19 former East-bloc republics.
For the European Community, however, the collapse of Communism has posed a more fundamental challenge. The 12 have already signed association agreements with Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary and will do so next with Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, thus acknowledging that the very character of the community is changing.
Until late 1989, the community's immediate goal was to create a regional trading bloc, which will go into effect on Jan. 1, 1993. Then, after the Berlin wall came down, looking for a way to anchor a united Germany in the West, President Mitterrand persuaded Chancellor Kohl to join him in sponsoring new moves toward greater economic and political unity.
Finally, after a year of negotiations, European leaders agreed in December at a conference in Maastricht, the Netherlands, to establish a single currency and a regional central bank by 1999 and to move toward common foreign and security policies. Indeed, only Britain objected to committing the community to a "federal goal."
But then members immediately began wondering how these goals could be achieved by a community that might number 20 to 24 nations.
"The community's federal vocation becomes less and less likely as enlargement brings more and more countries that are different culturally as well as economically," Mr. Giscard d'Estaing noted.
Further, the cost of integrating Eastern European countries has already been brought home by the richer members' commitment to develop the community's current "poor four" -- Spain, Portugal, Greece and Ireland.
Germany, for one, wants to focus its spending on Eastern Europe. "Germans are increasingly asking why they should show more solidarity with Portugal than with Poland," Alfred Grosser, a French political scientist, said. "They already feel they're paying out too much for Southern Europe. Still more dangerous, it's creating anti-community feelings in Germany."
Mr. Giscard d'Estaing commented: "In the past, there was a feeling that Germany was in debt to Western Europe so it could always be tapped for money. That's over now."
 
The Importance of Aid
Making Friends By Spending Money
 No Western European country has more reason to feel vulnerable to instability in the East than Germany.
"We're once again the front-line state," Arnulf Baring, a history professor at Berlin's Free University, argued. "It's in our interest to help Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary so they become a buffer zone against chaos in the former Soviet Union."
As a result, well over half the aid to flow from West to East in the past 28 months -- some $50 billion -- has come from Germany, some channeled through the community but most delivered directly as grants, credits and food assistance. German businesses are also investing heavily; in Czechoslovakia they provide 80 percent of all new foreign investment.
Yet while Germany is taking the lead out of self-interest, it has also appealed to the rest of the West to play a bigger role: the German economy is already strained by the cost of integrating its own eastern lands and it is alarmed to hear its community partners accuse Bonn of trying to annex Eastern Europe economically.
"The French protest to the Czechs about the level of German investment, so the Czechs say, 'Why don't you invest more?' " one German official said. "We ask the same thing. We also want France, Italy and Britain to do more. The political risks of an economic vacuum, of economic failure, are too great."
But Germany may have to get used to being "damned if it does and damned if it doesn't," a British official said.
"Germany is going to find itself in the old American position," said Mr. Grosser, the French political scientist. "If you give aid, you're imperialist; if you don't, you're selfish."
The rest of Western Europe, though, is still hesitating. And this is adding to pessimism. "If you look back 10 years from now," Mr. Worner of NATO said, "most likely we will come to the conclusion that we did not live up to the challenge of helping the East in this very critical phase."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
As a Thousand Cheer, Brown Pays Dinkins a Visit

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Edmund G. Brown Jr. brought his eclectic brand of populist oratory to New York's City Hall yesterday, courting Mayor David N. Dinkins and addressing a crowd of about 1,000 supporters and passers-by outside.
Mr. Dinkins, who plied Mr. Brown with papers pressing the cause of urban America, said that as Mayor of the host city for the Democratic National Convention, he was neutral in the contest between Mr. Brown, the former Governor of California, and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. But he said there was "always a chance" that he might yet endorse one of the contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and that he expected to meet with Mr. Clinton before the New York primary on April 7. 
 Some mayoral aides were so concerned that pictures of the two men together could be misinterpreted that they pulled Mr. Dinkins back to prevent him from wading into the cheering crowd of Brown supporters outside City Hall. Mr. Brown has been making a push to win support from minority groups.
"New York is a major battleground," Mr. Brown said as he left City Hall. "This is the place where we start turning the party around and the country around."
Today, Mr. Brown is to head to Albany for a rally at the Capitol and a meeting with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Meantime, Governor Clinton made one campaign stop yesterday, at Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Bayside, Queens. He spent the rest of the day in private meetings with labor leaders, money raisers in New Jersey and at a meeting with the editorial board of The Daily News.
 
New Electricity for Brown
 Earlier in the political season, Mr. Dinkins met with Mr. Clinton at Gracie Mansion. He also met Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, but their withdrawals from the race and the approach of the New York primary added electricity to his meeting with Mr. Brown yesterday.
To the crowd of supporters and the curious drawn by leaflets passed out in nearby subway stations, Mr. Brown continued to try to position himself as an outlet for voter dissatisfaction in both parties. "We lack a recognition and a commitment at the highest levels of this society to economic and social justice," he said, criticizing "an oligarchy of privilege ripping us off."
Asked later if he wanted the Mayor's endorsement, Mr. Brown said, "Sure." Asked if he thought it would help, he again said, "Sure."
But Mr. Brown had started the day in a meeting with two dozen labor leaders, including one Barry Feinstein, the president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, who is not so sure that association with the Mayor is a good thing these days. Mr. Feinstein, once a strong Dinkins supporter, has lately wondered aloud whether the Mayor's standing is so diminished that the union should reconsider whether to support him for re-election.
Mr. Feinstein spoke glowingly of Mr. Brown, however. "I was really very excited," he said after their meeting. "I think we've got a race here."
But George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton deputy campaign manager, said the Arkanas Governor planned to concentrate on challenging Mr. Brown's ideas, especially a plan to replace most taxes with a 13 percent flat tax on income, which the Clinton camp says could harm the poor.
"We have to bear down hard," Mr. Stephanopoulos said. "We're going to be here, which means taking Jerry Brown seriously."

HEADLINE: Plenty of Fish in Sea? Not Anymore

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GLOUCESTER, Mass.

 BODY:
Since colonial days, fishermen like Matthew Vitiello have cast their lines in Georges Bank and reaped the harvest of plentiful waters, returning to the wharf with a boat full of fish.
Now, an expanded fleet stays out twice as long to bring back half as much fish. Overfishing has seriously reduced the stocks of cod, haddock and flounder that have sustained New Englanders for centuries. 
 Under a court order, the New England Fisheries Management Council is drafting a plan to rebuild the stocks of groundfish, which live and feed along the ocean floor. The stocks of cod, haddock and flounder are at their lowest level ever. The plan being considered would limit fishermen's days at sea, increase their net-mesh size and ban newcomers to the fishery.
If the plan is approved, fishermen say, a livelihood that has been part of New England tradition will be in danger of extinction. "What are we preserving the stocks for, if you're going to put the fishermen out of business," asked Tony Verga, executive director of the Gloucester Fisheries Commission, which oversees the fleet in this fishing port.
 
Fewer Days at Sea
 Under the plan, Mr. Verga said, fishermen will have to reduce their days at sea by 10 percent every year for five years. "How are you supposed to pay your bills when your ability to make a living is cut in half?" he asked.
The council's plan would also force fishermen to throw back smaller, younger fish and would require fishermen with vessels of 61 tons or more to buy a $5,000 electronic tracking device for their boats so the National Marine Fisheries Service could regulate them. It would also restrict access to haddock fishing grounds and place a 2,500-pound limit on the amount of haddock that could be caught on each trip.
Mr. Verga suggested that the council recommendations might save the fish but that they showed little concern for the fishermen. "The fishermen are not programmed to do anything else," he said. "Fishing is something that gets in your blood. It's that freedom when you're heading toward the open sea. There was a freedom to it, and now that's being taken away from this industry."
But Peter Shelley, senior attorney at the Conservation Law Foundation, disagrees. "What we have here is a conflict between short-term economic interests and long-term economic interests," he said. "The fishermen's representatives are worried about this year's profits instead of the long-term interests of the industry."
"At this point, fishermen have to be able to make short-term sacrifices to reap the long-term benefits of rebuilding the stocks," Mr. Shelley said. "There is no way around it."
Scientists agree. "There is no way the stocks can survive at this rate," said Vaughn C. Anthony, a scientist at the Northeast Fisheries Center, the research arm of the National Marine Fisheries Service. "The fishing mortality has never been this high."
Fourteen out of the 20 groundfish stocks are being "overexploited," he said. Fishermen are landing 50 percent to 70 percent of the available stock, he said, and "that's twice as much as they should be taking."
Yet total groundfish landings dropped to 95,000 metric tons last year, from 200,000 metric tons in 1982.
While fish like cod, flounder and haddock once made up 75 percent of the groundfish stock in the waters off the coast of New England, these stocks now represent only 25 percent of the stock. "Trash fish" with little commercial value, like spiny dogfish, skate and mackerel, have replaced them.
But Mr. Anthony said fishermen could more than double their catch, if the stocks were rebuilt. Cod and flounder are expected to be restocked in five years under the plan; haddock is likely to take 10 years.
 
Economic Pressure
 But one fisherman, Matt Carter, wonders whether others like him will be able to hold on to their businesses that long. "There is going to be a lot of people falling out of this industry," said the 30-year-old captain. "People aren't going to be able to pay their bills."
Fishermen are already having problems selling their boats and getting bank loans, he said. The only thing keeping fishermen afloat are the higher prices, he noted. As consumer demand for fish has increased, fishermen have tried to keep up with demand, despite warnings that stocks were being severely reduced.
The depletion of the groundfish stock has already taken its toll on the economy. The reduction in annual landings of groundfish by 137 million pounds has cost New England $350 million and 14,000 jobs, according to a 1990 report from the Massachusetts Offshore Groundfish Task Force.
This is not the first time New England's groundfish stocks have been in danger of collapsing. In the 1970's, foreign fishing fleets harvesting the fisheries with sophisticated equipment were overwhelming United States fleets and rapidly depleting the groundfish stocks.
In 1976, Congress passed the Magnuson Fishery Management and Conservation Act, establishing a 200-mile limit off the shores of New England as an exclusive economic zone of the United States. The act also created regional fishery councils like the New England Fisheries Management Council, and charged the councils with rebuilding the depleted stocks.
 
Suit May Be Settled
 Quotas were placed on cod, haddock and flounder, but then abandoned in 1981, after fishermen pressured the council to lift them.
The Conservation Law Foundation and Massachusetts Audubon Society sued the National Marine Fisheries Service and the Department of Commerce, which oversee the council, for failing to meet their charge under the Magnuson Act. But the conservation groups agreed to settle the suit if the council would develop a plan by Sept. 1, 1992, that would reduce the number of fish harvested by 50 percent. If the council fails to develop a plan, the National Marine Fisheries Service and the Department of Commerce must develop one by Nov. 1, 1992.
Mr. Vitiello, a long-line fisherman, continues to fish for fertile ground in the waters of Georges Bank. A couple of years ago, he and three other crew members used to land 40,000 to 50,000 pounds of groundfish, like cod, cusk, haddock and halibut, after a three-day trip.
Now, it takes five or six days to land 20,000 pounds, he said. "Now that I've been able to expand I haven't been able to fill it up," he said.

HEADLINE: Rudman, Irked by the Senate, Is Retiring

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Senator Warren B. Rudman, who attacked and scorned business-as-usual in two terms in the Senate, today announced his retirement, complaining that there was no challenge left in serving in a government that was "not functioning."
While he made it plain that he included the executive branch in his general criticism, Mr. Rudman, a moderate New Hampshire Republican, said that in the last year or two partisanship and posturing had made the Senate a trying experience. 
 "Here we are, getting zero done, staying up to midnight debating amendments that everyone knows won't become law, because somebody wants to get a press release out," the 61-year-old Senator said in a telephone interview from Concord, shortly after saying he would not run again.
 
'Satisfying' Memory
 He took a leading role in the Iran-contra inquiry as the senior Republican on the special Congressional investigating committee, sharply criticizing the Reagan Administration's arms-for-hostages effort. He said today that that was a "very satisfying" memory.
"I was swimming against the tide of my own party," he said, "but the Government was very seriously out of control."
He is the fifth Senator to say he will not seek re-election in November.
Mr. Rudman was best known nationally for his co-authorship of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act of 1985, which limited growth in discretionary Federal spending. But in the Senate, he was noted for his impatience with behavior that he regarded as self-serving and trivial.
 
Lashes for North
 During the Iran-contra hearings in 1987, he lectured Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North about pursuing foreign-policy initiatives that he thought Congress would disapprove if Congress only knew about them. "I want to point out to you, Colonel North, that the Constitution starts with the words 'We the people,' " Mr. Rudman said. "This Congress represents the people."
He went on: "I guess the last thing I want to say to you, colonel, is that the American people have the constitutional right to be wrong. And what Ronald Reagan thinks or Oliver North thinks or what I think or what anybody else thinks makes not a whit."
Last fall, when Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, defended himself against a Senate Ethics Committee decision that he had improperly aided Charles H. Keating Jr., the former savings and loan executive, by saying he only did what others did, Mr. Rudman angrily took the floor to say most senators had higher standards.
"What I have heard as a statement I can only describe as arrogant, unrepentant, and a smear on this institution. Everybody does not do it," said the vice chairman of the ethics panel.
When other senators, panicky after the Clarence Thomas hearings last fall, rushed to subject the Senate to court review on sexual harassment charges, Mr. Rudman fought a losing battle in arguing that the Constitution commanded the Senate to police itself, something he said it had been doing confidentially and successfully through its Rules Committee.
"The Senate is a very special place with very special obligations, a very rich history, and, I hope, a very rich future," he said. "None of us who serve here will serve here longer than a brief blink of time. And there are some institutional values which are worth protecting."
And submitting personnel actions to review "by a judge who is appointed for life tramples any semblance of separation of powers that I have ever read or heard of."
The burgeoning Federal deficit has been an interest of his in the Senate, and Mr. Rudman held forth on the subject for some time at his news conference today in New Hampshire.
He renewed the arguments he made in the Senate on March 12 in denouncing the Democratic tax bill and President Bush's proposal, saying then:
"There can be no doubt that sustained record budget deficits, high real interest rates, and the devotion of an incerasing portion of the economy to pay interest on the skyrocketing national debt is the primary factor.
"And there can also be no doubt that the blame for this lies with the Congress and the President, with Democrats and Republicans alike, most all of whom have been unwilling to make the hard choices or to explain to the American people that there is no such thing as a free lunch."
Mr. Rudman's two most likely successors are Gov. Judd Gregg or former state Attorney General Tom Rath, a close friend of Mr. Rudman's who has indicated he will not seek the Republican nomination if Mr. Gregg runs. No obvious Democratic candidate is in place, and the seat would be very hard to wrest from the Republicans.
Grumpy, impatient with colleagues and reporters, and given to lecturing, Mr. Rudman made enemies as well as friends in the Senate. But his departure, which he had hinted at to colleagues for months, was greeted with regret from both parties.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said Mr. Rudman "never ducked a tough issue, a tough vote, or a tough fight on the Senate floor."
"You don't replace a Warren Rudman," he said. "You just thank the people of New Hampshire for giving us the honor of serving with this one-of-a-kind public servant."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said: "He has been an able and eloquent voice for the needs of New Hampshire and the nation. He reminds me of the E. F. Hutton ad. When he talks, everyone in the Senate listens, because he always has something worthwhile to say. No senator is better liked or more respected."
In the interview, Mr. Rudman said his warmest memory of the Senate was in recommending, supporting and helping win confirmation of a protege, David H. Souter, to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
He said he had no specific plans for retirement, though the former state Attorney General suggested he was more inclined to a career in business than to returning to law, even though "the offers would be stupendous."
In Concord today, he said he was leaving the Senate because "I just don't think I would enjoy it for six more years."
"I've enjoyed serving this state enormously," he said. "Great state. Great freedom. I thank the people of this state for giving me an unbelievable opportunity to serve."

BOSTON, March 24 (AP) -- Representative Brian Donnelly, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that he would not seek re-election because he wanted to spend more time with his children, ages 10 and 5. Mr. Donnelly, a 46-year-old Bostonian, has served seven terms.

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
AS the unemployment rate continues to climb, each month hundreds of thousands of Americans discover that involuntary joblessness is often more of an emotional and physical challenge than any job they have ever held.
It is not, as some may think, unfettered free time to do chores and pursue pleasures, at least not if a paycheck is needed to keep a roof over one's head and food on the table or pay tuition or insurance premiums. 
 Nor is unemployment a relief from drudgery, particularly if one's job is a source of personal identity, pride or camaraderie. Rather, many studies have shown or strongly suggested that unemployment breeds a host of personal, family and social ills, from depression and heart attacks to child abuse and criminal violence.
The hazards of unemployment are not suffered solely by the person who loses the job. Many who still have jobs labor under the stressful fear that they may be next to join the bread line. During recessions, there is often more competition between workers and less possibility of promotion. Or, because of cutbacks, employees may be stripped of needed support personnel or have to do the jobs of two people.
Wives of unemployed men face an increased risk of mental and physical health problems, and children may show physical or behavioral symptoms from rising family tension. When unemployment suddenly halts affordable health insurance, whole families often forgo important preventive health measures or ignore early signs of illness until it is too late to prevent serious consequences.
Even older workers who take early-retirement deals are vulnerable to the ill effects of suddenly having no job, especially if they have not prepared emotionally or situationally for a stay-at-home life.
But experts on the psychosocial consequences of unemployment believe that it is possible for most unemployed people and their families to defray many of the costs of joblessness and reduce the toll on health and family stability.
 
Out-of-Work Blues
 Periods of economic recession marked by high rates of unemployment and business failures and reduced per capita income have long been linked to an increase in personal and social ills. Dr. M. Harvey Brenner, a sociologist at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, has found that during and after recessions in the 1970's and 1980's there was a significant rise in deaths from heart disease, stroke, cirrhosis of the liver, suicide, traffic accidents and homicides in the general population. There were also more admissions to mental hospitals, more arrests and more cases of assault and fraud.
Even when the country emerges from a recession, the problems do not necessarily recede. Dr. Brenner maintains that those who suffer the most serious economic consequences and who do not participate in the national recovery face the most severe stresses when things get better. For others, bad habits acquired during the recession, like alcohol and drug abuse, can take their toll years later.
Dr. Richard H. Price, professor of psychology at the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research in Ann Arbor, analyzed recent studies showing that emotional disorders are most often the result of job loss, not its cause. For example, in a Michigan study, people who had lost their jobs because of mass layoffs and plant closings were three times as likely as steadily employed people to show serious symptoms of anxiety and depression.
In another study of families of auto workers who had recently lost or were expecting to lose their jobs, job loss was associated with increased household conflict, tension and stress. The unemployed workers were more likely to have fights with their spouses and to have hit, slapped or spanked their children.
Dr. Paula M. Rayman, a sociologist at Wellesley College who studied unemployed workers at a Hartford aircraft factory, found that the stress of joblessness worsened family relationships. Unemployed workers were also more likely to suffer from severe headaches, chronic nausea, stomach troubles and constant fatigue.
 
Preventing Problems
 Some people weather problems of unemployment better than others with similar life circumstances. Dr. Jacob Trachtenberg, a psychiatrist at Northwestern Institute in Fort Washington, Pa., said: "People who adjust easily to change, who can tolerate the frustrations of everyday life and who can control their impulses will have an easier time than others. Also people who have good relationships with family and friends and a strong sense of self-esteem will weather the stress of unemployment better than those people who do not."
He and other experts urge the newly unemployed to take steps immediately to head off the depression and sense of worthlessness that can both damage health and make the search for a job more difficult. Here are some helpful measures:
*Don't blame yourself for the cutbacks that left you jobless.
*Try to turn your anger and frustration about losing your job into motivation to find a new one.
*Admit to your concern about being out of work and discuss it with your family and close friends. Let the children know that they are not to blame for the sudden unhappiness at home. Sharing the burden makes it easier for everyone to bear.
*Develop a concrete plan to find a new job. Prepare a resume, read the want ads, sign up with public and private employment agencies and let as many people as you can know what kind of job you are looking for.
*If your old line of work is no longer an option or you have lost interest in it, consider a job retraining program. Analyze your skills, abilities and interests and take the opportunity of joblessness to assume a new vocational direction.
*Try to maintain as much of the structure of your old life as possible. Continue with activities you can afford that bring you satisfaction and keep you in touch with friends.
*Find positive ways to vent your negative feelings, for example through physical exercise, which can also help you maintain your physical and mental well-being.
*Take a part-time job. Or become an "entrepreneur." Working out of your home, turn a hobby or your skills into a money-making operation.
*Fill your spare time with volunteer work. It will enhance your self-esteem.
Another positive step is to join a support group of people who have lost their jobs. Participants can offer helpful survival hints and sometimes job contacts as well as make you feel you are not alone.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Major-League Hopes of Life's Minor Leaguers

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Box Socials
By W. P. Kinsella
225 pages. Ballantine Books. $20.
After delivering two fictional fast balls with "The Iowa Baseball Confederacy" and "Shoeless Joe" (the basis for the movie "Field of Dreams"), W. P. Kinsella confounds his fans by throwing a change-up in "Box Socials." His new novel is more about small-town life than big-time baseball. It's a story filled with nostalgia about a time when the game was played on real grass and was called on account of darkness. But even more, it's about the everyday hopes of what it must be like for most people to play out their lives in the minors. 
 Some of the most lasting baseball literature does, in fact, take place in the environs of the bush leagues. In "The Natural," Bernard Malamud devised a mythic bat for his star who came up from the sticks. Eliot Asinof's authentic novel, "Man on Spikes," became a metaphor for the gritty struggle of someone who couldn't quite make it to the majors. With perfect pitch, Ring Lardner's classic "You Know Me Al" letters reduced his brash busher, the bullpen's Jack Keefe, to human dimensions.
None other than Virginia Woolf praised "You Know Me Al" as vivid prose that provided insights into American society. In an introduction to the Scribner edition of his father's book, John Lardner recalled that Mrs. Woolf wrote that as the boastful Keefe "babbles out his mind on paper, there rise up friends, sweethearts, the scenery, town and country: all surround him and make him up in his completeness." Her observation happens to fit the half-literate character, Truckbox Al McClintock, and his neighbors in Mr. Kinsella's "Box Socials."
In a down-home style that resembles the humorous voice of Garrison Keillor, Mr. Kinsella begins, "This is the story of how Truckbox Al McClintock almost got a tryout with the genuine St. Louis Cardinals of the National Baseball League, but instead ended up batting against Bob Feller, of Cleveland Indians fame, in Renfrew Park, down on the river flats, in Edmonton, Alberta, summer of 1945 or '46, no one can remember which, though the date in question has brought on more than one disagreement."
The narrator, Jamie O'Day, is a teen-ager who lives with his parents in farm country miles away from the big city of Alberta, surrounded by Ukrainians, Norwegians, drifting American families and native Canadians. His wise South Carolina mother recognizes that the family are hillbillies, but she is determined to improve their fortunes.
"I married your daddy because he was a nice, cheerful man who never expected to bat less than .400, never expected to lose a game, and certainly never expected a Depression," she tells Jamie. His father is a wanderer who plays with a barnstorming team called Brother Pettigrew's Divine Light Baseball Mission. Brother Pettigrew said his team combined "the two Gods of rural North America, the mysterious and sometimes troubling one in the sky and baseball."
The small-town pickup teams outside Alberta have such names as the Sangudo Mustangs, New Oslo Blue Devils and Fark Red Sox. They rarely had time to practice. When they did, the Red Sox coach urged his players on with such admonitions as, "Want you boys to try as hard as a homely girl on her honeymoon."
In the cold winters in western Canada, sex is never far from the minds of the baseball-mad hillbillies and the author. Everybody in "Box Socials" is randy and available: if not in their neighborly bedrooms, then in their fields, barns and trucks. There isn't a four-letter word in the book, but Mr. Kinsella manages to get what he means across with such coy lines as, "The young people who were anxious for a chance to rub their personal body parts together on the dance floor didn't mind dancing to seven straight renditions of 'Alice Blue Gown.' "
Matchmaking takes place at the box socials of the title. At weekend get-togethers, the women prepare boxes of food and cakes and wrap them up without their identifying names. The man would look for one of the boxes prepared by the woman he coveted. It was a good guess that a marriage was shaky when a man avoided buying his own wife's box lunch. Truckbox Al McClintock saved up his 35 cents to buy the box lunch of a particularly unattractive young woman who was reputed to be -- one of Mr. Kinsella's euphemistic snappers -- "hot-blooded."
There are a number of amusing characters in the book, including a short American soldier whose truck breaks down in one of the Alberta towns and who never wants to get away. With a steady paycheck from the Army that has forgotten him, he's pursued by a Ukrainian sexpot named Lavonia Lakustra. Their six-day wedding ceremony calls to mind the ethnic wedding in the film "The Deer Hunter." Then, too, there's the luscious Velvet Bozniak who, the author writes with a wink, knows more about sex than any girl has a right to know.
But what about small-town baseball and those fields of dreams? Teasing the reader with the arch sociology of the inhabitants of a little-known place in a forgotten time, Mr. Kinsella delays the big game until the final pages of his novel. Now it was up to Truckbox Al McClintock to bring fame to the hillbillies. After all, he batted cleanup for the Oslo Blue Devils and could hit a ball 50 yards over the centerfielder's head.
But how would he do in an exhibition game against Bob Feller's hundred-mile-an-hour fast ball at Renfrew Park, down on the river flats, in Edmonton, Alberta, in the summer of 1945 or '46?
"That game, which might have been Truckbox Al's big break, was, though not one of us realized it at the time, an end to an era, and a beginning to a new one," Mr. Kinsella writes in his highly original story. "The rapidly improving economy soon made it possible for ordinary folks in the Six Towns area to own cars, and once they owned cars they traveled, and once they traveled things were never the same again."

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:

Sort of Rock
They Might Be Giants has just released its fourth album, "Apollo 18" (Elektra), and like its other ones, it has a small, low-tech feel to it. The band, the guitarists and songwriters John Flansburgh and John Linnell, are a product of bohemian Lower East Side life in New York in the early 1980's, and the music comes without a genre to identify it. It's pop, in a way, and rock, in a way, and it's loaded with clever wordplay and obvious melodies. But the songs aren't normal pop but rather the pop incarnation of irony, with such tunes as "The Statue Got Me High," "My Evil Twin" and "She's Actual Size," pretty much explaining their stance. 
 "Essentially, we're a cultural U.F.O.," said Mr. Flansburgh. "We don't fit into a trend, and the people who like us like us for a wide variety of reasons. We're definitely pro-melody, which is not the coolest way to be. We want to take melody back from the forces of evil."
When the band first started performing, Mr. Flansburgh and Mr. Linnell worked in tiny Lower East Side clubs, backed by a boom box. They created dial-a-song, an underground favorite that features a new song every day or so and can be dialed on the phone. On their last record, "Flood," they suddenly became college rock icons and can now sell out the Beacon Theater. It's the revenge of bohemia on mainstream pop.
"When we started, we just made ourselves available to the general public by things like dial-a-song and by playing a tremendous amount of gigs," said Mr. Flansburgh. "Then we started making records, which kind of surprised me. Because I think bands like us don't get to make records.
"People aren't really interested in music that challenges them. Our music challenges things that are familiar to people, the proper use of melody, what the function of song is, things like that."
 
Sounds of Puerto Rico
 "Ritmos y Cantos Callejeros" (Ansonia/750 Paterson Ave, East Rutherford, N.J. 07073) first came out in 1970, and it was immediately clear that this album was different from most Latin records at the time. It paired two of Puerto Rico's best percussionists and band leaders, Cortijo and Kako, in a setting that was less commercial than most salsa records being made, by them or others.
The album, just released on CD, features bombas and plenas, based on rhythms specific to Puerto Rico. There's no horn section, and the chorus uses the gorgeous sound of a Puerto Rican choir. The main singers (Chivirico Davila, Ismael Rivera and Gilberto Cruz) use the freedom of the tracks to improvise a bit. It's a classic album, loaded with easy, graceful rhythms, and with smooth call-and-response sections, both from the drums and from the singers.
 
Still Political, but . . .
 When Rono Tse and Michael Franti were members of the group Beatnigs, they'd run around onstage wrapped in chains, shouting political slogans, banging on refrigerator doors and car gas tanks, and taking most of their clothes off. It was industrial rock agitprop from San Francisco, and it was obviously informed by performance art as much as by the music scene.
The Beatnigs broke up a few years ago, and Mr. Tse and Mr. Franti are now rappers traveling under the name the Disposable Heroes of Hiphoprisy; they've just released their first album, "Hypocrisy Is the Greatest Luxury" (Fourth and Broadway). Mr. Franti raps in the deep authoritarian tones of Chuck D of Public Enemy; his pieces are no less political than they were before, and the samples range from avant jazz to noise.
"Rap's the music Rono and I listen to," said Mr. Franti. "With the Beatnigs we weren't really making music; it was more like political theater."
It's also music that doesn't resort to racism to condemn racism, pointing out the fallibility of standard hip-hop positions, from gangsterism and anti-Semitism to consumerism.
"Black roles used to be very circumscribed," said Mr. Franti. "Today we have other opportunities yet we still see these roles existing both in entertainment and in consumers perpetuating the roles to present some modicum of personal success. A lot of roles we black people put on ourselves. For example, during the mid-80's when black America was hit hard economically, we were being encouraged by each other to buy commodities like gold chains and sneakers, which aren't putting money back into the community and just show off who's biggest and baddest. Bashing Jews became the thing to do. We want to resist all that and to choose what kind of symbols of blackness we are."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Olympia & York pulled out all the stops in hiring some of the financial world's star players, including Thomas S. Johnson, former president of Manufacturers Hanover, to help it in restructuring billions of dollars in loans on its vast holdings. [Page D1.]

HEADLINE: Trying a Market Approach to Smog

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 21

 BODY:
After laboring for decades under the nation's toughest air-quality rules, companies in Southern California now face a daunting new challenge: proving that they can figure out on their own how best to clean up the nation's worst smog.
Under a plan that regional air-quality regulators approved earlier this month, Southern California will scrap most of its cumbersome rules for oil refineries and other large industrial polluters. Instead, the regulators are introducing a radical new free-market approach. Companies will still face strict quotas for reducing emissions. But they will be free to satisfy these limits in almost any way they see fit -- even by buying the right to pollute from another company that has surpassed its cleanup quota. 
 The plan will not take effect for a year and many important details remain to be worked out by the South Coast Air Quality Management District. But companies are already gauging the effects on their operations and laying plans to cut emissions or buy pollution rights.
Southern California Edison envisions savings and is stepping up efforts to help customers develop less-polluting technologies. ARCO, the big oil company, anticipates such great costs that it is lobbying for changes.
The plan's goal is to reduce the costs to industry -- and the region's economy -- of eradicating the choking brown haze that covers the Los Angeles basin. It is the most ambitious effort in the nation to use free-market forces to reduce pollution. The results are certain to have a profound influence on national policy, which is already moving in the same direction.
Several companies large and small, ranging from Terra Furniture of City of Industry to ARCO of Los Angeles, say the plan demands too much additional emissions reduction and will ultimately prove unworkable.
George H. Babikian, the president of ARCO's gasoline refining and marketing division, said the plan "would impose an additional burden on industry that is technologically unrealistic and financially unreasonable."
 
Big Savings Expected
 But most companies say the new approach will save them hundreds of thousands or even millions of dollars as the region pushes to meet Federal clean-air standards by early in the next century.
The Coatings Resources Corporation, a small company in Huntington Beach that makes paints and coatings for products like Mattel toys, plans to use new technologies and less polluting paint ingredients, reducing emissions enough to become a seller of pollution credits. In contrast, Southern California Edison says it can meet its emissions requirements more cheaply by buying credits than by investing in additional pollution-control technologies itself.
"The market will assign the cheapest way to get the necessary emissions reduction," said Michael Hertel, Edison's manager of environmental affairs.
The plan frees companies to reduce pollution in the most cost-effective ways they can find and provides incentives for research into new pollution-control techniques.
 
Creating a Market
 Companies that exceed their emission-reduction quotas can sell pollution credits on an open market. The trading will be monitored by the regional air-quality agency, which will most likely vouch for the validity of the credits and provide up-to-date price information.
The buyers would be companies that could not meet their quotas or that decided it would be less expensive to buy credits than to invest in new technology. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency is developing a similar program on a national scale to promote reductions in the pollutants that cause acid rain.
"What the business community has been saying is, 'We can clean up the air cheaper if you let us do it our way,' " said Joel Schwartz, a staff scientist at the Coalition for Clean Air, an environmental group. "If the program goes forward, they're going to have to prove to us that they can give us real, quantifiable reductions in emissions and progress towards clean air. Otherwise we have to go back to the old system, which may be more onerous, but also easier to enforce."
Many business groups, eager to increase the potential supply of emissions credits and therefore hold down their price, want the plan to include not just the 2,700 largest polluters, as the air-quality agency has proposed, but almost all companies in the sprawling Los Angeles basin. Some environmental and health groups want to exclude certain large polluters, including utilities, on the ground that they are just coming under tough new regional regulations and should not be allowed to escape them.
 
Trying to Save Jobs
 But the overall plan has apparently gained unstoppable political momentum. At a time when many companies are fleeing from California, in part because of high regulatory costs, officials are eager to save jobs by granting industry more flexibility.
Some critics of the system say it will actually encourage the flight of businesses because if they close they can sell credits equal to their total emissions -- money they could then use to relocate to another state with looser rules. They could also move to Mexico, though Mexico City's mayor just issued a warning to companies to cut their emissions.
But a study by the air-quality district found that the program would reduce 1994 industrial-compliance costs by $427 million, a reduction of 65 percent based on projected costs under current regulations. In 1997, the savings would be $270 million, or 29 percent. By 1997, the study said, the region would be losing nearly 2,000 fewer jobs a year than under the current approach.
Southern California Edison, for example, has seven large plants in the region, all of which emit nitrogen oxides in burning fuel to create electricity. Nitrogen oxides are one of the two basic classes of smog-forming pollutants covered by the plan; the other is reactive organic gases, which are released primarily in the use of paints, coatings and solvents.
Mr. Hertel said that Southern California Edison has reduced its nitrogen oxide emissions by more than 70 percent since 1979. The company's estimated cost for each further ton of annual reductions is $30,000, he said. Because many other companies can reduce their emissions more easily, the cost of buying a credit for one ton of annual nitrogen oxide emissions is projected at $6,800 or less, he said, making it highly attractive for Southern California Edison to be a "smog credit" buyer.
 
Working With Customers
 At the same time, the utility is helping some of its customers reduce their emissions through imaginative uses of electricity. Fender Guitars was having trouble meeting air-quality standards because its wood coatings emit gases as they dry. But Southern California Edison developed a process to cure the coatings using ultraviolet and infrared light, reducing the quantity of solvents needed and therefore reducing the pollution.
Under a broad-based program of trading pollution credits, Mr. Hertel said, more companies would be willing to invest in similar innovations, since they could pay for the investment by selling the resulting emissions credits.
"By unleashing the innovation that comes from people looking to make a dollar from reducing emissions," Mr. Hertel said, "I think we're going to see much more rapid progress towards the clean-air goal than we would under the old command-and-control system."
The owner of the Coatings Resource Corporation, Ed Laird, said the company was well on its way to eliminating completely its use of paint and coatings ingredients that contain a type of gas known as volatile organic compounds. Suppliers of the resins that go into his paints and coatings are already developing products that do not have the compounds, he said.
But what to many companies is the plan's virtue -- allowing industry to meet emission-reduction quotas any way it wants -- is a curse to others. Mr. Babikian of ARCO said the program would benefit the company for several years because it knows how to squeeze a certain additional amount of pollution out of its operations. After that, Mr. Babikian said, there is no assurance that the oil industry will be able to develop the technology needed to reduce its emissions of nitrogen oxides by 8 percent annually through the year 2010, as the plan requires.
"We'd be relying on technological innovations that may or may not take place," he said. If ARCO were forced to bid for pollution credits to meet its quota, Mr. Babikian said, it would only encourage more small companies to cash in their credits and move out of the region.
At Terra Furniture, Gary Stafford, the chief financial officer, said the company, which has 50 employees, probably could not afford to meet its emission-reduction quota by purchasing credits at an estimated cost of $40,000 per annual ton.
Yet the cost of meeting the quota by installing new technology to reduce emissions is also prohibitive, probably $1 million plus operating costs. Even being able to sell the resulting emissions credits would not make a $1 million investment economical, Mr. Stafford said.
It is unclear whether furniture makers will be included in the new plan. The air-quality agency wants to start only with companies that emit more than four tons of pollutants a year, and about half the furniture companies in the region fall below that threshold. But despite his reservations, Mr. Stafford is lobbying for the industry to be included because the new approach would delay until after the year 2000 emission-reduction goals that furniture makers and some other companies would otherwise have to meet by 1997.

WHAT FACTORIES WILL HAVE TO DO
 
A factory must reduce emmissions each year by preset amounts (8 percent annually for nitrogen oxides and 6 percent annually for reactive organic gases). The rules would initally cover 2,700 at the largest polluters.
 
A company that pollutes can . . .
 
. . . reduce production or close down.
If a factory cuts pollution by more than the required amount it can . . .
 
. . . invest in new technology or processes to reduce pollution by at least the required amount. If the company reduces polution by more than the required amount, it can . . .
 
. . . purchase a credit from a company that has exceeded its goal for emissions reductions.
 
. . . sell the credit on an open markeet.
It can keep the money or use the investment in pollution-control technology.
 
. . . bank the credit to help meet its reduction quota in coming years.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Nippon Phone Looking for Cash

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Japan is moving to allow foreigners to buy a stake in its largest company, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation. It is an offer that foreigners can be grateful was not made earlier.
The shares of N.T.T., once a Government-owned telephone monopoly, have fallen 80 percent from their 1987 peak. The company, which is still partly owned by the Government, has faced growing competition within Japan. That, plus the Japanese bear market, has made N.T.T.'s stock a disastrous performer. It has become a symbol of Japan's financial excesses in the 1980's. 
 The Japanese Cabinet is expected to approve on Friday a proposal from the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications to allow N.T.T. to sell shares directly to investors, and allow foreigners to buy up to 20 percent of the company. Cabinet approval would send the proposal on to the Parliament, where approval is expected. The legislation would specify that no foreigners could serve on N.T.T.'s board.
 
How High Is Too High?
 Whether foreigners will want to buy may depend on whether they accept arguments that N.T.T., its market capitalization down to about $75 billion, is no longer priced absurdly high compared with the world's other telephone companies. On the surface, that does not appear to be the case. Even after falling 19,000 yen, to 640,000 yen yesterday -- or about $4,800 a share -- the total value of its 15.6 million shares is still greater than the $70 billion market value of Philip Morris, the largest American company by capitalization.
N.T.T. shares are trading at a multiple of about 50 times estimated earnings for the fiscal year ending next week, and the company, citing the slowing Japanese economy, has warned that profits may fall next year.
But Jeffrey Zavattero, an analyst for Jardine Fleming in Tokyo, argues that as a multiple of cash flow, the stock price is comparable to that of other phone companies -- about six times cash flow. N.T.T. takes a huge charge for depreciation, reflecting its large capital spending program and its relatively rapid depreciation of many assets, but the cash-flow calculation ignores depreciation, as well as capital spending.
Mr. Zavattero said yesterday that he believed N.T.T.'s profits could rise rapidly if Japanese Government regulators would allow it to raise rates on local calls, which are now much cheaper than in most other countries.
Such issues did not seem to matter in early 1987, when N.T.T. was one of the hottest stocks in the world, with a market capitalization that amazed foreigners. It went public when the Government sold part of its holding in February 1987, at 1.6 million yen a share. There was a frenzy to own the shares, and those who got in on that first offering quickly felt rich, as the shares nearly doubled, reaching 3.18 million yen.
At its peak, foreign skeptics noted, N.T.T. was valued at about $350 billion, or more than the entire German stock market. Even after the 1987 market crash, the Government was able to sell shares to the public in two additional offerings, at 2.55 million yen and 1.9 million yen a share.
In the days of hectic rises for N.T.T., the Government ownership of most of the shares helped push up the share price. Japanese institutional investors had to have a market weighting in N.T.T., but at the beginning only one-eighth of the company's shares were publicly held, although the company's weighting in stock indexes assumed that all shares were available. Not everyone could have a market weighting, but many were trying.
Now, with the Government's stake down to about 65 percent, its holdings seem to have the opposite effect. The Government wants to sell more, in large part to keep its budget deficit down. It had planned to sell 500,000 shares in the fiscal year that ends March 31, and the same number of shares in each of the next four years. Such sales would cut the Government's stake to about 50 percent and raise, at the current price, about $12 billion.
But no sale will be made in the current year, in large part because officials concluded the market could not absorb those extra shares. In the current fiscal year, the shares have fallen 40 percent in value. The Government still wants to sell shares in the next fiscal year, however, and the knowledge that those shares are overhanging the market may have helped depress the price.
The proposed legislation expected to be approved by the Cabinet on Friday would not affect those sales. Instead, it would clear the way for the company to make its own sales, with the money going into its coffers rather than the Government's. Mr. Zavattero said he expected any such sale would not be of shares outright, but of convertible bonds.
N.T.T. can use the money. A company official was quoted by Bloomberg Business News yesterday as having said that the company planned capital spending of 1.94 trillion yen, or about $15 billion, in the fiscal year that begins next week, up 3 percent from the current fiscal year.

HEADLINE: Pace of Congressional Politics Picks Up

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 24

 BODY:
With a new redistricting map in place, the tempo of Congressional politics quickened today with the announcement of a Republican candidate in the redrawn Sixth District on the Jersey Shore and an acknowledgement by Frank J. Guarini that he will fight to keep his seat in the newly drawn, heavily Hispanic 13th District in Hudson and Union Counties.
In the Sixth District, Grace Applegate, who served in the administrations of Gov. Thomas H. Kean in Trenton and President Bush in Washington, announced today that she would run for the Republican nomination for the seat vacated by Bernard J. Dwyer. Mr. Dwyer, a Democrat, announced on Saturday that he would not seek re-election to the seat he has held since 1980.
 
Moving to Old Bridge
 
 A major reason, the 71-year-old Congressman said in a statement, was that he did not want to run again in a district that had been so revised that he would not know half the voters and they would not know him.
His withdrawal left Representative Frank J. Pallone Jr. as the odds-on favorite to become the Democratic nominee in the Sixth. Mr. Pallone now represents the adjacent Third District, in Ocean and Monmouth Counties, but was thrown into Mr. Dwyer's Sixth District by the redistricting plan adopted last week.
As the only incumbent seeking the Democratic nomination, Mr. Pallone will have a strong advantage, but he may be challenged in the primary by Assemblyman Robert G. Smith of Piscataway, who is expected to announce his intentions on Thursday.
Ms. Applegate is leaving a job as special assistant to an Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services. She will move to Old Bridge from Washington. Before taking the Washington job, she served for eight years in the New Jersey Department of Labor.
Meanwhile, Mr. Pallone stepped up his own campaign for election to a fourth term in a new district by gaining the endorsement of the Sierra Club, which is considered important along the Jersey Shore, where pollution is both a personal and economic consideration because of the tourist dollar.
The newly drawn 13th District, in Hudson and Union Counties, was inherited by Representative Frank J. Guarini, the incumbent Democrat in the 14th, which is being dismantled. There has been speculation that Mr. Guarini might not run for an eighth term to make way for a Hispanic candidate in the new district, which has been redrawn to become 43 percent Hispanic.
But a spokesman for Mr. Guarini in Washington, Brook Anderson, said today that "he is running" in the reconstituted 13th, but no date has been set for a formal announcement. Speculation has centered on a possible candidacy by a Democratic State Senator, Robert Menendez of Union City, a Cuban-American with a substantial following, but he has not made his intentions known.
Brian Hughes, son of former Gov. Richard J. Hughes, has announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination to oppose Chris Smith, the Republican incumbent, in the Fourth District, which sprawls across parts of Burlington, Middlesex, Mercer, Monmouth and Ocean Counties.
Mr. Hughes, who is employed by the Governor's Council on Alcohol and Drug Abuse and who is in favor of abortion rights, has said he will concentrate on health care and economic issues, but is also expected to make an issue of Mr. Smith's prominence as a nationally known anti-abortion leader.

HEADLINE: Trenton Ponders Change In Tough Sewer Controls

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 24

 BODY:
Environmentalists and advocates of development clashed today over suggestions for easing New Jersey's stringent moratorium on sewer connections.
The law, which has been in effect since 1973, halted any new hook-ups last year in nearly half of the state's communities because local treatment plants were releasing unclean water or were at maximum capacity. 
 The state Department of Environmental Protection and Energy is considering relaxing the sewer connection ban. At an informal hearing at Rutgers University here today, department officials heard arguments from both sides on options that ranged from keeping the ban to adopting intermediate measures where violations are minor to scrapping all the restrictions.
Last year, 249 of the state's 567 municipalities where wholly or partly under a ban. The list was reduced to 142 municipalities when dozens of communities in Bergen and Union counties were recently removed after large central sewer plants came into compliance.
 
Economic Impact Cited
 Modifying the New York metropolitan region's most stringent sewer restrictions, the department said in a working paper, would open the way for more development in an economically depressed time. It would also undermine some municipalities' use of sewer bans as a tool for stopping growth, which the state described as an unintended result.
The law has come under particular attack from developers since the Clean Water Enforcement Act took effect last summer. That law, which the developers fought, imposes stiff fines on communities that pollute.
With the ban slowing development in many communities, representatives of business interests declared, the state's economic recession, in which 50,000 construction workers have been idled, is being made worse.
"Of all the Department of Environmental Protection regulations, this one has probably had the most devastating effect on development," said Peter A. Buchsbaum, a Woodbridge lawyer who spoke for a commercial developers' group. "It's not like wetlands rules, which only say, 'Don't go there, go here.' It simply stops all development in its tracks."
But William R. Neil, assistant director of conservation, of the New Jersey Audubon Society, challenged that view.
"Hard economic times are being used as the justification for caving in to officials and special interests who never liked these laws or met the funding deadlines, even in much better financial times," Mr. Neil said in a prepared statement.
 
Some Cities Like the Ban
 The state seemed to acknowledge that an unintended consequence of the sewer ban law has been for many municipalities to accept the moratorium as more or less permanent, neither seeking to lift it nor appropriating the money to correct the defect that brought it on.
Some communities have had all or part of their area on the restricted list for more than a decade. The state says, for example, that Caldwell Borough in Essex County has been under a ban since Jan. 1, 1979, because its treatment plant is at maximum capacity and is discharging insufficiently treated water. Allentown Borough, in Monmouth County, has been under the ban since July 1973, and dozens of the 144 areas where sewer hook-ups are banned have been in that situation since the mid-1980's.
Dirk Hoffman, the head of the Sewer and Waste Water Trust Fund, which was set up by the state to help communities meet state rules, pointed out today that many municipalities had not bothered to apply for the funds available to them.
As a result, the state working paper noted, the violations that prompted many restrictions on new hook-ups have not been corrected.
Of four options being weighed, the state seemed to favor a modification of the law to take into account the degree of pollution and the willingness of sewer authorities to fix the problem.
 
Second Law Applies
 "When a sewer-connection ban is imposed for permit violations that are environmentally insignificant," the discussion paper said, "strict compliance with the sewer-connection ban criteria is difficult to implement and defend."
The other options are to withhold the ban if the violation is intermittent and the sewer authority agrees to correct the problem, to scrap the ban outright or to leave the law unchanged.
John R. Weingart, assistant commissioner for regulation, said any formal proposals to modify the law would be published in the fall and subject to formal hearings before their adoption.
The meeting today came a day after the Department of Environmental Protection released a study of the first six months' operation of the Clean Water Enforcement Act. The act's stiff fines for improper waste water treatment systems were held up today as making the system of sewer bans unnecessary.
The report noted a large increase in the number of agreements to correct waste-water violations, most of them coming before the act took effect from officials seeking to avoid the law's penalties.
But Alan I. Mytelka, director of the Interstate Sanitation Commission, a regulatory agency covering New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, urged the state to retain some role in regulating local sewers. Local politics seems to get in the way of effective regulation, Mr. Mytelka said, when only local officials decide issues with statewide impacts.

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Votes $25 Billion for S.& L.'s

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
The Senate Banking Committee adopted legislation today that would provide an additional $25 billion for savings and loan bailouts and would, for the first time, make public the examiners' reports on failed financial institutions.
The bill, sent to the full Senate on a voice vote, would bring the total taxpayer cost of the bailout program to $130 billion. That is still short of the $160 billion the Bush Administration says it needs to complete the bailout but would be enough to carry the program until April 1, 1993, well past the election. 
 The committee voted 12 to 8 to include "sunshine" provisions sponsored by Senator Timothy Wirth, Democrat of Colorado. They would require regulators to make public the examination reports of banks and savings and loan associations that later failed. Names of borrowers would be deleted, except those of board members and other insiders.
Regulators also would be required to make public the terms of settlements they reached with bank officials sued for fraud or negligence.
Two weeks ago the House Banking Committee voted 31 to 17 to adopt similar financing legislation, but without the broader provisions of the Senate bill. The chairman of that panel, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, refused to permit amendments.
In a letter today, Mr. Gonzalez asked House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington to demand support for the bill from President Bush. Mr. Gonzalez said he saw little Republican backing for the measure in the full House and doubted whether it would pass without a majority of both parties.
The Senate provisions on disclosure are intended to make it easier for Congress and the public to assess failures and judge the fairness of civil settlements that recoup losses.
"Let's get these decisions out into the sun," Senator Wirth said. "Sunshine is the best antiseptic."
Regulators opposed his provisions, arguing that the threat of disclosure would turn bank examinations into an adversarial proceeding and that disclosing terms of settlements might encourage defendants to fight Government suits rather than settle quietly.
Another provision by Mr. Wirth would extend from three years to five years the statute of limitations for such civil suits brought by the bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corporation. The agency seized more than 300 failed savings and loans in 1989 and said it was having trouble meeting the current three-year deadline.
 
Aid for Ailing Savings Institutions
 At the urging of Senator Terry Sanford, Democrat of North Carolina, senators also agreed to earmark $1.85 billion of the $25 billion for assistance for operating but ailing savings institutions.
Senator Sanford said pumping money into open institutions was cheaper in many cases than closing them. He said it was better for the economy because it would avoid the forced sale of the loans and real estate owned by the weak institution.
A Bush Administration oversight panel headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is considering whether to adopt a policy on assistance for open savings institutions and has scheduled a hearing on the subject for Wednesday.
The Senate committee rejected by a mostly party-line 11-to-10 vote a motion by Jake Garn of Utah, the senior Republican on the panel, that would have stripped all provisions but the financing from the bill.
Mr. Garn said even well-meant extraneous provisions would encourage a flood of amendments when the legislation reached the Senate floor, making it impossible to meet an April 1 deadline for keeping the Resolution Trust Corporation going. Legislation passed by Congress in November authorized an increase in bailout spending but said it must be spent by April 1.
