HEADLINE: Bank Fund And C.D. Yields Mixed

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and short-term certificates of deposit continued to give mixed signals last week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, which tracks bank rates.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday: "Despite the fact that there are more than $100 billion in certificates of deposit maturing in April, banks are going to have a tough time recapturing all that money because of their low interest rates. In the past year, for example, the average yield on one-year certificates of deposit has plunged from 6.53 percent to 4.15 percent." 
 "Typically," he added, "you would now see banks bumping up rates to grab those certificate of deposit rollovers, but because loan demand is weak, their deposit rates suffer." He believes that savers, accustomed to high yields, may now "swing into more speculative, higher-paying investments, such as stocks, bonds and mutual funds."
 
New York-Area Yields
 At New York area commercial banks, the average money market account yield dropped by 2 basis points, to 3.40 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. Among the savings institutions in this area, money market accounts averaged 3.96 percent, up from 3.95 percent a week ago.
Among individual banks in the New York area showing the largest changes in yields, First Fidelity of New Jersey cut its money market account by 25 points. Crossland Savings made the largest changes in three- and six-month certificates of deposit, reducing its three-month certificate by 15 points and its six-month by 9 points.
The Bank Rate Monitor said the average three-month yield at 20 large banks outside the New York area dropped by a point, to 3.57 percent, while the six-month certificate averaged 3.91 percent, up 2 points, an indication of the mixed movements in yields.
By comparison, at the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, the average rate was 4.08 percent and 4.27 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Slow Trading As Dealers Await New Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower in light trading yesterday as the market awaited further reports to confirm improvement in the American economy.
Currency traders said there was little news to affect the dollar. 
 "It didn't do much -- absolutely boring," said Christopher Bourdain, who heads foreign exchange sales for Credit Suisse in New York.
"The market is mildly convinced we're in some sort of a recovery," he added. "People are waiting for some further confirmation before they buy dollars more."
 
4 Reports Scheduled
 Such news could come today, when the Government releases figures on February durable goods orders, or tomorrow, when fourth-quarter gross domestic product and corporate profits numbers will be announced along with the weekly figures on new unemployment claims.
The disappointing mid-March auto sales figures reported yesterday did not affect foreign exchange markets, Mr. Bourdain said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 133.80 yen, down 0.40 from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 133.70 yen. In New York, a dollar bought 133.45 yen, unchanged from late on Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7200, from $1.7170 late on Monday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.7205, more expensive than $1.7190 late on Monday.
In London, the German mark traded at 1.6645 German marks, down from 1.6685 late on Monday. In New York, a dollar bought 1.6635 marks, down from 1.6665 on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5125 Swiss francs, down from 1.5145; 5.6315 French francs, down from 5.6515; 1251.50 Italian lire, down from 1,252.75, and 1.1903 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19175.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Women's Work: The Pay Paradox

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
COMPARED with their European counterparts, American women are more skilled and enjoy greater legal protection against job and pay discrimination. Why, then, is the gap in pay between men and women roughly the same as in Europe -- and in some cases, far greater?
One possibility is that discrimination is actually more pervasive in the United States than indicators suggest. But Francine Blau and Lawrence Kahn, economists at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign campus, offer a very different explanation in an article to be published in the May issue of the American Economic Review. 
 The unique American problem, they argue, is not discrimination but the yawning gap in wages between skilled and unskilled labor. On average, they note, American women are less skilled and have less job experience than American men. And rewards to skill (or penalties for lack thereof) are far greater in the United States than in other countries. Indeed, adjusted for this wage dispersion factor, the gender pay gap is no higher in America than in Scandinavia.
As might be expected, Sweden and Norway do well in gender pay comparisons. By the late 1980's, women were paid 85 to 90 percent as much as men, per hour worked. By contrast, women in tradition-bound Switzerland lagged far behind at 68 percent.
The real surprise is that American women do only slightly better than Swiss, earning roughly 70 cents for every dollar brought home by men for an hour's work. Even more disturbing, the differences between the leaders and the laggards on the pay equality front have widened since the rise of feminism. Back in 1967, the difference between the United States and Norway was 11 percentage points; by 1989 it had widened to 16.
It is not easy to find the smoking gun that explains such large and growing differences. The United States had laws protecting the right to equal pay and equal access to better jobs before Sweden or Norway -- or for that matter, before other European countries that rank fairly well on the gender pay gap.
The two economists do note one striking difference between the United States and other rich countries: Only the United States fails to guarantee the right to maternity leave beyond the period of actual disability. Indeed, most other countries guarantee time off with pay for both pregnancy and care for infants. It thus seems likely that more American women are forced to choose between high-paying careers and motherhood.
But Mr. Kahn argues that the actual impact of leave policies on the gender pay gap is ambiguous. While the laissez-faire American approach surely drives some women off the fast track, it surely also pulls some on. American women who are effectively forced to forgo parenthood to further their careers are better positioned to compete than European women who try to have it both ways.
What, then, does explain the lackluster American performance? Ms. Blau and Mr. Kahn see it as a double whammy. Like Scandinavian women, American women are, on average, less productive than men because they have less training and experience. But unlike Scandinavian women, they are the inadvertent victims of a wage-setting system that has been increasingly apt to punish a lack of skills or experience.
American women are thus "swimming upstream," starting from a position of economic inferiority in a labor market that reserves an ever-skimpier slice of the pie for those at the bottom.
This is only a hypothesis, of course. The meat of the Blau-Kahn contribution is their statistical analysis, which isolates the factors in intercountry pay differences that are specifically related to gender. And as the two economists predicted, sex discrimination does not seem to be an important cause of the relatively poor American experience. Indeed, differences in pay for comparable skills explain 100 percent of the difference in the gender pay gap between Scandinavia and the United States.
On first glance, that appears to be good news. American law and culture seem to have done a good job -- or, at least, as good a job as Sweden and Norway -- in attacking sex discrimination in the workplace.
It is, however, an awkward sort of victory for the American system. The labor market may not be discriminatory in intent. But it is plainly discriminatory in result, rewarding the haves and punishing the have-nots. As the blues singer Billie Holiday once put it in a slightly different context, "God bless' the child that's got his own."
The best one can say for the American labor market is that, given time, unintentional discrimination should be self-correcting. The gap in average skill and experience levels should narrow as better-educated generations of women permeate the work force. Moreover, the gap in pay levels between skilled and unskilled work will probably also narrow as more people, male and female, respond to the increased incentive to go to college.

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Testing of Food Pyramid Comes Full Circle

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
ONE million dollars ago, the United States Department of Agriculture put the Eating Right Pyramid graphic on hold because, health professionals and some Federal officials charged, there had been opposition from the meat and dairy industries.
Eleven months later, extensive testing has shown that the pyramid, which divides foods into five groups, remains the strongest choice for conveying one of the Government's most important nutrition messages: eat less fat. 
 That means that the Agriculture Department is faced with a dilemma: it must either go with the original graphic, despite industry opposition, or reject the graphic, despite its advantages, and anger many nutritionists and health professionals. The department would not comment on the report or speculate on when it would be released. The decision will probably affect how nutrition is taught for decades to come.
Concerned that the Agriculture Department cannot educate the public about nutrition while promoting the economic well-being of the food industry, the Department of Health and Human Services has involved itself in the deliberations.
"H.H.S. put money in to keep U.S.D.A. honest," said one Agriculture Department staff member involved in the deliberations who was afraid she would lose her job if she allowed her name to be used. So the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, will help the Secretary of Agriculture, Edward R. Madigan, make the final decision.
Meat and dairy producers have not changed their minds about the pyramid, which advises the public to use fats and oils "sparingly," and says that meats and dairy products should be eaten less frequently than fruits, vegetables and grains.
"The industry would have preferred anything but the pyramid," said Jeannine Kenney, legislative representative for the National Milk Producers Federation. "The pyramid gave a very negative image. It appeared to rank food." Mark Armentrout, chairman of the food policy committee of the National Cattleman's Association, said, "Something is a better alternative than the pyramid."
The Eating Right Pyramid, created for the Department of Agriculture, was to have made its debut last April. When Secretary Madigan delayed its publication, he denied that there had been industry pressure and said the graphic had to be tested on schoolchildren.
Since then Bell Associates, a research firm in Boston, has tested a number of other graphics and has narrowed the choices to the pyramid and a bowl, which orders the five food groups horizontally rather than vertically. The research was designed to prove once and for all that one graphic was superior to all the others and to remove politics from the decision.
According to the final draft of the report, the original pyramid, with slight modifications, continues to communicate best the need to reduce the consumption of fats, oils and sugars, and to convey the amount of food that should be eaten from each of the five groups. It also presents the information in the clearest fashion.
The bowl graphic performs best if the primary message is the importance of eating a variety of foods from each of the groups.
If the final report says the same thing, then the pyramid would be the logical choice, said James A. Harrell, deputy director of the office of disease prevention and health promotion in the Department of Health and Human Services.
"If those are the final recommendations from the contractor and the people who do the review of the report, I would have to agree," he said. "But I can't concur now.
The differences between the two graphics are statistically significant but not great. "It's a call of which is the most important message," said the Agriculture Department staff member.
The Health and Human Services Department regards reducing fat as the most important message, as reflected in a report by the Surgeon General in 1988.
"The strongest focus in the Surgeon General's Report is that dietary fat is the single most important factor related to chronic disease," said Dr. Rachel Ballard-Barbash, a medical officer in the division of cancer prevention and control at the National Cancer Institute.
Dr. Ballard-Barbash was an adviser on the original study when she worked in the office of disease prevention and health promotion. At the Agriculture Department, she said, the nutritionists "were certainly aware that the consensus was that dietary fat was of paramount importance."
Experts involved in the project, both inside and outside the Government, have always thought the Government was asking too much from one graphic.
"They can't have one graphic do everything -- children, adults, Hispanics, low income -- or teach everyone what they should eat, how much they should eat, about fats and oils and sugar," said Elaine Arkin, a health communications consultant and adviser on the report. Joanne Tighe, deputy project director at Bell Associates, said: "We told them on July 1 that one graphic will not do everything. They have been putting off the moment of truth."
There are those who think the Government has wasted its money redoing the survey.
"It's a little troubling to see a large sum of money spent and still arrive at a similar conclusion," Dr. Ballard-Barbash said, "but that doesn't mean it shouldn't have been investigated. The folks who did this originally were fairly well-trained nutritionists who had a good knowledge of what was contained in the Surgeon General's Report and in Dietary Guidelines, and they understood where the emphasis was in terms of disease prevention."
To answer the questions raised by Mr. Madigan about the effectiveness of the pyramid, committees were formed to find possible alternatives. Focus groups were consulted and the result was a handful of graphics: variations on the pyramid and on a bowl, a shopping cart, a pie chart, a table top and even some designs from children, like a spaceman.
After further testing, the pyramid and bowl were the clear winners. But consumer groups and many nutritionists still preferred the pyramid.
The bowl and pyramid were then tested on 3,000 people in three age groups. A draft reporting the results of the testing was sent to a panel from the two Cabinet agencies in early January, somewhat behind schedule.
"We were given a ridiculously huge piece of work to do in a very small amount of time," said Jeanne Goldberg, an assistant professor of nutrition at Tufts University, who was the principal investigator on the project.
No one was happy with that draft. Neither the bowl nor the pyramid jumped out as the superior graphic because the Agriculture Department had not decided in advance what messages were the most important: variety, proportionality (how much to eat from each group) or reduction of fats and sugars.
"The problem," Ms. Tighe said, "is that they have to set priorities, because they can't get all the messages across and they have to decide which is the target audience."
Hoping to get a more definitive answer, the panel returned the first draft to the investigators. They were asked to look at the data again and give more weight to some of the questions, particularly those that had to do with the three key messages.
"I think this draft tilts a little bit differently than before, toward the pyramid," said John Vanderveen, director of the division of nutrition at the Food and Drug Administration's Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition.
Dr. Cheryl Achterberg, an associate professor of nutrition at Pennsylvania State University and one of the report advisers, said, "Avoiding fats and sugars comes through better in the pyramid." Many people involved generally agree. But all believe that neither the bowl nor pyramid, standing alone, does a particularly good job at conveying information.
"The average person picked up on about one-third of the message on first impression," Dr. Achterberg said. "There was a whole lot they didn't get without instruction."
The latest draft of the report notes "the necessity for presenting either graphic in an educational context."
The respondents were also asked which graphic they preferred, but there was very little difference. "People didn't strongly dislike either one," Dr. Achterberg said.
Few of those involved with the project appear to favor the bowl; some say either would do the job. But among those who favor the pyramid, the support is very strong.
"Looking at the question as an educator," Dr. Achterberg said, "there is no question which one I would pick from an instructional perspective. The pyramid depicts the concepts more clearly and is more teachable. The bowl is more difficult to teach from."
So now the two Secretaries will have to make a policy decision, which is to say, a political decision.
"I wish there were no politics involved in it," said Mary Abbott Hess, former president of the American Dietetic Association and a consultant to the project. "Political influences in nutrition education messages should not be part of the process."
The U.S.D.A. staff member said, "Putting the best light on the expenses and manhours spent searching for the perfect graphic, at least it confirms that the original research project was pretty well designed."

HEADLINE: Two Sound Choices;
A Business Pro at City Hall

 BODY:
Mayor David Dinkins made a wise move by naming a prominent banker to be New York City's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. The appointment of Barry Sullivan, retired chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, sends a positive message to business leaders in search of a sympathetic ear at City Hall.
Mr. Dinkins often calls on competent experts from the business world, but just as often fails to act on their counsel. As a member of Mr. Dinkins's inner circle, Mr. Sullivan could have a more direct impact on policy -- if the Mayor is receptive. 
 Not that the Bronx-born banker will always be right. But at least he'll be in a position to bolster business confidence in the city. And he can strengthen City Hall's ties with the private sector, which are still weak despite the tireless efforts of Mr. Sullivan's predecessor, Sally Hernandez-Pinero. Mr. Sullivan is no newcomer to urban issues and political realities; he advised several Chicago mayors.
He will remain a consultant to First Chicago for three years, at an annual salary of $780,000, while donating his after-tax city salary to schools and charity. His deal with First Chicago raises the fear of future conflicts of interest, but that shouldn't be a problem if he keeps his commitment to recuse himself from any dealings the city might have with First Chicago.
Mr. Sullivan's success will depend on many factors, including the overall economy. Not the least of these factors, however, will be the Mayor's willingness to consider his counsel.

HEADLINE: Russia Acts, U.S. Slumbers

 BODY:
No blank check. With that vapid phrase, President Bush sidesteps pressure to organize large-scale Western economic aid for Russia. Apparently unsure that Russian economic reforms are real, he sits on the sidelines as the Russian economy verges on collapse.
Mr. President, take another look. In February the Yeltsin Government and the International Monetary Fund reached agreement on economic measures that will be formalized once Russia becomes a member in April. Since then Russia has further decontrolled prices, slashed military spending, cut subsidies to state enterprises and opened its borders to trade and investment. That's an astonishingly quick leap to markets. 
 These are momentous events; in Russia last August, the Communists were supreme and private property a heresy. Seven months later the Government is about to adopt a plan to privatize more state-owned enterprises in a month than Margaret Thatcher privatized in a decade.
But the transition is painful. Economic output in Russia has fallen 20 percent, a horrifying collapse. Factories are closing because they have been stripped of the ability to import crucial machine parts. Living standards of millions have disintegrated in the wake of galloping inflation. External aid is needed, without delay.
The I.M.F. has now stepped in where Mr. Bush and other Western leaders have refused to tread. It has carefully estimated Russia's need, and negotiated commitments by Mr. Yeltsin to institute strict, immediate fiscal discipline. The I.M.F. staff will recommend that the West provide Russia this year about $12 billion for debt relief, imports to keep factories running and emergency food, medicine and consumer goods to help Russia make it through the cruel first stages of inflation. The staff will also recommend creation of a $6 billion fund to help stabilize the value of the ruble in order to facilitate free trade and investment. The total aid package of $18 billion isn't overly generous, but should prove adequate.
Mr. Yeltsin has begun to carry out his commitments. Virtually all consumer prices have been, or soon will be, set free. The budget deficit has been cut from about 20 percent of gross national product to less than 5 percent -- about the same as in the U.S. And a single exchange rate will be created, its value set by market forces.
There is still one crucial reform to negotiate -- braking the explosive growth in money and credit. Without monetary discipline there will be no reliable price system and economic reform will fail.
Success of a Western aid package will rest on the I.M.F.'s ability to force the Russians to stick by their agreements. The fund has already shown encouraging results in Poland. There the Government undertook radical economic reform subject to an I.M.F. agreement, then wavered under economic pain and political chaos. But the I.M.F. threatened to withdraw aid, and this week the Polish Government proposed a budget that fulfilled its I.M.F. commitments.
What happened in Poland can also happen in Russia, if the U.S. and the rest of the Western Alliance supply enough assistance to give reform a chance.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Tsongas, Still Ahead of the Curve

BYLINE: By John B. Anderson; John B. Anderson, visiting professor of law at Nova University in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was an independent candidate for President in 1980.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Paul Tsongas's decison not to contest yesterday's Connecticut primary and pull out of the Democratic Presidential race may dishearten those of us who felt 1992 might see a victory of political substance over style. The lesson, however, is not that the Tsongas campaign failed but that it went as far as it did. Measured against expectations, the Tsongas saga was a triumph.
Unfortunately for Mr. Tsongas -- and for the country as well -- exceeding expectations and scoring moral victories are not what counts in politics. As Churchill growled after the moral triumph of Dunkirk, "Wars are not won by evacuations." 
 America needs a politician committed to cleansing the Augean stables of the residues left by the excesses of the 80's. That resolve has to be accompanied by the ability to create the political, financial and organizational depth to transform it into effective support.
Mr. Tsongas had the right message, an economic message, and it created his candidacy, giving voters a reason to choose him over his more charismatic opponents. His principal failure was an unwillingness to project that message relentlessly throughout the campaign.
It took him far indeed -- much further in delegates and primary victories than a similar message took me in the Republican primaries of 1980. We should recognize its powerful themes. Investment should be emphasized over increased consumption. There is a need for sacrifice, including an energy tax on each gallon on gasoline. Increased military spending and lower taxes will not yield a balanced budget except with the use of mirrors.
I believe that the Tsongas campaign succeeded in New Hampshire -- his greatest triumph -- because the candidate was better at retailing this message than at packaging it for wholesale distribution. In the Granite State, where voters believe they have to meet a candidate to know him, his almost painful honesty could be discerned and respected.
In the unblinking eye of the television camera, which was the means of communication in larger states, that important characteristic was somehow strained out.
As time went on, his novelty was eroded by a growing suspicion, nurtured by his adversaries, that in some Orwellian way truth in a political campaign is really fiction. He unwittingly fortified that assessment when he began attacking Gov. Bill Clinton on the issue of electability. Even the most unsophisticated voter understood that this was really an assault on Governor Clinton's character. That tactic reduced Paul Tsongas to just another political brawler. In any contest simply between politicians, Mr. Clinton was clearly the superior craftsman.
The American people are prepared more than ever to support a return to sensible economic policies. They are prepared for sacrifice if convinced that sacrifice will bring results. They are prepared for higher taxes if convinced the money will not be wasted. They hunger for someone who has a credible plan for long-term economic growth that includes reinvigorating industries that create real wealth such as high technology.
Deeply skeptical of politicians and promises, the public is even prepared to hear the truth. And as the protracted recession, the shrinking of the middle class and the dramatic loss of our economic power to other countries expose the fraud of the Reagan economic myths, the public is becoming increasingly angry and more than just a little scared.
Why, then, will Governor Clinton probably win the nomination? Personality, chutzpah, good organization, good networking, a strong regional constituency and enough money raised early to overcome political setbacks and to survive -- all these are important.
But Bill Clinton will win by default. Not just because Mr. Tsongas abandoned his message and Senators Bob Kerrey and Tom Harkin had no relevant messages to begin with, and not just because Jerry Brown was a supremely flawed messenger from the start, but because the heavyweights of the Democratic Party -- people like Mario Cuomo, Al Gore and Dick Gephardt -- lacked the moral courage and political conviction to fight for their principles and for their country's well-being when the occasion demanded it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Metal Detectors Won't Stop School Violence;
Expectations of Failure

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your excerpt from Dr. Johnny Ray Youngblood's eulogy for Ian Moore, one of two students shot to death by another student in a Brooklyn high school Feb. 26 ("What Will Ian Tell God About Us?" Op-Ed, March 8), leaves a great deal unspoken in its plea to all, especially black youth, to reflect on violence's implications.
There seems to me to be essential facets of the black experience in America that crave, but seldom find expression. That is because the dynamics of oppression rely upon the victim blaming himself for his own victimization. 
 The African-American experience began with slavery. Slavery was extremely costly -- most costly when it was most ruthless. It had to go. The Industrial Revolution brought new indignities for blacks. Not only did they all now have to fend for themselves economically, but also in the South, until very recently, they lost virtually all protection of law. In the North, Jim Crow ruled.
Throughout our history, every black child who can trace his or her origins to the slave trade has grown up surrounded by the most profound expectations of failure. How some black families have prospered and thrived, and how some black children have nevertheless managed to excel, represents not only the proverbial triumph of hope over experience, but a wellspring of creative love that can only be imagined by others.
Today, for most black children without effective networks of personal support, the first complete confirmations of expectations of failure occur regularly in inner-city public schools. By the age of 9 or 10, many a black child has become aware of only two certainties: schools are places where learning is supposed to take place, and he or she has learned next to nothing. Such black children do not have to hear Patrick J. Buchanan or David Duke tell them they are unworthy of full participation in the broader culture. Children always tend to blame themselves for the omissions of those responsible for their welfare.
Of all the passions, the passion for justice may be the most transcendent. That is why the mind that is entreated to "Think! Think!" is likely to do precisely that -- and come up with the wrong answer. The injustice of an educational system that will not teach is so monumental that the infant's search for justice sees no alternative but to resolve itself into a false conclusion that there must be an innate inability to learn.
As for the gun that killed Ian Moore and Tyrone Sinkler, it is something you and I put into their assailant's hand.
 
HARVARD HOLLENBERG
New York, March 8, 1992

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise as New Notes Sell Well

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices jumped nearly a point yesterday on a successful note auction and fresh signs of weakness in the auto industry, sending the key long-bond yield below 8 percent.
"There was a lot of fear going into the auction," said Mead Briggs, trading department manager at Deutsche Bank Government Securities. "When the results came out, everyone sort of sighed with relief." 
 The 8 percent 30-year bond closed up nearly a full point, or 30/32 , at 10017/32 , sending the yield down to 7.95 percent, from 8.03 percent Monday.
 
Gain on Auto Numbers
 Mr. Briggs said the market first gained on a surprising dip in auto sales. Sales of North American-made cars and trucks fell 2.7 percent, major auto makers reported, breaking a string of sales gains for Detroit.
But the early upward move was tempered, as traders waited for the results of the two-year note auction to be released in the afternoon.
The Treasury Department said it sold $14.8 billion of the notes at an average yield of 5.85 percent and set a 5.75 percent coupon. Traders picked up the two-year notes in the when-issued market and brought the yield down to 5.79 percent by the end of the day.
"The two-year was the stellar performer," Mr. Briggs said.
 
Retail Sales Outlook
 The market also took some heart from a Johnson Redbook Service report that showed weak retail sales, one analyst said. The report showed sales at discount and department store chains fell 2.6 percent in March from February.
The analyst, who asked not to be identified, said the market was growing relieved after weeks of positive economic news raised fears of unbridled growth, which could touch off the inflation that erodes the value of fixed-income securities.
"The market assumed a more rapid pace of recovery than seems likely and the auto sales number brings people back to reality," the analyst said. "The improvement will be limited."
The success of the two-year auction sets an encouraging precedent for the $10.25 billion five-year note auction today, but several factors could temper enthusiasm, traders said.
If the market is overvalued, a strong rise in February durable goods data to be released today could shatter the market's gains of yesterday, they said. Five-year yields may also need to rise from current levels to woo investors, traders added. The when-issued five-year note was yielding 6.98 percent.
 
Good Day for Bills
 The bill sector had solid price advances yesterday. Three-month yields were down 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.05 percent; six-month yields fell 7 points, to 4.19 percent, and the one-year bill was down 11 points, to 4.40 percent.
The price of the 5 3/8 percent two-year note rose 6/32 , to 9912/32 , to yield 5.72 percent. The price of the 7 1/2 percent 10-year note increased 19/32 , to 9927/32 , to yield 7.52 percent.
Federal funds were trading at 3.75 percent late in the day, just below the Federal Reserve's presumed 4 percent target. The Fed refrained from open-market activity when funds were trading at 3.875 percent.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Strategy;
NEW YORK BATTLE GAINS IN INTENSITY AS BROWN SURGES

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The battle for New York began in earnest yesterday as Gov. Bill Clinton struggled with a gritty new problem handed him by the voters of Connecticut: how to deal with former Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr., emboldened by victory and ready to roll.
Mr. Clinton's campaign had hoped to be focused on President Bush by now, but instead found that Mr. Brown's upset victory in Connecticut on Tuesday had transformed the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination and left the Arkansas Governor with a lot to prove in the April 7 primaries in New York, Wisconsin and Kansas. 
 Mr. Clinton responded yesterday with a new attack on Mr. Brown's proposal for a 13 percent flat tax, which aides said was the beginning of a renewed debate with the former California Governor on economics. Mr. Brown countered with a bitter assault on Mr. Clinton's labor record, and the stage seemed to be set for a bruising, two-week New York campaign.
 
Clinton's Headaches
 Despite his seven-to-one edge in delegates, Mr. Clinton finds himself confronted with an opponent who revels in probing his "character issues" and delights in assaults on the Democratic establishment. Add to this the discontent among voters this year with politics-as-usual, and the movement of this two-man race into ever-volatile New York, and Mr. Clinton has major headaches.
Mr. Brown, who has suddenly acquired the news media entourage and other trappings of a winning candidate, said, "It's David vs. Goliath, but that slingshot is getting pretty big and pretty heavy."
In Albany, he looked on with delight as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo declared that Mr. Brown was a viable candidate. Mr. Brown, who condemned his rivals as creations of the news media and tools of special interests, clearly relished his moment in the limelight.
 
'The Campaign Has Just Begun'
 The humbling of an establishment front-runner fits perfectly with the script of the Brown campaign. Patrick Caddell, a strategist who advises Mr. Brown, declared in an interview yesterday: "People are being told that the system will be what it is, and it's being jammed down their throats. Yesterday, they turned around and said, 'No, it's not going to be jammed down our throats.' " Mr. Caddell added, "As far as I'm concerned, the campaign has just begun."
Mr. Clinton, many Democrats agree, needs to rebuild his image as a populist for the middle class, an image that he rode to victories in primaries in the South and Midwest. He also needs to convince voters that he, not Mr. Brown, is the most promising candidate of change, these Democrats say.
These are the strategic imperatives behind Mr. Clinton's new attack on Mr. Brown's tax policies, which he declared yesterday was a "war-on-New-York tax" that "sounds great and sounds simple but would make things worse."
James Carville, Mr. Clinton's strategist, said, "We're going to run against him the same way we'd run against any other candidate who wants to raise taxes on people making $50,000 a year and cut them on people making half a million."
Mr. Brown defends his proposal as a measure that would result in lower taxes for middle- and lower-income people. On the CBS News program "This Morning" yesterday, he asserted that the tax plan "will shift to business the share that they have often been able to avoid by deducting their power lunches, their trips to Hawaii and all of the other things that they do that average people can't do."
 
An 'Immunized' Candidate
 In general, Mr. Clinton must walk a fine line. If he goes head to head with Mr. Brown, he runs the risk of letting the former California Governor set the terms of the debate, and being distracted from the larger dialogue with Mr. Bush, some Democrats fear. Moreover, some Democrats suggest that Mr. Brown has "immunized" himself from many of the Clinton attacks, by the very nature of his campaign.
"He's saying, 'This isn't about me, this is about taking back the system,' " said Bill Carrick, a veteran Democratic strategist. "He says, 'Yeah, I raised the money, yeah, I did all this, but now I've seen the light.' "
Other Democrats, however, agree with Jeff Neubauer, the chairman of the Wisconsin Democratic Party and a Clinton supporter. "To borrow a phrase from Lee Atwater, I think they're going to have to scrape the bark off Brown."
Mickey Kantor, the Clinton campaign chairman, who also ran Mr. Brown's 1976 presidential campaign and 1982 Senate campaign, asserts that the voters will soon see the difference between the two men. "Jerry is getting what he wants," said Mr. Kantor. "Jerry wants attention. When the lights go off, Jerry disappears."
There are also clear dangers for Mr. Clinton in seeming to slight Mr. Brown's challenge; he runs the risk of seeming presumptuous and setting himself up for another comeuppance from the voters. For now, at least, the Clinton campaign seems intent on sending humility signals. "Clinton is out there fighting for the nomination, fighting for the votes of New York and Wisconsin and everywhere else," said Mr. Stephanopoulos.
The calendar over the next month brings only three small caucuses and a primary in Puerto Rico before the New York, Wisconsin and Kansas contests; after the voting there, the next major primary is not until April 28 in Pennsylvania, meaning that candidates who falter in New York would have a long wait to recover their footing.
Many of Mr. Clinton's allies yesterday tried to present the Connecticut results as a valuable lesson, delivered early enough in the process so that he can quickly correct course. Other Democrats argue that Mr. Clinton should consider Mr. Brown's challenge an opportunity to address the voters' unease about such issues as his wife's partnership in a law firm that does business with the state of Arkansas.
"It would be a lot easier to answer them with Jerry Brown raising them, than with the President of the United States raising them," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic polltaker.
Mr. Stephanopoulos said Mr. Clinton will handle those doubts the way he did in earlier primaries: "by fighting for something bigger than yourself, by making people understand that this is a big election about big issues, and by putting Bill Clinton out there."
Still, Mr. Caddell, who said he was informally advising Mr. Brown, asserted that forces were stirring in the nation that would be hard to stop. He compared it to the collapse of the Hapsburg Empire, and said the residents of the Washington establishment were utterly unaware of its magnitude. "I think the thing builds," Mr. Caddell said. "Once the toothpaste is out of the tube, it's hard to put it back in."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Allies to Resume Effort To Get Sanctions Against Libya

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 25

 BODY:
The United States, Britain and France indicated today that they would press ahead with demands for Security Council sanctions against Libya because it appeared unready to turn over two suspects in the 1988 downing of an American jetliner.
The United States representative to the United Nations, Thomas R. Pickering, said he would now speed up discussion of the sanctions resolution with other Council members. 
 Mr. Pickering had expressed skepticism on Monday when the Libyan United Nations representative said his country would turn over the two agents to the Arab League, initiating a procedure for eventual trial in Britain or the United States. Today, Mr. Pickering accused the Libyans of playing "a shell game."
 
Libyan Offer Unclear
 Accounts from the Middle East differed on the exact position Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's leader, had taken on the matter. But envoys from the Arab League who met with him in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, on Tuesday night were in agreement when they returned to Cairo today that Colonel Qaddafi is unwilling to see the two accused officials delivered to American or British authorities, as the Security Council has demanded.
American, British and French diplomats predicted that the Council would vote either Friday or next Monday on a resolution that would impose a ban on airline flights to and from Libya, prohibit the sale of planes, spare parts and all arms to the North African nation and require all governments to reduce the size of Libyan embassies in their capitals. It would also ask Colonel Qaddafi for concrete evidence that he has renounced terrorism, for instance by providing details about terrorists he has trained or armed.
The diplomats brushed aside reports circulating in the Arab world that Libya's Arab League envoy, Ali Treiki, was on his way to the league's Cairo headquarters with a letter giving Colonel-Qaddafi's "reply" to a plan the Arab envoys presented to him on Tuesday night for turning over the accused men to the West.
 
Role of U.N. Leader
 Under this plan, the Arab League would have taken custody of the Libyans and turned them over to the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Ghali, who in turn would transfer them to London or Washington. Mr. Ghali never accepted such a role, however, saying the Arab League should turn the suspects over directly to the United States or Britain in the presence of a United Nations official.
However, hopes rose on Monday that the Arab League might be able to negotiate a transfer arrangement with Libya acceptable to the three Western powers after Libya's United Nations representative said a "decision" had been made in Tripoli to give the accused men to the Arab League.
Significantly, though, the Libyan representative, Ali Ahmed el-Houderi, gave no clear commitment that the Arab League would then be allowed to pass them on to Britain or the United States, although a number of diplomats suggested that this was what would happen.
 
Sanctions Effort Suspended
 As a result the British and French had said on Monday that they would briefly suspend their sanctions campaign in order to give the Arab envoys a chance to work out an agreement with Libyan diplomats.
The Security Council voted in January that Libya must hand over the suspects to the United States or Britain and send four other Libyans for questioning by a French magistrate investigating the destruction of a French airliner over sub-Saharan Africa in 1989 with the loss of 170 people.
Accounts also varied as to what happened when the seven-member Arab League team reached Tripoli on Tuesday. But it appears that the four Foreign Ministers and three high officials were kept waiting until after midnight before Colonel-Qaddafi received them along with his second-in-command, Abdul Salaam Jalloud.
Colonel Qaddafi, the accounts say, then berated the Arab team for trying to conduct business with him during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. He said that what Mr. Houderi had said was "inaccurate," although India's Ambassador in Tripoli had been told by Mr. Jalloud last week that Libya was ready to yield the accused men to the Arab League .
In Cairo today, some of the Arab envoys said Libya wanted the league to hold the two suspects in a United Nations building in Tripoli until the World Court rules on its argument that it has a right to try them itself. The World Court at The Hague is to begin hearing Libya's case on Thursday.
Others thought the Libyan leader was unwilling to hand them over to anyone until the World Court gives its judgment, which could take months. A third version of events was that Libya would only surrender them if ordered to do so by the World Court.
Although the Security Council is expected to vote sanctions against Libya by a comfortable margin, representatives of Arab nations and developing countries appear unhappy at the prospect. Yet they are obviously reluctant to incur the wrath of the United States, Britain and France by seeming to defend Colonel Qaddafi.
 
Warnings to Libya
 But they have been warning Libya, diplomats here say, that the sanctions the Council is planning to impose may prove much harder to lift than to impose.
This is because in its proposed form, the sanctions resolution requires Colonel Qaddafi not only to renounce terrorism but to provide persuasive, specific evidence that he has done so.
This means that handing over the accused Libyans and sending the others to the French magistrate would not necessarily lead to the restoration of normal aviation links or the relaxation of any other restrictions.
At present, a number of international airlines, including Swissair, Lufthansa, K.L.M. and Alitalia, fly to and from Libya, in addition to Libyan Arab Airlines, the country's national carrier.
The United States and other western Security Council could demand that Libya also destroy terrorist training camps under international inspection and disclose the names of all the terrorist groups whose members it has trained, supported or armed, including identification of individuals.
Britain has already accused Libya of training and arming Irish Republican Army guerrillas operating in Northern Ireland, and international police forces and justice ministers believe that many Palestinian groups have close ties with Libya.
As a result, some third world countries are warning Colonel Qaddafi's representatives that the sanctions the Council is now discussing, once adopted, may be in force for a long time. They assert that the real aim of the United States is to force Colonel Qaddafi from power, just as it wants to keep sanctions in place against Iraq until President Saddam Hussein is overthrown.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: New York;
Brown and Clinton Trade Blows in New York Contest

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In a political world redefined by Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s narrow victory in the Connecticut primary, Mr. Brown and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas campaigned yesterday for the pivotal New York primary, which will decide who gets the bulk of the state's rich lode of 244 convention delegates and whether Mr. Clinton can get back on a glide path to the nomination.
Mr. Clinton, trying to rebound from the setback dealt by Mr. Brown's populist send-them-a-message campaign, demonstrated that he, for one, had got the message. The Arkansas Governor immediately focused his campaign on Mr. Brown, the former California Governor, denouncing his proposal to replace existing Federal taxes with a flat 13 percent income tax and a 13 percent value-added tax on goods and services as "a war on New York tax." Mr. Clinton suggested that the state's April 7 primary be transformed into a referendum on the tax plan, which is a centerpiece of Mr. Brown's campaign. 
 Mr. Clinton's assessment of the effect of the tax proposal was largely echoed by Carol O'Cleireacain, New York City's finance commissioner, in an analysis ordered by Mayor David N. Dinkins and presented to Mr. Brown on Tuesday as he paid a courtesy call on the Mayor before holding a rally outside City Hall. A copy of the analysis was made available to The New York Times in Washington by people close to the Clinton campaign, but from outside the Dinkins administration.
 
Some Broad Implications
 Mr. Dinkins has not endorsed either candidate. But the brief analysis he commissioned could have broad political implications -- particularly if the Mayor endorses the findings by Ms. O'Cleireacain, who was the chief economist for a municipal employees union that has endorsed Mr. Clinton. She held a similar post for the Rev. Jesse Jackson in his campaign for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination.
Some of Mr. Clinton's supporters in New York were incensed at Mr. Jackson over his flirtations with Mr. Brown, who has said he might want Mr. Jackson as his running mate. Mr. Jackson has said it would be premature for any candidate to offer or to accept the Vice-Presidential nomination.
Mr. Dinkins reitereated yesterday that he might invite some of his fellow mayors to New York before the primary to press the candidates on urban issues.
Mr. Brown, who said he would get back to Ms. O'Cleireacain but had not as of yesterday evening, wasted no time in resuming his assault on Mr. Clinton, calling the Arkansan a "right-to-work, union-busting, scab-inviting, wage-depressing, environmental disaster" governor.
 
Labor's Pleasant Surprise
 Mr. Brown sought his share of labor endorsements Tuesday at a breakfast in Manhattan led by Barry Feinstein, who heads Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Other union leaders, accustomed to bodacious demands to meet the high cost of campaigning in New York, said they were pleasantly surprised to be asked for contributions of only $100 -- Mr. Brown's self-imposed limit.
Mr. Clinton is counting on labor as a central ingredient to delivering his vote in a campaign. He campaigned at the Staten Island ferry terminal in Manhattan early yesterday, and then delivered his salvo against Mr. Brown's tax plan in front of an H & R Block tax preparation office. Mr. Brown unleashed his attack on Mr. Clinton on a train to Philadelphia, where he conferred with labor leaders before flying to Albany to meet with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
So far the New York campaign has been devoid of customary ideological and racial rifts, although Mr. Brown and Mr. Clinton appeared ready to defy a local political custom in which the candidates themselves are usually more civil than their supporters and the news media.
New York Democrats, who anointed front-runners in the 1984 and 1988 Presidential primaries, are preparing to play that role again on April 7 as Mr. Clinton mobilizes the organizational support he locked up months ago, and Mr. Brown strives to translate his anti-establishment message into votes.
Despite that message, Mr. Brown has not been shy about courting labor leaders like Mr. Feinstein, Jan Pierce of the Communications Workers and Sonny Hall of the Transport Workers Union, as well as public officials who are still uncommitted.
Yesterday, at his meeting with Governor Cuomo, Mr. Brown declared that the Governor's assessment that the primary race is "wide open" was a boost to a candidate who, until the Michigan primary last week and the Connecticut contest on Tuesday, had been largely dismissed as a spoiler.
"What Connecticut does," said Norman Adler, a political consultant who is helping Mr. Brown's labor supporters in New York, "is just make the Brown people feel better and the Clinton people work a lot harder."
Although Mr. Brown edged Mr. Clinton by one percentage point in the Connecticut primary, winning 63,624 votes, or 37 percent, to 60,894 votes, or 36 percent, for Mr. Clinton, each candidate won 21 of the 53 delegates at stake. Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who withdrew from the campaign last week, gained 11 delegates.
John A. Marino, the Democratic state chairman, discounted the Connecticut outcome. He said Mr. Clinton remains the heavy favorite, with money for television commercials that are expected to begin next week and organizational support from labor and party leaders who can still deliver in some upstate counties and, to a lesser degree, in sections of New York City.
What Connecticut may also have done is lower the level of expectations for Mr. Clinton, who was deemed to be in need of a decisive victory in New York and now may be satisfied merely with winning. Mr. Clinton refocused his New York campaign yesterday to reflect a vital lesson involving the calendar and the alphabet: April comes before November, and Brown before Bush.
"He's the only one to campaign against," Harold M. Ickes, the Clinton campaign manager in New York, said of Mr. Brown.
 
Low Turnout Predicted
 Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College's Institute for Public Opinion, predicted a relatively low turnout from among the state's 3.7 million enrolled Democrats, 2 million of whom live in New York City. Only enrolled Democrats can vote in the primary.
The turnout may depend in large part on the organizational skills of the Clinton campaign and whether New Yorkers not only view Mr. Brown's message as appealing, but also consider the messenger credible.
Mr. Pierce of the communication workers said Mr. Brown's showing in Connecticut, where he defeated Mr. Clinton by one percentage point, represented more than an anybody-but-Clinton protest vote, but an emerging movement.
"There has been a lack of media attention to the Brown campaign to date," Mr. Pierce said. "When a hard-nosed populist gets into a contest, the media doesn't pay attention until the candidate starts to attract a constituency. Brown is doing what Jackson did in 1988, but this time Brown's bringing in another segment of the left out and left behind that is not dependent on high-tech or paid TV."
That view was echoed by Mr. Feinstein. "We're major underdogs," he acknowledged. But Mr. Brown is "drawing people, and apparently they're listening and that translates into excitement," the teamster leader said, adding: "It doesn't matter what you think about the flat tax or 'Governor Moonbeam' or anything else. It translates into 'let's go send a message.' Now it's a matter of delivering the message."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
In a policy change, the F.D.I.C. is now protecting individual and business depositors only up to the insured maximum of $100,000 per insured account. Hundreds of bank depositors have been unpleasantly surprised by the change. [Page D1.] 
 Sales of existing homes jumped 9.3 percent in February, to the highest level in three years, a real estate trade group said, as buyers rushed to take advantage of low mortgage rates. [D1.]
Factory orders for durable goods fell 0.1 percent in February because of plunging demand for military equipment. [D4.]
In an impasse over providing $25 billion to sell or close down savings and loans, Congressional Republican leaders met with President Bush as other members of Congress squared off at a public hearing. [D6.]
The prestige of being a director for a bank or savings institution brings more responsibility and risk than many expect. [D1.]
Jerry Brown's radical plan for a flat tax is more friendly to the mighty than the meek, many economists say. The poorest fifth of Americans would pay 26 percent of their income in taxes, up from 6.7 percent, one group says. [A1.]
 
Companies
Rockwell International will plead guilty to criminal charges for its conduct in running a Government-owned nuclear weapons plant, the Justice Department will announce. [A1.]
Warren Buffett will leave his post as Salomon Inc. chairman, he announced, surprising members of the firm. He said he would leave after the U.S. investigation of the Treasury auction scandal is complete. [D1.]
Prudential Insurance said it had strong growth in 1991, with its capital base rising 21 percent, to $9.7 billion. Its brokerage operations earned $201 million in 1991 after a loss in 1990. [D1.]
GlenFed announced the resignation of its chairman and chief executive, Norman M. Coulson, and said it expected to post a $110 million quarterly loss. [D6.]
Procter & Gamble plans to sell its wood pulp business, which it uses as a source of paper for its consumer products. [D3.]
 
International
Poland is trying to impose a Western-style personal income tax system on a country where evasion of the Communist-era tax collector amounted to a patriotic duty -- and it is turning to the I.R.S. for help. [D1.]
Canada's Energy Minister announced rule changes that would make it easier for foreign investors to buy into Canada's oil and gas industry. [D3.]
Mongolia, in perhaps the most unusual economic strategy by a former Communist country, has run away with the circus. [D5.]
The Ukrainian Parliament has adopted a set of economic goals that include replacing the ruble. [A12.]
 
Markets
Stocks closed mixed in heavy trading, with blue chips taking a slide at the end because of a Salomon error in executing an order. The Dow lost 1.57, to 3,259.39. [D8.]
Treasury bond prices inched higher, helped by a dip in orders for durable goods and a smooth auction of five-year notes. [D15.]
The dollar declined after reports furnished a murky picture of U.S. economic conditions. [D16.]
Nervous coffee traders sent futures prices into a sharp decline, falling 3 cents a pound. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
Wall Street seems to like the BankAmerica-Security Pacific deal, but some people see risks. Market Place. [D8.]
The New Republic is doing well, and advertisers do not seem to be leery of the opinion magazine's openly gay top editor. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Council's Spending Plan Rejects a Commuter Tax

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The New York City Council released an alternative to Mayor David N. Dinkins's spending plan yesterday that would shift more money to libraries, schools and the police while rejecting the administration's proposals to tax commuters and cars.
The Council's flat rejection of the Mayor's tax package bodes ill for its chances of passing the State Legislature, where it would have faced an uphill battle even with the support of both branches of the city government, aides to state lawmakers said. 
 Mr. Dinkins said, "I cannot see for the life of me why" the Council had jettisoned his tax package. "It surprises me that they have abandoned any effort at the commuter tax in the fashion that they have," he said.
The Council's response to the Mayor's preliminary plan is the first move in the annual political chess game over how to shape the city's $29.4 billion budget. It marks a sharp change from January, when Council leaders warmly received the Mayor's outline on spending, prompting speculation that this year's budget negotiations would be less confrontational than last year's.
 
Pressure From the State
 The plan comes as Mr. Dinkins has been feeling increasing pressure from state fiscal monitors, who want him to squeeze more savings from labor, and unions, who have warned him he will suffer politically if he caters too much to Wall Street.
Under the Council's plan, the city would spend about $124 million more than Mr. Dinkins has budgeted, relying on rosier predictions for the local economy and a new package of taxes that would bring in more revenue than taxes that the Mayor proposed.
Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat and the Finance Committee chairman, said the Council's plan contained "creative ideas that will allow us to lessen the impact of the trauma" of shrinking the government.
But city budget officials expressed doubts about the Council's projections on economic growth and said the Council's tax proposals had no better chance in Albany than the administration's proposals.
"It's easy to be spending revenues when you adjust your revenue estimate up by $200 million," said Norman Steisel, First Deputy Mayor.
The centerpiece of the Council's plan is using $700 million that could be borrowed through a complex bond refinancing involving the state Municipal Assistance Corporation. The Council would spend $500 million for school construction projects and materials for students.
The remaining $200 million from the refinancing would be put in the city's general reserve, freeing money for operating expenses. The Dinkins administration wanted to use the borrowing to avoid layoffs, but dropped the idea after bond raters and state fiscal monitors warned it might jeopardize the city's credit rating.
 
Rohatyn's Comments
 Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, who last week sharply criticized the administration's borrowing plan, said the Council's plan "is certainly a more straightforward use of borrowing" and would probably not raise eyebrows among bond raters. But he said that it would be cheaper for the city to sell general bonds for school construction than to refinance old city bonds held by the corporation.
Besides the $700 million borrowing, the council's plan relies heavily on higher estimates of tax revenues than the city had made, predicting another $141 million in tax revenue in the fiscal year beginning July 1 and $100 million in surplus funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation to plug shortfalls in the budget.
The Council's plan would restore $47 million the administration cut from the Police Department. The money would go toward hiring more than 1,000 civilians next year to free uniformed officers from desk jobs, and would add 364 new police officers. It also calls for restoring $18 million to the library system to reopen branches five days a week.
On taxes, the Council will push for abandoning the Mayor's $110 million package of a gasoline tax, a one-percent tax on the value of cars and a tax on suburban commuters. In its place, the council has proposed a tax on natural gas, gasoline, diesel, coal and fuel oil, penalizing fuels that produce pollution, raising $82 million in the next fiscal year.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Wisconsin;
Wisconsin 'Snoozer' Stirring to Life

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, March 25

 BODY:
"Bill Clinton has been doing fine in Wisconsin," said Robert H. Friebert, one of the Arkansas Governor's main fund-raisers in this state, as the news of former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s upset victory in Connecticut lit up television screens on Tuesday.
"But local campaigns always get swamped by the national results, and what Connecticut did is going to encourage the ABC people here -- the Anybody But Clinton gang. It isn't about Jerry Brown in the Oval Office. It's about stopping Bill Clinton, but it could still be a serious problem." 
 He is not alone in sounding the alarm for the front-runner.
"There's only one avenue left for protest, and that's Jerry," said Bill Dixon, a Madison lawyer with extensive experience in Presidential campaigns. "Bill Clinton had better watch it. The $18-an-hour jobs are gone, the crime rates are going up and everyone hates the establishment."
 
Open Primary
 Wisconsin, whose Presidential primary is one of the oldest in the country, votes on April 7, the same day as New York. Only a third as many delegates are at stake here, 82 against 244, but television ads are much cheaper, and there are other elements that could work in Mr. Brown's favor.
For one thing, the primary is open, which means that Republicans who like the Californian's attacks on the political system can cross over and support him in the Democratic primary. Wisconsin also lacks several of the things that have proved central to Clinton successes elsewhere, like a sizable black or Hispanic population and a strong party structure.
Mr. Brown is "a bit more progressive in a state that invented progressivism, where Bill is sort of middle-of-the- road," said State Representative Stan Gruszynski, who is trying to make up his mind between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown. "People here care more about that than they do about giving their vote to the guy who's eventually going to be nominated."
Although conservatism has taken hold in Wisconsin in recent years, the liberal, reformist tradition of Robert LaFollette retains an influence, particularly in Madison, the state capital. When Mr. Brown talks about clean government and open politics, and when he rails against the nefarious influence of big money in Washington, he sounds not unlike LaFollette.
 
Drawing Crowds
 Mr. Brown came into the state last week, in the words of Jonathan Sender, executive director of the Wisconsin Democratic party, "and knocked everyone's socks off." He drew several thousand students at a rally at the University of Wisconsin in Madison and another large crowd, perhaps 1,500, at a labor hall there.
So even before Tuesday's surprise in Connecticut, Mr. Brown had pulled within striking distance of Mr. Clinton, who has not visited the state this year. A Milwaukee Journal poll of 404 likely Democratic primary voters, published last Sunday, showed Mr. Clinton ahead, 49 percent to 35 percent, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
"The thing to be careful about," said Craig Gilbert, a political reporter for The Journal, "is Wisconsin's tradition of high turnouts -- 40 per cent of the voting-age population in 1988, highest in the country. That tends to help the candidates with broad appeal and hurt the ones with a hard core of activists. It could end up hurting Brown, or helping him."
Wisconsin's primaries in the past have often generated considerable drama. In 1960, John F. Kennedy held off Hubert H. Humphrey here, even though Mr. Humphrey came from neighboring Minnesota, and established his national credentials. In 1976, Morris K. Udall came within a hair's breadth of beating Jimmy Carter and robbing him of momentum at a crucial moment. Four years ago, the Rev. Jesse Jackson drew big crowds at Serb Hall and elsewhere on Milwaukee's heavily blue-collar, central European South Side, raising vain hopes that he was putting together a biracial working-class coalition.
A few days ago, as Mr. Gilbert said, this year's Wisconsin race had "looked like a snoozer." With the unemployment rate relatively low, at 5.1 per cent, the potential for an outpouring of protest had seemed slight.
But Edward R. Garvey, the former California Governor's state campaign chairman, said Mr. Brown's victory in Connecticut had turned this into an "extremely important" state that Mr. Brown would contest strenuously, with a packed schedule Thursday and Friday in Kenosha, Racine, Milwaukee and Green Bay.
"Connecticut said this race is not over," said Mr. Garvey, a former attorney for the National Football League players who has lost two races for the United States Senate. "Wisconsin can make the point indelibly."
Mr. Clinton is coming here, too. He will speak to the State Assembly on Friday and will be back for a joint appearance with Mr. Brown at a Jefferson-Jackson dinner in Milwaukee three days before the primary.
His campaign chairman, Herbert A. Loftus, a former speaker of the Assembly, promised that "Brown's issues will get the same intense scrutiny as Bill Clinton's have, and the first thing to crash and burn in Wisconsin will be Brown's tax plan." It calls for a flat 13 percent income tax rate, along with a 13 percent value-added tax, a kind of Federal sales tax.
 
Tax Proposals Criticized
 A number of Wisconsin union leaders joined today in backing Mr. Clinton and blasting Mr. Brown's tax proposals. One of them, Candice Owley of the Federation of Nurses and Health Professionals, said the Californian's ideas on taxes were at least as regressive as the Bush Administration's.
But other labor leaders support Mr. Brown, and Joseph Gruber, a vice president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., predicted "a rank-and-file mobilization" behind him, at least partly because of Mr. Clinton's record in Arkansas, which has a law barring closed union shops.
As in many states, Mr. Brown has put together little in the way of an organization here. The Madison telephone number for the Brown effort, as listed by the Democratic National Committee, is in fact the home number of Doug Belknap, a psychologist who said he had never been involved in politics. An office was opened last week, he said, but it has no telephone yet.
"I got involved with Jerry Brown because I think this campaign is psychotherapy on a national cultural scale," Mr. Belknap said.
But for all the amateurism of his effort here, Mr. Brown is starting to assemble a coalition of union members who resent Mr. Clinton's support of a free trade zone with Mexico, because they fear it would lead to the export of their jobs; students and other liberals in Madison and elsewhere; environmentalists, who abound in this state of lush lakes and forests, and people who are frustrated with all incumbents and who like Mr. Brown because he is not from Washington and refuses to play politics by the usual rules.

HEADLINE: Prudential Says It Had A Good 1991

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest insurer, yesterday disclosed strong growth in 1991, with its capital base rising 21 percent, to $9.7 billion.
At a luncheon in New York, Prudential's chairman and chief executive, Robert C. Winters, pointed to gains last year in the company's group insurance and reinsurance businesses, as well as a turnaround in the security brokerage subsidiary, Prudential Securities. The brokerage operations earned $201 million in 1991 after losing $259 million in 1990, Prudential said. 
 The company also announced that for the first time last year its expanding managed-care operations showed a profit.
 
Reassuring Public
 As a mutual company, the Newark-based Prudential is owned by its policyholders and is not required to report per-share profits and losses. The announcement of its gains last year came as good news for a company whose rating was downgraded by Moody's Investors Service in January on concerns over its real estate and bond holdings. Like the rest of the industry, Prudential is striving to reassure a public that was jolted by several major life insurance company failures last year.
"The 21 percent increase is an impressive accomplishment considering the weak economy and the tough challenges for financial services," Mr. Winters said. "It clearly demonstrates that diversification is an all-weather strategy."
Frederick S. Townsend of the Townsend & Schupp Company, an insurance research company in Hartford, concurred. "It was an incredibly strong year for the Prudential," he said.
But Prudential, with more than $189 billion in assets and more than 50 million clients around the world, will still have to contend with worrisome real estate investments, which total 27 percent of its portfolio, analysts said. And as a result of lower returns on investments backing life insurance contracts, dividends paid to policyholders fell last year by 2 percent.
The company's statutory surplus, which is the amount of capital set aside to cover excessive policyholder withdrawals and is considered a gauge of profits, increased to $6.53 billion in 1991 from $5.39 billion in 1990. Revenues rose to $42.8 billion, from $40.9 billion the year before, and consolidated assets increased to $189 billion from $169 billion.
Prudential's results were bolstered by the restructuring of the Prudential Securities subsidiary and the rally in the stock and bond markets. At Prudential Securities, revenues leaped 20 percent, to $2.8 billion. They came as a result of an 18 percent rise in retail commissions, the company said, and a 44 percent increase in capital market revenues.
The company's group operations saw a 3 percent increase in new business premiums and fees, to $1.9 billion in 1991. New sales of managed- care plans to control health-care costs rose by 18 percent. The new customers joined a network of managed-care programs that now includes nearly 700 hospitals, 50,000 physicians and 2.5 million members.
"Managed medical-care programs, which we believe offer the best hope for curbing the rise in health-care costs, moved into the black for us in 1991," Mr. Winters said.
Prudential's revenues from real estate services increased 36 percent last year, with the company's mortgage unit originating $10.8 billion of new mortgages last year, up from 84 percent in 1990.
In January, Moody's downgraded Prudential's rating on financial strength and debt securities to Aa1 from its top Aaa rating. The rating change came as a result of questions about the future of Prudential's commercial real estate investments and the company's far smaller investments in junk bonds.

HEADLINE: Resales of Homes Soar 9.3% In Rush to Beat Rate Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Buyers rushing to take advantage of low mortgage rates in February pushed sales of existing homes to the highest level in three years, a real estate trade group said today.
Sales of previously owned homes jumped 9.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.52 million in February, up from 3.22 million a month earlier, according to the National Association of Realtors. Sales were 16.1 percent over February 1991 levels, the realtors said. 
 While the realtors offered their encouraging data, the Government issued a mixed report on durable goods orders, items like appliances and machinery expected to last three years or more. While total orders fell one-tenth of 1 percent in February, orders excluding military purchases rose 1.3 percent. [Page D4.]
All regions of the country posted gains. Even the Northeast, where the recession has inflicted much damage, chalked up a 2.1 percent gain.
Nationally, the February sales rate was the highest since it reached 3.62 million in January 1989, and the rise was the steepest since a 12.2 percent gain in January 1983.
"People who had been watching to see how low rates would go came off the fence as soon as rates started inching up," said Dorcas T. Helfant, the president of the realtors group. "The risk of future increases convinced them it was time to make their move."
According to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose to 8.83 percent at the end of the month from 8.67 percent at the beginning of February and a low of 8.23 percent in January. Since then, rates have risen to more than 9 percent.
Ms. Helfant said there had been some unfounded concern that prospective buyers would postpone purchases until they determined whether Congress would enact President Bush's proposed tax credit for first-time home buyers.
"Buyers seemed much more interested in getting a good mortgage rate than waiting for a tax credit to be enacted," she said.
The realtors' economist, John A. Tuccillo, said unusually mild weather also contributed to the February surge.
The Commerce Department reported earlier that sales of new homes had soared 12.9 percent in January, the biggest gain in a year. Some analysts suggested that sales continued to climb in February as the housing industry continued to lead the economic recovery.
The realtors also said that although first-time buyers had dominated existing sales activity in recent months, trade-up buyers had begun to join them last month.
The demand for homes in the higher price ranges lifted the median price of existing homes 9.3 percent above the level a year earlier to $103,800. The median means half of the homes cost more and half cost less.
 
Big Rise in the West
 Regionally, the West posted the biggest sales gain, up 17.9 percent, to a 790,000 rate. The median price there was $150,400.
Sales in the Northeast increased 2.1 percent, to 490,000. The median price was $143,100. Sales were up 8 percent from a year earlier.
Sales in the South rose 8.8 percent, to 1.24 million units, and the median price was $92,000.
In the Midwest, sales advanced 8.7 percent, to a rate of one million, and the median price was $82,500.

HEADLINE: BRITAIN TELLS ABC TO GIVE UP TAPES

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 25

 BODY:
ABC News and its chief European correspondent, Pierre Salinger, were ordered today by the British High Court to give the police tapes and notes of interviews with two Libyans charged in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988.
Mr. Salinger had interviewed the two men, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi and Lamen Khalifa Fhimah, last November, and on Nov. 27, the ABC News program "World News Tonight" program broadcast brief excerpts from the interviews. Both denied that they had had anything to do with the bombing, as charged in indictments in Scotland and the United States. 
 British anti-terrorist police officers investigating the bombing, which killed all 259 passengers and crew members and 11 people on the ground, demanded the tapes and notes of the complete interviews on March 6.
 
No Disclosure of Sources
 Today, ABC News said it would comply because the demand did not require the disclosure of confidential sources.
Libya, which has been threatened by Britain and the United States with economic and possibly military sanctions if it does not allow the extradition of the accused men for trial either in Scotland or the United States, has said it will turn them over to the Arab League.
In legal papers filed with the court here, ABC News said it had resisted the order to turn over the tapes on the ground that the police had not explained the reasons for seeking them. The court order today said that the police had made the demand after seeing the excerpts in ABC's London offices in December, when it said Mr. Salinger refused to show them the rest.
The court said the police had adequate reasons for making the demand, adding, "The overall objective should be to provide the recipient with as much information, preferably in writing, as early as possible provided this is consistent with the security of the operation."
