HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed; Trading Error Hurts Dow

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed mixed in heavy trading yesterday, with blue chips taking a slide at the end of the session. Traders said the dip was a result of an error by Salomon Brothers in executing an extremely large customer order. Until then, the session had been uneventful.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was at about 3,277 just before 4 P.M., suddenly retreated sharply to finish at 3,259.39, down 1.57 points for the day. 
 After the market closed, Salomon issued a statement saying "that it made an error today in executing a customer's program order."
"Salomon expects to correct the error through market transactions over the next few days," the statement said. "The customer will be unaffected. The amount of market exposure to Salomon Brothers is not material."
Some traders estimated the value of the erroneous transaction at about $500 million. A market watcher, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the way it was handled showed bad form. "It just passed the trading desk and went straight electronic," he said.
A spokesman for the New York Stock Exchange said last night that the exchange was reviewing the transaction, in cooperation with Salomon Brothers.
Analysts said the market yesterday felt the pinch of two conflicting economic reports for February. The Government reported that durable-goods orders were weaker than expected in February, fueling some speculation that an economic recovery would be limp. But another report said sales of existing homes posted a stronger-than-expected increase in February. The mixed signals kept the stock market from trading outside its narrow range.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 192.6 million shares, up from 192.3 million on Tuesday, as losing issues held the advantage over gainers by 883 to 767.
 
Gains in Other Indexes
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was off 1.36 points, to 407.52, while the American Stock Exchange index gained 0.72 point, to 400.29. Trading on the over-the-counter market pushed the Nasdaq composite up 0.80 point, to 619.48, as the Russell 2,000 closed at 206.92, down one-hundredth of a point.
Paul J. Kronlokken, a technical analyst for Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood, Minneapolis, said that a firm bond market provided early support for stocks, but that bonds sagged in the afternoon on fears that yesterday's Treasury auction of five-year notes might not go well. The auction did well, however, and bonds quickly rebounded.
"The unsettling of bond prices helped to set up the stock market and leave it vulnerable to volatility at the close," Mr. Kronlokken said.
Some analysts noted that the rebound in home sales was connected to low interest rates in February and should not last, since mortgage rates have recently begun to edge up.
In trading yesterday, Regional Bancorp fell 5/8, to 18 3/4. Gary Gordon, an analyst at Paine Webber, downgraded the stock to "neutral" from "attractive," in light of the stock's 50 percent gain in the last few months.
Quaker Oats dropped 2 3/4, to 54 1/2. David Goldman, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company, lowered his rating on Quaker stock to a "short-term sell" from "market performer" and trimmed his earnings estimate. He noted that the company was posting double-digit declines in sales of ready-to-eat cereals.
Morton International, a specialty chemical and equipment maker, lost 2, to 61 3/8. Based on the price of the stock, Dean Witter Reynolds cut Morton's rating to a "swap" from "buy-hold," traders said.
Oracle Systems, a computer software company, fell 2 1/4, to 15, after it posted third-quarter earnings that were below Wall Street expectations. Oracle's profits rose to 12 cents a share, from 9 cents a share a year earlier. Analysts had been expecting about 21 cents a share.

HEADLINE: From Princeton to Port Authority Planning;
Public Affairs Specialist Will Help Plot Future for Region's 'Third Government'

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., March 20

 BODY:
Richard W. Roper is a soft-spoken but persistent man who says he has spent much of his life chipping away at the margins of seemingly insoluble problems. Those who have watched his whittling say he has been influential in shaping New Jersey's responses to important public issues for a decade.
The Council on New Jersey Affairs, which Mr. Roper has led as executive director, has issued 17 working papers over the last eight years, dealing with transportation, land use, farmland preservation, the outlook for the cities, Medicaid, state and local finance and school financing, among other topics. 
 A report in 1984 that highlighted the disparity in computer use between suburban and urban schools led to a special state appropriation to place more computers in urban schools.
On April 1, Mr. Roper will leave his office on the fourth floor of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University for the Manhattan headquarters of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, where he is expected to help plot the future of an agency known as the region's "third government."
 
Praised for His Vision
 "I had been trying for over a year to get him to join the Port Authority in one capacity or another, but he was reluctant to move," said Richard C. Leone, the Port Authority chairman. "He had become an institution at Princeton University and, in a major way, is the university's link to the rest of New Jersey.
"For the last 10 years he has put together an unexcelled group of individuals to look deeply at New Jersey's problems and its public policy, and it is precisely that vision we want to use to help the authority decide where we should go."
The challenge that finally lured Mr. Roper to the Port Authority was an appointment as director of the Office of Business Development and Strategic Planning, which became vacant in January when Emily Lloyd left that post to become New York City's Commissioner of Sanitation.
Although Mr. Roper's decision to leave Princeton after 12 years was not expected, neither was it a surprise, according to Donald E. Stokes, the dean of the Woodrow Wilson School. "The astonishing thing is that we were able to hold onto him for so long," Dean Stokes said.
Mr. Roper was not thinking of building bridges but of finishing his college education when he left his home in Brunswick, Ga., to live with an aunt in Newark in 1965. Mr. Roper, the oldest of five children of Henry and Dorothye Roper, had completed two years at West Virginia State College when he decided to drop out and get a job to pay the rest of his way through school.
"I wanted the family support to go to a younger brother who was starting college," he said.
 
Fate from a Bus Window
 He got a job on his first day in Newark, as a salesman in a Sears store, and from a bus noticed four buildings under construction at the Newark campus of Rutgers University. He enrolled and soon became a campus leader, helping found the Organization of Black Students.
Mr. Roper, who had come to the attention of Ralph Dungan, then New Jersey's Chancellor of Higher Education, was asked after graduation in 1968 to help colleges prepare to meet the needs of minority students. The state had just established an Educational Opportunity Fund, partially in response to the riots of 1967, and wanted to increase black enrollment.
"Black students made up only 3 percent of the population in New Jersey's institutions of higher education at that time," Mr. Roper said. "And we had a lot of economically disadvantaged but educationally motivated students who needed help."
In 1990, minority students made up more than 22 percent of the undergraduate population in New Jersey colleges and universities, according to the Higher Education Department.
 
From Trenton to Washington
 After obtaining a master's degree in public affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School, Mr. Roper joined the Office of Newark Studies, which he said was "a kind of think tank administered by Rutgers that didn't have to deal with the bureaucracy." It dealt instead with finding ways to improve urban education and health care.
Mr. Roper next served as a Trenton lobbyist for Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark. "One thing we were able to do was get the state to pay Newark $8 million in lieu of tax payments for all of the city property taken over for state offices and schools," he said.
His next decision was to leave Newark in 1978 for a job in Washington. In the two years he spent as special assistant to Juanita M. Kreps, the Secretary of Commerce, and as director of the Commerce Department's Office of State and Local Government Assistance, Mr. Roper said he learned how things get done at the national level.
"Decisions are often made in isolation, and there is an extreme tendency to believe that Washington knows best," he said. Mr. Roper said he fought the idea that a solution to a problem in St. Louis would work in rural New Mexico, trying to tailor available resources to the needs of cities his office was trying to help.
His next step was a return to the Woodrow Wilson School in 1980 as director of the Program for New Jersey Affairs, which helps Princeton students learn how governments devise and carry out public policy.
In 1981, a major offshoot of the program, the Council on New Jersey Affairs, was created. It reached beyond the university and brought together leaders in government, business and education to search for solutions to state problems. Former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, who served four years as chairman of the council and is still a member, said Mr. Roper "was the contact man and was in the middle of everything."
As Mr. Roper prepares to join the authority, where he will be paid $102,000 a year, he said that he expected the agency's prime transportation and economic-development roles to grow and that he planned to work on programs to help municipalities find solutions to their solid-waste disposal and energy-conservation problems.
Mr. Leone said reaching outside the authority to fill a vacancy was unusual. "We have a lot of talented people, and usually promote from within, and that's how it should be," he said. But he said Mr. Roper "will bring a fresh perspective, and in him we'll have someone who really knows the New Jersey side."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard W. Roper at his office last week on the campus of Princeton University. He is to join the Port Authority on April 1 as the director of the Office of Business Development and Strategic Planning. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Economic Issues;
House Sustains Bush's Veto of Tax Cut for Middle-Income Families

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
The House today sustained President Bush's veto of a Democratic-sponsored middle-income tax cut financed by higher taxes on the well-to-do.
Democratic leaders could not muster even a majority toward an override. The vote was 215 to 211 against overturning the veto, far short of the two-thirds needed to defeat the veto. The compromise bill was passed on Friday, 211 to 189. 
 Calling the veto "a declaration of political war against the Congress," Representative Dan Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat who was a chief author of the bill, said "the real issue is tax fairness" for the middle class.
The House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, criticized Democrats for making "a silly argument that a few-hundred-dollar tax cut is worth the price of a giant tax increase."
The tax cut, chiefly a permanent $300-per-child credit for middle-income families, would have gone to about 78 million families. The tax increase, including a maximum tax rate of 36 percent and a surtax on millionaires, would have affected about a million couples and individuals.
Mr. Bush vetoed the bill on Friday because of the tax increases, even though it contained a version of six of seven proposals he had advanced for stimulating the economy.
The bill would have reduced capital-gains taxes, but chiefly for middle-income families; rewarded businesses for buying equipment this year; granted special tax relief for real estate developers; made tax-deductible Individual Retirement Accounts available to virtually all wage earners, regardless of income, and restored a deduction for interest on student loans.
The vetoed bill would have reduced taxes by about $77.5 billion in 1992 through 1996 and increased other taxes by about the same amount.

HEADLINE: Eligibility for College Loan Program Is Expanded

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 25

 BODY:
A seven-month-old college loan program intended for the financially strapped middle class in New Jersey was enlarged today and extended to families with annual incomes as high as $95,000.
The new loans will be backed with $50 million in bonds to be sold by the state's Higher Education Assistance Authority, which has lent $16 million to 3,700 families since the program began last September. The state expects the new round of loans to help as many as 10,000 families. 
 In announcing the expansion at the Rutgers University campus here, Gov. Jim Florio said the intention was to help the middle class, particularly families sending more than one child to college. The Governor said that more than half the loan recipients attend college in New Jersey and more than 85 percent are financing their undergraduate educations.
 
Raising the Limit
 The program, called New Jersey College Loans to Assist State Students, or Njclass, will raise income eligibility by $10,000, from $85,000 to $95,000. It will also increase the annual borrowing limit from $5,000 to $7,000 and the cumulative limit from $25,000 to $35,000. The interest rate is fixed, currently at 8.95 percent. A rate for the new loans will be fixed when the bonds are sold.
 
Decrease in Federal Aid
 The Governor, who proposed the loan program in his 1991 State of the State Message, said the loss of Federal tuition assistance in the last decade had seriously hurt middle-income families. The expansion proposal came as a result of recommendations from applicants, loan recipients and financial aid advisers at various schools, he said.
In 1981, he said, aid from the Federal Government made up 29 percent of the assistance received by New Jersey college students. The figure today, he said, is 9 percent. Recipients of guaranteed loans dropped from 20,000 in 1986 to fewer than 10,000 within two years. The decrease in both categories results from changing Federal eligibility standards.
The Federal Government has its own loan program, but with a variable interest rate and a narrower borrowing range. Other states also offer loans backed by bonds, some with income-eligibility restrictions and some without, although the amount of the loans and interest rates vary. New York is about to embark on a pilot program through the State Dormitory Authority, which would float bonds that would permit selected colleges to offer loans. The colleges would be responsible for administering the program, and they would also set the amounts to be borrowed. Connecticut has no state program.

HEADLINE: Weprin Calls for Tax Rise For Affluent New Yorkers

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 25

 BODY:
The Speaker of the Democratic-led Assembly, looking to raise the cash he said was needed to produce a budget deal, called today for higher taxes on New Yorkers earning more than $250,000.
The proposal by the Speaker, Saul Weprin, received a distinctly hostile reception from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Republican-led Senate. It also quickly set up Albany's version of a tax fight that in some ways mirrors the debate in Washington, where Democrats in Congress have pressed for higher taxes on more affluent taxpayers to pay for a tax cut for the middle class. 
 Although Mr. Weprin's proposal would not cut anyone's taxes, the $200 million he said it would raise would be used to offset proposed cuts in several programs that serve the poor and the middle class, including Medicaid.
 
Plan Faces Opposition
 Under the Speaker's plan, the maximum income tax rate of 7.875 percent would be raised an additional percentage point, to 8.875 percent, for all income exceeding $250,000. Thus, a person making $400,000 would pay an additional $1,500 -- 1 percent of the $150,000 above the threshold -- in state taxes.
The proposal's chances did not appear particularly promising today. Governor Cuomo reiterated his opposition to new taxes this year and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, declared Mr. Weprin's measure "off the table." Still, if Albany history is any guide, the idea could well come up for discussion again.
Last spring, after months of assurances that they would brook no new taxes, Mr. Cuomo and the Republicans reversed course and agreed at the last minute to an Assembly-backed plan for a temporary surcharge on incomes above $100,000.
Mr. Weprin himself had repeatedly said this year that he did not want to see any new taxes in the budget. But justifying his apparent switch in an interview today, he said: "I didn't make any pledge."
"This is a different type of tax," he added. "It's one thing to tax middle-income people or low income people when they're hurting in a time of economic distress, but the person making over $250,000 a year isn't hurting. And that person, I thought, could be in a different category and I don't consider it a violation of anything."
 
$500 Million Gapxxx
 The squabble over taxes -- as well as a less detailed recommendation from Mr. Marino to raise revenue through a new amnesty program for people or businesses who confess to having cheated on their taxes -- came as state leaders were struggling to bridge an imbalance of at least $500 million between spending and revenues in the roughly $30 billion budget due April 1.
Those talks continued to focus on Medicaid and school aid, but also included discussion of how to pay for millions of dollars in so-called member items, or special grants for everything from libraries to Little League uniforms that lawmakers like to dole out to constituents.
Mr. Cuomo, who has frequently railed against the member items as legislative pork, offered a somewhat gentler simile tonight when describing the legislators' negotiations over the items. He said they were "like the cherry laid gently on top of the exquisitely carved whipped cream" of the budget that he hoped they were about to produce.
Still, while all sides agreed that a budget deal might actually be reached in time for the April 1 deadline -- which the Governor and lawmakers have missed seven years in a row -- there were dozens of questions still to be settled. And Mr. Weprin's proposal seemed to throw a new wrinkle in negotiations.
 
Assuaging Democrats
 Even Mr. Weprin was talking about his idea in the past tense today after the Governor and Mr. Marino looked askance at it, but he made it clear that he remained an advocate. "He still thinks it makes sense," said his spokesman, Steven Greenberg. "He still thinks it's the right way to proceed."
Even if the idea does not come to pass, Mr. Weprin clearly made a move intended to assuage many fellow Democrats who have been pushing for tax increases to offset some of the spending cuts proposed to keep the budget in balance.
But it was a far cry from the tax increases of $1 billion or more that those Democrats, many of whom represent impoverished neighborhoods in New York City and other urban areas, have been calling for.

HEADLINE: GlenFed Chief Resigns; Loss Is Expected

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
GlenFed Inc., the parent of the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Norman M. Coulson, had resigned.
The Glendale, Calif., company, which has been hurt by its troubled real estate investments, also said it expected to post a $110 million loss for its third fiscal quarter, ending this month. GlenFed said the loss would cause it to fall below Government capital requirements. 
 Steven J. Trafton, vice chairman of GlenFed, was given the additional position of chief executive yesterday. Mr. Trafton, 45 years old, had already been directing the troubled company's turnaround efforts.
 
214 Branches in 3 States
 E. Gareth Plank, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds in San Francisco, said Mr. Trafton told analysts that Mr. Coulson's resignation had not been prompted by a request from regulators.
GlenFed is the parent of the Glendale Federal Bank, which has 214 branches in California, Washington and Florida.
Like other savings and loan companies, GlenFed encountered difficulties in the 1980's when it expanded into the real estate development business. The company has sold assets, slashed its work force and has been working to build its reserves. But the company said yesterday that additional action was needed.
For the quarter ending Tuesday, the company said it would set aside $145 million to cover bad loans. GlenFed also said it would write down the value of its real estate investments by $65 million. In taking the steps yesterday, the company blamed the "prolonged recession and the continued deterioration in the real estate markets, which have seriously affected the value of the company's real estate investments."
The increased loan-loss provision and the markdown of real estate holdings will result in a loss of $110 million for GlenFed's third fiscal quarter. For the corresponding quarter last year, GlenFed earned $1 million, or 3 cents a share. For the first six months of its fiscal year, GlenFed earned $51.6 million, or $1.51 a share.
The loss means that GlenFed will fall below Government minimum capital requirements when the quarter ends Tuesday. GlenFed said it was developing a capital restoration plan to submit to the Office of Thrift Supervision.
The company has been actively trying to raise additional capital to bolster its reserves. Options include issuing stock or finding an outside investor, possibilities made more difficult by the failure of the institution to meet capital requirements and its weak financial condition.
"There is a question about the appetite of investors to send money their way," said Mr. Plank of Dean Witter.
He said Mr. Trafton was more aggressive than Mr. Coulson in seeking outside investors and in building up the bank's reserves to cover bad loans. "Clearly Steve won out," Mr. Plank said.
Phone calls to Mr. Trafton and Mr. Coulson were not returned.
The announcement came after the stock market closed. GlenFed stock closed at $5.375, down 37.5 cents, yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Coulson, 59, had been with GlenFed for more than 30 years. Mr. Trafton joined GlenFed in 1990 and was named president and chief operating officer in October 1991.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Canada Lifts Oil Industry Investing Bar

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 25

 BODY:
Canada's Energy Minister today announced rule changes that would make it easier for foreign investors to buy into Canada's oil and gas industry -- a move that may be linked to the troubles of Olympia & York, the Toronto-based real estate giant.
Existing oil regulations, which hark back to nationalistic economic policies of the 1970's and early 1980's, prohibit foreigners from acquiring healthy oil and gas companies with assets of $5 million or more. 
 Because few companies are that small, the restrictions have effectively kept foreign money out of the industry.
 
New Levels Set
 The Energy Minister, Jake Epp, said the Government was abolishing the outright prohibition and instead was setting thresholds at which foreign investment in oil would be reviewed. This is similar to the procedure that applies in other industrial sectors.
For investors from the United States, the level of asset value at which such examinations will be conducted is $150 million, the level that already applies to other industrial sectors under the three-year-old Canada-United States free trade agreement. Other foreign investors will be subject to review when the assets they seek are worth more than $5 million.
The liberalization, which has been sought for years by officials in the Alberta oil industry, would permit a company like Gulf Canada Ltd. to be bought by foreigners for the first time.
The Reichmann brothers, the owners of Olympia & York, the world's biggest real estate company, paid more than $3 billion for a 74 percent stake in Gulf in a diversification move in 1985.
 
Could Relieve Squeeze
 If Olympia & York were able to sell Gulf today, the proceeds might go far toward relieving the cash squeeze in which the brothers -- Albert, Paul and Ralph -- have found themselves as a result of the recession in commercial real estate in London, New York and Toronto, the sites of most of their holdings.
Mr. Epp did not tie the policy change directly to the problems of Olympia & York. He made the announcement in a speech to a group of oil executives in Calgary, who enthusiastically welcomed the change.
He noted that other countries, including various republics of the former Soviet Union, Argentina and Venezuela had been liberalizing their investment policies to attract more foreign investment.
He also pointed out that by allowing foreign investors to become potential buyers of Canadian assets, "we will be directly increasing the prices which Canadian producers can obtain for their assets." This would improve the "fairness of our policies towards Canadian producers," he said, and also help in financing future oil and gas investments.
Because of the size of Olympia & York's operations and the debt, estimated at $20 billion, it owes largely to Canadian and American banks, the Government has taken an especially close interest in the affair.
John H. McDermid, Minister of State for Finance, told the House of Commons Tuesday that Ottawa was working with national and international financial institutions "in assuring that there will be little disruption in the financial market."

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Off 0.1%; Military Items Plummet

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Plunging demand for military equipment reduced factory orders for durable goods by one-tenth of 1 percent in February, the Government reported today.
But analysts noted that without the 19.4 percent drop in the military category, durable goods orders rose 1.3 percent. 
 Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers, said the report "is consistent with the slow overall course of economic activity."
David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York securities dealer, said the report "signals a weak and uneven recovery."
He added, "The real question is is it sustainable?"
Asked on Tuesday whether the economy has enough momentum to guarantee a recovery, the Presidential news secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, replied: "There are encouraging signs of recovery. But the economic statistics are still embryonic. We'll just have to wait and see."
 
3% Growth Projected
 Most analysts project just 3 percent economic growth this year, compared with an average of 6 percent during the first year of recovery from other recessions after World War II.
Over all, orders for durable goods -- costly items like cars and communications equipment that are expected to last more than three years -- fell to a seasonally adjusted $120.5 billion, according to the Commerce Department report.
After declining 5 percent in December, orders rose 2.4 percent in January, to $120.6 billion. The January advance first was estimated to be 2.2 percent.
Orders, a gauge of future manufacturing activity, had peaked at $134.4 billion in December 1988.
The Commerce Department report showed that military orders had fallen 20 percent in January after soaring 89.4 percent a month earlier, illustrating their volatility.
But analysts said the overall trend would be down as the Government cuts back expenditures with the end of the cold war.
"Any region of the country" that had military-type activity, said Evelina M. Tainer of Prime Economic Consulting, a Chicago forecasting service, "will continue to be hurt by cutbacks."
Unfilled orders fell 1 percent, the sixth consecutive decline. These orders, now at their lowest level since September 1989, measure whether plants and manpower are sufficient to keep up with demand.
"It suggests there will be no great urgency in hiring new workers," Mr. Jones, of Aubrey Lanston, said. "It hints that the employment situation will remain soft."
Shipments of durable goods, a measure of current production, were up 2.9 percent, the 10th increase in 11 months.
Transportation orders rose 1 percent after advancing 1.9 percent in January. Demand for automobiles and railroad equipment more than offset decreases in aircraft, shipbuilding and tank orders. Excluding this category, orders fell four-tenths of 1 percent.
The only other major category posting a gain was primary metals, up 7.9 percent after rising 2.2 percent month earlier.

HEADLINE: Asking I.R.S. What's Polish for 1040

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAROZ, Poland

 BODY:
For the first time, Poland is trying to impose a Western-style personal income tax system on a country where evasion of the Communist-era tax man amounted to a patriotic duty -- and it is turning to the Internal Revenue Service in Washington for help.
Although it is tax time in the United States, two veteran American tax experts took time out earlier this month to provide a round of basic training to 25 of their newly anointed counterparts in Poland. 
 Roman Zorn's brow furrowed in concentration as one of the American instructors outlined the twisted finances of a typical tax cheat at a session at this lakeside resort. Then Mr. Zorn, one of the 1,520 inspectors who make up the newly formed fiscal police, sorted through the maze of numbers and estimated the amount of concealed income.
The arrival of the American tax agents in this village 120 miles north of Warsaw is another sign of the times in Eastern Europe. Not so long ago, Poland and its neighbors turned to their comrades from Moscow for expert advice. These days, they are looking westward instead.
All of the former Communist countries in Eastern Europe face similar problems as they try to collect taxes without the tools of a police state. In February, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development announced plans to train tax inspectors from Eastern Europe at centers in Budapest, Copenhagen and Vienna. The organization of 24 industrialized nations also said it would help the countries set up "national tax schools."
In many ways, paying taxes runs against the grain in Poland. Under the previous system, individuals' taxes were paid by the factories where they worked. Officially, people were also required to report any outside income, like pay from second jobs. In practice, a huge underground economy flourished, and it has grown when the limits on private enterprise were lifted with the fall of Communism.
Under the new system, there is some withholding by corporate employers. Self-employed people are required to report monthly to an office where they wait up to four or five hours to pay taxes each month. A computer system is expected to be operational later this year.
Collection of taxes is crucial to Poland's wobbly transition from central planning to capitalism. Until 1991, state budget revenues came mostly from Government-run companies. They stopped paying into the treasury when their profits dried up, leaving a yawning budget gap. This year, the hope is to make up the difference with tax revenue from private companies -- which are required to pay a levy on gross revenue -- and from individuals.
This year, Poland hopes to collect $10 billion in personal income taxes, about one-third of projected total state revenue of $30 billion. Reviewing the considerable obstacles of actually getting hold of this money, a recent confidential report by the World Bank observed with a touch of understatement, "The task facing Poland remains arduous."
 
Privacy of Bank Records
 At the training course, Polish tax inspectors marveled at the possibilities for obtaining data in an information-rich environment like America. In Poland, they said, permission to rummage through a taxpayer's personal bank accounts is rarely granted by the Finance Ministry, and the exercise is typically useless anyway, because most business is conducted in cash.
"You have an easier time of it," said Mr. Zorn, who works in a tax office in the northern port city of Gdansk. "In the West, it seems like you can trace nearly everything through the banks. For us, it's all cash, and there is usually no proof of what has happened."
In Poland, the inspectors face daunting odds. The private sector has well-honed and inventive techniques for hiding profits from prying eyes. Investigators have no computers yet, and in Warsaw, the country's financial center, a staff of 74 confronts more than a million business and individual taxpayers.
A second I.R.S. course is planned for tax inspectors, and the agency has also provided some advice on computer programming.
In the training course, the textbook emphasizes treating taxpayers with courtesy and fairness, but it also mentions the use of surveillance and informants to catch wily white-collar crooks.
That is a touchy subject in Poland, where people are aggressively enjoying their freedom from the former totalitarian system.
 
Furor Over Informer Bounty
 A senior tax official created a furor earlier this year when he was quoted by the leading Warsaw newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza, as saying informers would be rewarded with chocolates or flowers for turning in their neighbors and with cash for information about large companies. The official insisted his remarks were "metaphorical," although tax officials say that since the beginning of this year, several people a day have phoned the Finance Ministry with leads.
Zygmunt Sachnowski, national director of the fiscal police, contends that the recently passed law setting up the personal income tax leans too far in the direction of protecting citizens' rights. The statute, for example, specifically bars inspectors from conducting sting operations, in which they would pose, for example, as businessmen looking for tax shelters.
"I think this is very beautiful, very noble," Mr. Sachnowski said. "But this kind of legislation is not effective for the times we have now. In Poland, this is a primitive capitalism, a predatory capitalism. We should be equipped with teeth and claws."
George F. Blair, the Internal Revenue agent from Washington who taught the class here with John R. Krawczyk, a special agent from Louisville, Ky., said his Polish counterparts faced an uphill task.
"These are very sincere people, and they want to do an absolutely good job," Mr. Blair said. "I think they will be a bit hampered by the tax laws here. There's room for a lot of loopholes. In the U.S. all income is taxable unless specifically excluded. Here the tax system points to specific items as included."
 
U.S. Officers Have More Power
 Mr. Blair also noted that in the United States, the authorities had the power to pursue an individual for failing to pay taxes on illegal income. Such powers have not yet been granted to Polish revenue officers.
At the higher end of the economic system, Poland has been victimized by dozens of sophisticated wheeler-dealers who understand far better than the tax collectors the potential for sharp dealing in a newly capitalist country. The result has been a succession of "affairs" in which the state treasury and tax authorities have been defrauded of millions, even hundreds of millions of dollars.
The budget deficit is projected to be $4.5 billion for this year, and Poland is preparing sharp cuts in the health service, pensions and other public services to stem the flow of red ink. Polish officials say that every zloty lost in taxes will have to be made up through program cuts.
Some help will arrive when Poland introduces a value-added tax on businesses. But that step has been delayed several times, and now is not expected to begin until 1993.
Meanwhile, the new tax program is going ahead, although it has not been well publicized.
"There is still a big unknown whether we will get this money or not," acknowledged Karol Lutkowski, the economist who resigned his post as Finance Minister earlier this year.

He is shown with a group of the trainees during a recent class session in Maroz. (Witold Jaroslaw Szulecki for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Luke Family's Reign Is Extended at Westvaco

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The Luke family has run the Westvaco Corporation since the large paper and specialty chemicals company was founded in 1888. And yesterday the New York-based company continued that tradition by announcing that it had named John A. Luke Jr., executive vice president, to be the company's president and chief executive.
Mr. Luke, the great-great-grandson of the company's founder, will assume his duties Nov. 1. The 43-year-old Mr. Luke will replace his father, John A. Luke, who turned 65 last November. The board had asked the elder Mr. Luke to stay through this year; his brother, David L. Luke 3d, will remain as chairman. 
 Westvaco has benefited during the recession from its strategy of forgoing the commodity grades of paper in favor of higher-quality products that typically command higher prices. In recent years, for example, the company has concentrated more and more on bleached board, which is used in frozen food packaging and cigarette cartons, as opposed to linerboard, the paper that goes into shipping boxes. As a result, even though Westvaco's earnings fell about 27 percent last year, the downturn was roughly half the average decline for paper companies in 1991.
The younger Mr. Luke said he would continue to focus on the quality-products strategy, adding that he would continue to press for new product development as well as increasing sales overseas.
"We have worked hard and will continue to work hard to take our existing product lines and facilities and look for ways, through our research, to improve upon those products," Mr. Luke said in a telephone interview yesterday.
He added that he would also like to see growth in the company's specialty chemicals business, now about 10 percent of Westvaco's sales. "That growth would be through continued product development and investing in the facilities," he said.
John Luke Jr. joined Westvaco as an auditor in 1979. He graduated from Lawrence University in 1971 and holds an M.B.A. from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. By 1982, he was an assistant treasurer and became treasurer the following year. In 1989, he assumed responsibility for the international sales department of the company and its subsidiary in Brazil. He became executive vice president in 1990. From 1971 through 1974 he was an Air Force officer in Southeast Asia. He is married and has two children.

HEADLINE: Mongolia Adopts a 3-Ring Promotional Strategy

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
And now, ladies and gentlemen and children of all ages, the newest -- and perhaps the most unusual -- economic strategy yet by a former Communist country: Mongolia has run away with the circus.
When the 122d edition of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus opens today in Madison Square Garden, its centerpiece will be a horde of 42 dancers, musicians, animal riders and acrobats from Mongolia. Never an enterprise to underplay its stars, the circus has had advance posters in a dozen cities proclaiming, "The Mongolians Are Coming!" 
 The performers make up the first major national troupe the Mongolian Government has ever permitted to tour America. A major reason for the change, Mongolian officials say, is that their nation is greatly in need of higher economic and cultural visibility to compete in a world paying increasing attention to breakaway Soviet republics and Eastern European countries.
 
A Marketing Vehicle
 Mongolia is hoping the troupe will become a marketing vehicle that will attract investment, tourism and trade benefits that will replace the markets lost after the collapse of Soviet empire.
"We feel that the circus can help serve as an economic and cultural ambassador of our country," said Luvsandorjiin Dawagiv, Mongolia's Ambassador to the United States.
Mr. Dawagiv (whose name is pronounced DAH-wah-give) has two family members who have trained as circus performers. His niece, Indra Tsogtbaatar, is a star contortionist in the Ringling show. And his 19-year-old daughter, Undra, a student in Maryland, practiced contortion in Mongolia, where it is considered to be a high gymnastic art.
Although Ringling is relying on Americans' awe of, and sparse knowledge about, things Mongolian, the performers hope to change that. "I think some Americans have misconceptions about Mongolia and Genghis Khan," said Indra Tsogtbaatar, who is 19. "He is a hero to our people, since he united Mongolia as a single state and brought together the Mongol people."
Dashpuntsag Amarjargal, a 38-year-old strongman who juggles 60-pound weights, said, "We all see ourselves as cultural ambassadors, and we would like Americans to know that the Soviet influence is no more."
 
Circus to Tour 90 Cities
 About 12 million Americans will be exposed to Mongolia's soft-sell message as the circus tours 90 cities until November 1993.
"From an advertising standpoint, this is a good marketing decision for the Mongolians," said Cindy Shevrovich, a market research analyst at Joyce Julius & Associates of Ann Arbor, Mich., a firm that estimates the monetary value of image-building.
"Just considering the people who see the show, the Mongolians' association with Ringling" is the equivalent of more than $1 million in national television advertising for Mongolia, she said. "And Ringling's own promotional advertising would be worth millions more to the Mongolians."
While unusual, Mongolia's circus act is a model for the kind of marketing ingenuity needed by former Communist countries vying with one another for favorable publicity and economic development, said Kenneth Feld, president and producer of Ringling. These are "the kinds of things these countries will be doing," said Mr. Feld, just back from the former Soviet republic of Moldova, where he was scouting circus acts.
Mr. Feld belongs to the United States-Mongolian Business Council, a Washington-based nonprofit private trade organization of 50 American business executives and corporations interested in commerce with Mongolia.
Though it was long known as the "unofficial" 16th Soviet republic, Mongolia was never formally part of the Soviet Union. "Consequently," said Richard E. Gillespie, executive director of the business council, "it has been one of the fastest of the former Communist countries to begin setting up a market economy and a multiparty democracy."
 
'Starting From Zilch'
 "As far as American trade, we are starting from zilch," Dr. Gillespie said. He hopes that joint ventures in food processing and manufacturing will be attractive to American businesses.
Ambassador Dawagiv said he had seen a sharp increase in interest from Americans looking for opportunities in Mongolia. The first major group of American companies will soon be making a trade mission to Mongolia under the auspices of the United States-Mongolian Business Council.
The nation held its first free elections in the summer of 1990, established a multiparty system that has 10 registered political parties, opened its first stock exchange on Feb. 6 and adopted a new democratic Constitution on Feb. 13, the Ambassador said. Mongolia needs help because now that it can no longer depend heavily on oil supplies and manufactured goods from the Soviet Union, its economy "is in disarray," Mr. Dawagiv said.
Traditionally, Mongolian trade has centered on leather goods, hides, cashmere and other exotic products. The country is also a mecca for hunters, with abundant bighorn sheep.
The attraction of Mongolia to the Ringling show is that the country "is strange and remote, and there are not too many places left these days that are mysterious and different," Mr. Feld said. Besides contortionists, the show features tumblers and fast-charging horseback riders. It also showcases members of the Monglian National Folk Dance Troupe.
 
Ticket Sales Are Brisk
 Their presence seems to have helped ticket sales. So far, as the show has been previewed in various cities on the way to its official opening in Manhattan, Mr. Feld said, attendance is up 18 percent over March 1990.
So far, "this is the single biggest year we've ever had," Mr. Feld said of the privately held Ringling company, which is estimated to take in between $250 million and $300 million in revenues each year. The company has two circus units, three touring ice shows and other productions.
As might be expected of a circus that has registered "The Greatest Show on Earth" as its trademark, the ringmaster, Jim Ragona, announces the troupe with traditional bombast: "From the mystic land beyond the far Himalayas, for the first time in America -- the culture and the glory of Genghis Khan and the Mongolian Empire!"
Mr. Feld first saw Mongolian performers in Poland in 1984, he said, but the Soviet-dominated Government that Mongolia had then would not permit its circus stars to travel to the United States.
Ambassador Dawagiv said he planned to see the circus this weekend. Unlike his daughter and his niece, he has not studied the art of contortion.
"Though," he added, "it might have its uses for an ambassador."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off on Mixed Data; Gold Prices Gain Modestly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against major foreign currencies yesterday after reports furnished a murky picture of United States economic conditions.
Gold prices gained modestly. A troy ounce of gold closed at $341.10 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, up $1.50 from Tuesday's settlement price. Later, the Republic National Bank quoted a troy ounce of gold at $341, $1.50 higher than the late bid on Tuesday. 
 A pair of economic reports sent divergent signals and underscored the fragility of the economy as it struggles out of recession.
The Government's report on new orders for durable goods showed a decline of one-tenth of a percent, which was attributed largely to a slump in bookings for military equipment. Excluding the military category, orders grew 1.3 percent.
A separate report from the National Association of Realtors said sales of previously owned homes rose 9.3 percent in February.
Analysts said the reports indicated an uneven economic recovery with the housing industry benefiting the most from the interest-rate decline. The prospects for a sluggish rebound undermined forecasts for a rising dollar.
The dollar, meanwhile, lost ground against the German mark on increasing speculation that German interest rates would be moving higher in the near future. Higher rates in that country would tend to increase returns on mark-denominated holdings and encourage demand for marks.
The dollar finished trading in New York at 1.6520 German marks, down from 1.6635 marks late Tuesday.
The dollar ended the New York session at the same level against the Japanese yen as it did Monday and Tuesday. A dollar fetched 133.45 yen late in New York. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.02 yen, to a closing 133.78 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 133.35 yen.
The dollar also retreated against sterling, even though the British currency has been under pressure because of the coming election in that country. The pound cost $1.7320 late in New York, more expensive than $1.7205 late Tuesday. In London, a pound rose to $1.7320, from $1.7200 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.5015 Swiss francs, down from 1.5125; 1,245.25 Italian lire, down from 1,251.50; 5.6025 French francs, down from 1.5125, and, 1.1877 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1903.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Many Money Fund Yields End Week Slightly Higher

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The yields on tax-exempt and taxable money funds continued to reflect the recent slight overall rise in market yields, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
"What we are seeing is that money fund yields finally are reflecting the unchanged Federal Reserve policy over the course of the first quarter, and they are remaining near their lows," Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist, said regarding the yields on taxable money funds. "This will continue until there is some action by the Federal Reserve, but we don't expect any action in the near term." 
 The Money Fund Report collects figures on the tax-exempt funds for the week on Monday and on the taxables on Tuesday.
The seven-day compound average yield for the tax-exempts rose to 2.77 percent, from 2.60 percent, while the seven-day simple yield rose to 2.73 percent from 2.56 percent.
During the same period, the 30-day compound yield was 2.60 percent, up by 2 basis points, while the simple yield was also up by 2 basis points, to 2.57 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Among the yield leaders in the three-state area, the top Connecticut fund was Dreyfus Connecticut Municipal Money Market, which reported a seven-day compound yield of 3.12 percent.
In New Jersey, the top fund was Calvert Tax Free Reserve N.J. Portfolio, reporting a seven-day compound yield of 3.16 percent.
In New York, the top fund again was the Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market fund. It had a seven-day compound yield of 3.47 percent, up from 3.41 percent.
The assets of the tax-exempt funds dropped by $760 million, to $97.4 billion. Donoghue's said the average number 0f days to maturity of securities held in the tax-free portfolios dropped by a day, to 51.
 
Fidelity Tops List
 Of the funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Fidelity Spartan Municipal Money Market Fund led the way with a seven-day compound yield of 3.62 percent.
The assets of the taxable funds rose by $900 million, to $498.1 billion. Mr. Frank noted that institutions accounted for all of the inflow and more, because they put $1.3 billion into the funds, whereas individual investors withdrew money. He added that the average days to maturity of holdings in the taxable funds declined to 55, from 56.
The average seven-day compound taxable yield rose by a basis point, to 3.80 percent, while the seven-day simple yield increased by the same amount, to 3.73 percent.
At the same time, the 30-day compound yield on the taxables declined by 2 basis points, to 3.80 percent, while the 30-day simple yield dropped by the same amount, to 3.73 percent.
Fidelity's Spartan Money Market Fund also led the way as the highest-yielding taxable fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.39 percent.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.65 percent, off by a basis point, according to the national index of The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
BankAmerica: Time for a Bet?

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
IS now the time to bet on the biggest banking merger in the nation's history? The BankAmerica Corporation received permission from the Federal Reserve Board on Monday to buy the Security Pacific Corporation in a deal valued at roughly $5 billion. Now it's up to BankAmerica to combine the two California banking giants and realize the benefits it projects.
Wall Street seems to like the deal, which will create the dominant bank in the West and the nation's second largest after Citicorp. BankAmerica's stock traded yesterday at $44.625, off 12.5 cents on the day but up from $37.38 the day before the deal was announced last August. 
 That is despite several facts: California is in a deep recession and behind the rest of the nation in recovering; BankAmerica will have to divest itself of more than twice as much in branches and deposits as initially proposed, and Security Pacific has continued to suffer loan losses, raising questions about what BankAmerica is buying.
Driving the support for the deal is the belief that it will result in huge savings, largely by eliminating overlapping branches and personnel. BankAmerica estimates it will eventually save $1.2 billion a year in operating expenses.
"We see substantial earnings power coming out of this company," said Donald K. Crowley, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, who is one of the most bullish on BankAmerica. Despite changes in Security Pacific's loan portfolio and the increased amount of divestitures, "the economics of the deal remain essentially unchanged," he said.
But others see risks that could derail the stock.
One is that the savings may turn out to be less than expected. Even BankAmerica's own economists note in the bank's merger application to the Fed that nearly all the studies of commercial bank mergers in the last 20 years "suggest there are few economies to be realized in mergers: the resulting combined banks did not improve overall efficiency or profitability."
But BankAmerica's economists argue, and many analysts agree, that many of those mergers were aimed at geographic expansion, rather than at growing larger in a given market, as would occur with the BankAmerica-Security merger. After Wells Fargo & Company bought the Crocker National Bank in the same market in 1986, its expenses dropped to as little as 47 percent of revenues from more than 60 percent a year before the merger, the economists argued.
Another big risk is Security Pacific's loan portfolio. The Los Angeles bank has been rocked by a series of hefty loan losses since BankAmerica announced the merger agreement last August. How much more there will be could depend on the depth and length of the recession, which has hit Southern California and its real estate market particularly hard.
But the bullish analysts think those problems will be overcome. Ronald I. Mandle of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, who recommends buying BankAmerica stock, said that Security Pacific was "further along than investors might have given it credit for in dealing with its problems."
Then there are the nuts-and bolts-risks from trying to combine the two big institutions. Consolidating computer operations is not easy, and there will be disruptions from layoffs -- BankAmerica has said there will be up to 12,000 -- and the combining of two different cultures.
Because of such risks, Lawrence W. Cohn, banking analyst with Paine Webber, rates the stock a hold. "We think we'll have an opportunity to buy it cheaper," he said. "There will be some bumps along the way before they get this to work."
One bump, he said, is that customers will defect, lowering first-year revenues of the combined bank. Large corporate customers, in particular, that have used both banks might now take some of their business elsewhere rather than be overly dependent on a single bank, he said. Other customers will depart because of the confusion or disruption that results from closing redundant branches.
But in the long run, Mr. Cohn said, the merger makes sense. "Anyone who's patient will end up owning a very attractive bank once it's over," he said.
More negative is Michael Murphy, editor of the Overpriced Stock Service, a newsletter that recommends issues for short selling. Mr. Murphy said that Security Pacific was in danger of failing and that BankAmerica might have been able to acquire it for next to nothing, had it waited.
His February newsletter summarizes what he thinks of the deal: "It should become clear over the next four quarters what BAC shareholders got: heavy up-front expenses, less savings than expected, more branch divestitures than expected, bigger loan losses than seemed possible and a stock price that should look like a bungee jump gone wrong."
To some extent, the results of the merger will come down to execution. Mr. Crowley of Keefe, Bruyette said that BankAmerica executives had already proved they could carry out a mega-merger successfully. Most of the managers were with Wells Fargo when it took over Crocker.

HEADLINE: A GARDENER'S WORLD;
There's a Providence In the Fall of a Tree

BYLINE: By ALLEN LACY

DATELINE: HILLSBOROUGH, N.C.

 BODY:
SINCE its founding in 1984, Montrose Nursery has become one of the best small mail-order sources of rare and unusual plants in the country, and a place I regularly visit on pilgrimage.
But Montrose is more than Montrose Nursery. Its spacious grounds have borne their name since the early 19th century, as home to several generations of the Graham family, going back to William A. Graham, a Governor of North Carolina and Secretary of the Navy under President Millard Fillmore. 
 Since 1977, the owners of Montrose have been Craufurd Goodwin, a professor of economics at Duke University, and Nancy Goodwin, the proprietor of the nursery. But the Goodwins say they are primarily stewards of this historic property, and I have long suspected that its true owners are not human beings but trees.
Billowing hedges of ancient boxwood embrace the large two-story white house and define parts of the garden, separating it from a rolling meadow that in March is a sea of daffodils. Above the garden and its broad green lawns, trees stand sentinel: magnificent hemlocks, white oaks so tall you have to crane your neck to see their crowns, and prodigiously fruitful pecans. Near the house there is an immense deodar cedar, the ground below its widespread branches carpeted thickly with the several species of hardy cyclamens the nursery grows from seed and offers as its main specialty.
But one tree in particular has always seemed emblematic of Montrose: a cucumber magnolia (Magnolia acuminata) growing by the driveway of crushed bluestone just where it curves past the house. This tree -- who can bear to talk of it in the past tense? -- comes suddenly into view from lower down the hill, where the lane passes between hollies on one side, hemlocks on the other. It can be taken in in its entirety at a single glance, despite its vast proportions and the complexity of its structure.
The tree is lovely in every season, starting in high spring when its long, pale-green leaves unfurl and it lifts its thousands of greenish chalices of flowers. The flowers bear a closer resemblance to those of tulip poplars than to the immense, open and creamy white flowers of Magnolia grandiflora, the evergreen Southern magnolia. But the cucumber magnolia and the Southern magnolia share the same sharp, bracing fragrance of lemon and spice, among the headiest perfumes in the entire plant kingdom.
This particular cucumber magnolia, by any reckoning 100 feet high and at least 250 years old and surely one of the largest and oldest in North America, is -- alas, was -- the most powerful in its beauty in winter. Bare of leaves, its architecture was revealed, as in an epiphany. From its central trunk, a massive bole six feet in diameter at its base, it tapered up to a spire like a steeple. The main branches grew outward and downward, but they seemed to have elbows that suddenly defied gravity by turning up, as if in supplication, and at their very tips they raised to heaven the buds that would unfold in spring.
This tree, I believe, was a dance, perhaps of the god Siva, perhaps of the tree gods my Druid ancestors worshiped centuries ago. It was more than a tree. It was endowed with energy that bordered on something beyond the natural order.
I have shifted to the past tense, for the Montrose magnolia is no more. For several years it had developed a noticeable lean, more and more pronounced. Tree surgeons were called to remove some limbs and branches, in hopes of saving it in a severe storm. But on March 11, late in the day and in only a moderate wind, it toppled to the ground, blocking the driveway and badly damaging a huge fir nearby. Its fall was so sudden that it killed birds nesting in its branches.
I arrived at Montrose the next morning, unprepared to discover that the tree had gone to earth. Douglas Ruhren, Nancy Goodwin's associate at the nursery, said very little. Neither did I. There were no words. But Mr. Ruhren scattered camellia and daffodil blossoms along the prostrate trunk. Five workers arrived with chain saws and forklifts and took three days to remove the tree piece by piece to a place in nearby woodlands, where it will decompose, enriching the soil with its substance.
In its life, this tree spanned much history. It was a sapling when Hillsborough was a capital of the colony of North Carolina. Cornwallis's troops, rumor has it, camped in the meadow below during part of the British attempt to crush the American rebellion. In the Dixon House in nearby Hillsborough, papers of agreement were drawn up between Sherman and Confederate officers, leading shortly to the end of the Civil War. The tree lived through other wars and rumors of wars, through periods of prosperity and periods of economic distress.
This tree had many friends and they mourn its loss, passing on the news by telephone. They called the Goodwins to offer sympathy, and to express their conviction that when this magnolia fell, it left a wound in the world that will not soon heal.
The word traveled like the news of the death of a president. Some people even visited the tree in its resting place, and carried back with them a twig or a piece of branch as some inexplicable talisman of the grace and power the magnolia had during its long, long life.
I am now going home to New Jersey, bearing a large chunk of bark torn from the tree as it fell. It will hang in the study where I write, as a symbol of both death and life.

GRAPHIC: Photo/Drawing: The Montrose magnolia, sketched in its winter glory, above, and after its fall, left. (Alan Lacy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
About Death, Bad Dreams And D. Boone Debunked

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 22

 BODY:
Debilitating illness and rituals of death were among the themes dramatized at the 16th annual Humana Festival of New American Plays at the Actors Theater of Louisville this weekend. In fact, there was so much medical equipment onstage in the marathon of eight plays and three 10-minute one-acts that one could conjecture that the Humana Foundation had not only given financial support to the festival but had also supplied scenery, props and costumes.
In a program note, Jon Jory, the company's artistic director, characterizes our times -- and presumably the plays in the festival -- as "fraught with fear and omens of disaster." Moving out of a hospital environment and responding to current social and economic crises, other plays dealt with violence, both actual and metaphorical. 
 This year there was no feeling of discovery, as there was when Beth Henley's "Crimes of the Heart" and Romulus Linney's "2" had their world premieres in Louisville. But there were three plays of more than usual interest. All of them are elevated by a highly individualistic sense of humor and each needs more work from the playwright before taking a next production step. Those three are Jose Rivera's "Marisol," a black-as-night comedy about urban nightmares, the most challenging of the plays in the festival; David Henry Hwang's "Bondage," a social satire set in an S & M parlor, and Marsha Norman's exuberant time-machine yarn, "D. Boone."
"Marisol" suffers from an overload of myth and portent, but it is fired by a comic ferocity. This could evolve into Mr. Rivera's most venturesome work. While some Louisvillians might have been perplexed by the weird urban extremities depicted onstage, beleaguered New Yorkers may identify them as the norm.
Deserted by her guardian angel and left to die or survive by her own wits, the doll-like title character (Karina Arroyave) bolts herself into her apartment behind a 10-foot-high door with 14 locks, and then watches fearfully, as with a click each lock falls to the floor. Standing next to her on the subway in another scene is a creature that could be a twin of the Wild Man of Borneo, and on the street she is accosted by a man with a scorched face. These and other grotesqueries are played by V. Craig Heidenreich, a masterly match for the vulnerable heroine. The play is too sprawling and ambitious to fit into the Actors Theater's small upstairs stage, but in a more fluid production and with a tighter script, angels would fly and devils would terrify.
Seeing a marathon of plays over a period of three days, theatergoers can be overcome by restlessness, or worse, but from its opening image, Mr. Hwang's "Bondage" riveted the audience to its seats. The scene is a brightly lighted Los Angeles house of dreams, in which a man, covered from head to toe with heavily zippered black leather, is hanging spread-eagled on chains. In the subsequent interplay, a similarly garbed dominatrix and this willingly masochistic client act out fantasies and demonstrate that, as one character says, "All's fair in love and bondage."
In this uncharacteristic mode, the author of "M. Butterfly" proves to be a wry observer of contemporary mores and racial stereotypes. The actors (B. D. Wong and Kathryn Layng) play their roles to the hilt, even as they unmask, an exceedingly intricate maneuver because of the technical complexity of the costuming. As the play moves from Genet-land to something approaching a romantic comedy, it occasionally stalls. An hour is too long for this escapade, but there is no denying that the playwright is having fun with his bondage badinage.
The Hwang play is a part of a new Actors Theater emphasis on multi-culturalism. Its companion one-act is Suzan-Lori Parks's "Devotees in the Garden of Love," a drawing room comedy set in a war zone. With its convoluted narrative, "Devotees" abandons the audience in a labyrinth. But there are sparks in it of the limber black patois that previously marked Ms. Parks's talent.
Ms. Norman's "D. Boone" was commissioned especially for Kentucky's bicentennial. Daniel Boone is, of course, at the top of the state's pantheon of heroes (along with college basketball stars). A tree stump in which the frontiersman is supposed to have carved his name stands in the Filson Club historical society as an artifact for the true Boone believer.
In her spoof, the playwright debunks the stump and the myth himself, and turns D. Boone into a guileful pragmatist, playing diplomacy to stall the Indians from attacking. The playwright engages in her own game of make-believe, freely mixing history with fanciful figments, as contemporary characters step through a teepee in a museum installation and find themselves Boone's companions. This "Back to the Future" framework allows the author to comment on historical revisionism and on almost anything else that enters her mind.
One might regard "D. Boone" as good ol' boy regionalism. I view it from the opposite direction, as a comedy that, with substantial revisions, might be transformed into a film starring Steve Martin and Billy Crystal, with Robin Williams in a cameo as Chief Blackfish, Boone's friendly foe. Cinematized, it could, of course, be a boon at the box office.
While Ms. Norman lightened up and revealed her droll side, John Conklin, in his debut as playwright and director, revealed nothing at all. The signs for his "Carving of Mount Rushmore" were auspicious. Mr. Conklin is one of our most creative designers of theater and opera, and the monumental subject would seem to be a natural one for his imagistic talent. But in an act that Mr. Hwang might characterize as masochistic, he unwisely turned his back on his role as scenic designer.
A tiny home movie screen used for shaky projections and dozens of chairs (a tag sale from "Grand Hotel"?) substitute for scenery. In this spare setting, actors speak randomly from the record, with one tourist quoting adjectives like "colossal" to describe the edifice we do not see. Only hinted at in this brief exercise is the serious question raised by Rushmore, whether it was a defensible act of art or a desecration of the natural environment. Ms. Norman is far more telling in her commentary on that tree stump.
The festival's other keen disappointment was John Olive's "Evelyn and the Polka King." No amount of good will toward the playwright for his past plays could justify this work's production. The story line is as tiresome as the polka music insistently played by an onstage band. Perhaps the play would have been more interesting if it had been "Evelyn and the Poker King."
Some theatergoers were touched by Mayo Simon's "Old Lady's Guide to Survival," about a lonely octogenarian who is losing her eyesight and forms an alliance with an Alzheimer's patient. Lynn Cohen in the title role is the chief asset in a play that sacrifices wistfulness for sentimentalization. In Ross MacLean's "Hyaena," a ghoulish visitor hangs around a hospital preying for patients to die. Despite a promising premise -- the title character is the opposite of the carekeepers we have seen in other plays -- this is a work without subtext. Joyce Carol Oates's 10-minute "Procedure" is procedural rather than dramatic, a slice of death as two nurses prepare a body for the morgue.
In contrast, the other 10-minute plays are exemplars of the short form: Jane Anderson's "Lynette at 3 A.M." is an absurdist cartoon about a woman's sleepless night in which she encounters the ghost of a neighbor who has just died. Lanford Wilson's "Eukiah" is a Faulknerian story about barnburning, with a jolting Wilson twist. Mr. Wilson wastes no words, offering an object lesson in artistic economy to less disciplined peers at this year's festival. He also has a warning to Kentuckians awaiting the Derby. As one of characters in "Eukiah" says, "Never trust anything anyone says if it's about horses."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Karina Arroyave in Jose Rivera's "Marisol," at the Humana Festival in Louisille, Ky. (Richard Trigg/Actors Theater of Louisville)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Man Who Missed Steinbrenner

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
THE good doctor was surprised to see me. After all, it had been quite a long time since my last visit. He led me to his couch.
"A terrible thing has happened to me, Doctor," I said, lying down and propping up my feet on his furniture, "and I need help." 
 "Terrible?" he said. "How so?"
"I've had a certain feeling, Doctor, which has created great guilt and angst and confusion in my mind."
"Does it have anything to do with love? Marriage? Business? The gross national product?"
"No, Doctor, the fact is, I think I miss George Steinbrenner."
The doctor sprang from his chair, rushed around his office, and returned with a cold compress, which he applied to my forehead. "No, Doctor," I said, "it's not physical. It's mental."
"You're telling me?" he said, with uncustomary sarcasm.
"Doctor, I saw in the papers where George went to a baseball game the other day. Like Elvis at 7-Eleven's, there had been sightings of George at ball games, but this was the first one actually confirmed. And something stirred in me. 'Yes,' I said, 'it was right.' "
"Hmmm," said the doctor.
"And then I saw yesterday that he wrote some cockamamie letter to the other owners, saying he's tried everything he could to get back into baseball, and he wants justice, and so on and so forth. You know there's some ploy there, some subterfuge to maybe getting a suit going even though he had a signed document that he wouldn't do it. And, Doctor, I laughed to myself when I read it."
"How loud was the laugh? A chuckle? A guffaw? Or a kind of hysteria and rolling around on the carpet?"
"Something in between. You see, I don't think I've been fooled by George in the past. I mean, I know he's often been a bully, a knee-jerk jerk, a publicity hound, a twister of facts and arms, but for all his own misjudgments and failings, I miss him. He adds something to my life."
"Your life?"
"With all the badnews every day, from the front page to the sports page, George made me laugh. He is the master of the outrageous, the king of the bizarre. He is vaudeville, Doctor. Baseball is his stage."
"You think so?"
"No, doctor, please, no more compresses." I closed my eyes. "Yes, George Steinbrenner is vaudeville. He's a pie in the face, a kick in the pants, a pratfall on a banana peel."
"How about two fingers in the eyes?"
"That too. Listen, I wouldn't want to work for him. He berates. He screams. He makes people crazy. When you go home at night from him it's like being on a work release program. But he can also be generous, I understand, and he does a lot of charity work, especially with schools and minorities. But that's not why I miss him."
I'm not sure, because it was rather dark in the room, but I think the good doctor was now applying the compresses to his own head. I went on.
"For one thing, his teams had often been competitive. They've fallen on hard times, but that doesn't mean they won't bounce back. Even the Cubs have bounced back. O.K., let's forget the Cubs. But I think, what's so important about winning? I mean, isn't entertainment the name of the game in professional sports? And George helps entertain us. He is by far the most recognizable owner in sports. The only one close to him is Gene Autry, and who would recognize him unless he's wearing a ten-gallon hat, strumming his gee-tar and warbling 'Tumbling Tumbleweeds'? And I'm sure that if you asked George, he'd jump up on his desk and sing for you, too. He's that kinda guy."
"Does he know 'Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer'?" mumbled the doctor.
"Doctor, please, no jokes. Now, what other owner would enjoy the nickname some call him, 'Attila the Hun,' and go on to read some nutsy book titled, 'The Leadership Secrets of Attila the Hun'? And underline passages, and quote it to people? One of George's favorites from the book is, 'Do not expect everyone to agree with you -- even if you are King.' And here's another he liked to quote: 'Chieftains must teach their Huns well that which is expected of them. Otherwise, Huns will probably do something not expected of them.'
"And what other owner has been quoted as widely as George? Remember when Goose Gossage was complaining about something? The Boss said, 'Goose should do more pitching and less quacking.' "
The doctor cleared his throat.
"Doc," I said, "will I be all right? Can I overcome this affliction of missing Steinbrenner?"
"Hmmm," he said, opening his appointments book. "Will next Thursday at 6 P.M. be convenient for you?"

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Democracy Wins in South Korea

 BODY:
South Korea's voters made democracy their own this week. Taking advantage of four years of reform by President Roh Tae Woo, they used their parliamentary election ballots to shake up an obsolete party structure, opening the fall presidential campaign to new entrants.
No specific American interests in Korea were at stake beyond the desire to encourage democracy in a country that has only recently begun to enjoy it. And while President Roh's ruling Democratic Liberal Party lost an embarrassing number of seats, the overall results resoundingly vindicate his democratic vision. 
 The Democratic Liberal Party, formed by a 1990 merger of several factions, hoped to emerge as a permanent majority force, like Japan's Liberal Democrats. Until two months ago its only serious challenger was the Democratic Party, also a coalition, led by Kim Dae Jung, the longtime dissident leader.
In their different ways these two parties represent legacies from the Korean past. Many veterans of former military regimes fill Democratic Liberal ranks. Kim Dae Jung's reputation rests largely on his courage in opposing a succession of dictators since the early 1970's.
But the sudden emergence of the Unification National Party, a pro-business group led by the founder of the Hyundai conglomerate, broke the old political pattern. Voters split their preferences three ways, denying the ruling party an absolute majority and encouraging new entrants to join the presidential race.
Koreans impatiently await a new generation of politicians. They know how to use their ballots for fine-tuned change. And they now worry more about practical issues of economic management than the old political polarities. That evolution of voter attitudes testifies to the impressive success of Mr. Roh's democratic endeavor.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
