HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Fairness and a Flat Tax;
Citing Justice, Brown Pushes Radical Idea, But Critics Call Proposal Inherently Unjust

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Throughout the Presidential campaign, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California has sought to portray himself as a friend of the powerless against the powerful, but many economists say the centerpiece of his economic proposals, a radical plan for a flat tax, is more friendly to the mighty than the meek.
Calling the present tax system too complicated and corrupt, Mr. Brown would scrap the progressive income tax, the corporate income tax, Social Security taxes and the gasoline tax and replace them with two basic taxes: a 13 percent flat income tax and a 13 percent value-added tax, similar to a national sales tax. 
 He insists that this would produce a simpler, fairer system that would spur economic growth. Among the backers he cites is Milton Friedman, the conservative economist, and some other conservative economists also favor the plan.
But other politicians and other economists question how fair Mr. Brown's plan would be. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Mr. Brown's opponent in the New York primary, launched a vigorous attack on the proposal today calling it a "war on New York tax."
And Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York signaled that he felt the same way when he gave a critical analysis of the tax plan to Mr. Brown during a visit to City Hall on Tuesday. A copy of the analysis was made available to The New York Times today by someone outside the Dinkins administration.
 
Looking Back to Mellon
 Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal tax policy group, says that under Mr. Brown's proposal the poorest fifth of Americans would pay 26 percent of their income in taxes, up from 6.7 percent at present. The richest 1 percent, whose income averages $567,000, would pay 13.5 percent of their income in taxes, down from 28.6 percent at present, the group says.
"It will be the greatest thing for the rich and powerful since Andrew Mellon was Calvin Coolidge's Treasury Secretary in the 1920's," said Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, which is financed in large part by labor unions.
Robert E. Hall, an economist and senior fellow at the Hoover Institution in Palo Alto, Calif., proposed a flat plan a decade ago on which Mr. Brown's ideas are partly based, but he criticizes the former Governor's plan for being more regressive than his own. "The absence of a consistent, thoroughgoing effort to make it progressive seems to be the key missing element from the Brown proposal," Mr. Hall said today in an interview.
The plan that Mr. Hall developed with Alvin Rabushka, a tax specialist who is also a fellow at the Hoover Institution, would exempt from taxes the first $16,000 in income. Mr. Brown's plan has no such exemption.
Mr. Brown insists that his plan would be more progressive than the current tax system because it would eliminate most exemptions while allowing deductions for mortgage interest and rent. This, the Democratic candidate said, would allow low-income people and the middle class to deduct a substantial part of their income. (The plan also allows deductions for charitable contributions, a point Mr. Brown does not dwell on.)
"The 13 percent will lower the taxes on the middle class and the lower-income people," Mr. Brown said today on the CBS News program "This Morning." "It will shift to business the share that they have often been able to avoid by deducting their power lunches, their trips to Hawaii and all of the other things that they do that average people can't do."
Like much of Mr. Brown's Presidential campaign, the flat tax plan seems to be rapidly evolving, with some campaign officials saying it might need to be modified in light of the growing criticism that it is kinder to the rich than to the middle class.
 
Conflicting Spokesmen
 "Where unfairnesses are shown to be in there, obviously we want to get in there," said Lee Newman, a Brown spokesman.
But showing the degree of chaos in the organization of the Brown campaign, Tom Pier, the deputy press secretary, said later today that Mr. Newman was not authorized to speak for the campaign on economic issues.
"What you're seeing," Mr. Pier said, "is the intention of Governor Brown to simplify the tax system. The nuts and bolts are still to be determined, in a sense."
Mr. Brown's proposal is part of a five-page position paper called "Flat Rate Tax: A Silver Bullet Solution for the 1990's." Developed by Mr. Brown and a group of campaign staff members, the proposal says, "No amount of tinkering will correct the built-in inequities and red tape" of the current tax system.
The former Governor asserts that his plan would spur economic growth because it would lower taxes on savings and investment It would also let corporations depreciate the value of their investments in one year and would be much simpler and faster than the multiyear schedules for depreciation that companies must now wade through.
 
Effect on State Taxes
 Mr. Brown says his proposal seeks to create a pure tax program that would not be preyed upon by special interests. But analysts say there is no way that his proposals would pass intact through Congress.
One particular problem, many economists point out, is the effect of the flatrate plan on cities. It would end Federal income tax deductions for local and state taxes and would therefore increase the amount paid in Federal taxes by residents of high-tax cities and states. That would make it more difficult for such localities to increase local taxes, these analysts say, and some add it could also hurt cities by encouraging taxpayers to move to areas with lower taxes.
The study ordered by Mayor Dinkins, and done by the office of the New York City Finance Commissioner, Carol O'Cleireacain, said the Brown proposal would make New York City taxes more burdensome and would spawn a movement to cut local taxes. It noted that $4 billion in deductions were at stake and that eliminating the Federal tax exemption for interest on state and municipal bonds would increase the cost of debt service.
"It would be very difficult to continue our present tax structure without similar Federal taxes," Ms. O'Cleireacain wrote in the study.
 
Praise From Republicans
 Mr. Brown's plan has received more praise from supply-side Republicans than from liberal Democrats.
William A. Niskanen Jr., the chairman of the Cato Institute, a free-market policy institute in Washington, said he welcomed it. "I'm in favor of a flat tax," he said. "It is both pro-growth and anti-government."
Mr. Niskanen, who was a member of President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, said a flat-tax would raise the nation's economic output by 7 percent in the long term and would increase pressure by the middle class to reduce Government programs because the flat tax would increase that class's taxes.
"The downside," he said, "is that to move toward a flat tax and generate the same revenues we have now, there is no way to do that without raising the average tax rate of the middle class."
Mr. Niskanen said that he once urged the Reagan Administration to support a flat tax, but that Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d rejected it on the ground that it increased the tax burden on the middle class.
According to figures issued by the Brown campaign, the flat income tax would in effect be progressive because of the deductions. The average tax liability would rise from 5.6 percent for the poorest fifth of Americans to 10.1 percent for the middle fifth and would reach 10.8 percent for the highest fifth, the campaign says.
But those figures do not take into account the value-added tax, which is levied on goods at the retail level and is based on how much value is added at each step of production. Mr. Brown maintains that such a tax will be paid by businesses, but most economists say it is paid by consumers, because businesses tend to pass increases in their costs on to consumers in the form of higher prices.
The poor and middle class spend a higher percentage of their income on goods than do the rich, and so, according to most economists' studies, a value-added tax is regressive.
In a statement designed specifically to rebut the Citizens for Tax Justice's analysis of Mr. Brown's program, the candidate's campaign headquarters says, "Taxpayers at all income levels pay less in Federal income tax under the flat tax than under the existing system."
Mr. Brown also says the value-added tax would pick up the loss in Federal revenues projected by Mr. McIntyre's group.
 
Would the Deficit Rise?
 But many economists say the plan will increase the Federal deficit, which is expected to be more than $350 billion this year.
"I don't see how he could get a 13 percent tax rate to be revenue neutral if he is saying it will raise revenues that we now get from the income tax and Social Security," said Barry Bosworth, an economics official under President Jimmy Carter and now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
When Mr. Hall, who is also an economics professor at Stanford University, published his flat tax study in 1985, he proposed a 19 percent flat tax. Brown campaign officials say they came up with the 13 percent proposal after independent computations with personal income figures.
Citizens for Tax Justice estimates that the Brown proposal would increase the Federal deficit by $200 billion. It said that for a flat tax to be revenue neutral, the rate would have to be increased to 16 percent. At that rate, it said, the bottom four-fifths of Americans in income would pay higher taxes while with a 13 percent rate the bottom three fifths would.
Mr. Pier, the Brown campaign's deputy press secretary, vigorously denied that the 13 percent rate would increase the Federal deficit, saying: "Many analysts fail to take into account the real economic growth that this tax plan would gneerate. Obviously, growth yields more revenues in the long term."
Mr. Hall said that Brown campaign officials had called to ask for his advice on modifying their plan, but that he has not returned their calls. "I have distanced myself from the Brown people," he said.
Mr. Hall said he was worried that if he advised the campaign he would become associated with its protectionist proposals, which he eschews.

Because of an editing error, a news analysis article yesterday about former Gov. Edmund G. Dinkins, and a copy was provided to The Times by people who are close to the campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton and who are outside the Dinkins Administration; it was not provided by Mayor Dinkins.


GRAPHIC: Edmund G. Brown Jr. has made a proposal for a sweeping overhaul of Federal Taxes a central part of his campaign for President. He would scrap the existing personal and corporate income taxes, Social Security tax and the excise tax on gasoline, and replace them with a flat 13 percent tax and a value-added tax, akin to a sales tax but imposed on wholesale as well as retail sales.
Graph: "Impact of Brown's Flat Tax Plan: Two Views"
 Who would pay more and who less under Brown's plan? Supporters and critics differ sharply, especially on the plan's impact on lower-income people. Their figures conflict in part because they are based on different sets of assumptions. Here is the analysis offered by the Brown campaign and that of Citizens for Tax Justice, an advocacy group that opposes Brown's plan.
 
Brown's Analysis
 * Compares the amount paid in four Federal taxes under current law with the flat income proposed by Brown.
 * Does not include the effect of the value-added tax, which Brown's proposal calls a tax on corporations, not individuals.
 * Calculates that his proposal would raise about as much revenue as the taxes it would replace, but that individuals will pay a smaller share and corporations a larger share.
 * Is based on 1990 income, household spending and tax figures.
 
Citizens for Tax Justice Analysis
 * Assumes that the value-added tax will be passed on to consumers by businesses in the form of higher prices.
 * Adds together the effect of the proposed flat income tax and the value-added tax.
 * Calculates that Brown's proposal would raise about 20 percent less revenue than the current Federal taxes it would replace.
 * Is based on 1992 income and tax figures, the Federal budget for fiscal 1993, and a computer model that estimates the effect of sales taxex.

HEADLINE: The Heart of the City Now Beats in the Mall

SERIES: Modern Mecca -- First of a series of occasional visits to a regional shopping mall.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DANBURY, Conn.

 BODY:
Here, as everywhere, it is just off the highway. It is a great concrete box in an asphalt field and, with just a glimpse, a traveler can almost smell the scent of cinnamon and french fries that fills shopping-mall air everywhere.
It has been five years since the mall sprouted here, one of the climate-controlled selling palaces opened in the New York City area during the 1980's that left the region with, some experts say, the greatest concentration of giant shopping malls anywhere and helped foster a new suburban culture on the outskirts of the nation's most urbanized center.
 
Some Survive, Some Thrive
 Within a 90-minute drive of Times Square there are now 48 of them, with an average of almost a million square feet each, which means there are 2.4 square feet of mega-mall for every man, woman and child in the region. 
 Even in hard times, these are places that draw people. The recession has battered malls across the region, and there are many in the retailing industry who say a survival-of-the-fittest winnowing is beginning. But at top-of-the-line malls, like the Danbury Fair here, vacancies are virtually nonexistent; there are still crowds, and life, in a place that is now one of the region's centers, goes on.
Cause and effect will probably never be determined, but as the malls have mushroomed, downtowns across the region have faltered. Even the region's urban core, which includes Manhattan, has lost some of its share of shoppers, who for centuries have been crucial to the health of commercial centers. "The suburbs," a Rutgers University report on regional malls concluded last year, "have emerged victorious in the regional retail war."
Sociologists and urban planners call malls the new town squares. They are, said people interviewed in a series of visits to the "town square" of the Danbury Fair Mall, places not just to buy but to stroll, meet friends and, many said, to escape the dreariness and danger of old urban centers.
Legal scholars debate whether they are public places that should be open to pamphleteers and protesters. They are, Joan Didion once wrote, "toy garden cities in which no one lives but everyone consumes."
In the visits to the mall here, a picture emerged of a center that is part small town, part big top. It has a life and a character of its own, even if that character is an echo of malls everywhere.
It is a place that draws people. Some succeed at the mall, others fail. Some fall in love and some have their hearts broken there. It is a place, framed by name brands, where the lives of sometimes as many as 100,000 people intersect in a day.
Arthur Pieplow, a retired accountant, was sitting with his friends in the food court the other day. Like a lot of people here, he said he comes to the mall because it is clean and safe and interesting in its own way. And he said he had not been to downtown Danbury in years.
"Everybody, eventually, comes to the mall," he said.
Everybody comes to the mall. But in conversations over the months, many of those who came here talked about this skylit place with an ambivalence normally reserved for situation comedies and fast food.
"To tell you the truth, I hate it," said 22-year-old Matthew Schork of Brookfield. He said it, of course, at the mall. And he said he used to come so often that, for a while, he thought of himself as one of the "mall rats."
These adolescents are as much fixtures at the mall as the Tivoli lights on the food court carousel that is meant to evoke memories of the Great Danbury Fair. The real fair lasted 112 years on the same site before its grandstand and its zany facades were leveled to make room for the future.
Mr. Schork recalled the fair, where his family sometimes ran a food concession, and he said the mall replaced its honky-tonk with blandness. "This place here," he said, "you see the same thing every day, every year."
Joseph Biraglia, a gravelly voiced former Danbury detective who is the head of security at the mall here, calls it "Main Street, U.S.A." If it is, it is a starkly different kind of Main Street from the one in the memories of people here.
Danbury's real Main Street, a two-minute drive and several decades away, was once the heart of a thriving industrial city that made hats for most of the men in America before that industry vanished. Even now, five years after Wayne Newton crooned at the mall's opening ceremonies, nostalgia for the old fair is, for many, a symptom of their ambivalence about malls everywhere.
Richard Lipton, a 32-year-old doctor, was at the mall getting a spoon-feeding of ice cream from his 4-year-old son, Andrew, one day recently. "In some ways," he said, "every mall is a kind of stamped-out version of malls everywhere. If you've been to one mall, you've been to them all." It offered, he said, safety, comfort and predictability. "It's like McDonald's," he said. "If you go in, you know you're going to get the same thing all over the country."
Even though he grew up on Long Island, Dr. Lipton remembered that his father took him to the Danbury Fair when he was a child. The mall does not have the fair's character, and, if it is a Main Street, it is one without a church, or elections or a Hyde Park corner where ideas can be spouted from soap boxes. "I can't say," he said, with a look at little Andrew, "that I look forward to the day we're going to reminisce about the days we spent at the mall."
But among the things the mall lacks, too, are litter, panhandlers, cold winds or, indeed, excesses of any kind. It is private property, in this case owned and run by a family corporation, Wilmorite Inc. of Rochester, and subject to its rules.
The Wilmot family's company is one of the top 20 shopping center developers in the country, according to Monitor magazine, which covers the shopping-center industry. Like its peers in the industry, Wilmorite is a master of what has become the performance art of retailing. A computer insures temperatures remain between 68 and 72 degrees and adjusts lighting to keep it forever at the brightness of daylight, between 30 and 40 foot-candles. On the roof, a huge dish antenna insures an adequate supply of piped-in music.
The crews who work for the mall's manager, Patricia A. Frisaro, remove the wooden benches in rotation to sand and refinish them, keeping them looking perpetually new. Last spring, they put 25,000 tulip bulbs in the parking lots.
 
It's Only an Illusion
 "Everything is literally planned and controlled," said Marc Weissman, the New York City architect who designed the mall and 80 others across the country. "How the people come in, how they go out. They're not aware of it. But it's planned."
That sense of being processed, like the audiences crammed into the bleachers at Barnum & Bailey's afternoon show, may explain why some people feel uncomfortable while they stroll along the quarry-tile floor.
But it may also help explain why they keep coming back.
Across the country, the shopping mall formula has been proven to be a potent one. In a national poll conducted by The Gallup Organization for the International Council of Shopping Centers, 77 percent of respondents said they would rather shop at shopping centers than at downtown stores.
In the New York region, according to the Rutgers report, while mall developers expanded, the region's urban "core," which includes New York City and three urban counties in New Jersey, has lost some of its share of the retail shopping market, dropping from 39.1 percent in 1977 to 32.4 percent in 1987.
"America is overmalled, and New York is not only following that pattern, it is one of the driving forces in it," said James W. Hughes, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University and one of the authors of the report. "For better or worse, malls are the focal points of our communities."
A survey conducted for The News-Times of Danbury found that in a multicounty area that stretches from Kent, Conn., in the north to South Salem in New York's Westchester County, more than 7 of every 10 residents go to the Danbury Fair Mall at least once every month.
"It's like a circus, the colors that you see in a circus, the people that you see," said David Busman, 69, of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. "It's entertaining."
It is a 1.3-million-square-foot, seven-day-a-week show. Under the big top are the selling floors of the "anchors" -- Sears, Lord & Taylor, G. Fox, Macy's and J. C. Penney. The sideshows are 215 smaller shops dominated by scores of household names: Banana Republic, The Gap, Disney.
Together, with Wilmorite's staff, the retailers practice the art of illusion. "Everything's good," said Mr. Weissman, the architect. "The stores are good. The mall is good. The food court is good. It's supposed to provoke new buying ideas."
And among the mall's people, failure does not make polite conversation. When it comes, it is usually quick and painful, and no evidence remains at the scene. This winter, the seven employees of Sterling Optical were repeatedly assured by their managers that the company's bankruptcy would not affect their store. Then, in an hour one morning, someone came from the regional office, swept all the frames into boxes and told them all they were dismissed.
For a year, down at the end of one of the mall's aisles, Eugene C. Cushman, a lawyer, and his partner, Richard Kushman, a baker, struggled against $250,000 set-up costs and an annual rent of more than $40,000 for 1,000 square feet. They thought their bakery, Benjamin Rigby's Ruggelah Factory, might be a hit everywhere, and they thought the mall's high traffic would justify costs that are many times greater than they are in most suburban downtowns.
Mr. Cushman and Mr. Kushman lost every cent they invested before they gave up. And now, it is not possible to tell exactly where it was that they had hoped to launch an empire. To any budding entrepreneur, Mr. Cushman offered this advice: "Don't go in the mall."
Sometimes, the effort of the performance is exhausting. Lili Kyritsis, 29, rents 520 square feet on the upper level for her Noah's Arc, which specializes in plush stuffed animals. Her marketing strategy, Ms. Kyritsis explained, involves encouraging hugs of the product.
Out there on those 520 square feet, she said, it is supposed to look easy. The customers do not see the carloads of boxes that have to be unloaded, they do not know about the loan on her parent's house. They do not see her late at night, when she gets so tired that she falls asleep on the cold mall walkway, as happened this Christmas season.
Not long ago, she said, a wealthy couple wandered in. They were so charmed that they began wondering aloud whether they could buy a shop like this for their daughter.
"They just saw me all dressed up and I'm having a good time," Ms. Kyritsis said. "And that's all they saw. They didn't see anything that went into it."
But when she was next seen, Ms. Kyritsis was back in character, out cuddling on the sales floor.
Mr. Weissman, the architect, said, "You try to get people to perceive certain things without noticing it: comfort, playfulness, a desire to keep shopping."

HEADLINE: PENTAGON SEEKING 140,000 REDUCTION IN RESERVE FORCES

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Challenging one of Congress's political sacred cows, the Defense Department today proposed eliminating 140,000 military reservist positions in the next two years to balance cuts already made in the shrinking active armed forces.
Lawmakers have traditionally shielded the National Guard and service Reserves from deep cuts, partly because of the economic benefit their constituents reap from the part-time salaries and local armories. 
 On Capitol Hill today, Republicans and Democrats criticized the military strategy, and some Democrats accused the Bush Administration of seeking political advantage from the reductions, which would affect 830 Guard and Reserve units in all 50 states. There are a total of 1.2 million members in the National Guard and the service Reserves.
 
$20 Billion in 5 Years
 Over the next five years, the Pentagon wants to reduce reservists by 234,000 positions, at a savings of $20 billion. Congress would have to approve any cuts.
The outcome of the struggle between Congress and the Pentagon over reservists will not only shape the future makeup of the United States military; it also promises to mark one of the strongest clashes of wills over competing strategies to shrink the armed forces in the post-cold-war world.
"The Congress cannot have it both ways," Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said at a news conference. "They cannot tell us we have to cut the defense budget and then object every time we move to cut the defense budget."
 
No Longer Needed
 Mr. Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said nearly 80 percent of the Reserve units designated for cuts were support troops for active-duty forces that have been withdrawn from Europe and are no longer needed.
New York State would lose 9,865 reservist positions, about 18 percent of all reservists in the state; New Jersey would lose 4,725 reservist positions, about 20 percent of all positions in the state, and Connecticut would lose 2,836 positions, about 27 percent of reservists there.
Lawmakers said they were analyzing the proposed cuts. The Defense Department proposed the reductions -- 33,000 in the current fiscal year and 107,000 in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 -- in January, but today it presented the first details of what specific units would be cut.
"What I want to do is examine very closely whether they are cutting the Guard and Reserve in order to save funds, or in order to assign those missions to active-duty forces," said Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee.
Some lawmakers have urged the military to move some active duty units into the Reserves, where their maintenance costs are 25 to 80 percent of active forces.
 
Big Economic Losses
 Representative G. V. Montgomery, Democrat of Mississippi, a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee and a major supporter of the Guard and Reserves, said the proposed cuts would affect one out of every three Guard armories in the country. Mr. Montgomery said a 150-person armory pumps an average of $2 million a year into a local economy.
The clash over reservists recalls battles between Congress and the Pentagon in the past three years over the closing of military bases. After a hotly disputed first round of closings in 1988, Congress gave its blessing to a Federal commission's recommendations and agreed last year to close 34 military installations around the country.
The states with the largest proposed reservist cuts were California, with the loss of 12,775 positions; New York, 9,865; Massachusetts, 8,473; Michigan, 7,212; Ohio, 8,041; Wisconsin, 6,546, and Illinois, 5,879. Hawaii would lose only 7 reservists.
General Powell said New England would suffer the steepest proportional reductions, largely because population declines in the region have left many Reserve units there scrambling to fill positions. Under the proposal, Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont would lose from 26 percent to 37 percent of all their reservists.
Mr. Cheney rebutted charges of playing politics with the cuts, saying, "I did not look to see to whether we were hitting Republican districts or Democratic districts."
But he was clearly trying to make Congress feel the pain of military reductions. In recent weeks, the Secretary and General Powell have warned Congress against cutting active-duty forces faster than the 25 percent cut by 1995 that the Pentagon has planned.
 
Conflict Over Budget
 The House, which favors deeper military budget cuts in the fiscal year 1993, and the Senate, which may not, appear to be on a collision course over further reductions. Mr. Nunn, for example, has recommended against further cuts in President Bush's proposed $281 billion military budget for the fiscal year 1993. But Mr. Nunn said he favored reducing military spending by $80 billion to $85 billion over the next five years, $30 to $35 billion more than Mr. Bush has proposed.
House members favor deeper cuts than Mr. Nunn proposed over the next five years.
In addition to hurting local communities, the reductions would hurt individual families. Reservists earn about $5,000 to $6,000 a year, about 20 percent of the salary of their active-duty counterparts, for training one weekend a month and two weeks a year. Reservists are also eligible for education benefits.
The Army National Guard and Reserve would lose more than 125,000 positions in the next two years. The Navy and Marine Corps Reserve would lose about 13,000 positions. The Air Force Reserve and Air National Guard would lose only 742 positions, mainly because reservist pilots are picking up the job of flying fuel tankers that used to be handled by active-duty pilots.
Mr. Cheney said he regretted the reductions, but added that the Pentagon was a military organization and "not a social welfare agency."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
White House Sees Trips As Way to Revive Bush

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The White House is counting on a series of foreign trips and diplomatic events in coming months to resurrect foreign policy as a campaign issue and reassert President Bush's primacy in world affairs before the fall election.
For Mr. Bush and his advisers, the effort is in part an attempt to redirect the political debate as the White House veers between campaign themes in its search for an approach that will cure Mr. Bush's political problems. 
 It is also an exercise in repairing the damage from frittering away Mr. Bush's greatest political strength on a disastrous trip to Japan, a hesitant approach to the breakup of the Soviet Union and by continuing to permit Saddam Hussein to thumb his nose at Mr. Bush from Baghdad.
The White House's attempts to exploit trade, the Persian Gulf war and other foreign-policy issues in the campaign have fallen flat. But so has its retreat into domestic affairs. Weeks of talking about the economy have failed to help Mr. Bush recover from his political plunge, a problem driven painfully home once again to Bush advisers by the 33 percent vote against him in the Connecticut primary on Tuesday.
 
Push for Foreign Affairs
 Once criticized for spending too much time on foreign affairs, Mr. Bush is now under fire from critics who say he has gone too far in the other direction, that his fear of Patrick J. Buchanan's isolationist campaign has, for example, hobbled the Administration's efforts to produce an aid package for the former Soviet republics.
Mr. Bush is being urged to re-engage in foreign affairs by some of his advisers and outsiders, including former President Richard M. Nixon, who chastised Mr. Bush recently for being too slow to provide aid to the former Soviet republics.
Mr. Nixon's prodding, which clearly irritated the White House, was all the more sharp since Mr. Nixon proved so adept at using his diplomatic schedule in the 1972 campaign, during which he went to China, signed a treaty with the Soviet Union on limiting nuclear weapons and moved to wrap up negotiations to end the Vietnam War.
Some Administration officials said political considerations had distracted the White House from foreign affairs, putting issues like aid to Russia on a "back burner." One official said, "The domestic side of the White House and the political operation are really driving things in a way they never did before."
 
Words of Uncertainty
 The White House strenuously denies that the campaign is hurting foreign policy. But Administration officials acknowledge that politics is now more tightly woven than ever with foreign affairs.
The President is clearly uncertain how much he can afford to concentrate on foreign affairs and travel abroad during this election year. His indecision was evident this week as he mused aloud about how hard it was to make up his mind about going to the United Nations environmental conference in June in Brazil, where Democratic lawmakers and a host of foreign leaders want him to sign an antipollution treaty that he does not want to sign.
Many Republican strategists say they believe it is imperative that foreign policy return to the political stage and that the worst thing Mr. Bush could do is to appear hesitant again.
"They got snake bit, but they have to get back into it," said a senior Republican adviser. "It's his strength and it's a perfect way to show you are governing. He ought to lead with it and do it in a style to which he's accustomed, really stepping out front and center and acting like the leader of the world."
Between mid-June and mid-July, Mr. Bush will meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin in the first Russian-American summit meeting, go to Munich for a meeting of the seven biggest industrialized democracies, visit Poland and probably attend the Brazil conference and a European security meeting in Helsinki, Finland. Campaign strategists make no secret of their delight that that schedule will end just before the Democratic National Convention in New York City.
"We need to spend the next months talking about the domestic agenda, but we need at some point in the campaign to emphasize his foreign-policy accomplishments and credentials," said Charles Black, senior adviser to the Bush campaign. "There's enough on the plate that we can have a few weeks of foreign policy, and the timing is just right."
But Administration officials fear the Brazil conference could prove to be a political trap.
 
'A North-South Fight'
 "For political reasons, we'll probably have to go to show he's got an environmental program," an official said. "But we're afraid of the conference turning into a North-South fight with us cast as the ogre of the North with no environmental agenda."
The Munich meeting should be an opportunity for Mr. Bush to play the role of leader in the club of industrialized nations. But Mr. Bush is facing political and policy problems that could taint the conference.
For one thing, the meeting is likely to be dominated by the subject of aid to the former Soviet Union, and Mr. Bush's political advisers are worried about inflaming the strong sentiment against foreign aid that has been evident in the campaign so far.
The White House is reviewing State Department proposals for further financial assistance to the former Soviet republics, including a proposed ruble stabilization fund. But such a fund would require hundreds of millions of dollars more from an Administration that is already having trouble coming up with the $645 million in aid it pledged in January.
Not only is the White House concerned about how additional aid could affect the election, but the Administration and Congress will also be hard pressed simply to find any more money. Mr. Bush has committed himself to the 1990 budget agreement, which prevents him from taking it from one obvious source, the Pentagon budget.
Beyond that, Mr. Yeltsin is clamoring to attend the meeting in Munich, backed by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany. Mr. Bush does not want to snub Mr. Yeltsin, but officials said the United States is not very enthusiastic about inviting him, since it would merely open the door for the leaders of Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan to demand invitations as well.
Mr. Yeltsin's visit to the United States in mid-June seems tailor made as a campaign photo opportunity, Republican strategists said, as long as Mr. Bush can pull it off without making it seem like too crass an attempt to create a photo opportunity.
"An event like that shows Presidential stature on a turf that Bush is familiar with and comfortable with, not like domestic policy," one said. "But he must not give it a partisan or political orientation. He must govern. He must not campaign with foreign policy. When he goes overseas, or sees Yeltsin, he has to be President."

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Bill Would Open Kennedy Death Files

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Leading lawmakers from both houses of Congress today introduced legislation to make public almost everything in Government files on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963.
Representative Louis Stokes, the Ohio Democrat who headed the House investigation into the killing in the late 1970's, said the measure was supported by Congressional leaders and had no discernible opposition. "This resolution is going to sail through," he predicted. 
 Senator David L. Boren, the Oklahoma Democrat who heads the Senate Intelligence Committee, said he had been assured of cooperation by the directors of the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He predicted that "99.999999999 percent of the documents" in Government files would be fully released.
Under the legislation, a five-member commission would be appointed by Federal judges to rule on whether information could be deleted or withheld. None of the panel members could be Government employees or have been involved with previous investigations of the assassinations.
 
2 Years for Disclosure
 The commission would have two years to see to the release of files from the House Assassinations Committee, the Warren Commission and any material held by other Government agencies. The bill urges Russian authorities to make public information in the files of the defunct K.G.B. and the G.R.U., domestic and military intelligence agencies of the Soviet Union.
The only grounds allowed for continued secrecy would be to protect personnel records of previous investigations, cases in which a current intelligence agent or informer's identity would be disclosed, where a current intelligence gathering method would be compromised, and where there would be a severe invasion of privacy of a living person. Some details of the autopsy of President Kennedy would also be kept from public display, Mr. Boren said.
Both leaders, and others of both parties who joined them, said it was important to make the information public to dispel suspicion, especially among young people whose view of the event came from Oliver Stone's movie "J.F.K.," which suggests that the assassination was plotted by the Government to keep the President from halting the Vietnam War.
Mr. Stokes said he doubted the files would provide any sensations. "I can assure you we didn't seal up any smoking gun in our files," he said.
 
Measure on Forests
 On the Senate floor today, an overwhelming majority approved a measure that could begin to decide the fate of the nation's last stands of virgin forests. It would carve up more than six million acres of timberland in Montana into tracts to be preserved and other tracts eligible to be cut.
The ambitious proposal sets out broad goals for managing timberlands in 10 national forests in the state. The compromise measure was adopted by a vote of 75 to 22.
This bill was developed by Montana's two Senators, Max Baucus, a Democrat, and Conrad Burns, a Republican. But Montana's Representatives, Ron Marlenee, a Republican, and Pat Williams, a Democrat, have both expressed reservations. Both environmentalists and timber companies have said they were disappointed in this bill.
The measure joins several others the House is set to consider this spring over cutting the old growth forests of the West.
The Senate bill calls for setting aside 1.2 million acres as permanent wilderness, diverting another one million acres as recreational areas and regions off limits to cutting, and designating 4 million acres to be managed by the Forest Service for timber harvesting and other industrial development.
 
America's 'Marshall Plan'
 Congress's Joint Economic Committee called for a "Marshall Plan for America" to strengthen the nation so it can compete more effectively against Japan and Germany.
The committee said cuts in the military budget should be invested in areas like high-speed rail, air traffic control systems and a nationwide data communications network. Under the 1990 budget act, such shifts from military spending cannot be made until next year; the Senate tonight killed a Democrtaic effort that would have allowed the transfers this year. House leaders have repeatedly put off votes on a companion proposal because they cannot find enough support to pass it.
Also today, the Congressional Budget Office issued a report analyzing President Bush's budget, saying it would have little effect on the outlook for the Federal deficit. It said the President's proposals would slow the accumulation of the Federal debt by just $3 billion over the next five years.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Edward H. Fleischman resigned abruptly from the S.E.C. The agency's senior commissioner and its most vocal in-house critic, he cited frustrations over his limited impact and many sharp disagreements with the chairman, Richard Breeden. [D1.]
The U.S. economy edged up just 0.4 percent at an annual rate in the final three months of last year, an even weaker pace than previously calculated, the Government said. [D1.] 
 The Senate passed a bill providing $25 billion more for S.&L. bailouts, after hours of lobbying. [D2.]
Initial claims for jobless benefits climbed by 15,000 in the second week of March, the Labor Dept. said. [D2.]
To hear one car dealer tell it, sales are so slow it is hard to keep cars on the lot, pay salespeople and keep the showroom roof from leaking. [D1.]
 
Companies
Salomon's austerity does not appear to begin at home. Since July, the firm has been paying $1,000 a day for a "temporary residence" in Manhattan for Deryck C. Maughan, Warren Buffett's No. 2 man. [D1.]
Ariad Pharmaceuticals, a new biotech company with only about a dozen employees and with products years away from reaching the market, has raised $46 million in the largest start-up financing in the industry's history. [D3.]
Topps said it planned to start publishing comics in October. The company, the top seller of baseball cards, would not disclose the star of its first issues. [D3.]

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

THE LIFE OF A MALL
It has been five years since opening of the Danbury Fair Mall, one of the climate-controlled selling palaces opened in the New York City area during the 1980's that left the region with, some experts say, the greatest concentration of giant shopping malls anywhere and helped foster a new suburban culture in the nation's most urban area. And while the recession has battered malls across the region, at top-of-the-line like the Danbury Fair, vacancies are virtually nonexistent; there are still crowds, and life, in a place that is now one of the region's centers, goes on. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
LOOKING BEYOND THE NUMBERS
With reported crime down in every major category in New York City last year for the first time since the early Eisenhower years, police officials are asking themselves: Did we do something right? Experts agree that it is too soon to say. But the provisional answer appears to be yes. News analysis, B3.
 
TOUGH TIMES FOR THE SHERIFF
New York City's sheriff, Phillip A. Crimaldi, came under fire this week for his aggressive campaign to crack down on parking-ticket scofflaws through such hard-nosed tactics as seizing their cars and leaving them stranded on the street. B3.
 
OFF-DUTY POLICEMAN KILLED
An off-duty New York City Health and Hospitals police captain was shot and killed, apparently during a robbery, in the lobby of his Queens apartment building. The officer died a little more than 30 minutes later at the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst. B3.
 
HOMELESS MAN SET AFIRE ON SUBWAY
A 39-year-old homeless man was set on fire and severely burned as he slept on a subway train passing through the Bronx, the transit police said. It was the most serious in a series of similar attacks on homeless people on New York City trains this year, and advocates for the homeless said the attack reflected growing intolerance of homeless people. B3.
Officials deny delay in handling of ambulances at plane crash site. B2.
Council approves plan for commodities exchange. B3.

COURT RULES FOR ALLSTATE
In a ruling that raised questions about the state's method of regulating automobile insurance rates, a court has allowed New Jersey's largest insurer, the Allstate Insurance Company, to raise its rates for high-risk drivers by an average of nearly 17 percent. B5.
 
A BURGLAR'S BOUNTY
As burglars went, Frank J. Mascari cut a remarkable swath across Long Island. Made up in a bouffant hairdo and furs, he carefully picked the homes of middle-aged and elderly women, making off with thousands of heirlooms, including oil paintings, Persian rugs and crystal, from 1986 until his arrest in 1989. Now, some of his bounty will be put up for sale at an auction being held by the Nassau County District Attorney's office. B5.

HEADLINE: A Dealer's Lot Is Not a Happy One

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 25

 BODY:
Step into Dwight W. McGuirk's Ford showroom these days, and he will tell you that like lots of auto dealers his mark-up over invoice is $500 at most and sometimes as little as $200. The number is so small -- and sales have been so slow lately -- that it is a monthly scramble for Mr. McGuirk to finance the $3 million worth of cars and trucks on his lots, pay his three salesmen and keep the roof over his showroom from leaking.
In fact, he cannot do it all even though what he pays for his cars and trucks is slightly less than the much talked about "invoice price" that many car buyers believe is the dealer's cost. His profit margin can pay the salesmen, but there has not been enough to fix the roof as well. When it rains hard, the water trickles onto a patch of plastic draped on the hood of a blue Taurus sedan parked near the American flag. 
 "It's tough, real tough," said Mr. McGuirk, whose father bought Smith-Cairns Ford in this suburb north of New York City in 1961, and where Mr. McGuirk, 36 years old, has worked for 16 years. His sister Amy, the office manager, watching him dash from the showroom to the lot to the service shop to the body shop and back, has a name for the mode in which he tries to steer the dealership through this recession. She calls him "the mad jogger."
While customers often feel the deck is stacked against them when they enter a car dealership, many dealers like Mr. McGuirk are owners of small businesses trying to survive on shrinking margins and struggling with the mistakes and mandates of Detroit and the seesawing moods of consumer spending. In Mr. McGuirk's view, the deck is stacked against him.
To dealers, the world is a hostile place, strewn with printouts that tell customers what the dealer pays for a car, which some shoppers brandish like weapons; filled with trade-ins that break down almost instantly and besieged by vandals who steal everything from radios to cup holders.
Detroit's Big Three rolled up their worst losses in history last year, and 1,600 car dealers, almost 7 percent, closed their doors. The National Automobile Dealers Association estimated that most dealerships lost money last year on new-car sales, though Mr. McGuirk believes that measuring the profitability of new-car sales, used-car sales and repairs is all a matter of how a dealer chooses to allocate costs.
But with the economic recovery uncertain, competition among the 23,500 survivors seems more intense, especially in the older urban areas where dealerships abound. (Mr. McGuirk must contend with at least seven Ford and Lincoln-Mercury dealerships nearby, one of which declared bankruptcy earlier this month.) People do not have as much to spend, and everyone, including the dealers, say the fun has gone out of buying a new car.
 
Profits in Service
 Mr. McGuirk's repair shop is profitable but costly. He recently bought a $35,000 computer for repairs, the most expensive thing he says he ever bought. While the place still looks like a repair shop -- tools, lifts and pin-up pictures -- it is actually a room where computers interrogate computer chips under the hood. The best mechanics spend 10 days a year in school, learning the intricacies of electronics.
Nominally, the shop has $400,000 in inventory, but when pressed, Mr. McGuirk admits, "probably $100,000 of it is junk." When he cleaned out the parts department a few years ago, he found a radiator with a hole in the middle for a crank.
A front-end alignment machine costs $5,000, and because of tightening air-pollution regulations, Mr. McGuirk may soon have to spend $40,000 on a painting booth to contain chemicals.
But most frustrating is the new-car sales slump. Last year Mr. McGuirk sold 953 cars and trucks, down 27 percent from his best sales year in 1988. Two or three times a week a trailer arrives with new cars, and Mr. McGuirk and his salesmen wonder who will be the buyers.
"I don't have a choice to buy low and sell high," he said. "I pay what Ford charges and sell at what the market will bear. The only thing I control is overhead."
 
Solid Prospects
 Joseph and Mildred Cotter were in the showroom the other day looking for their first new car in 10 years. Mr. Cotter, a retired English and Latin teacher, said he ranked shopping just above surgery and buying a house and below every other possible activity.
Mrs. Cotter, a retired librarian, seemed to like shopping even less. "I'm a Toyota person," she told the salesman, Arthur E. Behrmann. The Toyota the Cotters drive is 23 years old, Mrs. Cotter said, and "she's a good little car, but she's beginning to show her age."
Mr. Behrmann, who has sold cars here for 39 years, thought the Cotters were a good prospect. He offered them the keys to a Taurus sedan for a test drive, and as Mr. Cotter reached for his wallet to show his license, Mr. Behrmann said, "You drove in here, that's good enough."
(Mr. McGuirk said that twice in his 16 years in the business customers on test drives had smacked up cars. Once the driver apologized and left; the other time the driver said he liked the way the vehicle handled and bought it.)
The Cotters took the Taurus out of the dealership, past the Mustang convertible that Mr. McGuirk parks every morning right out front when the sun shines. As they disappeared, Amy McGuirk was doubtful that the Cotters were ready for a new car, but Mr. Behrmann thought patience would pay off.
Customers think that car dealers are shady, said Mr. McGuirk, adding that in some ways it is hard to appear otherwise. He said he had shied away from high-pressure sales tactics. Ford makes this nearly impossible by offering rebates of $1,000 or more for a limited period, so he must tell a customer to buy this week or risk paying more. Even worse, he said, is when Ford abruptly raises the rebate, and a customer who bought a car the day before comes in to complain.
But worst of all, he said, "99 percent of your customers think you make more than you really do."
 
Low-Key Image
 Mr. McGuirk would not disclose what he makes, except to say that in a good year, which this is not, he makes a good living. His own car is a 1987 Taurus with 103,000 miles on it, partly, he says, because growing up as one of seven children of a car dealer, he got used to driving high-mileage models his father took in trade. But the Taurus is in good shape, he said, and will tow his jet ski.
Part of what a car dealer sells is himself, and Mr. McGuirk is good at that. He is also careful about his image. The only jewelry he wears is a watch, but he will not wear a Rolex, he said, because times are tough and he does not want to send the message that he is rolling in money. His business is still profitable, he said, but only because he takes a small salary and keeps overhead down.
He believes that the economy will turn around and that the dealership will survive because he is straight and honest with customers. A big part of that is a modest mark-up and a hope that a fair deal translates into repeat sales.
"There's no reason to nail a guy," Mr. McGuirk said, explaining why he would never sell a car at list price. Everybody talks cars, he said, and then the customer will know he got a bad deal. "You'll only nail him that one time."
In any case, the last time anyone routinely sold Fords at list was six years ago, when the Taurus first came out, he said. The Mustang convertible could sell for close to list price, he added, if early June brings the right buyer and the cars are in short supply. The Mustang is an exception in another way: It sits out front to lure shoppers even if they are not looking for a sports car.
 
Complex Formula
 Exactly what dealers pay for cars is more complicated than indicated by the popular factory-price printouts that are available from a host of car buying services. Most dealers pay the factory the invoice price represented on these printouts. But at the end of the calendar quarter, the dealer gets a rebate from Detroit of 3 percent of the invoice price, called a "hold-back."
In some cases, the invoice also includes an advertising budget for cooperative advertising by area dealers. It also includes some money for the cost of paying interest on the car while it is on the showroom floor, called a "floor-plan allowance."
Ford's invoice to the dealer includes $9.80 for eight gallons of gasoline the factory puts in the tank and 50 cents for the computer message from Ford confirming Smith-Cairns's order. The state takes its share, too. On each car, for example, Mr. McGuirk must calculate the amount of lubricating oil, transmission oil, power steering fluid and other fluids and pay a tax of 10 cents a quart just as service stations do.
But dealers have other chances to make money. The sharpest salesman in most dealerships, according to Mr. McGuirk, is the "F.& I. man," who had originally handled "finance and insurance." That person takes over after the price has been set and arranges any financing, often sharply marked up. That person also sells undercoating, exterior paint sealant, protective upholstery treatment, antitheft locks and extended repair warranties that can add a total of $3,000 to the price and plenty of profit.
"They could sell a snowball to an Eskimo," said Mr. McGuirk, with some admiration, though he does not push those after-sale items very hard.
"People have gotten clued in," he said. "I can't remember the last car I rust-proofed."
 
Better Than Early 80's
 But a car might sit on the lot for months, and Mr. McGuirk pays Ford one percentage point over the prime rate, which is now 6 1/2 percent. This recession is easier than the last because interest rates are lower, he said, and because the Ford Taurus and Explorer, the popular four-wheel-drive wagon, sell better than models Ford was offering in the early 80's. Back then, Mr. McGuirk added, he and his father went to auctions to buy used vehicles to have something attractive to sell.
Some aspects of selling a car have mostly disappeared. Almost no one asks about engine design anymore. And women customers, Mr. McGuirk said, arrive better prepared than men. Dealers have lost business by not taking a woman seriously if she comes in by herself. "Even if you think that way," he added, "you should never act that way."
The market will eventually pick up, Mr. McGuirk predicted. In the meantime, Mr. Behrmann managed to sell a Taurus sedan to the Cotters. But Amy McGuirk was partly right: The Cotters decided not to part with their 23-year-old Toyota. Not yet anyway.

HEADLINE: Stocks Close Day Mixed; Dow Up 8.28

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed in moderatly heavy trading yesterday, with blue-chip issues firm, and the broad market weaker. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 3,267.67, up 8.28 points for the day.
Analysts said the market hardly reacted to yesterday's news that the United States economy edged up at an annual rate of just four-tenths of 1 percent in the final three months of last year, a pace that was even weaker than previously calculated, and that the number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits jumped to 447,000 for the week ended March 14. Instead, traders looked ahead to next week, when a fresh batch of economic data is due, including March consumer confidence and unemployment. 
 Blue-chip issues rose near the close, rebounding from Wednesday's selloff, but the late strength did not carry over to the secondary market. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 0.34 point to close at 407.86, while the American Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.43 points, to 398.86. In active over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite finished down 4.08 points, to 615.40, and the Russell 2,000 dipped 0.68 point, to 206.24.
 
Volume Declines a Bit
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 176.7 million shares, down from 192.7 million shares on Wednesday, with losing issues narrowly outpacing gainers by 842 to 765.
Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the day began filled with high expectations that only seemed to fizzle at the end. "A repeat of the last few sessions," he said. "Investors are still not clear just how strong or how weak this economy is."
He noted that the market was not sure of the trend interest rates would take and that it did not have leadership, since economically sensitive issues and the old growth leadership stocks were locked in battle. "Coupled with investors waiting for first-quarter corporate results to emerge, and the need for fresh economic data, you have a market running in place," Mr. Jarrett said. "You need clear direction before investors can make a major decision to buy or sell."
Stocks opened firmer, as the market appeared to be correcting from a program-induced selloff late Wednesday that followed a Salomon Brothers trading error.
In trading, Borland International fell 5 1/8, to 56 3/4. David Readerman, an analyst with Shearson Lehman, cut his fourth-quarter estimate for the software company to 5 cents a share from 20 cents a share. Traders said he was one of a number who have already revised their estimates.
Citing lower material costs and improvements in United States residential construction, James Wilbur, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, repeated his "buy" recommendation on Dow Chemical . He said the recent upturn in housing construction should improve the pricing outlook for Dow's residential vinyl and plastics products, and if oil and gas prices remain low, they could lift annual earnings by as much as 60 cents a share. The stock gained 7/8 to close at 61 5/8.
American Express was up 1/2, to 24, mostly in block trading, as Alison Deans, another analyst at Smith Barney, raised her recommendation on the stock to "buy" from "hold."
Walker Interactive Systems rose to 22, up from an initial public offering price of 15, making the computer software manufacturer among the most actively traded on the Nasdaq yesterday, as 3.3 million shares traded. The most active was Intel the semiconductor company, which fell 1 1/2, to 58 3/4, on 3.9 million shares.

HEADLINE: Less Crime to Count;
Was It Community Policing? Experts Try to Explain Drops in Major Crimes

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
With reported crime down in every major category in New York City last year for the first time since the early Eisenhower years, police officials are asking themselves: Did we do something right?
Experts agree it is too soon to say. But the provisional answer appears to be yes, at least to some extent. While the turnabout was marginal in some cases and hardly qualifies as a trend, examination of the figures suggests that the department's sweeping program of neighborhood patrols and saturation coverage seems to be having an effect in at least certain high-crime precincts. 
 Moreover, the dip, which bucks the national trend, shows no sign of abating. Robbery complaints were down a marginal 1.8 percent last year. But perhaps more significant is that with one exception, the city has now recorded 18 consecutive months in which the seven major reported crimes totaled less than in the same month the previous year. Robberies in December 1991 were down nearly 4 percent, and down nearly 7 percent in January and February of this year.
Predictably, questions outnumber answers in the wake of the upbeat 1991 figures, the first time since 1955 that all seven "index" crimes -- murder, rape, robbery, assault, burglary, larceny and motor vehicle theft -- went down instead of up.
Why, for example, if crime was down 4.4 percent citywide, was it down so much more sharply in some precincts and up sharply in others? Of the nearly two dozen high-robbery precincts, those with 1,000 or more robberies per square mile last year, why did some show dramatic downturns and others upsurges?
No one knows for sure, but a closer look at the figures suggests that some precincts are more responsive than others to the stepped-up neighborhood patrols of community policing, Commissioner Lee P. Brown's signature program of teams of foot officers who seek to resolve local problems before they blow up into criminal crises. Midtown South and Midtown North, both notoriously robbery-prone Manhattan precincts, in part because of the supply of business victims, recorded drops of more than 19 and 18 percent, respectively.
Yet another high-robbery precinct, the 28th, just north of Central Park in Harlem, declined a statistically insignificant 1.5 percent.
According to Assistant Chief Michael A. Markman of the Office of Management Analysis and Planning, which puts out the figures, the midtown precincts, where crime clusters along corridors like 42d Street and the day population is largely one of transient workers, are particularly responsive to saturation patrolling and community policing. Since April 1990, he said, special programs that added overtime patrols and put desk officers out on the street one day a week added an extra 150,000 tours to the police presence in high-crime areas like Midtown South.
But the same stepped-up police coverage works less well in poor, residential neighborhoods high in violent crime, said Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a watchdog group.
The hypothesis gains some support from subway crime figures, Mr. Reppetto said. With intensified patrols by the transit police, reported robberies in the subway -- included in the citywide tabulations -- were down nearly 12 percent last year. Overall reported felonies were down 15 percent last year, and every month for the last 15 months, there were fewer subway felonies than in the corresponding month the year before.
While citywide figures show interesting fluctuations, experts cautioned against seeking significance in any small sampling, such as one precinct or even a borough. Queens, for example, recorded an 8 percent increase in robbery complaints, with some precincts, like the 100th in Rockaway, showing a nearly 30 percent jump.
But the raw figures are so relatively small that a few active teams of robbers during the course of a year could push the percentages way up.
While local disparities might be interesting, the statistical portrait of crime in the city requires the same kind of perspective as a Pointillist painting: from too close it just looks like a jumble of dots.
But even the broadest brush strokes should be viewed with caution, officials say. While saying, "I'm optimistic some of the things we're doing are beginning to make a difference," Commissioner Brown said, "One year does not constitute a trend." As a career criminologist as well as a longtime street officer, he said, he knew there was no single cause of crime, or single cure for it.
Still, others found the figures encouraging. Hubert Williams, president of the Police Foundation, a research organization in Washington, said he was struck by the way New York City appeared to be "turning the corner on its own historical norms."
"Crime going down is not a phenomenon we see very much of today, especially across the board in all categories."
Marvin Wolfgang, a professor of criminology and law at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, said a 4.4 percent decline in reported crime "is very difficult to explain."
"If you had a 4.4 percent drop in unemployment, it would be very significant," he said.
But to draw further conclusions, he said, he would want to know the role of community policing in achieving such results.

HEADLINE: Region Rethinks Its Dependence on the Sales Tax;
Some Government Officials See Wobbly Revenue and an Unfair Burden on the Poor

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
In the 1980's, when conspicuous consumption was elevated to an art, county and state governments around the New York region enjoyed a spectacular stream of revenue from sales taxes, with receipts routinely rising more than 10 percent a year.
But when the recession hit, that stream slowed to a trickle, contributing to fiscal crises in Hartford, Albany and Trenton. In New York, for example, where sales taxes bring in about a fourth of the state's revenue, state sales-tax receipts fell $323 million between 1990 and 1991, to $5.4 billion. 
 Now, leaders in government are rethinking their dependence on the sales tax. Many have concluded that it is an unreliable source of revenue and also places an unfair burden on the poor, who generally pay a higher portion of their income for sales taxes than more affluent taxpayers.
Nationwide, experts say, state governments are moving away from the sales tax and relying more on income taxes. Connecticut, for example, adopted an income tax last year after a bitter struggle and cut its sales tax to 6 percent, from 8 percent. On Monday, the New Jersey Assembly passed a bill to roll back the sales tax to 6 percent, from 7 percent, following through on a pledge that helped Republicans win a veto-proof majority in both houses of the Legislature.
Still, the sales tax holds strong appeal for many governments. While New York State has not raised its basic 4 percent sales tax since 1965, many county governments have been raising their sales taxes to the legal maximum, largely because voters find it less objectionable than higher property taxes. That may be because people pay the sales tax in dribs and drabs, and virtually no one can say how much he or she paid in sales tax in a given year.
"There's no day of reckoning where the consumer is reminded of the aggregate amount spent, the way there is with property-tax bills and income-tax returns," said Dave Kehler president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey in Princeton.
In New York, the average combined state and county sales tax is around 7 percent, but in Nassau County it is 8.5 percent -- one of the highest in the nation -- and in New York City it is 8.25 percent. Orange and Westchester Counties raised their sales taxes last year, and Westchester officials are seeking another increase of half a percentage point this year, to 7.25 percent.
To a degree, the increases reflect the weakness of the sales tax during the recession, which has forced counties to raise the tax rate just to break even.
Of course, revenues from other taxes have also faltered of late, but experts said the drop-off in sales-tax revenue was the steepest.
According to the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany, income-tax revenue rose nine-tenths of 1 percent nationwide during the last quarter of 1991, compared with the same period in 1990, but sales-tax revenue fell by 2 percent.
"During this recession, sales-tax revenues have performed even worse than they normally do in bad times," said Steven D. Gold, the center's director, "and that's because of the unprecedented depression in consumer spending.
"It makes it a lot tougher for governors and legislators to produce a balanced budget," he said.
 
In Good Times and Bad
 Connecticut is a prime example. Without a tax on wages, it depended heavily on the sales tax. During the 1980's, it had huge budget surpluses, with an increase in sales-tax revenue of as much as 17.1 percent in 1984. But by 1990, the increase, adjusted for changes in the tax rate, had fallen to just seven-tenths of 1 percent, and in the first three months of this year, sales-tax revenue actually declined an estimated 5 percent, compared with the same period last year.
"That kind of fluctuation is something you just don't see with respect to personal income," said William J. Cibes Jr., who heads Connecticut's Office of Policy and Management.
Of equal concern to longtime income-tax advocates in Connecticut, and elsewhere, is the regressive nature of the sales tax.
A study by Citizens for Tax Justice, a nonpartisan research group that favors the income tax over the sales tax, found that in 1991 Americans in the bottom 20 percent income bracket spent 5.7 percent of their income on sales taxes, while those in the top 1 percent spent only 1.2 percent.
That discrepancy, however, has often been lost on taxpayers.
"The thing about the sales tax is that, because it's taken a nickel and a dime at a time, the perception among politicians is that people won't notice it," said Michael Ettlinger, tax policy director for Citizens for Tax Justice. "But at some point there's a backlash, and New Jersey is a good example of that."
In New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio won an increase of one percentage point in the sales tax in 1990. Though the new rate of 7 percent was relatively low by the standards of the metropolitan region, it was part of a $2.8 billion package of tax increases that led to a tax revolt.
"Taxes became a high-profile debate in the state," Mr. Ettlinger said, "and the difference between a tax that's regressive and the progressive income tax was made apparent to the public."
Frank Catania, a Republican who is Deputy Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, said legislators had targeted the sales tax for a rollback because of its regressive nature. "It hurts the little guy," he said. "Senior citizens and low-income people are paying much more of their income on sales taxes than the wealthy."
He also said that a rollback would bolster consumer spending. "Repealing the increase in the sales tax would put $608 million back into the economy for people to spend any way they want," Mr. Catania said. "In order for our retailers to be in competition with surrounding states, we have to be more realistic."
To offset the regressive nature of the sales tax, most states exempt certain goods. In New Jersey, for instance, there is no sales tax on clothing. Connecticut exempts fuel and clothing that costs less than $50 an item. New York does not tax prescription or non-prescription drugs. None places a tax on most food bought in stores.
Many people in and out of government say the shift to a service-oriented economy in recent years has meant an erosion of the traditional sales-tax base. "More and more consumer goods, so to speak, are services," said James W. Wetzler, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. As a result, New York now applies a sales tax on the services provided by security guards, private detectives and interior decorators.
When Nassau County tried to expand its base by taxing home heating oil, however, there was such an outcry that the proposal was withdrawn. With a rate of 8.5 percent, Nassau officials believe they have arrived at an uncomfortable threshold.
"Right now, it's unrealistic to think it can go any higher," said Peter King, Nassau's Comptroller. "It's not an option, and it's not an option to consider an increase in the property tax. We're really at a crossroads because the traditional means of taxation have really been exhausted."

HEADLINE: 4 Exchanges A Step Closer To New Space

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
With the threat of losing thousands of jobs to New Jersey hanging over its head, the New York City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved a city-subsidized effort to build a new commodities-exchange headquarters in Manhattan without knowing whether the project would go forward.
The vote removed the last governmental hurdle to a project aimed at keeping four of the city's five exchanges, which traditionally have had their headquarters in the Financial District, from acting on their threat to move to Jersey City, taking nearly 9,000 jobs and $50 million in tax revenues with them. 
 But even with the Council's approval, a spokeswoman for the four exchanges, Michele de Milly, said yesterday that the future of the project was uncertain. The project was dealt a severe blow in January when the largest of the exchanges, the New York Mercantile Exchange, pulled out of the deal, saying it was looking for another site.
 
City-Owned Parcel
 In a 42-to-5 vote with one abstention, the Council gave its approval for an 18- or 22-story building with a 51,000-square-foot trading floor on city-owned land bounded by Greenwich, West, Warren and Murray streets in TriBeCa. While the Council approved the use of the land, it has no influence on the tax incentives, a point that irked many members.
Councilwoman Kathryn F. Freed, a Democrat who represents lower Manhattan, argued against the approval, saying the Council was giving the state and city development corporations free reign to give away tax breaks for an uncertain project.
She said it made no sense to subsidize a new building while vacancy rates soaring were soaring. "This is a project that will never go forward; it will never happen," she said. "To vote yes on this project is to vote for our own loss of power."
But the majority of the Council members said that while they had misgivings about the project, they did not want to be blamed for the loss of jobs.
The project was originally to be built with $100 million in state and city grants. Two weeks ago, the city and state development corporations offered the four remaining exchanges a $60 million grant with fewer tax incentives, about $42 million over 20 years, said Carl B. Weisbrod, the president of the city Economic Development Corporation.
The four exchanges -- the Commodity Exchange, the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, the New York Cotton Exchange and the New York Futures Exchange -- have yet to respond. Ms. de Milly said the exchanges were still studying the financial underpinnings of the city's offer and had yet to decide.

HEADLINE: New Claims By Jobless Up by 15,000

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The number of people filing new claims for unemployment benefits climbed by 15,000 in the second week of March, the Labor Department said today, pointing to what various economists say is likely to be a lackluster, slow-to-arrive recovery.
The department said 447,000 people filed for unemployment benefits in the week ended March 14, up from a revised 432,000 the previous week. It had previously put the number of new claims in the March 7 week at 433,000. 
 Wall Street economists had expected 440,000 new applications in the latest period.
"There are no signs of any strengthening in the labor force," said Kevin Flanagan, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds.
The claims numbers, said David Wyss of DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc., "were disappointing and indicated that we are certainly not out of the woods yet." He added that although claims had appeared to be declining, today's report showed that "we still have a problem."
Mr. Wyss also noted that unlike overall unemployment, jobless claims should show improvement fairly quickly as the economy began to recover.
The department said the four-week average for new claims, regarded as a more accurate measure of the number of jobless than the weekly figure, slipped to 444,000 in the latest period from 446,750.
The Labor Department said the total number of people receiving state unemployment benefits in the latest period was unavailable.
Oklahoma registered the biggest rise in new claims, with 4,124 new filings, followed by Michigan's 2,776.
Michigan said its increase in claims stemmed from layoffs in the automobile industry, reversing the trend of the previous week. Oklahoma officials did not comment.
Missouri and New York reported the largest drop in new claims, with both states reporting about 4,000 fewer filings. Missouri reported nearly 1,700 new claims the previous week because of layoffs in the food processing and transportation industries. No reason was given for the decline in New York.
