HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
New York State canceled a 20-year contract to buy power from a giant hydroelectric complex that Quebec wants to build in the Canadian sub-Arctic, and abruptly cut short negotiations with the Quebec Government. Governor Cuomo said that New York did not need the power and that it would be cheaper to rely on energy conservation and other energy sources instead. [Page 1.] 
 Japanese land prices have fallen significantly for the first time since 1975, the National Land Agency reported. Land, Japan's most precious asset, had soared to such heights that mere patches of Tokyo were worth more than the entire state of Florida. [37.]
The White House cleared the way for the American purchase of space and nuclear technologies totaling $14 million from the former Soviet Union, calling it a bold first step in what would be a substantial aid package. [1.]
Hungary's General Electric-Tungsram joint venture has called a timeout, as losses of more than $13 million a year continue and substantial layoffs seem possible. [37.]
Representatives of Olympia & York asked lenders to roll over hundreds of millions of dollars of debt that will mature in the next 10 days, the company said. [38.]
 
The Economy
Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan is being investigated by Federal authorities along with other directors and executives of the failed Olympic Federal Savings Association of Berwyn, Ill., a western suburb of Chicago. The inquiry is standard practice for every failed bank and savings association. [37.]
The Senate authorized an additional $25 billion in Federal spending to take over insolvent and unsound savings and loan institutions and to extend the April 1 deadline for the spending of $17 billion already authorized. [41.]
Personal incomes jumped 1.1 percent in February, the biggest leap in three years, the Government said, and consumer spending rose nine-tenths of a percent. [37.]
A Federal prosecutor said there was a "substantial likelihood" that Michael Milken would be a Government witness in the coming trial of a former colleague at Drexel Burnham Lambert. [41.]
 
Markets
Stock prices tumbled, with technology stocks particularly hard hit. Intel, the most actively traded Nasdaq issue, closed at 55 1/4, down 3 1/2, after a few investment firms lowered their ratings on it. The Dow Jones industrial average fell to 3,231.44, down 36.23 points for the day and 44.95 points for the week. [37.]
Treasury bond prices were sharply higher after evidence of new economic strength failed to shake investor confidence. [40.]
The dollar settled lower on world currency markets. Gold prices were mostly higher.[47.]
Pork futures rallied on the Chicago Merc, but after the close the Government projected a huge oversupply of hogs. [47.]
 
 Companies
Goodyear Tire and Rubber said that it had agreed to sell its polyester resin business to Shell Chemical. Analysts said Goodyear was likely to receive $350 million to $400 million. [39.]
General Motors will relocate within Mexico a truck plant now in Mexico City because of pressure from the Mexican Government to reduce pollution and traffic congestion in the capital. [39.]

HEADLINE: Witness for Prosecution Is Likely to Be Milken

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that there was a "substantial likelihood" that Michael R. Milken would be a Government witness in the coming securities fraud trial of a former colleague at Drexel Burnham Lambert.
It would be Mr. Milken's first public testimony about the business activities of Drexel's junk bond division, which he headed, since the Government began its investigation in 1986. 
 Any testimony could be crucial to Mr. Milken, who is trying to persuade the court to reduce his 10-year prison sentence for securities fraud. But Roger S. Hayes, Acting United States Attorney, said yesterday that any consideration of reducing Mr. Milken's sentence should be delayed until his testimony had been evaluated.
Mr. Hayes said Mr. Milken was expected to be a witness against Alan E. Rosenthal, the former head of co nvertibles in Drexel's junk bond department, who was indicted last May on charges of conspiracy, mail and securities fraud, and pension fund embezzlement.
 
 
Unusual Position
 The situation puts Mr. Milken in the unusual position of either having to admit that despite his lawyers' statements that he knew of no other crimes committed at Drexel, he was aware of wrongdoing by one of his chief lieutenants, or providing testimony that will be of little help in gaining him a reduced sentence.
Mr. Hayes's disclosure that Mr. Milken may become a highly visible prosecution witness was in a letter yesterday to United States District Judge Kimba M. Wood, who is considering Mr. Milken's application that his sentence be reduced. Mr. Milken is serving the sentence at a minimum-security prison work camp in Pleasanton, Calif.
Thus far, Mr. Hayes said in the letter, "Mr. Milken's cooperation has not resulted in the successful investigation and prosecution of other individuals."
 
 
Prosecutors Have a Voice
 Part of the arguments Judge Wood will consider in deciding whether to reduce Mr. Milken's sentence is one offered by prosecutors in which they will evaluate how valuable he has been in obtaining indictments and convictions of Wall Street figures.
"In practice," Mr. Hayes wrote, "the simple rule has been that only defendants whose cooperation has resulted in successful criminal prosecutions and successful S.E.C. enforcement actions have received substantial sentence reductions."
Mr. Hayes cited, for example, Ivan F. Boesky, Dennis B. Levine and Boyd L. Jefferies, each of whom provided testimony or evidence, resulting in either more favorable plea agreements or a prison-sentence reduction.
 
 
'Limited Results'
 Mr. Hayes said that defendants whose cooperation produced only "limited results" should receive "only a slight sentence reduction." Thus far, Mr. Hayes said, Mr. Milken fell into that category, and for that reason has not yet "merited a significant sentence reduction."
In contrast, Mr. Milken's defense lawyers, led by Arthur L. Liman, submitted a motion yesterday in which they requested a reduced sentence based on what they described as his successful cooperation. Mr. Liman said Mr. Milken was cooperating in an S.E.C. investigation, but did not provide any details.
The courtroom spectacle of Mr. Milken turning against a former colleague could also undermine his claims that he committed no crimes other than those to which he pleaded guilty and his extensive and well-financed efforts to clear his name.
Prosecutors contend that Mr. Milken had intimate knowledge of Mr. Rosenthal's purported illegal activities, on the ground that he was named a co-conspirator in the indictment against Mr. Rosenthal.
The indictment contends that the two conspired to confer unlawful economic benefits on a former Drexel client, David B. Solomon, and, in turn, to misappropriate funds from Mr. Solomon's clients. At one time, Mr. Solomon's junk bond company, Solomon Asset Management, was one of Drexel's largest clients, controlling about $2 billion, most of it from pension and employee-benefits funds.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 36.23 Over Doubts On Recovery

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices were down sharply in moderate trading yesterday, as investors' fears that the economic recovery would be sluggish left the market vulnerable to bouts of program trading. Technology stocks, under pressure for weeks, were particularly hard-hit because of those doubts.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell to 3,231.44, down 36.23 points, or 1.11 percent, for the day and 44.95 points, or 1.90 percent, for the week. 
 Declines in overseas markets also weighed on the market, analysts said. Tokyo fell to a new five-year closing low of 19,636.99 on the Nikkei.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange slipped to 166.1 million shares, from 176.7 million shares traded on Thursday, with losing issues leaping ahead of winners by 1,244 to 449.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 4.36 points, to 403.50, as the American Stock Exchange composite fell 4.50 points, to 394.36. Trading on the Nasdaq was heavy. Investors jumping out of technology stocks pulled the composite down 10.73 points, to 604.67, and the Russell 2,000 index down 2.41 points.
The most actively traded Nasdaq issue was Intel, which closed at 55 1/4, down 3 1/2, after a few investment firms lowered their ratings on it. Andrew Neff, a Bear, Stearns analyst, issued a research report saying that Cyrix, a privately held technology company, was expected to introduce a product soon that will directly compete with Intel's 486 microprocessor and could be aggressively priced.
Among the other technology stocks that took heavy hits were Borland International down 2 3/4, to 54; Lotus Development down 2 5/8, to 31 1/2; Micsosoft , down 3 3/4, to 121 1/4, and Novell, down 2, to 57 1/4.
Blue-chip issues tumbled in afternoon trading, under pressure from the significant weakness in the technology sector, and some futures-related selling.
News that Household International, the financial services company, expected to see first-quarter results that are 40 to 50 percent below analysts' estimates caused some nervousness in the market. The stock fell 9 1/4, to 46 3/4, on the Big Board.
Stocks also reacted yesterday to the weaker-than-expected gain in the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index and to the larger-than-expected increase in the February personal income and personal spending numbers.
John Brooks, a technical analyst for Davis, Mendel & Regenstein in Atlanta, said the mixed economic signals being emitted might be decent for bonds, "but I'm not sure the stock market will ignore weak economic numbers."
He continued: "The market also ran into problem with Salomon Brothers' error this week. You have a market that is psychologically shaky at best and than you throw in one error by one brokerage firm, it exposes fragile structure of the market."
William Maguire, a Merrill Lynch analyst, lowered his earnings estimates and intermediate-term rating on Chiquita Brands International to "neutral" from "above average," citing uncertainty over the pricing of bananas in Europe. The stock fell 1 7/8, to 29 1/8, as the analysts noted that Europe accounts for more than 65 percent of the company's earnings.
James Parker, an analyst with the Robinson-Humphrey Company, added Hi-Lo Automotive to the firm's "best buy" list, as the stock rose 1 1/2, to 17 5/8.
The share price of Handex Environmental Recovery collapsed after the company said it expected first- quarter earnings to fall as much as 30 percent. The news caused the stock to plunge 7 1/2 and close at 14.
Catalina Markets, a distributor of store coupons, was up $8 from its initial public offering price of $20 in heavy trading yesterday.

HEADLINE: WALDHEIM IS GIVEN WELCOME BY KOHL

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, March 27

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl met with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria in Munich today and then angrily criticized prominent Jews who had deplored the meeting as inappropriate.
In a nationally televised news conference after the meeting, Mr. Kohl said he alone would decide with whom he was to meet in Germany. 
 "I don't need any advice," he said in response to leaders of Jewish organizations who had scorned him for becoming the first Western leader to receive Mr. Waldheim since his election in 1986. The Austrian leader has been widely shunned since then for having concealed his role as a German Army officer in World War II.
 
'Dishonor to Germany' Seen
 In New York, Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, said Mr. Kohl "brought dishonor to Germany." He contrasted the Chancellor's behavior with that of Germany's President, Richard von Weizsacker, who, he said, "by not meeting with Mr. Waldheim defended Germany's honor."
German Jewish groups also denounced the meeting.
At the meeting with reporters, where he was accompanied by Mr. Waldheim, Mr. Kohl said he did not understand such criticism. He lashed out in particular at the World Jewish Congress, accusing its leaders of having tried to derail efforts toward German reunification after the fall of the Berlin wall.
Visibly annoyed, Mr. Kohl declared: "I ask the gentlemen of the World Jewish Congress for a reply to a request for information about an occurrence in November 1989, when they sent an emissary to East Berlin, where he polemicized in an outrageous manner against German reunification, and thereby against Germany's right to self-determination." Mr. Kohl said he had not received a reply to a request for an explanation.
Answering Mr. Kohl's charge, Mr. Steinberg said in a telephone interview that the organization's president, Edgar Bronfman, had been informed of the charges last year in a letter from Mr. Kohl, in which the allegations were attributed to a report based on information contained in East German Government files.
Contradicting the Chancellor, Mr. Steinberg said the World Jewish Congress had denied the charges in a letter sent by Mr. Bronfman to Mr. Kohl in October.
 
Criticism From Opposition
 The encounter and a luncheon in Munich's elegent Prinzenpalais, which was attended by Bavaria's Prime Minister, Max Streibl, also drew criticism from the opposition Social Democratic Party, which accused Mr. Kohl of currying favor with conservative supporters by welcoming Mr. Waldheim.
Leaders of the Free Democratic Party, the junior partner in Mr. Kohl's coalition Government, said the meeting displayed "lack of sensitivity."
The 72-year-old Mr. Waldheim, who served as United Nations Secretary General from 1972 to 1982, has been treated as a virtual pariah by Western leaders after disclosures during his 1986 presidential campaign indicated that he had covered up his service in a German Army unit that was accused of atrocities in the Balkans in World War II. His six-year term as President ends in June.
Officials in Mr. Kohl's office have been careful to describe the visit by Mr. Waldheim to Bavaria, where he received an award from a conservative foundation for contributions to freedom, as a private visit. He was accompanied by Austria's Foreign Minister, Alois Mock, a supporter of Mr. Waldheim and one of the major proponents of Austrian entry into the European Community, a goal Germany supports.
Mr. Kohl's Christian Democratic Party faces elections in the states of Baden-Wurttemburg and Schleswig-Holstein in coming months, and the Chancellor has been at pains to win the favor of conservative voters as his party struggles to prevent a heavy loss of votes to the far-right Republican Party.
Mr. Steinberg said: "Chancellor Kohl, who brought us Bitburg, showed shocking insensitivity to the moral concerns of the Jewish people as well as others who feel deeply the tragedy of the Holocaust and those terrible years."
Mr. Steinberg was referring to the Chancellor's visit with President Reagan in 1985 to a military cemetery at Bitburg, Germany, where soldiers of the Nazi SS are buried. The visit brought strong criticism from Jewish organizations and also from American veterans' organizations.
Mr. Steinberg contrasted the behavior of Mr. Kohl with that of Mr. Weizsacker, who has always staunchly refused to meet officially with Mr. Waldheim.
German-Jewish ties, always sensitive because of the slaughter of European Jewry at the hands of Germans in World War II, have been tense since the Persian Gulf War, when Bonn was initially hesitant in its backing of the coalition effort against Iraq. Though Bonn subsequently agreed to a large share of the financing of the war, relations have continued to be troubled by Israeli objections to Bonn's willingness to take in large numbers of Jews from the former Soviet Union whom the Israelis would prefer to see settled in Israel, and to German willingness to follow the American lead in refusing loan guarantees intended for the construction of settlements for the immigrants in Israel.
To relax those tensions and to provide assurance that Bonn is dealing with a surge of radical right-wing political activity against immigrants to Germany, German leaders have invited several recent high-level delegations of American Jews to the country. This led some prominent Jews to express surprise that Mr. Kohl would welcome Mr. Waldheim.
 
Meeting Called Inappropriate
 "Given Mr. Waldheim's record, to host him when no other leader in Europe would do so is inappropriate," said Malcolm Hoenlein, the executive director of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, who is on a tour of Germany sponsored by Mr. Kohl's party. Mr. Hoenlein said the attacks against criticism by Jewish organizations were "not warranted."
"Certainly it is directed at Mr. Waldheim and anything that would give him acceptability and legitimacy," he said.
Mr. Waldheim has said he will not seek re-election. That announcement ended months of debate among Austrian leaders, many of whom feared that a second candidacy would further mar Austria's reputation as it seeks entry into the community.
Later today, at a ceremony in which Mr. Waldheim was awarded a prize by the conservative Peutinger Foundation, Bavaria's former Economics Minister, Otto Schedl, praised him for dedication to the values of peace and freedom, and mocked the accusations brought against him because of his wartime record. In a thinly veiled reference to the Austrian President's Jewish critics, Mr. Schedl said, "Once the accusations had collapsed like a house of cards and the intriguers were unmasked, one hardly read or heard anything more about them."

HEADLINE: G.E.-Tungsram Venture In Hungary Hits Snags

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, March 27

 BODY:
The General Electric-Tungsram joint venture that opened to much fanfare here in 1989 has called a timeout in its light-bulb making as losses of more than $13 million a year continue and substantial layoffs seem possible.
The suspension of many Tungsram operations is the worst setback yet for the emerging market economy of Hungary, which has attracted more than $2.3 billion in foreign investment, more than its Central European neighbors combined, except for Germany. 
 The Tungsram venture has been a drawing card -- and case study -- for other Western companies considering setting up shop in Hungary.
"Because of G.E.'s high profile, it draws additional attention," said Theodore Boone, an East European specialist for Arnold & Porter, the Washington-based law firm. "But for a lot of people who are very active here, it's not something that's a complete surprise."
Tungsram continued to advertise "for a brighter world," in newspapers and on billboards this week, but as of Monday most of the operations at 10 of Tungsram's 11 Hungarian plants were suspended for two to five weeks, and workers were sent home with 80 percent of their salaries.
The company announced a 90-day moratorium on new investments in the venture. Tungsram's chief executive, George Varga, predicted that G.E. would cut by half its planned $40 million investment this year.
Mr. Varga, a Hungarian emigre who had risen through G.E.'s ranks and won the coveted job of nurturing the infant joint venture, attributed its losses to the combination of 30 percent annual inflation and small devaluations of the Hungarian currency, the forint: 1.9 percent in mid-March, following devaluations of 5.8 percent in November 1991 and 15 percent in January 1991. The company's loss last year came despite a rise in sales of 16 percent.
"Since 75 to 80 percent of Tungsram's products end up in the most competitive markets, in the United States and Western Europe, if costs in Hungary multiply 90 percent in three years, then it is logical that the profit margin should fall," Mr. Varga said. He added that "the East European market has practically disappeared."
The Central Statistical Office reported that as of February the annual inflation rate had fallen to 25.8 percent, from 33.2 percent a year earlier.
 
 
Government Criticized
 At a recent news conference, Mr. Varga lashed out at the Hungarian Government. "I understand that the Government's first priority is the fight against inflation," he said. "But I am convinced that in such a time of recession a tight monetary policy hardly serves the interests of industry," he said.
The daily newspaper Nepszabadsag quoted him this week as having said, "I think it is fatal to have the Finance Ministry be the ruler in economic policy."
Mr. Boone commented, "G.E. has built up so much good will through their investment here, I think they feel they should be listened to." Mr. Varga is reported to be frustrated that in three years he has been unable to get Hungary's Prime Minister, Jozsef Antall, to receive G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr., even for a courtesy visit. Finance Ministry officials declined to comment on the matter today.
"Economically and politically, the first priority is inflation," said Maria Zita Petschnig, senior scholar at the Monetary Research Institute. "You can't solve unemployment in the short term, but you can achieve something with inflation."
 
 
Motivations Questioned
 Dr. Petschnig questioned Tungsram's real motivations in suspending operations at the plant, saying that while the forint was overvalued, this was a less significant factor in companies' economic well-being than their markets, for example.
"Maybe Tungsram is being used as a Trojan horse for domestic enterprise lobbyists," she ventured. "A lot of people are threatened with unemployment, but there's no direct social pressure."
Similarly, Laszlo Lang, an economist, suggested, "If a company with G.E.'s backing can't sustain its market, it may go back to reasons other than an overvalued currency."
He added, "Even with an overvalued currency, some Hungarian companies have been cashing some good export receipts in the past two years."
Mr. Lang described G.E.'s purchase of its share in Tungsram as a "strategic buyout," to get a well-known brand in the regional market. "Perhaps some in G.E. are wondering if it was worth the price just to get a trademark," he said.
It is still too early to tell whether Tungsram's problems will have an effect on the flow of other Western investments into Hungary. Mr. Boone said, "Companies currently considering investments may analyze some of the risk factors more closely."
When G.E. purchased its share of the business for $150 million in 1989, the Tungsram joint venture inherited a manufacturing operation that was overstaffed, like most state-owned enterprises in Eastern Europe.
 
 
Minimal Layoffs
 Mr. Varga's team opted for a "soft" approach, offering early retirement options to about 4,000 employees instead of laying off workers.
"We've gone down over 5,000 in two years, but with only 400 real layoffs," said Jim R. Conheady, Tungsram's vice president for organization and personnel development, said last month. Now Mr. Varga is pointing to more drastic moves.
"We are planning about a 25 percent cutback in personnel, which first of all will affect the approximately 1,000 people in administration," he told Nepszabadsag.
Union officials at the plant said they understood the motivations for suspending operations. Still, they are nervous about the future.
Gyorgy Selmeczy, head of the Tungsram Workers' Independent Trade Union, said: "On the positive side, it looks as if the enterprise will survive. But every one of the employees wonders which of us will end up on the street next."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Abortion is the great white shark of American politics. At the moment this intractable, emotional moral issue is gliding silently below the surface of the Presidential campaign. But that won't last.
Within a few months the Supreme Court will almost certainly rule on the constitutionality of a Pennsylvania law that hedges access to abortion with a number of conditions. The Court's decision may show the extent of the vulnerability of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 ruling that gives women the right to choose abortion. 
 Whatever the outcome, Congress this summer will take up the proposed Freedom of Choice Act. The bill would codify Roe v. Wade, although some of its supporters, as well as all of its opponents, say the legislation would go beyond Roe in barring any legal restrictions on abortion.
Both sides in the debate are eager to make abortion an issue in the general election, forcing candidates and voters to stand up and be counted. Less enthusiastic are those Republicans and Democrats whose strong beliefs on abortion are at odds with their party's positions. Their plight is a poignant one, and looking into it reveals much about the dynamics of moral frustration.
"I have never been a single-issue voter, but that's changing," said Ann Stone. "I don't know how many Republican candidates who are anti-choice I could vote for." Ms. Stone is the national director of Republicans for Choice, a group seeking to repeal the Republican platform's endorsement of a constitutional amendment outlawing abortion.
The Republican dissidents have at least won a hearing for what the late Lee Atwater, President Bush's campaign director in 1988, called the "big tent" -- a party with "enough room for all kinds of positions."
Democratic dissidents have not scored a comparable success. With the Democratic Presidential candidates pledged to support the Freedom of Choice Act, there has been no talk of a "big tent" for Democrats.
Last Jan. 27, Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, a Democrat, complained that his party's unqualified support of abortion rights was alienating millions of voters. Mr. Casey delivered his analysis at the National Press Club in Washington in January and plans to make his case in detail at the University of Notre Dame next Thursday.
Yet quite apart from questions of political consequences, the Democratic and Republican positions have created moral misery for some who have been active party members and who find precious principles pitted against each other.
Ms. Stone, an important fund-raiser for Ronald Reagan, says she is committed to keeping government out of people's lives. "We can't be a party that says we trust corporate executives but we don't trust women," she said. "It's not good politics and it's not good ethics."
Politically active Democrats who oppose abortion sound even more torn. Some link their opposition to abortion to their qualms about military force and the death penalty. For Democrats like Governor Casey, opposing abortion is of a piece with access to improved health care and nutritional programs for infants and mothers. They are bitterly opposed to President Bush's economic policies.
David Medema is a case in point. In the early 1980's he left social work to become an aide to Stephen Monsma, a liberal Democratic state legislator from western Michigan who fought for many welfare measures but opposed state financing of abortions.
"We expected tolerance from the Democratic Party but found that tolerance evaporated around the abortion issue," Mr. Medema said. "For pro-life Democrats, money would dry up in election campaigns."
By 1988 he concluded that the party was simply losing touch with religiously and culturally conservative constitutencies. Today he is an independent and directs Justlife, an interdenominational Christian group that endorses liberal Congressional candidates who oppose abortion.
For many other anti-abortion Democrats the split conscience is simply reflected in a cooling of ardor. James R. Kelly, for example, is the chairman of the sociology department at Fordham University, a lifelong Brooklynite and a Democrat who voted for the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Mayor David N. Dinkins.
"Oh, I'll vote Democratic once again," he said. "But I'm no longer a proselytizing Democrat, and I think my name is legion."
These politically seasoned people seem to be objecting to something beyond the painful compromise that is inherent to a democracy. They believe that views like theirs are being silenced and caricatured.
Ms. Stone speaks of pro-choice Republican women who feel "intimidated." Governor Casey said "pro-life Democrats get written off as Neanderthals, and religous stereotypes come to the fore." Both sets of dissidents decry "litmus tests" and, at the very minimum, hope for a recognition that their parties can legitimately contain diverse views.
"If all the Democratic candidates show up at a National Abortion Rights Action League rally, couldn't they find a Birthright center for unwed mothers to visit?" Mr. Kelly asked. "Couldn't they make a gesture recognizing that some Democrats could be against abortion without being against women, or without being made to feel like they're fascists?"
Of course, that is exactly the kind of mixed message that many advocates of the right to choose abortion, and many of their anti-abortion counterparts, will not tolerate. Insofar as democracy ultimately demands a vote for or against, a case can be made for their pressure on parties to adopt clear-cut positions on abortion.
But democracy also demands rich and unconstrained exchanges of opinions. It is eroded by the disaffection of conscientious people who feel that their voices are stifled. The polarization of the parties on abortion is certainly generating such disaffection.

HEADLINE: Personal Incomes Jump 1.1%; Consumer Spending Up 0.9%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Personal incomes jumped 1.1 percent in February, the biggest leap in three years, the Government said today. The gain helped support a nine-tenths of a percent increase in consumer spending that will be crucial to any economic recovery.
February's strong figures "may overstate the underlying strength of the economy," said Lynn Reaser, an economist with First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles. But "there is an indication that the recovery process is under way," she added. 
 At the White House, the Presidential spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the spending increase in February and a similar one a month earlier meant that real consumption is rising at a solid 5 percent to 6 percent rate in the first quarter.
Noting that consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, he said the gains "represented a significant positive contribution" to overall growth.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, addressing a luncheon audience in New York, cited "a number of important signs that the U.S. economy is returning to a pattern of growth," including stepped-up activity in housing and higher retail sales.
But he counseled the Federal Reserve, as have others in the Administration, against a repeat of last summer when the central bank allowed money-supply growth to slow and the economy stalled. "If that happens again in the spring or summer of 1992, the recovery will be threatened and an opportunity lost," Mr. Brady said.
It was the latest call for monetary easing by an official of the Bush Administration, which is hoping for interest rates to remain low and for the recovery to be solidly in place by the time President Bush goes head-to-head with the Democratic nominee in Presidential campaigning this summer and fall.
In a separate report yesterday, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said 30-year fixed-rate mortgages declined this week for the first time in nearly two months. Rates averaged 8.98 percent, down from 9.03 percent last week.
Consumer spending rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in both February and January, the sharpest gains since back-to-back advances at the same pace in February and March last year, the Commerce Department said.
Spending totaled $4.03 trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate last month, up from $3.99 trillion in January. The department reported on Thursday that personal consumption remained flat through the final quarter of last year.
"The increase in spending is critical because there had been a buildup of inventories last year," Ms. Reaser said. "That had caused a reduction in orders from factories and a cut in production. That seems to be reversing now."
Incomes reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.97 trillion, up from $4.92 trillion in January. The increase was the largest since a 1.3 percent advance in January 1989, the department said.
But it also reported that January's revised two-tenths of 1 percent drop in incomes was a bit steeper than the original one-tenths of 1 percent estimate.
The report said income growth was driven by a $33.2 billion jump in wages and salaries, an increase in farm subsidies and a speed-up of life insurance dividends to veterans.
The 1.5 percent advance in wages and salaries, excluding Government payrolls, was the biggest since a 1.7 percent gain in December 1987. The Labor Department had reported earlier that 164,000 new jobs were created in February and the average workweek increased by four-tenths of an hour.
Disposable incomes -- incomes after taxes -- rose 1 percent after slipping one-tenth of 1 percent a month earlier.
Americans' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- rose to 4.7 percent in February, up from 4.6 percent a month earlier but down from 5.6 percent in December.

HEADLINE: Treasuries Up Sharply on Stocks' Plunge

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Big losses in the stock market and rumors that some investors were moving to bonds from equities helped send Treasury bond prices sharply higher yesterday after evidence of new economic strength failed to shake investor confidence.
"Part of the upward bias is the stock market," said Lawrence Schuster, the trading desk manager at Harris Government Securities in New York. "There might have been reallocation going on." 
 After sliding back on new signs of economic strength in February personal income and spending data, the benchmark 8 percent 30-year bond abruptly changed direction, closing 20/32 higher at 10020/32 .
The bond's yield sank to 7.94 percent, from 8 percent on Thursday.
 
Goldman Talk Cited
 Rumors that investment analysts were telling investors to shift out of stocks and into bonds gave way to talk that Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank, had changed the asset allocation of its model portfolio.
Goldman quickly denied the rumor, saying it was still bullish on stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.23 points yesterday to close at 3,231.44 in a market vulnerable to fears about the strength of any economic recovery.
Traders said the bond rally was also spurred by heavy short-covering, once the market proved itself able to withstand the shock of big increases in personal income and spending for February. Shorting occurs when when investors sell borrowed holdings in the hope that prices will fall so they can buy back the bonds at a low cost.
Evidence of economic strength usually undermines the bond market by increasing the possibility of higher interest rates and inflation.
 
Short-Sellers Caught Short
 But strong economic data failed to shake bonds yesterday, making prices rise and forcing investors who had sold short to scramble to buy back the bonds.
In yesterday's reports, personal income rose 1.1 percent in February and spending increased nine-tenths of a percent. Most traders had expected the figures to rise by seven-tenths of a percent and eight-tenths of 1 percent, respectively.
Treasury prices experienced an initial jolt after the data were released. But when the 30-year futures contract for June reached a floor price of 981/32 , the security met with investor demand and began to rebound.
 
Yield's Range Confined
 Analysts said the long bond's yield was basically boxed into a trading range of 7.9 and 8 percent.
"It's a fairly wide range to be fluctuating in, but we're in uncertain economic times," said Dan Seto, economist at the Nikko Securities Company International Inc. in New York.
The bill sector ended flat. Three-month rates fell by one basis point, or one-hundredth of a percent, to a discount rate of 4.01 percent. Six-month rates were down by 2 basis points, to 4.14 percent, and the year-bill was 3 basis points lower at 4.35 percent.
The two-year note was slightly higher at 1005/32 , yielding 5.67 percent. The 7 1/2 percent 10-year note climbed by 12/32 , to 9927/32 , to yield 7.52 percent.
Federal funds were trading at 3.62 percent late yesterday, compared with the Federal Reserve's presumed goal of 4 percent.

HEADLINE: Land Price Begins Fall In Japan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 27

 BODY:
After soaring to such heights that mere patches of Tokyo were worth more than the entire state of Florida, the price of land, Japan's most precious asset, is falling.
The National Land Agency reported on Thursday what real estate agents, bankers, some of the world's biggest manufacturers and scores of bankruptcy judges already knew: Land prices throughout the country have fallen significantly for the first time since 1975. 
 After years of sharp gains, any declines come as a shock, especially since many speculators are deeply in debt. Real estate analysts say that the Government's survey vastly understates the true magnitude of the declines, in part because large landholders are too frightened to reveal the prices they have received for some of their holdings.
 
Drop in Stocks
 According to the official statistics, prices dropped more than 5 percent nationwide and upward of 15 percent in Tokyo. In Osaka and Kyoto, which saw some of the most substantial run-ups in recent years, residential land was down 25 to 35 percent.
The real estate bust has propelled the decline of Japanese stocks and provided further evidence of the economic slump that has gripped the country.
Falling property values are in part the deliberate result of Government policies, like discouraging bank lending for speculative land deals, that the country's leadership is now under tremendous pressure to reverse.
 
Bankruptcy Filings Up
 Already the decline in land prices has caused a good deal of chaos in an economy that prides itself on calm and stability. Real estate speculators and large corporations that sought to cash in on rising prices now face major losses, as do the banks that backed them. Bankruptcy filings are up sharply.
The battle over land prices here is one of those subterranean tremors that shatters the myth of Japanese harmony. This one has pitted the banks, big manufacturers and real estate speculators against millions of young Japanese who grew up certain that they could never afford a home.
"Individuals and businesses have very different interests," said Tokunosuke Hasegawa, the executive director of the Research Institute for Construction and Economy, which was established by Japan's construction ministry. "Businesses saw through the 80's that Japanese land was a way to easy profits, and now they are hurting and putting a lot of pressure on to stop the decline."
But most people are cheering, and today several of the country's most influential newspapers urged the Government to stop putting industry's interests ahead of consumers, as the ruling Liberal Democratic Party almost always does.
 
More Decline Called For
 "The Government should not repeat past mistakes this time," warned Asahi Shimbun, in an editorial that called for land prices to decline an additional 20 or 30 percent. "Businesses and individuals that suffered losses in expectation of rises in the price of land should not be bailed out thoughtlessly."
Even the far more conservative Yomiuri Shimbun, while stopping short of seeking further declines, warned there was already evidence that the Government was cracking under the pressure and said that the nation's wavering land policy "looks like a repeat of past policy failures, and that could reignite the land price boom."
Joining the calls for a steeper decline is one more interested party: the United States. In trade negotiations over the last several years, American officials and business leaders have called Japan's phenomenally high land prices one of the biggest obstacles to doing business here. In theory, lower land prices should make it possible for more American companies to establish manufacturing and distribution centers in Japan and rent more offices and stores. In reality, the prices are still so high in comparison with the United States that the current decline is unlikely to persuade most American executives that Japan is suddenly a bargain.
In fact, it is not. Since 1986, when the current land boom began, prices in the hottest residential and commercial districts -- notably in Tokyo, Osaka and Kyoto -- have doubled or tripled. By most measures, less than half of those increases have been washed away in the last 18 months or so. "I think it still has a long way down to go," said Akio Mikuni, the president of Mikuni & Company, a bond-rating service that spends much of its time assessing the true value of land held by companies.
The total amount of debt involved in bankruptcy cases in 1989 was only 1.2 trillion yen, or about $9 billion at current exchange rates. The figure soared to $60 billion last year. Not all of these debts reflected bad real estate investments, but many involved speculators who borrowed when Japan's interest rates were among the lowest in the industrialized world, and secured their loans with the land they were purchasing. Now, they cannot unload it, and there is beginning to be a surplus of office space.
The speculators also included some of the country's biggest manufacturers. They bought land in the 1980's rather than report huge profits that would have subjected them to more taxes, the specter of new regulation and pressure to reduce their prices. Many borrowed against their land to finance new factories, new offices and new equipment.
The run-up in prices led to international comparisons that seemed to border on the ludicrous. The Imperial Palace grounds in the center of Tokyo was estimated to be worth more than entire American states, including Florida. The market value of the whole country's real estate, according to Government estimates, exceeded the market value of the United States -- even though Japan is about the size of California. In the Ginza, the commercial heart of Tokyo, a piece of property about the size of this newspaper page was worth roughly $50,000.
 
Windfalls For Some
 There were scores of unlikely beneficiaries. Among them were American companies, which sold office buildings and other property purchased in Japan during or just after the postwar American occupation of Japan. Australia sold 54,000 square feet of its embassy's land for something in the neighborhood of $400 million, and sent the money home to retire part of the national debt. Myanmar, formerly Burma, sold some of its property, leading to speculation by diplomats that it was using the money to arm more troops against rebel groups battling its repressive government.
Many ordinary Japanese who own their own homes -- more than 60 percent of families do -- found themselves overnight millionaires. But their enthusiasm for high prices was tempered by the high inheritance taxes levied on their huge assets.
For a while, the skyrocketing market turned small Japanese companies into huge real estate investors, many of them using quick profits to buy political influence, touching off several of the scandals that have shaken Japanese politics.
"It was more like money earned gambling," said Masashi Kojima, the president of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the giant domestic telephone company and one of the country's biggest landholders. "It will take the banks two years or so just to determine what their losses are, and what loans can be recovered. Only when the economy sorts this out can we move forward again." Falling real estate values have helped account for an 80 percent drop in Nippon's stock price since 1987.
 
Pressure on Banks
 The decline in prices is attributable at least in part to a half-hearted Government initiative to bring the real estate market down slowly, rather than risk a calamitous crash. The Government put pressure on banks to stop lending for land deals, a ban that was eased several months ago. Local governments reviewed proposed sales, and refused to issue permits and approvals if they thought the prices were too high.
But the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, fearful of the effect on its own campaign coffers, stopped short of enacting the significantly higher real estate taxes that would discourage companies from using property to store their wealth.
Officially the Government says that it wants prices to fall further, so that a Japanese family could buy a standard house or apartment for five times an average annual salary. That would mean housing that costs about 30 million yen, or $225,000, for a home considerably smaller than the average in America, and much farther from the center of large cities. Right now the average Japanese cost is twice that or more.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Despite Release of Favorable Economic Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower on world currency markets yesterday despite the release of positive economic news.
Gold prices were mostly higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $342.40 an ounce, up $1.30 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold gained $1.70 an ounce to a late bid price of $342.20. 
 In two reports that were more positive than many economists had expected, the Government said personal incomes posted their biggest increase in three years in February, rising 1.1 percent. And the Commerce Department said consumer spending, a key to economic revival, rose nine-tenths of a percent in both February and January.
Despite the fresh signs of growth, some analysts cautioned that the figures might be overstating the economy's underlying strength.
The dollar was down in both European and domestic trading, falling to its lowest levels in several weeks. Analysts said the currency was the victim of overall bearish sentiment.
"To see the dollar break down in this situation leads me to believe it is structurally weak," said Randolph Donney, research director of Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J.
The dollar was also undermined by speculation that the Bundesbank of Germany may have to raise interest rates and widespread expectations of a rate cut by the Bank of Japan.
Also putting pressure on the currency were comments by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who warned that the economy could falter again if the Federal Reserve failed to provide enough money to sustain the recovery.
Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors, diminishing their need for the United States currency.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.65 yen to close at 133.85 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 133.15 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 133.05 yen, down from 134.03 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7385, from $1.7215 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.7430 to buy a pound, compared with $1.7245 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Moratorium Spawns New Hope for Salmon

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant

 BODY:
One of the major obstacles to the restoration of significant spawning runs of Atlantic salmon to the rivers of Newfoundland, mainland eastern Canada and New England has been swept away, and champions of the species are elated.
The obstacle was a fixed gill net fishery in Newfoundland that was depleting that province's salmon stocks and also intercepting salmon bound for their natal streams in other provinces and New England. Some estimates, based on the recapture of tagged fish, had suggested that more than half of the salmon headed for the United States were being waylaid in the Newfoundland nets. 
 Earlier this month, Canadian officials overcame the obstacle and announced a moratorium on commercial salmon fishing in Newfoundland for at least five years. This will be coupled with a voluntary buyout of salmon licenses held by Newfoundland commercial fishermen. One-time payments to those licensees who wish to accept the offer will range from $8,000 to $50,000. Total cost of the program is estimated at $40 million, to be shared 70-30 by the Canadian Government and Newfoundland. In Labrador, which is part of Newfoundland, there will be no moratorium, but the same buyout offer is being made. Labrador's commercial salmon fishermen hold more than 400 of the approximately 3,000 licenses in all of Newfoundland. Labrador was exempted from the moratorium because of its high dependence on commercial salmon fishing, but the allowable commercial salmon catch in Labrador will decrease as the licenses there are retired.
The announcement was made by John C. Crosbie, Canada's Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, and Walter Carter, Fisheries Minister for Newfoundland. Commenting on the buyout payments, Carter said, "This offer allows fishermen the option of accepting up to eight times the value of their best year's landings since 1989, and given the current state of the resource may be acceptable to many license holders."
Approximately 433 metric tons of salmon were taken in the Newfoundland-Labrador commercial fishery in 1991, 39 percent below the lowest year in the 1980's and the fourth consecutive year of a declining harvest.
Carter noted that commercial salmon fishing was banned in Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick nearly 10 years ago.
David Clark, president of the Canadian-American Atlantic Salmon Federation, the largest and most influential salmon conservation organization in North America, said: "This will produce a healthy recreational fishery and will be a boon to local economies through outfitting, tackle and tourism industries. Salmon conservationists have worked for over 40 years to reach this moment."
While acknowledging that salmon netting has been a way of life in Newfoundland for scores of years, those who oppose it have long pointed out that an angler-caught salmon is worth 10 or more times more to the local economy than one in a commercial fisherman's net. The average guided angler in Canada spends about $350 to catch a single salmon. There was a time when those who opposed salmon netting believed that salmon farming, which was pioneered in Norway, would take the heat off wild stocks. That hasn't happened, even though farmed fish now account for most of the salmon that go to market: In 1990, only 10,000 of the 235,000 metric tons of salmon sold worldwide were wild fish.
While at sea, salmon from the United States, Canada, Europe and the United Kingdom congregate in the Davis Strait off Greenland. After one, two or three years, the survivors return to their natal streams to spawn. In the early 1960's, native Greenlanders launched a high-seas drift net fishery for salmon. That fishery is now under a quota set by the North Atlantic Salmon Conservation Organization and in recent years, with dwindling salmon stocks, that quota has not been met.
Some salmon conservationists think the Newfoundland development -- which had the backing of the Atlantic Salmon Federation's Newfoundland Council -- could result in further curtailment of the Greenland fishery. It might also result in more intense efforts to end the unlicensed drift net fishery for salmon that goes on off Ireland.
 
On the Fly
 A show devoted exclusively to fly fishing is scheduled for Park Plaza Castle in Boston April 24-26. Arranged by the magazine Fly Rod and Reel, it will include more than 85 manufacturers, shops and lodges, and experts will be on hand to discuss all aspects of the sport in both fresh and salt water. There will be a preview party from 5-9 P.M. April 24. Hours on April 25 are 10 A.M.-6 P.M., and 10 A.M.-4 P.M. on April 26. Tickets, available at the door and at some fly fishing shops, are $25 for the party and $7 for daily admission. The Park Plaza Castle is at 64 Arlington Street.

 
 
Croton Cleanup
 The streams of the Croton River watershed offer some excellent trout fishing, and there is no better way to learn about them than to attend one of the monthly meetings of the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited, which are open to the public. The next meeting is at 7:30 P.M. April 21 at the Fox Lane Middle School in Mount Kisco. Or, you might jump the gun and take part in a major Croton watershed trash cleanup on April 11 in which the Croton chapter is one of several organizations participating. To find out how you can help, call the Croton chapter's Richard Jogodnick at (914) 632-1269. . . . Trout Unlimited's New York City chapter will hold its Opening Day Gala and spring auction at 6:30 P.M. April 8 at the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue (12th Street).

HEADLINE: The Weekend Warrior War

 BODY:
If you get up early tomorrow you may see them, trooping through the morning mist to their armories in midtown Manhattan and suburban Seattle, as they do on many weekends during the year: They are the reservists and National Guard members who serve as the country's second line of defense. But if Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has his way, their numbers will drop by 140,000 in the next two years.
His proposal has ignited an expected counterattack from members of Congress and others eager to keep all those armories open. But on this military personnel question, Mr. Cheney is unarguably right and he deserves support. America can't cut the defense budget and redeem the peace dividend if it also tries to preserve peacetime patronage for part-timers. 
 But the Pentagon's full-time personnel policy suffers from its own flaws. The Defense Department wants to keep more active-duty forces than it needs. And it's resisting further budget cuts by contending these would require it to lay off more troops. The collapse of the Soviet threat warrants larger reductions in both active and reserve forces.
Part-time soldiers typically make about $5,000 a year for training one weekend a month and two weeks in the summer. And National Guard armories bolster communities in every state. That kind of patronage may be tolerable when it has military justification. But many units serve no purpose now that the forces they supported in Europe have been withdrawn. Eliminating 234,000 positions over five years will save $20 billion.
But reducing reserves offers only a start on prudent economies. Les Aspin, the House Armed Services chairman, wants to cut Mr. Cheney's proposed $281 billion budget by an additional $15 billion. That need not require, as Mr. Cheney contends, drastic cuts in active-duty personnel.
There's much to be saved by eliminating wasteful weapons like the B-2 bomber and the Army tactical missile system, and deferring others like the new aircraft carrier. Other savings can be realized by cutting back exercises and using fewer escort ships in carrier battle groups.
The Pentagon is right to resist hasty reductions in the active-duty force. That could damage military morale, break faith with service families and swell unemployment rolls. But it's extravagant to keep all of its so-called "base force" of 1.6 million troops.
The best way to spare its people undue hardship would be to plan now for inevitable cuts later. As any personnel manager knows, nothing so saps morale as repeated layoffs and continuing uncertainty. Then Congress needs to find ways to cushion the impact with job placement and retraining. America owes that to those who have served the country well, weekend warriors and full-time military personnel alike.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Battery Park City Adds to New York Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A March 8 news article speaks of Battery Park City as a project that no longer contributes to the economy of New York City. The Battery Park City landfill was completed in 1975 after four years of work, at a cost of about $80 million. From 1980 to 1988, the Battery Park City Authority spent about $11 million a year on such improvements as streets, the esplanade and public parks. 
 The authority has spent more on construction in each of the last three years than any past years. We will complete a $20 million park in May and the esplanade, north of Stuyvesant High School, joining Battery Park City to West Street ($3.2 million) in June. This year we begin on a four-block street ($2.6 million) and a two-acre park ($6 million).
By September the authority will complete construction for the Board of Education of the new Stuyvesant campus at a cost of approximately $150 million.
 
DAVID EMIL
President & Chief Executive Officer, Battery Park City Authority
New York, March 12, 1992

HEADLINE: S. & L. Role of Offcial Scruntinized

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan is being investigated by Federal authorities along with the other directors and executives of a failed Illinois savings association over their role in the institution, Federal officials said.
The investigation, which is standard practice in every failure of a bank and savings association, is concerned with whether Mr. Madigan and the other directors and officers were negligent in their management of Olympic Federal Savings Association of Berwyn, Ill., a western suburb of Chicago. 
 Officials said the investigation might determine whether to bring a civil lawsuit against the directors to make up the taxpayer losses or to refer the matter to the Justice Department for criminal prosecution.
 
Assets Are Sold
 The investigation came to light as the Government announced today that it had sold the assets of Olympic.
The investigation is one of hundreds into the conduct of directors and officers of failed institutions conducted by three Federal agencies that supervise the nation's banks and savings companies. The agencies have stepped up their investigations in recent months as they face increasing pressure from Congress and statute-of-limitations deadlines for bringing civil lawsuits.
Olympic was seized on Dec. 14, 1990, by Federal officials after it was unable to meet regulatory requirements. Its failure will cost taxpayers $111 million.
The assets were sold today by the Resolution Trust Corporation to 12 other institutions. The association had $521 million in assets and $621 million in liabilities, including $450 million in deposits.
Mr. Madigan was a director of Olympic from September 1983 until June 1990, the same time he served as a Congressman from Illinois and rose to the position of ranking Republican on the Agriculture Committee.
 
Another Inquiry
 He is the second senior Administration official known to be under investigation over the failure of a bank or savings association. Regulators have said that President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, is being investigated over his role as a director of the National Bank of Washington, which failed in 1990.
Roger D. Runningen, a spokesman for Mr. Madigan, said that the Agriculture Secretary "has not been alerted to any investigation" and that Mr. Madigan had been told that an audit last year by the Office of Thrift Supervision in a different legal proceeding had found no evidence of bad decisions by the Olympic directors.
A financial-disclosure report filed by Mr. Madigan last year showed that he was paid $56,900 in director's fees from Olympic and that he donated the money to charity. The disclosure statement also indicated that Mr. Madigan took out a 30-year mortgage of between $15,001 and $50,000 from the savings association in 1989, at a interest rate of 10.5 percent, for a condominium in McLean, Va., a suburb of Washington.
Mr. Madigan became Agriculture Secretary last year, replacing Clayton K. Yeutter, who left to head the Republican National Committee. He is one of three Cabinet members to disclose recently that as a member of Congress he had written checks on the House members' bank without sufficient funds to cover them.
On March 17, Mr. Madigan said his House bank account had had 49 overdraft checks after 1987, including one for $8,618.84 for a real estate settlement. The other two Cabinet members, Labor Secretary Lynn Martin and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, said they had written fewer overdrafts.
The failure of Olympic figured prominently in the appointment of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. in 1990 to head the newly created Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates the savings industry. On March 21, 1990, Olympic persuaded a Federal district judge that the Government could not seize it because the agency's acting director and his predecessor, M. Danny Wall, had been appointed unconstitutionally.
Mr. Wall and his immediate successor, the acting director, Salvatore R. Martoche, had not been nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate when they took their posts at the agency after it was created as part of the industry bailout bill signed in August 1989.
Other larger institutions then moved to block their seizures, and Mr. Ryan was quickly approved by the Senate in a bitter confirmation fight to avert the paralysis of the agency.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4; Column 2; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 955 words

HEADLINE: Concern for Greece Delays U.S. Move on Yugoslav Republics

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Concerned about the fragility of the Greek Government, the Bush Administration has delayed action on recognition of the successor republics of shattered Yugoslavia because of Greece's objection to an independent republic called Macedonia.
 The Macedonia dispute pits one Balkan nationalism against another, that of the Greeks against that of the South Slavs who call themselves Macedonians. 
After a referendum last year, the Republic of Macedonia declared independence from Yugoslavia. Greece, which had already been cool to the republic, began to insist that nobody but Greeks could use the name Macedonia, which they say is part of their heritage from classical antiquity. They call the state north of their border "the Republic of Skopje," a reference to the Macedonian capital.
 The Greek Prime Minister, Constantine Mitsotakis, has a two-vote majority in Parliament, and members from northern Greece have threatened to abandon him if he gives any ground on the Macedonia question.
 
Bush Spoke With Mitsotakis
 Administration officials said President Bush had told Mr. Mitsotakis last week that the United States would not recognize Macedonia in early April as previously planned. On April 6, the European Community, which has already recognized Slovenia and Croatia, is to meet to discuss recognition of Macedonia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. But American officials said today that it was increasingly unlikely that recognition would be extended to those republics at that time.
 Although the United States in principle is ready to recognize the sovereignty of all the former Yugoslav republics, it will probably wait until the European Community moves before it will go ahead with recognition of any of them.
 Last weekend, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3rd sent a letter to the 12 members of the European Community, including Greece, saying the United States still intended to follow the community's lead on recognition.
 At the same time, Mr. Baker said it was United States policy to give equal treatment to all of the pieces of the former Yugoslavia that have emerged from the six-month war of 1991 as independent republics. That means diplomatic recognition for four successor republics, Administration officials said.
 
40 Countries Followed Europe
 The European Community members extended recognition in mid-January to Slovenia and Croatia, which had seceded from Yugoslavia six months earlier. About 40 other countries followed suit.
 At a meeting in Brussels this month, community members agreed to try to grant recognition to the troubled multi-ethnic republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and perhaps to Macedonia at their next session, on April 6.
 But a community consensus on Bosnia and Herzegovina, the scene of sporadic fighting in recent weeks between Serbs and an alliance of Croats and Muslim Slavs, has not yet been reached, European diplomats said. Now as before, Greece stiffly refuses to approve joint European recognition of an entity called Macedonia.
 European diplomats said the community -- and now the United States -- had agreed to pause on the Macedonia issue to give "diplomacy time to work." Portugal, which now holds the community presidency, is trying to mediate a compromise on the name of Macedonia -- perhaps something like "Slav-Macedonia."
 
U.S. Won't Delay for Long
 But Administration officials said the United States would not delay recognition for long. "The way I understand it, we will recognize Slovenia, Croatia, and Bosnia-Herzegovina soon after the European Community acts on Bosnia-Herzegovina," one official said. "Then, after a short pause, we will recognize Macedonia, too, regardless of what the others do."
 For the 12 members of the community, the Macedonia issue has become a new test of its intention to maintain a common foreign policy. The question of recognizing Slovenia and Croatia was already very contentious. This time, several countries, notably Denmark and the Netherlands, have indicated that if the community could not reach an adequate consensus, they would feel free to recognize Macedonia.
 For the 10 million Greeks and the 2.5 million Macedonians, the issue has become much more than a matter of what's in a name.
 In the judgment of Bush Administration officials, the Macedonia dispute has stirred Greek emotions more than any issue since Turkey invaded Cyprus in 1974. They noted that on Feb. 14, more than a million Greeks demonstrated against the Macedonian Republic in Salonika, the capital of northern Greece.
 
Greeks See Slavic Threat
 Northern Greece, a region the Greeks call Macedonia, was inhabited mainly by Slavs before World War I. They were largely supplanted in the 1920's by Greek refugees from Asia Minor after the Greek-Turkish war, although thousands of ethnic Slavs remain in Greece.
 An Administration official specializing in Greek affairs said that despite the collapse of the Communist system in Europe and the collapse of Yugoslavia, many Greeks seem to fear a revived Slavic threat, even though the new Macedonian republic has no army. As a result, he said, Washington now acknowledges that a hasty move could topple Mr. Mitsotakis.
 There is tension north of the border too. In Skopje, President Kiro Gligorov has come under increasing pressure to promote Macedonian nationalist causes from radical members of the large political formation called the Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization-Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity.
 The radicals' cause has been strengthened by severe deterioration of Macedonia's economy resulting from the Yugoslav civil war and from sporadic Greek measures blocking commercial traffic.

HEADLINE: DOES SHE SPEAK FOR TODAY'S WOMEN?

 BODY:
New York NOW members march and demonstrate for reproductive choice and civil rights for lesbians and gay men, but we have also worked long and hard to help women assert their economic rights and to change the laws that maintain the unequal status of women as wives and mothers as well as in the workplace. Very little of this activity gets reported by the news media or is understood by the public. 
 For example, in both New York City and New York State, the largest number of phone calls to NOW have consistently been from women seeking help with problems of sex discrimination on the job (particularly pregnancy-related discrimination) and domestic-relations law issues. Some women may feel that NOW doesn't represent them, but the truth is, when these women need help, NOW is still the place they call.
 
BARBARA T. ROCHMAN
Special Counsel to NOW-New York State
New York, N.Y.
