HEADLINE: Columbia's Big Medical Center Plans Expansion

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
THE Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, already the most formidable private force in upper Manhattan real estate, is poised to expand significantly westward, to the river side of Riverside Drive, where its affiliate, the New York State Psychiatric Institute, would build a new home.
The site is an empty 1.37-acre tract south of 168th Street. Wooded and shrubby, the land looks much like the surrounding Fort Washington Park, but it is owned by Columbia University. If developed, the six-story institute would be one of few large structures ever built on the west side of Riverside Drive. It would also have pedestrian bridges over the drive. 
 Although the project is still taking shape, it has already been criticized as an intrusion in a parklike setting.
"I just think you can't put a building on that open space," said Betsy F. Gotbaum, the Parks and Recreation Commissioner. "I think they're going to have a hell of a time with the community if they don't leave it." She said that although the plot is privately owned, it is shown on the official city map as parkland and she is trying to raise money to acquire it.
Meanwhile, the medical center is also poised to expand eastward, across Broadway, where Columbia would develop three blocks around Mitchel Square as a research park. It would begin with the first phase of the Audubon Research Building, between 165th and 166th Streets, behind the facade of the old Audubon Theater and Ballroom. Next would come the Center for Disease Prevention, on St. Nicholas Avenue, between 167th and 168th Streets.
Given that construction has virtually stopped in New York -- and that upper Manhattan never saw much in boom times -- the $84.3 million Psychiatric Institute project and the $37.6 million Audubon project represent notable initiatives.
"It will give us expanded space that will give additional employment opportunities," said Dr. John M. Oldham, director of the Psychiatric Institute. "And many of the employees come from the neighborhood: clerical people, data-processing people, support staff."
Dr. Herbert Pardes, Columbia's vice president for health sciences and dean of the faculty of medicine, said: "We've had a large number of companies from the U.S. and abroad come to us and say: 'We want to have a collaborative program with you. We want to be near you.' That's the kind of thing that made the Boston and Palo Alto areas thrive. But we've had no place to put them."
"THIS center is in one of the tightest straitjackets of any academic center in the country," Dr. Pardes said. "We've been working on ways to develop the center in such a way as to keep Columbia right at the top and also develop opportunities for science, clinical programs and increased economic activity in the area. We're the biggest economic entity in this part of town."
Some 14,000 people work for the Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University at the medical center.
The Audubon project has already been at the center of intense debate, out of which emerged the plan to preserve as a memorial the Broadway facade and much of the old ballroom, where Malcolm X was killed in 1965. And the Psychiatric Institute project is also likely to come in for sharp scrutiny.
Officials of the 97-year-old state-run institute, which has been affiliated with the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center since the 1920's, believe that a new building is the only practicable way to provide patients, researchers and staff with quarters that are modern, smoothly running and capable of meeting accreditation codes.
Financed by state bonds, the new building would contain 300,000 to 350,000 square feet. Its six floors would cover almost the entire lot. It would be directly across Riverside Drive from the existing institute, linked by overhead bridges to the Dr. Lawrence C. Kolb Research Facility and the Milstein Hospital Building. The architects are Ellerbe Becket, of Manhattan.
Within the building would be 72 patient beds, treatment areas, offices for administrators and residents, an auditorium, classrooms, some research departments (most are in the Kolb building), a psychiatric library and outpatient research clinics for depression, late-life depression, anxiety, memory disorders, eating disorders, schizophrenia and child psychiatry.
As soon as the Psychiatric Institute vacated the existing building, it would revert to Columbia. No decision had been made yet whether to demolish the structure or put it to some kind of limited use, said Dr. William A. Polf, a deputy vice president of Columbia.
The existing building, which has four finger-like wings and rises to a 20-story tower, was completed in 1929. It has almost as much square footage as the new building, but only about half is usable, Dr. Oldham said.
"The building is configured and constructed in a way that's very outdated," he said. "In many ways, we're extensively out of compliance with current, existing codes."
For example, he said, the long wings do not allow fire exits at both ends. The narrow configuration also does not permit enough common rooms for patient care.
MOREOVER, Dr. Oldham said, there has been no major renovation in 63 years and "the infrastructure has become quite marginal, with fairly frequent breakdowns and emergencies."
The boilers, he said, are barely hanging on. Ventilation is inadequate. The building does not have sprinklers. A water main has broken twice. The driveway had to be closed. There is not enough power for buildingwide air-conditioning.
Going back to the early 80's, Dr. Oldham said, various renovation plans were considered, but "the more we studied it in earnest, the more we realized the difficulties involved in doing anything with the existing building."
The institute could not find "a way to locate adequate swing space and then to build around ourselves," he said. "It would take much more time and our money would not cover those additional expenses."
That was when officials looked to the west, to Columbia's land across Riverside Drive.
Columbia and Presbyterian each own a tract between Riverside Drive and the Henry Hudson Parkway, 165th and 168th Streets. They are part of the Harkness patent, a gift of 22 acres made in 1925 by Anna M. Richardson Harkness and her son, Edward S. Harkness, to the medical center, which was coming into existence. A 1928 rendering showed that three small buildings were envisioned on the west side of Riverside Drive.
As to Presbyterian's current thinking about its parcel, David L. Ginsberg, the executive vice president and chief planning officer, said: "We have absolutely no plans for that. It's a piece of parkland and we left it as such in our master plan."
The Columbia and Presbyterian parcels were mapped as parkland in 1966, said Jack T. Linn, an assistant commissioner in the Parks and Recreation Department. He said there were one or two other instances around the city of this kind of anomalous mapping.
Ms. Gotbaum said the city had received an $828,000 grant from the state, through the Environmental Quality Bond Act, toward the purchase price of the parcels, which she estimated as $2 million. It would be "foolhardy," she said, if the city did not try to acquire the land as part of Fort Washington Park.
However, Dr. Oldham said: "It isn't parkland. Technically, there is a clear title owned by the university." He said the process by which building could take place was "still being worked through" and that the institute was committed to an environmental review. "We want as much input as we can," he said.
Any suggestion of construction in a park could raise the temperature of the debate, since the project involves Columbia, which was paralyzed in the 1960's by its plan to build a gymnasium in Morningside Park.
Councilman Stanley E. Michels, a Democrat who represents upper Manhattan, said of the proposed building site that "even though Columbia owns it, the community regards it as parkland."
"To do something on the other side of Riverside Drive is very disturbing," he said. "I think the community will be very resistant to it. We have nothing built on that side. You have beautiful views of the George Washington Bridge and the Palisades."
But Dr. Oldham said: "Our feeling is that we've worked very hard to be sensitive to community concerns. One example is our attempt to keep the building at a low level, so it won't interfere with the view corridor." Considering the local topography, he noted, "if you were standing on Haven Avenue, you'd be one story above the roof."
Councilman Michels said he would keep his mind open but confessed to "some very, very bad feelings about what they want to do," adding that "they're going to have to prove to me that this won't be a bad precedent."
Other elected officials from the area seem more positively inclined toward the project.
"I don't have a major opposition to it," said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., a Democrat. He added, "I could be educated."
"I am not dying because you're on that side of the street," he said, "but I know people who would get upset about that. I think they've dealt with the problem of blocking of light by lowering it, so that when you're standing on 168th Street, you'll be able to look across to New Jersey."
As for the property itself, Mr. Farrell said: "That area is nothing but a strip zone and anyone who gets caught there after sundown is in dire trouble. It isn't like an area that's being used constantly, that we're stealing from folks. When they finish cleaning it, it gets dumped on again."
Indeed, the area was dubbed Dead Dog Park after Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern came upon a dog carcass there.
State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat whose district embraces upper Manhattan, said: "I'm not supporting the project yet but clearly the medical institutions up there are very important. Finding space is always a problem. I think they've been good neighbors to the community and the community has to recognize the importance of reaching an accommodation."
The chairwoman of Community Board 12, Maria Luna, said the board has not taken a position, as it had not seen the proposal until last Tuesday. She said, however, that it was widely assumed in the neighborhood that the building site was part of the park.
The Audubon plan had to survive a controversy of its own, since Columbia began by proposing to raze the old structure entirely. As the site of the assassination of Malcolm X, the ballroom drew many defenders -- among them Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan -- who wished to see it preserved for its historic significance. A compromise was reached and the project was approved by the Board of Estimate in 1990.
As the plans now stand, the first Audubon Research Building will be constructed on the northeast side of the block on which the 80-year-old theater sits.
This commercial building, Dr. Polf said, is intended for companies that want to be located near the medical center or that spin off from research conducted at the center. The first phase will have about 100,000 square feet and rise six stories. The second phase could include up to 250,000 square feet more.
The architects for both the preservation and new construction are Davis, Brody & Associates of Manhattan, one of whose partners, J. Max Bond Jr., has been associated with the Audubon project since 1984.
The existing Broadway facade -- a vibrant but badly deteriorated terra-cotta fantasy -- will be preserved, as will a major portion of the ballroom. There will be a community health clinic and stores on ground level.
The city will pay for the $1.6 million demolition job. Preservation will be financed by $7.1 million from the city and $1.1 million from the borough president's office. Construction will be financed by $11.2 million from the city, $8.1 million from New York State and $8.5 million from Columbia.
"IT'S a project that's moving forward and it will be a tremendous economic benefit for northern Manhattan and the city as a whole," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
"We're providing a significant amount of public funding to this phase," he said, "because we want to jump-start it."
The next installment in the research park plan would be the first phase of the Center for Disease Prevention, which might involve a building of at least 150,000 square feet, growing over time to 290,000 square feet. Three small structures now stand on the block -- a bank on St. Nicholas Avenue, a two-story commercial building next door and a day-care center on 168th Street. No one lives there, Columbia officials said. The university's current plan is to develop along St. Nicholas Avenue, after relocating the day-care center and commercial tenants.
One block south is a parking lot owned by Columbia, which will also be the site of a commercial building, but that development is "a long way down the pike," Dr. Polf said.
The Presbyterian Hospital completed the enormous Milstein Hospital Building in 1989 and the Allen Pavilion, at the northernmost tip of Manhattan Island, in 1988.
Today, "there are no major new buildings anywhere near on the horizon," Mr. Ginsberg said. However, he said the hospital would support and join in redeveloping the Fort Washington Armory, at Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street, which is now an enormous men's shelter.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

MEDIEVAL MUSIC
 Two men and two women calling themselves the Voice of the Turtle will sing and play the music of medieval Spanish and Portuguese Jews, known as Sephardim, at Temple Israel in Westport on Friday at 8:30 P.M. The temple has chosen to mark the 500th anniversary of the expulsion of the Jews from Spain in 1492 with this performance. 
 The music group, based in Boston, was formed 13 years ago. It travels throughout the United States, Canada and England, performing Sephardic music.
"We discovered the music through hearing someone sing it and listening to musicologists' recordings made in Jerusalem, New York and other places where Sephardic communities exist," said one of the musicians, Julia Wachs. There is almost no written text; the songs are passed on orally from one generation to the next.
Most of the music is sung in Ladino, the medieval Judeo-Spanish language, and some of it reflects the influences of the eastern Mediterranean countries to which Spanish Jews fled, including Greece, Turkey and Morocco.
Appearing in traditional costume, the musicians accompany themselves on antique instruments or reproductions. The psaltery, harp and rebec are the more familiar ones, but there is also the kamanja, a Turkish fiddle; the shawm, ancestor of the oboe; cornetto, descendant of the shofar or trumpet-like ram's horn; baglama and saz, Turkish lutes of varying sizes, and the Spanish medieval bagpipe with only one drone, a smaller instrument than its Scottish counterpart.
The concert, at 14 Coleytown Road, is open to the public free of charge.
 
BASS FISHING
 Larry Nixon of Bee Branch, Ark., a professional bass fisherman to be reckoned with. was voted best overall angler on the Bassmaster Tournament Trail last August by The B.A.S.S. Times, a fishing publication, and he won the 1990 B.A.S.S. Megabucks Tournament in Leesburg, Fla.
Mr. Nixon will conduct free seminars on his favorite subject, complete with demonstrations, Saturday and next Sunday in New Milford at 10 A.M. and 1 P.M. each day at the Fischel Marina on Lake Lillinonah. The marina is on the West Street Extension. Call 354-2578 for more information.
 
SISTINE FRESCOES
 The next best thing to visiting the Sistine Chapel in Rome may be to view the film that documented the restoration of its ceiling frescoes. "Return to Glory: Michelangelo Revealed," filmed on the scaffolding from which the frescoes were cleaned and narrated by Edwin Newman, will be screened on Saturday at 4 and 7:30 P.M. in the Stanley Center, 1255 Corbin Avenue, New Britain.
The viewer may observe at close range the paintings and the actual restoration process. Candle grease, air pollution, dirt and incense built up over centuries, were removed.
Showings of the film will help support the restoration of Andrew Wyeth's painting "McVey's Barn," owned by the New Britain Museum of American Art. Tickets, at $10, may be reserved by calling 229-0257.
 
SYMPHONIC PSALM
 Arthur Honneger's symphonic psalm "King David" will be performed at 7 this evening in Wethersfield, commemmorating the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth in 1892. The performance, adhering to the original 1922 orchestration, will take place at the First Church of Christ, 250 Main Street, under the direction of David Spicer.
The Rev. Alvan Johnson, pastor of Bethel A.M.E. Church in Hartford, will be the narrator; Christine Andreas will portray the witch, and Peter Harvey will be the tenor soloist. The First Church Choir and Cantata Singers, the church's youth choirs, the City Singers of Hartford, the junior and senior high school choirs of Rocky Hill and five adult soloists will take part. Admission will be $7, $5 for students and the elderly.
 
OLD AND YOUNG
 Explaining the death of a loved one to a young child is a daunting task for most parents. "The Arkansaw Bear," a play by Aurand Harris, deals with the subject in a manner that children can respond to without fear or distress. It will be presented by the Hartford Children's Theater today at 2 P.M. in the Roberts Theater of the Kingswood Oxford School, West Hartford.
Using the circus as a setting, the story concerns an aged bear who must inevitably confront the Ringmaster, the play's symbol of death, a non-threatening figure in a brightly colored uniform. A young girl saddened by the impending death of her grandfather learns to understand something of life's continuity by helping the bear teach circus tricks to a young student.
Tickets are $8, $6 for children. Call 523-4479 for reservations.
 
LOVE OF GARLIC
 Requests for garlic ice cream may be limited (garlicless ice cream will also be available), but visitors to the Garlicfest at Notre Dame High School in Fairfield will surely salivate over steak, chicken, focaccia, pork and beef bracciola, pasta and vegetables cooked, stuffed or garnished with a variety of garlic sauces, chopped garlic, whole garlic and garlic in many manifestations dreamed up by chefs from more than a dozen local restaurants.
While most of the dishes will be Italian, there will be some Greek and Thai foods prepared with the celebrated bulb, and a garlic gourmet shop will be stocked with garlic dressings, seasonings, wines, jellies, mustards, pastas and olive oils. Other items for sale include T-shirts, garlic storage jars and garlic presses.
The school is at 220 Jefferson Street, and the festival will be open on Friday from 5 to 11 P.M., Saturday from noon to 11 P.M. and next Sunday from noon to 6 P.M. Admission will be $1. Proceeds will aid the school's scholarship fund. Call 372-6521 for more information.
 
RIGHTS AND NATURE
 A conference titled Earth Rights and Responsibilites, at the Yale Law School in New Haven Friday through Sunday, will explore the connection between human rights and environmental protection. Among the speakers are Guido Calabrese, dean of the Yale Law School; Sherwood Rowland, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science; Chief Joagquisho, director of Native American Studies at the State University of New York; Senator Al Gore, author of "Earth in the Balance: Ecology and the Human Spirit," and Kerry Kennedy-Cuomo of the Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Human Rights Foundation.
Topics to be discussed in daily roundtables include establishing standards by which a healthy environment can be measured; the legal rights of individuals, groups and communities to participate in decisions affecting their environment, and ways in which world populations might influence decisions made by the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to pursue projects of global import.
A sampling of experts taking part in the discussions includes Eduardo Viola, professor of sociology at the University of Santa Caterina, Brazil; Andras Sajo, professor of law, Budapest University; Lalaneth De Silva, lawyer for the Environmental Foundation Ltd. of Sri Lanka, and United States Representative John E. Porter, House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Conference hours are Friday noon to 6:15, Saturday 8 to 6:45 and Sunday 8 to 2. Registration and two breakfasts cost $35, but the fee may be waived for economic hardship. Lunches and dinners are available at extra cost. Call 432-4876 for more information.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Rental Housing;
Taking Steps to Head Off Abandonment

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
WITH a fervent "Thank you O Lord!" Linda Frank walked out of a City Hall hearing room a happy woman last Tuesday.
An arcane city body called the In Rem Foreclosure Release Board had just voted to allow her to redeem the eight-family house at 36 Hawthorne Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn that the city had taken for nonpayment of taxes. 
 Mrs. Frank is a nurse who bought the house in 1977. She sank her savings into improving it, she said. She also fell behind on taxes after a seriously leaking roof forced a $10,000 repair and used up her savings. "I paid the contractor cash and the city came down on me," she said. Ultimately, she worked out a repayment plan. City officials supported her redemption appeal.
It was another vignette in the tax-foreclosure drama, played out against the background of concern in housing circles that property takeovers by city government will rise again as a consequence of the recession. Tax delinquencies have already risen amid bankruptcies and workout efforts.
Most delinquencies are repaid before city vesting, or takeover, occurs. Even after that many properties are redeemed, some during the four-month period when redemption by the city is mandatory if the taxpayer pays, and others during the discretionary redemption period thereafter. The Foreclosure Release Board is the body with the discretionary power. It seems kindly disposed to owners who want to pay up.
But housing thinkers these days are looking at ways to keep buildings from getting into the foreclosure bind in the first place. Essentially they want to head off owner abandonment, the housing scourge of the 70's and the cause of staggering rehabilitation costs in the 80's and 90's.
A new report from the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, "Preserving New York City's Low-Income Housing Stock," warns that new approaches are needed to do this.
Operating costs are rising sharply in some areas. Rent increases to offset them are either not affordable by low-income tenants or not available under the rent-regulatory system.
"Because there isn't the ability to raise operating income, buildings will eventually be milked or fall into city hands," said Joseph B. Rose, executive director of the council, a 55-year-old civic organization concerned with housing, planning and urban development.
Mr. Rose noted that the most drastic cost increases, for property taxes and prospectively for water use, have been caused by government itself.
The curative medicines prescribed by the council involve a mixture of new subsidies, rent passalongs and cost-capping, but not an overhaul of the rent-regulation system. "We recognize the need to operate within the context of current regulatory policies," Mr. Rose said.
The report was written by the council's research director, Frank P. Braconi, under the direction of a 14-member committee headed by Marvin Markus , an investment banker. It will become available to the public next month.
THE latest figures from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development show that vestings, or city takings, have averaged about 6,200 dwelling units a year over the last three years. About two-thirds of the units have gone back to owners in the redemption process.
The number of dwelling units finally abandoned, and left to the city to demolish or resell after a rehabilitation process, has averaged 2,000 units over the last three years. In some years of the 70's and early 80's, the city was taking 10,000 to 30,000 housing units and owners were redeeming very few of them.
The most recent projections are not encouraging, especially in Manhattan. There has been a 44 percent pick-up in the ratio of unredeemed to redeemed properties over the last two years.
The housing agency expects that 86 Manhattan buildings with 690 apartments will be abandoned in the the current fiscal year, ending June 30.
The greatest immediate danger to housing is that rent levels cannot cover rises in operating costs, endangering maintenance and fiscal stability.
Low-income neighborhoods are particularly threatened. There are about 350,000 privately owned regulated units in the 19 census districts where the poverty rate exceeds 25 percent, the council said.
A large number of the tenants in this housing already receive housing or other subsidies. To offset property tax increases, the housing council proposes a new program similar to the Senior Citizens Rent Increase Exemption program. That program provides exemptions from rent increases for elderly tenants earning under $15,000 a year who pay more than a third of their income as rent; owners are compensated by tax reductions equal to the rent exemptions.
THE housing council would expand this approach, providing nonelderly, nonwelfare tenants who pay more than a third of their income as rent with a similar exemption. The result would be greater tax savings for buildings in which owners cannot collect rent increases to which they are entitled because many tenants cannot afford higher rents.
Other recommendations, none of them novel, include an increase in the shelter allowance for welfare tenants; a new process to make hardship rent-adjustments possible in regulated housing, and more powers for the In Rem Foreclosure Release Board to enable it to help buildings return to financial viability.
To meet the prospective rise in water costs as metering takes hold, and to further metering's conservation goals, the council proposes a 50 percent pass-along of water and sewer charge increases for stabilized apartments. It would also cap at 15 percent the increase in water and sewer charges that any building could experience in a single year.
To private and nonprofit owners alike, a surge in water and sewer charges is the biggest immediate threat to operations. Many private owners have decided against metering their buildings because of the leap in charges they have heard about from others that did.
Ultimately, the city will meter those buildings itself. New or recently gut-rehabilitated properties are already metered.
The promotion of water conservation was one of the main purposes of the turn to universal water metering, which began in 1986. But the council notes that when metering is completed, nearly 1.1 million households in rental units will not be billed directly for their water use. They will have little incentive to conserve.
AT the Department of Environmental Protection, Steven P. Ostrega, director of the Bureau of Water and Energy Conservation, said that only 5,000 multifamily buildings have been metered so far. The estimate of the number of buildings with five units or more is 80,000.
Metering has already demonstrated an enormous range in average water use in multifamily buildings -- from 70 gallons per unit a day to a remarkable 800 to 1,000 gallons per unit a day. Malfunctions or leaks may explain some of the high figures, he said. Under national standards, "moderate" use is considered 70 to 110 gallons on average per day; 110 to 140 gallons is deemed "very high."
A joint study by the environmental agency and the Rent Guidelines Board is planned to determine the impact of metering on various types of multifamily units. If an unacceptable impact on housing is confirmed, the study would presumably lead the city to change its rent guidelines or a revise the rate structure. But officials speak guardedly of the possibility.
So far, many owners who lose their properties through tax foreclosures are finding ways to redeem them. But occasionally the tenants fight against redemption; they want the building in city hands or their own after a dismal experience with an owner.
That situation led to a lively battle over the six-story loft at 545 Broadway, at Prince Street, last year. The In Rem Foreclosure Release Board -- a body set up under the charter revision of 1989 and consisting of the Mayor, the president of the City Council and the Comptroller, each with two votes, and the five Borough Presidents, each with one vote -- returned the building to the owner.
"Any owner who wants his property back needs to get involved in the process before the hearing," said Jeffrey E. Glen, the lawyer who represented the owner. "To think you can come in and simply write out a check is naive."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: The Diamond District;
Behind the Glitter, Recession Hurts an Exotic Bazaar

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
GREETING everyone by name, Robert Waldron Jr., leasing agent for 36 West 47th Street, a 16-story, turn-of-the century building in the heart of the Diamond District, was making his weekly rounds of tenants occupying booths on the "exchange" -- the building's first floor retail space of 7,500 square feet.
It is here among the 62 booths that dealers, some born in Eastern Europe, Russia, Israel, the Middle East, India, Hong Kong, Korea and Iran, spend the day among a glittering cornucopia of gems, selling their wares in a lively atmosphere that combines elements of the Lower East Side a century ago with an Oriental bazaar. 
 From one of the booths a matronly woman acknowledged Mr. Waldron with the wave of a check, promising to keep it safe in her cash register so she could pay her rent promptly. "You see," she said as she shook it vigorously, "I'm putting it aside just for you."
In the recession that has dealt a mortal wound to a growing number of the district's smaller dealers, the personal touch can become the Midas touch to a landlord anxious to survive and prosper.
Rents in the district have fallen from a high of around $50 a square foot in the late 80's to around $25 today. Instead of a waiting list to get into the buildings along the block, owners must now aggressively market their space when it becomes vacant and coddle the tenants who remain. Instead of prompt rent payments they have to deal with arears and often must work out payment schedules.
Rents are slipping even at 580 Fifth Avenue, the district's 34-floor Beaux-Arts flagship building at 47th Street that houses the Diamond Dealers Club of New York. Its 10th-floor, 23,000-square-foot bourse is where many of the major deals are still clinched over an old-fashioned handshake and the Hebrew greeting, "mazal u'bracha" (luck and blessing).
"This business is like family," said Edwin M. Roer, the building's managing partner. "You do what you can to help. We want to keep our tenants. They're good people."
Moreover, the district itself is contracting. In the 70's and 80's it was rapidly spilling over from its original one-block nucleus on West 47th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues onto parallel stretches of West 46th and West 48th Streets and even -- the most radical reach of all -- onto the East Side of Fifth Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets. Now some dealers are abandoning what became a sort of jeweler's diaspora to return to the heartland.
ANOTHER reason space abounds is that rents spiraled so high in the boom years that it drove some jewelry manufacturing to Long Island City and the West 30's where rents were cheaper, said Frank Ring, owner and manager of 20 West 47th Street.
Other dealers had grown so prosperous they hankered after the prestige of a Fifth Avenue address to impress their growing international clientele. They moved into fancier buildings on the east side of Fifth that had rarely catered to diamond dealers before and many of them are not returning.
But there is always good in the bad, as the philosophical dealers would be quick to point out. Consider the experience of Amir Eli, a dealer who came to the United States from Israel 16 years ago.
A booth along Diamond and Jewelry Way, as the block was named a decade ago, had long been his dream. But it had also been out of his financial reach. By last November, however, rents had fallen low enough at 36 West 47th Street to transform his dream into reality. "Its where all the good customers come to look," said Mr. Eli, who sells accessories such as jewelry boxes and settings. "This is it."
The story of the 100,000-square-foot building at 36 West 47th Street mirrors, in part, the experience of other buildings along this colorful block where yamulkas and fedoras remain as much a symbol of its close fraternity as baseball caps at a truck stop.
Back in 1988 the building was considered a gold mine when it was bought for $25 million by a partnership headed by Harry Skydell, a developer and builder. Escalation clauses in leases had taken some rents as high as $70 a square foot -- on a par with the best midtown skyscrapers.
A $2 million renovation was planned. But just as it got under way, wholesale and retail sales of jewelry fell sharply as the impact of the 1987 stock market crash began to be felt in the industry. Tenants began leaving and by April 1991 occupancy was down to 58 percent, Mr. Waldron said, with half of the remaining tenants more than 60 days in arrears. Others were so fearful of the future they refused to sign new leases.
Existing leases were renegotiated to "more reasonable levels," said Mr. Waldron's brother, Eric, vice president and managing director of Waldron Associates, which had been brought in to handle the workout. Settlements were reached concerning arrears. Emphasis was placed on getting to know each tenant personally. "Around here it's still a people business," said Robert Waldron. "It makes a difference if they know you really care."
New leases were offered for only one or two years, enabling the removal of escalation clauses that has caused so much distrust and distress.
As rents dropped to around $25 a square feet and renovations were completed, word got out that the building was once again a good deal -- reputation being a prime marketing tool in the Diamond District, as Eric Waldron put it.
Today occupancy is up to 85 percent with only 5,000 square feet left to fill. About 10 retail booths are still available.
THE district is in flux in other ways. In a business where thousands of dollars of merchandise is often carried around in a breast pocket, security is a major concern. The dealers' insurance companies began making increasing demands. The result is that today visitors to the district quickly get the feeling that they have wandered into an armed camp. Closed-circuit monitors, turnstiles requiring electronically coded access cards and uniformed guards on patrol keep tabs on the comings and goings in all the buildings.
This need has also brought a new kind of tenant. Symbolic of the change was the transformation a year ago of 10,000 square feet of basement area in Mr. Ring's building at 20 West 47th Street into a headquarters for DGA Alarm Services. "It wasn't good enough to respond from 45 minutes away," said Brendan Gillespie, a DGA vice president. "You had to have a presence on the street."
The downturn has also forced other buildings to make changes in order to compete. Lobbies and hallways are starting to lose their dowdy 50's look and take on the spiffier character of the 90's. More of the street's first-floor exchange areas offer a contemporary ambience that combines dazzling mirrors with lots of gilt, glass and chrome.
The bourse itself was redesigned in the mid-80's at a cost $3 million to become the epitome of sophistication -- a floor-through area with soft carpeting and open seating, decorated in muted shades of gray and filled with an array of electronic gear. "Our place was too old world," William Goldberg, a former president of the Diamond Dealers Club, had remarked to his peers. "It smelled a little of herring. It was time to move into the Pepsi generation."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
A Restoration Aims to Perk Up Hartford

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE architectural centerpiece of Connecticut is about to be rejuvenated in ample time for its 200th birthday in 1996. The Old State House at the heart of downtown Hartford, the oldest legislative building in the country, the state's first capitol, an erstwhile City Hall and frequent candidate for demolition, has served as a museum and exhibition hall since 1979.
Topped with a gold-leafed dome, it sits on an acre and a half of prime real estate called State House Square, the same site where in 1639 the first written constitution in America was signed in a plain wooden meeting house. The handsome Federal-style building designed by Charles Bulfinch of Boston was completed in 1796. 
 Still clad in its original brick and brownstone, the deteriorating structure will be strengthened and restored with historical accuracy at a cost of $7 million. The state supplied $2.3 million, the rest was raised from corporations and individuals.
"We are creating a focal point," said Wilson Faude, executive director of the State House, "combining Williamsburg and the Faneuil Hall-Quincy Market in the middle of a business district."
The ability to mount exhibitions and run educational programs will be enhanced by upgrading the interior. Outdoors, on the east lawn, a year-round schedule of concerts, theater and holiday programs will be devised in conjunction with the Hartford Stage Company, the Hartt School of Music of the University of Hartford, the Hartford Symphony Orchestra and other institutions.
On the west lawn along Main Street, costumed vendors will hawk Connecticut produce, crafts, plants, flowers and foods from wagons and stalls. Lunches may be bought and eaten in a picnic area, and the tower bell, long silent, will again toll the hours. "We hope to double our 1991 attendance of 322,000 visitors," Mr. Faude said.
The restoration is symptomatic of the city's longing to polish its tarnished image and climb back to an economic as well as symbolic status befitting a State Capitol. But the recession remains an obstruction.
"The renovation is one factor in the revitalization of downtown, but it's no panacea," said Nicholas Fusco, chairman of the City Council's Operations, Management and Budget Committee. "Unemployment is almost 16 percent compared to 7.3 percent statewide, and we have not yet dealt with 7,500 workers let go at United Technologies."
Carl Traub, vice president of Cushman & Wakefield Commercial Realtors, summed up the market this way: "Office vacancies are running around 18 percent. There is no new construction and nothing planned. Rents are down 15 to 20 percent from two years ago, in the teens and low $20's per foot. Tenants can make deals, and there is free rent available."
Traffic congestion and a shortage of parking that plagued the city for years have abated as vacancies have risen. "There are a dozen garages within walking distance of State House Square, the Wadsworth Atheneum, the Hartford Stage and the Civic Center," Mr. Faude said.
Smith Edwards, Hartford architects, have spent five years planning the rehabilitation of the former capitol's 20,000 square feet. The west foundation will be shored up to support a newly excavated 10,000-square-foot underground wing that will display significant treasures of the Connecticut Historical Society. The museum shop will be expanded with 600 square feet of unused basement space.
The Great Hall at street level, once an open-air arcade passing through the building, will house a Connecticut Hall of Fame, flanked by the former Supreme Court chambers and an art gallery. The second floor contains the old Senate and House chambers and a museum of the building's history. Once a year the General Assembly will hold public sessions in the chambers, and an elevator will be installed to insure access by the disabled and elderly.
After many years, the west side gates on Main Street will be opened, permitting entry and egress east and west, and the east lawn will be enclosed by a reproduction of its 19th-century wrought iron fence.
Facing the building across Main Street is an ugly crater left by demolition when the Society for Savings planned new construction on the site, now stalled by the recession. The bank responded to complaints about the vacant lot by agreeing to create a paved and landscaped open-air market complementing the one at State House Square. It will remain until building plans are reactivated some five years from now.
Jim Williams, manager of 750 Main Street, an 18-story, 1922 landmark office building facing the Old State House, is a member of the restoration committee. He looks forward to the project as an amenity for his tenants. Most of them, like those in other buildings that overlook the former capitol, pay $10 a window for the privilege, contributing some $25,000 a year to its annual operating budget of $500,000.
CURRENTLY, only half of the 135,000 square feet at 750 Main Street is leased. "I've renewed tenants at half the price of their expired leases," Mr. Williams said. "Competition is keen and demand is rising. Lower rates are now affordable to people who went to the suburbs or were planning to relocate there."
"Taxes," he added, "are a problem that the city must address. We pay $5.50 a square, foot compared to $1.25 in the suburbs." Until a revaluation is done in 1994, bringing commercial property values down from their 1980's highs, taxes will not decrease. And tax abatements sought by new developers are a problem for a city "supporting 10,000 welfare cases when we budgeted for 4,000," Mr. Fusco said.
Among pending projects are the acquisition of the bankrupt and vacant Summit Hotel by a Manhattan investment group; the installation of a manufacturing company in the North Meadows Redevelopment Project and the disposition of the defunct Sage-Allen Department Store. The Pan Pacific Development Corporation of Vancouver, Canada, a shopping mall developer, plans to demolish it and build a $320 million Hartford Town Center on the site, according to Terry Partington, managing director for the company's eastern region. It will be Penn Pacific's first New England venture.
Meanwhile, three times a day, 365 days a year, cannoneers in Revolutionary War uniforms roll out the bronze cannon at the east gate of the Old State House and fire it in a Yankee Doodle Salute, "a spectacle as grand as the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace," Mr. Faude said.

HEADLINE: Jane Jacobs Versus the World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was one of those fortunate enough to work with Jane Jacobs on Architectural Forum more than 30 years ago, so I was delighted to read Robert Fulford's perceptive article on Jane and her book "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" -- even though I am not in full agreement with him or, even now, with her. 
 Mr. Fulford failed to mention one of Jane's enormously important accomplishments. In the 1950's and 60's, Robert Moses and an assortment of real estate operators had a harebrained scheme to construct a Lower Manhattan Expressway to cut right across what is now known as SoHo. The Lomex, as I called it, would have destroyed most of the wonderful 19th-century cast-iron buildings south of Houston Street and most of the great warehouses and other architectural delights of that area.
Jane Jacobs, almost single-handedly, stopped this mad scheme. She stopped the bulldozers in their tracks and even went to jail to make her point. She and a small handful of artists forced the city and its planners to abandon their favorite project and, as a result, created SoHo -- a district that may well go down as the only successful "urban renewal project" of those years in New York. It owes its existence not to any architect or planner, but to this one idealistic person who had the courage of her convictions.
 
PETER BLAKE
Washington

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Brokers Are Prospering, But Will It Last?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
On the American economic landscape, there are companies where profits never crumbled during the recession and there are companies where optimistic analysts see recovery coming soon. But there are not very many industries where it can genuinely be said to be a boom time.
Wall Street, as it happens, is one of the few. The quarter just ended may have been the best ever for America's brokers. The first of them to report profits, discounter Quick & Reilly, said earnings almost tripled in the quarter ended Feb. 29. For every dime of revenues, better than three cents fell into the pre-tax profit line. 
 All over Wall Street, brokers cannot believe their good luck. Individual investors began this year trading with more fervor than at any time in years. Corporations are retiring bonds, and selling new ones, at a feverish pace, generating underwriting fees for brokers. With markets rising, any firm that keeps inventories of securities is watching the profits role in.
Some of the highest fees come from the booming market in initial public offerings. The eagerness of buyers in that market was illustrated again Friday when Catalina Marketing, a company that distributes supermarket coupons to consumers, went public at $20 a share and saw its shares leap to above $28. At that price, the company is valued at 16 times its revenues for the last year, and 75 percent higher than the minimum offering price the company indicated when it filed to go public six weeks ago.
Amid the joy, the average brokerage stock has more than tripled over the last 17 months, while the S.& P. 500 rose 33 percent. So far in 1992, the S.& P. is off 3 percent, while the brokers are up 13 percent.
Even Salomon's little error last week, in which a clerk got confused and unleashed hundreds of millions of dollars of errant sell orders, was not enough to shake investors very much. Salomon shares fell only 62.5 cents, to $27.875. The other news from Salomon may yet prove more significant. Deryck C. Maughan, the anointed successor to interim chairman Warren Buffett, has spent the last nine months in a fancy hotel, with Salomon paying $1,000 a night.
Such costs could yet serve to remind investors that the history of Wall Street is that surprisingly little filters through to the shareholders when times are good. The bosses raise their pay, perks seem to multiply, and lots of people are hired. It was supposed to be different this time, but if the new Salomon is acting this way, what about brokers not in the spotlight?
It is never easy to tell when a boom will end, but some think this one is on its last leg. Jack Sullivan, a principal in Van Kasper & Company, a San Francisco brokerage firm, is convinced brokerage profits are peaking. He pointed to signs that individual investors have cut back from January's fevered pace, and forecast that the boom in companies going public will slow. That is why, he said Friday, "I'm shorting a basket of brokers."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Britain's Evolving Beverage Industry

BYLINE: By Steven Prokesch

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
British giants in the world alcoholic beverage market Bass, Guinness, Grand Met and Allied -- have been reshaping themselves in recent years by making a slew of acquisitions and divestitures, with various degrees of success, in the view of analysts.
One impetus has been the British Government's resolve to make the domestic beer market more competitive. By Nov. 1, brewers must greatly reduce their control of the nation's bars, or pubs, as Britons call them. 
 That is one reason analysts generally like Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Guinness P.L.C. as long-term investments the most, Allied-Lyons P.L.C. next and are divided on Bass P.L.C. Guinness, whose shares have recently attracted the savvy investor Berkshire Hathaway, never owned British pubs. Grand Met completed its withdrawal from brewing last year and put many of its pubs into a joint venture. By contrast, Bass, Britain's largest brewer, gets two-thirds of its operating earnings from beer and pubs. What is more, Analysts still question the wisdom of its $2 billion purchase in 1990 of Holiday Inn hotels, a business being squeezed by the American recession.
Only Grand Met and Bass have actively traded American Depository Receipts on the New York Stock Exchange. Each of their A.D.R.'s equals two shares.
Not coincidentally, Allied, Guinness and Grand Met rank among the leaders of the global spirits market, offering them some protection from the American and British recessions as well as from the turmoil in brewing and pubs. They have been highly successful in marketing more expensive drinks and cultivating markets in East Asia, South America and Southern Europe. Analysts rave about how Guinness, in spirits and beer, and Grand Met, in spirits and food, have exploited brands to generate fat profits.
Guinness owns Johnnie Walker, Bell's and Dewar's scotch whiskies, Gordon's vodka and gin and Tanqueray gin. Its Guinness Stout is one of the few global beer brands.
Grand Met's brands include J&B scotch, Gilbey's and Bombay gins, Smirnoff vodka and Inglenook, Almaden and Christian Brothers wines. It also owns Pillsbury foods, Haagen-Dazs ice cream, Alpo pet food, Pearle Vision eyewear centers and Burger King. Analysts predict Pearle, the British pub interests and Alpo will be sold, but expect Grand Met to wait for a good price.
"Grand Met will continue to deliver above-average earnings over a five-year period," said Edouard de Boisgelin of Merrill Lynch. With few concrete signs of economic recovery in America and Britain, though, he is neutral on the stock over the short term.
More bullish, Derek Brock of Nomura Research Institute Europe Ltd., said: "If you're looking for a play on the U.S. recovery, that's the stock" to buy.
In London, Grand Met shares were trading at more than 12 times anticipated earnings for the year ending next Sept. 30. Its A.D.R.'s closed Friday at $30.125, down from the high of $34.50.
With Guinness trading in London at a relatively high multiple of more than 15 times expected 1992 earnings, several analysts advise short-term investors to hold on to what they have or cautiously buy more. They think the stock has been helped by rumors, just confirmed, that Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. has been buying the stock. Its stake is less than 2 percent.
Analysts also admire the way Guinness Brewing has expanded in regional markets via joint ventures, licensing agreements and acquisitions.
How about Allied-Lyons shares? "I would hold them because the company is going through a period of rapid change," said Michael McCarthy of Smith New Court Securities Ltd.
After suffering a big foreign-exchange loss last year, Allied shook up top management and divested some businesses in an attempt to focus on its main brands. They include Balantine's, Canadian Club and Teacher's whiskies, Beefeater gin, Courvoisier cognac, Harvey's Bristol Cream sherry, the Mister Donut and Dunkin' Donut chains, Tetley tea and Baskin-Robbins ice cream.
The British Government is investigating plans of Allied and Carlsberg to put their British brewing units into a venture that would have about 20 percent of the market. It also remains to be seen whether the Conservative Government allows a deal that calls for Allied to lease 734 pubs to Brent Walker Group P.L.C. and for Walker's pub division to buy most of its beer from Allied.
If the Labor Party wins the April 9 elections, it could take new steps to curb the rapid rise in beer prices, warns Ian Shackleton, an analyst at James Capel & Company. While he thinks Grand Met and Guinness are safer stocks than Allied and Bass, he likes Bass at its current price. Snap up the shares if the Conservatives win, he says. Bass A.D.R.'s closed last week at $18.25, down from $20.20.
He predicts that Bass will slash its interest bill and its brewing unit's operating costs and its pre-tax earnings will be 575 million pounds, or $1 billion, in the year ending Sept. 30. But that is 15 million pounds to 25 million pounds more than most forecasts. A big bear on the stock, Christopher Wickham of Lehman Brothers International Ltd., expects 480 million pounds.

HEADLINE: Can Snelling Brainard Sell His Global Fishing Vision?

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
It is no accident that Snelling R. Brainard's yacht is named Tenacity. His efforts in the mid-1980's to show New England's conservative fishermen they could make profits using 30-mile lines with thousands of hooks instead of environmentally destructive nets ended buried in debts. But now Mr. Brainard, a 64-year-old Harvard-educated banker, business consultant and real estate developer, is back with a daring global venture rooted in the same technique.
This time Mr. Brainard hopes to do a lot more than save fishing stocks from overexploitation and seabeds from being scraped clean of habitats for various creatures. He envisions creating billions of dollars of new business for American shipyards threatened by the downturn in military spending and helping developing nations profit from their natural resources. 
 Mr. Brainard plans to convince investors from developing nations to buy fishing fleets mass produced in the United States by arranging financing along with the training and worldwide marketing system to operate profitably. Foreign investors would operate the fleets as joint ventures with the Consolidated Seafood Corporation, Mr. Brainard's company, whose 49 percent stake would be given to the fleet's employees after 10 years.
There are a lot of places where the plan could fall apart. To sell the fleets, Consolidated must help develop means to help foreign investors tap capital markers . It must also set up a new air distribution and marketing network to help them unload the fish they catch. But Mr. Brainard and his advisers have addressed enough of the basic challenges to intrigue disinterested observers like Richard S. Johnston, an Oregon State University fishing industry expert. "It sounds to me that he's thinking through the issues pretty well," said Professor Johnston after a reporter briefed him on the venture.
Plenty of potential partners in developing nations agree. Mr. Brainard said he already has preliminary orders from 14 countries for more than 36 fleets, each with 32 vessels.
Mr. Brainard said that fishing groups in Russia have ordered 18 fleets and could order 12 more in a matter of months. "The Russians immediately saw this project as the future of fishing and wanted in," said Frank J. Giovino Jr., Consolidated's representative to the former Soviet Union. "They have the largest fishing fleets and the lowest productivity in the world. They see this as a chance to leapfrog." Mr. Brainard says that more than $5 million has already been invested in the project by potential fleet purchasers and strategic partners who expect to build and outfit the fleets.
Daniel Georgiana, an economist at the University of Massachusetts campus at Dartmouth on Cape Cod, said developing countries that want their own fleets could do better by buying existing boats at huge discounts or signing favorable profit-sharing deals with existing fleets.
Yet many seem to like Consolidated's approach. "The financial proposals were what really attracted us," said Luis F. Paredes, president of Industrial and Marine Enterprises, a Venezuelan company that ordered a fleet early this month.
Purchasers must put $200,000 into an escrow account "as soon as possible." They must eventually raise $1 million for their 51 percent stake. Mr. Brainard is counting on loan guarantees from the United States Export-Import Bank and similar such subsidies to help raise the billions of dollars to mass produce the boats. With the guarantees, he says, each 32-ship fleet could be financed by bond issues of about $100 million.
Mr. Brainard expects to file the first formal application for Ex-Im Bank support in the next few weeks on behalf of Papua New Guinea, which would allow construction to begin as early as next year.
Each fleet will have clusters of 60- to 75-foot "mini-liners" working with a 265-foot "multiliner" with added freezing and processing space. The fleet will have a support tender, a barge-like vessel that would remain in or near port and provide repair, communications and training services.
Longliners, as the vessels are known, are already commonly used to harvest certain species of fish in various regions. But no group of fishermen has ever used longliners as extensively or in as coordinated a fashion as Consolidated plans to.
Its fleets would sport satellite-based communication systems, which some fishermen use today to pre-sell fish they have located but not caught. The fishermen learn via satellite how the fish should be processed and packaged for a particular customer. Consolidated expects to use such technology to make its air distribution system more efficient.
"No single idea is brand new but the combination is," said John W. Gilbert, a naval architect based here who has drawn up construction designs for the fleets.
The biggest losers if Mr. Brainard's vision works would probably be fleets from countries like Japan, Spain, Russia and Korea that routinely take huge catches from the waters of developing nations with little local competition. More-efficient third-world competitors might also make it hard for American fleets to hang on to their 40 percent of the domestic market. And those that sell pricey fish like tuna and swordfish to Japan and Europe might face more competition.
The American fishing industry is already struggling. Despite revenues of about $3.5 billion, only a small percentage of the 17,000 registered ocean-going vessels are thought to be profitable. Too many boats are pursuing too few fish. And few have the resources to invest in advanced technology. "American fishermen are in the Dark Ages," said Mr. Brainard. "There's no fishing company of any size in this country you can organize to do it right, and no one has capital."

MR. BRAINARD is counting on support from domestic manufacturers who will benefit from building the fleets to counter any protests in Washington by the domestic fishermen. "This has got to go fast and it's got to be big to work commercially, but the risk is mostly political," said Mr. Brainard over take-out Chinese food in the kitchen of the modest condominium in East Boston that doubles as Consolidated's headquarters and the home of his daughter, Rebecca, who is a student at Harvard. "The world has to want this to happen."
Peterson Builders Inc., a Sturgeon Bay, Wis.-based shipyard that will serve as the lead yard for mini-liners, and Bollinger Machine Shop and Shipyard in Lockport, La., which expects to build the first multiliners, are projecting savings of 50 percent or more from mass producing the vessels instead of building them one at a time. Those savings would make them cost-competitive with overseas shipyards that pay lower wages. High volumes would justify investment in new equipment, which would cut costs for other types of ships, said Larry Maples, Peterson's chief financial officer.

THE hurdles to Mr. Brainard's success, however, are formidable. Getting enough backing to finance a large number of Russian fleets, for example, would require Congress to increase the limits on Ex-Im Bank exposure to the former Soviet Union or to provide other forms of guarantees.
The biggest wild card may be how much of a premium Consolidated's fleets can charge for higher-quality fish. Mr. Brainard's earlier longlining venture failed after overfishing in the Georges Bank, off New England, flooded the market with product, sending overall prices of fish to much lower levels than he and his investors had projected.
There are also tough marketing and distribution questions. For example, Consolidated's transportation consultant, Robert Maidman, president of Romar International Inc., based in Columbia, Md., is working to find freight that can be "backhauled" to Australia so that chartered flights bringing fish from Papua New Guinea do not end up returning empty to the western Pacific.
Mr. Brainard said Consolidated is negotiating with "a major food distribution company" to handle the fish once they arrive in the United States. Most fresh fish is distributed by several regional firms that would be harder to integrate into Consolidated's scheme.
And then there's Consolidated, which Mr. Brainard said needs to hire a person to run the company as it approaches commercialization. Consolidated currently has no employees -- all work is done for it on contract and Mr. Brainard has donated his time.
Mr. Brainard said a private sale of stock would eventually account for about 40 percent of Consolidated's equity. A public offering would be made of 9 percent of the shares. He expects to transfer the remaining 51 percent to a charitable foundation devoted to conservation projects.
Mr. Brainard does not figure to be easily fazed if Consolidated's future is bumpy. Last year, when Tenacity was being overhauled, he found himself sailing a rented yacht as Hurricane Bob approached New England. Unable to convince anyone to go with him, he set off alone for Maine in an attempt to outrun the storm rather than risk damage to the boat in port. The storm caught up but Mr. Brainard emerged unscathed.
"It actually worked out that I came away with some ideas for improving the ability of our longliners to survive typhoons," he said cheerfully.
 
 
 
WHEN LONGLINING WORKS BEST
 Longlining is environmentally sounder than trawling, but just how much better depends on the skills of the fishermen and the species targeted.
Longliners may use 4,000 hooks or more when going after species like tuna, or 10 times that many when pursuing bottom-swimmers like halibut and cod. The type of bait and hook or trap used results in a large proportion of the prey being mature individuals of the target species.
Longliners can work effectively even when a target species moves into another's spawning grounds because spawning fish will not take bait.
By contrast, even the most careful trawling results in waste and, when bottom fishing, in destruction of fish habitats on the seabed. Studies show that huge numbers of young fish of the target species are killed before they have reproduced, along with other marine creatures that often are simply tossed overboard. Immature fish theoretically small enough to escape through a trawler's net can find their passage blocked by larger fish.
Longliners also have a quality advantage because they land and handle fish one by one as lines are retrieved. But even advocates of longliners say they are not suitable for species that move in dense schools near the surface, like herring, or in the seabed, like scallops.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1597 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/March 22-27

BYLINE: By Frederik Eliason

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
It's Hard Times at Canada's Giant Olympia & York 

 
The superlatives are hard to control when discussing the Reichmanns of Canada, one of the wealthiest families in the world. Paul, Ralph and Albert Reichmann own the world's biggest collection of real estate, including some of the most ambitious projects anywhere, like the World Financial Center in Manhattan and the Canary Wharf project to transform London's docklands into a 71-acre financial district. Now Olympia & York is involved in what may be the largest-ever restructuring of a private company. The company quietly disclosed last week that it had a "liquidity crisis" and was negotiating to rearrange billions of dollars in debt. Paul Reichmann, the company's chief strategist, stepped aside as president in favor of Thomas S. Johnson, former president of Manufacturers Hanover. And Olympia & York retained a number of prominent American and Canadian investment advisers to get to work quickly in stretching out its debt deadlines.
 
Buffett Goes With Guinness . . .
 
Warren E. Buffett became something of a cult figure by getting exceedingly rich on Wall Street using techniques that can be comprehended even on Main Street. Mr. Buffett's gimmick, which seemed exotic in the 1980's, was to take large stakes in companies whose products he believed in or whose management he admired and then hold the stock for the long term. This has worked extremely well with the likes of Coca-Cola, Geico and Capital Cities-ABC. Now there is a new name in the lineup: Guinness. Mr. Buffett, through his control of Berkshire Hathaway, has invested $264 million in the British brewer. Mr. Buffett, who has made a point in the past of saying how much he enjoys Cherry Coke, did not specifically praise any of the Guinness products, which include Johnnie Walker, Dewar's, Gordon's and a number of other liquor brands.
 
. . . But Plans a Salomon Exit
 
Mr. Buffett has been chairman and chief executive of Salomon Inc. since the firm's former leadership was ousted in the wake of the scandal involving bids at Treasury auctions. The embarrassments keep cropping up. Last week, for instance, it came out that the top two executives at the time of the investment firm's transgressions claim they are owed about $24 million in back pay, bonuses and severance. And it developed that the company is paying $1,000 a day to put up Mr. Buffett's hand-picked second-in-command, Deryck Maughan, and his family in a Manhattan residential hotel.
 
. . . As Another Gaffe Surfaces
 
In the meantime, there is one more Salomon embarrassment to look into, one apparently caused by bumbling rather than venality. On Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped an estimated 16 points in the last five minutes of trading. Reason? A Salomon clerk apparently made a mistake, instructing a computer to sell 11 million shares, rather than $11 million worth, of various stocks. Fortunately, some of the sales were not executed, and Salomon said it would repair the damage to the owner of the shares through other trades. But many on Wall Street said the incident showed the market's vulnerability to errors in this era of instantaneous trades by computer.
 
McDonald's on the Road
 
McDonald's, which sometimes seems to have a restaurant on every corner, may soon seem to have an outdoor ad on every road. The company is planning its first national billboard campaign, using 20,000 signs. The fast food company said the project, which will begin on May 1, would be the largest outdoor advertising campaign ever for a single brand.
 
Rockwell's Environmental Fine
 
Rockwell International pleaded guilty to violating Federal hazardous waste laws and agreed to pay a fine of $18.5 million for its management of the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver. The plant is said to have released cancer-causing chemicals into streams and to have burned hazardous wastes. But Rockwell said it had agreed to the settlement only to save the cost of a trial and it maintained that the Department of Energy, which owned the giant plant, had made policy decisions that produced the shortcomings at the plant. A Federal judge deferred a hearing on Rockwell's guilty plea until June 1.
 
Chicago's Very Own Gambling?
Hilton Hotels, Circus Circus and Caesars World have proposed investing $2 billion to build a gambling and entertainment center that would cover more than 100 acres in Chicago. The project would include casinos and hotels as well as a sports arena and theme park. Chicago's Mayor, Richard Daley, quickly backed the idea, but Gov. Jim Edgar indicated that he had serious reservations about allowing land-based casinos in Illinois.

 
 
ECONOMY

 
At Last, a Healthy Income Gain
 
The conventional wisdom is that if the United States is to have a solid economic recovery, consumers must lead the way. At last, there are signs that they may have the wherewithal to do so. In February, personal income advanced 1.1 percent, the largest monthly gain in more than three years.
 
Sales of existing homes also rose strongly in February, gaining 9.3 percent and reaching the highest sales rate in three years.
 
Little Hope for the Deficit

In the wake of a string of huge budget deficits in recent years, the White House Office of Management and Budget last year made a comforting prediction: that the Federal budget would have a surplus in 1996. Now that prediction has been sharply adjusted. The O.M.B.'s new projection is that the Federal budget will do no better than record a deficit of $180 billion in 1996 and worsen after that.
 
Redel at the Comex
 
Donna Redel was elected chairwoman of the Commodity Exchange of New York, becoming the first woman to lead a United States futures exchange. She will also be the first head of the Comex to be paid -- the salary is $125,000 a year. There are plenty of problems. Volume of trading in precious metals futures and options has been dropping, and new products have not filled the gap. Still, hope persists that a merger can be worked out with the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
 
Sayonara, the Tax Bill
 
The tax bill, passed just under President Bush's March 20 deadline and promptly vetoed, died with a whimper last week as the House failed to muster a majority to override. The sense of urgency that existed when President Bush set his deadline two months ago seems to have dissipated.
 
The 13 Percent Solution
 
With Congress's tax plan out of the way, attention turned to the plan offered by the new No. 2 Democratic candidate, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown of California. His approach is very simple: a flat income tax of 13 percent and a 13 percent value-added tax, which is like a sales tax imposed on wholesale as well as retail sales. The only deductions for income taxes would be for charitable contributions and for mortgage or rent payments. This feature, Jerry Brown says, means that middle-class and low-income people would pay less than they do now. But many others maintain that the biggest advantages would go to the wealthy, as they did with the previous attempt to simplify the tax structure: the 1986 tax law.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Chrysler Sheds More Mitsubishi

Chrysler, which has said it will spend about $13 billion in a three-year modernization program, has raised about $205 million by selling almost half of its remaining stake in Mitsubishi Motors of Japan. It is left with control of less than 5.9 percent of the Japanese company's stock, down from a high of 24 percent. Last year Mitsubishi bought Chrysler's half of their Diamond Star joint venture. Besides raising cash, the sale continues Chrysler's process of disengaging from its Japanese alliance. Chrysler's chairman, Lee Iacocca, has been a vocal critic of Japanese auto sales in the United States, and his designated successor, Robert Eaton, has suggested that American auto makers have been selling too many Japanese cars.
 
Banks Neatening Up Overseas

Not too long ago, a bank's weakness could be measured in large part by the size of its foreign loan portfolio. Then it was real estate loans. Now, it develops, prospects of collecting on some past-due loans involving overseas borrowers are improving. American bankers reported this week that they were making progress in talks with officials of Brazil and Argentina about repaying overdue interest and rescheduling their debt. It appeared, in fact, that some of the loans might end up having more value than is now shown on the banks' books.
 
Perrier Goes to the Swiss
 
When the Agnelli family of Italy acquired a big stake in Source Perrier from Exor S.A. three months ago without consulting influential members of the French business establishment, it set off a concerted effort to prevent the Italians from gaining total control of the bottled water company. In the end, Perrier agreed to be acquired for $2.7 billion by the Swiss, namely Nestle, which had allied itself with BSN of France. For Nestle, already the world's largest food maker, the acquisition means a sudden rush to the forefront of the mineral water business. But the Agnellis did not do badly. They will receive a big profit on their Perrier shares and collect extensive Paris real estate and the prestigious Chateau Margaux vineyard. Even with the settlement, however, Perrier's fate is not yet sealed. The European Community Commission said it would investigate whether the sale violates European rules on free competition.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference/Tax Time, 1992;
Mr. Taxes in the House . . .

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
This, many thought, was to have been the finale for Dan Rostenkowski, the year the 64-year-old chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee would pack up his gavel and, after 17 terms, slip into a comfortable steak-and-golf retirement.
As he contemplated the political twists that kept him from becoming Speaker of the House or Mayor of Chicago, Mr. Rostenkowski would be consoled by such legislative successes as the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and the leftover campaign contributions -- in his case, about $1 million -- that those retiring by the end of this Congressional session could take along. 
 Instead, the Chicago Democrat decided to stay on and has just survived a bruising primary battle in a redrawn district. And far from putting tax legislation behind him, he now finds himself in the awkward position of believing no tax bill should be passed this year but being responsible, for political reasons, for trying to push one through anyhow.
"The one time I agree with the economists," Mr. Rostenkowski said recently, referring to near-unanimous professional advice urging inaction, "I'm forced to do something other than sit on my fanny and do nothing. The political climate insists that we have something."
That something is still to come, however. A week ago, Mr. Rostenkowski closeted himself with Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, to iron out differences between Democratic tax plans. The compromise legislation was passed by both houses but immediately vetoed by President Bush, who objected, among other things, to an increase in the top tax rate and challenged Congress to pass instead the seven-point economic program he proposed in January. Last Wednesday, the House failed to override the veto.
Whether any tax changes will become law this Presidential election year is unclear, but what seems certain is that Mr. Rostenkowski will play a central role in the jockeying to come. Mr. Bush's veto, he said last week, was "a declaration of political war against the Congress."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference/Tax Time, 1992;
Henry Bloch's Season to Shine

 BODY:
It's that time of year again, the homestretch before the April 15 deadline for filing tax returns.
For Henry W. Bloch, the 69-year-old chairman of H & R Block Inc., it has been a typical tax season -- with a twist. 
 As in years past, Mr. Bloch has been busy starring in advertisements and commercials for Block, by far the nation's largest tax preparation company. Mr. Bloch's appearances are designed to alert taxpayers to the latest changes in the law -- and, of course, to drum up more business for the company he co-founded with his brother Richard in 1955.
There's plenty to tell taxpayers this year, said Mr. Bloch. Among other things, he said one recent day before rushing off to tape a television spot, most taxpayers are not aware that the requirements to qualify for the so-called earned income credit have been loosened.
And many people will attempt to write off credit card interest even though 1990 was the last year it was deductible.
"We live in a plastic-oriented society," Mr. Bloch said. "There are some people who will be sorely disappointed that the interest they pay on their cards cannot be deducted."
The twist in Mr. Bloch's routine was his announcement earlier this month that he had passed the title of chief executive to his son Thomas. The younger Mr. Bloch, who is 38, had already been president and chief operating officer.
"It is nice to build something up," Henry Bloch said after the March 17 announcement, "and then be able to pass the running of the company on to someone in the family."
But the senior Mr. Bloch has no intention of retiring, either. He will remain as chairman, overseeing strategic planning for the company, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., and is spelled Block for easy recognition. Last year, Block had revenues of $1.2 billion and net earnings of $140 million.
Although the chain already prepares about 12.4 million returns -- roughly one out of every nine that are filed -- Mr. Bloch sees more growth as the tax law becomes ever more complex. And he hopes to make acquisitions related to Block's non-tax businesses. The company already owns the computer database Compuserve and a temporary-help concern called Personnel Pool of America.
But that's in the future. These days, Mr. Bloch is still keeping busy awakening taxpayers to the dangers he sees lurking all around them. One of his biggest concerns: that employers are now withholding less from paychecks, courtesy of President Bush, who saw the move as a way to prime the economy. The problem, said Mr. Bloch, is that many people could find themselves with tax bills instead of refunds next year. (The change can be undone by filing a new W-4 form with employers.)
"Taxpayers tend to blame their preparers when they owe money," said Mr. Bloch, in what amounted to a pre-emptive strike. "In this case, they should blame the tax man."
