HEADLINE: Making a Difference/Tax Time, 1992;
. . . and in the White House

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On tax policy as well as almost every other aspect of economic and domestic affairs, Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, was the dominant figure in the first three years of the Bush Administration.
He was the driving force behind the sweeping budget compromise the Administration struck with Congress in 1990, which caused President Bush to break his campaign promise of "no new taxes." And he is the primary architect of the tax policies the President wants enacted this year, including a lower capital gains tax. 
 Mr. Darman, who is 48, has held Government positions most of his adult life. He has been in every Republican Administration since Richard M. Nixon's, working in six Cabinet departments and the Reagan White House. As Deputy Treasury Secretary in the mid-80's, he was more responsible than any other official for gaining enactment of the monumental Tax Reform Act of 1986.
No one else in the Administration has Mr. Darman's understanding of the agencies, programs and inner workings of the Federal Government, and he has years of experience in dealing with Congress. Independently wealthy and a graduate of the Harvard Business School, Mr. Darman has told interviewers he has no professional ambition other than to hold top Government positions.
But Mr. Darman has a quirky personality, many enemies and strong views that are often at odds with the Republican Party's right wing, and that may prove to be his undoing. Indeed, he has become a lightning rod for criticism of Administration policies from the right.
Samuel K. Skinner, who became White House chief of staff in December, is said by some insiders to want to clip Mr. Darman's wings. In January, Mr. Skinner forced him to stop the presses that were printing final budget documents and excise politically sensitive passages about health care. The passages suggested how to slow the growth of Medicaid and Medicare to help finance tax credits and other assistance for people without health insurance.
Some Administration officials expected Mr. Darman to resign. But others say President Bush believes him to be indispensable and will go to great lengths to keep him around.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
A Forthright Manager, A [Expletive] Trial

BYLINE: By Mary Billard; Michael S. Malone writes frequently about Silicon Valley from Los Altos, Calif.

DATELINE: LOS ALTOS, Calif.

 BODY:
A few years back, a profile by Tom Wolfe in Esquire of Silicon Valley pioneer Robert Noyce described how, in the early 60's, the employees of Fairchild Semiconductor, one of several companies he founded, gathered at the windows to gawk at a limousine and driver. Limos are no longer an oddity in Silicon Valley, but in this down-to-earth culture any symbol of social stratification still causes squemishness. That is evident in the periodic failed attempts to establish here that bastion of East Coast urban life, the private club.
"The high-tech community doesn't have much use for things like this," said Paul Franson of the public relations firm of Hagerty & Associates in San Jose. "They don't go out to fancy lunches. You're lucky to have a sandwich at your desk." 
 Exclusive clubs in Silicon Valley have had to open their gates to the rabble to stay in business. Courtside in Los Gatos had to open its restaurant almost immediately to the public. The De Anza Racquet Club, near the Cupertino headquarters of Apple Computer Inc., went broke and is now owned by the City of Cupertino. The Decathlon Club, perhaps the most celebrated of these ventures, quietly opened its dining room to the public, too.
Now comes a new contender for the patronage of patrician-pretenders: the Silicon Valley Capital Club, part of a Dallas-based chain operating in the West. While many of its counterparts bowed to the 80's gestalt by emphasizing fitness and fine dining, the Capital Club, atop the tallest office building in the redeveloping downtown of San Jose, has forgone lockers and racquetball courts in favor of wood paneling and neoclassical furniture. The only people who break into a sweat here are the waiters.
With many of the hot little start-up companies now residing on the Fortune 500, it is betting that aging tycoons are tired of equality and ready for a private club. Since it opened in 1989, the club has grown to 850 members, despite a $2,400 individual initiation fee and dues of $79 a month. But there is not much Silicon Valley in the Silicon Valley Capital Club. Most members are lawyers, accountants and bankers from downtown San Jose. So where are all those powerful electronics tycoons? "Maybe it's the mystique about going to downtown San Jose," said Ellen G. Harris, membership director.
Such organizations are anathema to a place created to contradict the hierarchical East Coast business establishment. Here, entrepreneurship, building one's life from scratch, rules -- and the guy in the Grateful Dead T-shirt sometimes turns out to be the vice president of research and development. The industry's two most important role models, Bill Hewlett and David Packard, were unassuming engineers who ate in the company cafeteria with the rest of the staff. In their wake, even an executive dining room seems unnecessarily plutocratic. Combine this self-conscious commonness with the demands of a 90-hour work week and it is no mystery why executives might rather go for a three-mile run than to an exclusive dining room for a meal bulging with cholesterol.
High expectations may also work against the club's success. "Back East, because there are so many private clubs, many of them around for literally hundreds of years, there is a much greater tolerance of the form," said Tom Fanella, president of the local PBS affiliate, KTEH. "In Silicon Valley, the Capital Club is the first of its kind and people have very high expectations. I personally think it's a nice private club, -- if you can call anything with 1,000 members private. It's a good place from which to see and not a bad place to be seen."
Norman C. Hulberg, president of Hulberg & Associates Inc. real estate appraisers, points out a subtler deterrent. "Some clients say, gee, this is a nice place; I'm glad Hulberg is successful enough to take me here," said Mr. Hulberg. "But some will resent that I can afford to belong to such a place, so I have to be careful."
Mr. Franson, a charter member, finds the place fine for press conferences, but otherwise "pretentious." "People with taste giggle about it," he said. "At dinner, there's the clicking of covers, the intrusive service, waiters calling you endlessly by name, frozen forks, giant pepper mills and all the other cliches you've ever heard of. I suppose it's not a bad place to take an out-of-town client -- if you don't mind the waiter being part of your group."
But perhaps the most telling assessment comes from another charter member, Jack Gorry, chief executive of CXR Corporation, which makes electronic medical instruments in San Jose. "All the Capital Club is is a high-class restaurant," he said. "It wanted to be a club but nobody showed up. That's because you can't do business and socialize at the same time. It's a contradiction in terms -- and that's why most clubs here haven't worked."
Mr. Gorry belongs to the one private club in San Jose that works, the century-old Sainte Claire Club. Tucked into a modest three-story brick building just five blocks from the Capital Club, Sainte Claire is everything the upstart is not: small (120 members), anachronistic (all-male) and expensive ($35,000 initiation). It does not try to meld business and pleasure. Its one fast rule: no papers or briefcases allowed. Mr. Gorry aside, the Sainte Claire Club has not a single member even remotely connected with Silicon Valley.
Meanwhile, the Capital Club becomes less exclusive. A recent letter to members proudly announced that guests would now be allowed to pay for members' meals.

HEADLINE: Back to Basics? Turn to Natural Gas . . .

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Talk About a Slogan for the Back-to-Basics 90's: Electrify!" (Technology, March 8) cites an example that debunks the "ecowatts" theory -- a high-efficiency natural-gas glass melter. Many many more could have been cited. The glass furnace will be 20 percent more efficient than conventional glass melters and 40 percent less expensive than electric equipment. It will also lower emissions of carbon dioxide -- all by direct use of natural gas. 
 Although the ecowatts concept is simplistically appealing, it is critically flawed. Efficiency improvements and emissions reductions have been driven in large part by an entire new generation of gas equipment -- efficient residential furnaces, fast-food cooking equipment and industrial processes. Coming down the road is a gas heat pump that heats and cools homes for the lowest cost of any energy option. (Let's see ecowatts match that!)
Electricity is important to America's future. And natural gas will be used in large volumes to produce it cleanly. But there is also a role for the direct use of clean, efficient gas. Unlike new power plants, gas is one resource that is economical and abundant in North America.
 
STEPHEN D. BAN
Chicago, March 11
 
The author is president and chief executive officer of the Gas Research Institute.

HEADLINE: Time to Build a Job Engine

 BODY:
To the Editor:
America cannot survive as a world industrial power without an economic plan to deal with the global economy ("Will Aerospace Be the Next Casualty?" March 15). During World War II, President Roosevelt created the War Production Board to meet the challenge of Nazism. The board, staffed with industry members, built the greatest industrial machine the world had ever seen. Now, we have lost our job engine, the manufacturing sector that for decades gave us world economic leadership. 
 To survive as a world economic power we need to establish an independent Industrial Policy Board staffed by people from the business community, whose agenda would be:
* Assume full responsibility for all trade agreements. All other government agencies involved in the trade process would relinquish this authority.
* Identify those industries essential to the welfare of the United States and establish mechanisms to revive these industries.
The board could accomplish these objectives by introducing a market sharing policy, identifying which portions of our market should be dedicated to domestic manufacturers. We have a precedent. Our Government has such a policy for the United States steel industry, which is assured 80 percent of the United States market. We protect the peanut and sugar cane growers. Why not jobs for our workers in industry?
Introducing market sharing would create a revival of manufacturing in America. These job engines would create millions of well-paying jobs for our citizens, reduce welfare and poverty and make available to this and future generations an opportunity to realize the Great American Dream.
The alternative is to see America sink into a third world economic status.
 
GEORGE VARGISH
Saddle River, N.J., March 17

HEADLINE: Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:

Exposition Anniversary
The very first United States commemorative coin is 100 years old this year. The controversy it stirred has long since abated; it is easily acquired today as a curiosity or to start a collection of American commemoratives. 
 The 1892 Columbian Exposition half-dollar began life in 1892 after the exposition's manager proposed that 40 million of the coins be minted as admission tokens. But Congress agreed to an order of only five million coins, to be sold at twice their 50-cent face value. Money from their sale was to help pay for thee fair, in Chicago. Congress also ordered that the Mint at Philadelphia strike the commemoratives, using silver recycled from older United States coins.
The coin's designers thought of using a portrait of Columbus, but in 1893, few people had any idea what he looked like. Old paintings were studied, statues photographed, fanciful drawings drawn, to design the definitive portrait of Columbus.
The designer of the coin's obverse, Charles E. Barber, copied from a plaster model by Olin Levi Warner, whose own model had been a 1892 Spanish medal modeled from a statue. The statue had been modeled on a portrait in the Spanish Naval Museum; the artist was a Frenchman, Charles Legrand.
As for the reverse side, the designer, George T. Morgan, used a Spanish replica of the Santa Maria as his main model. He placed the ship atop two globes, the Old and New Worlds.
Criticism of the designs was quick in coming. Newspapers said Columbus looked like Sitting Bull, Daniel Webster or Henry Ward Beecher.
At any rate, the commemorative's Columbus had not the dashing good looks expected of a fearless explorer. Even the reverse came in for some criticism, with charges that the Santa Maria looked like a wagon on wheels.
But the mint kept striking the coins. In 1892 950,000 were minted, 4,052,105 in 1893. Selling the 50-cent coins for a dollar was hard going in an economy in which the average working man made $6 or $7 a week.
When the Columbian Exposition closed in 1893, 3.6 million coins were still unsold.
In 1894, the Government sent them into general circulation to be used at face value. Suddenly, the coins bought for a dollar were worth only what was printed along the rim of the obverse -- "half dollar."
Ultimately, about half the coins were melted.
Even so, the Columbian Exposition half dollar was a familiar piece of pocket change around the turn of the century.
Today, commemoratives of lesser grade can still be bought fairly cheaply; they are the ones that show the battering that pocket change gets. Better examples, looking as though they had never been touched, can sell for hundreds or even thousands of dollars.
 
Mint Offers 3 Olympic Coins

The United States Mint has begun offering a set of three Olympic coins. The set is composed of one five-dollar gold piece, a silver dollar and a half-dollar copper coin clad in nickel.
The gold coin depicts a sprinter, while the silver one shows a pitcher in motion. The clad coin is of a gymnast. The reverses of all three use the five interlocking rings of the Olympic Games.
The half-dollar in proof grade, the finest, is $9.50, while the silver dollar is $32. The gold $5 in proof is $230.
In uncirculated grades, the coins are slightly less. Various sets consisting of different combinations of the coins are also available. The most complete is a six-coin set of three proof coins and three uncirculated coins. It costs $445.
A portion of the price of each coin or set goes to the United States Olympic Committee for the training of athletes. For more information, call (800) 572-8326.

GRAPHIC: Photo: On the reverse of the Columbian Exposition half-dollar is the Santa Maria, shown atop two globes that represent the Old and New Worlds. (Bowers & Merena Galleries)

S.O.S. for Hunger Relief
March 30 -- More than 100 culinary fund-raising events for Share Our Strengths will be held around the nation this week with funds going to 175 food banks, shelters and social-service agencies. The New York benefit will be aboard the yacht New Yorker. Guests will board at 7 P.M. at Pier 62, 23d Street and the Hudson River. Cocktails will be followed by dancing and a buffet prepared by 30 chefs from some of the city's more elegant restaurants. At 9 P.M., there will be an auction of vacations, events and fashion items followed at 10 P.M. by a one-hour cruise around the harbor. Tickets, $125, from (212) 382-5766.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
It's 1992, and No One Is Leading Europe's March to Unity

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
After nearly three years of epochal change and grand visions of the future, the European Community, much like the United States, is bogged down in the mundane realities of recession and parochial politics.
What Europe seems to lack is a leader articulating a clear vision of where the community is going and what its ultimate purpose is, now that the certainties of the cold war have been replaced by uncertainty and economic chaos in the countries that used to make up the Soviet Union. 
 European unity is more easily said than done, something the 12 heads of state and government who negotiated the Treaty on European Union in Maastricht, the Netherlands, a little over three months ago would all probably agree on now. At Maastricht, they decided in principle to create "an ever closer union among the peoples of Europe" by introducing a common currency as early as 1997, making more foreign policy decisions together, and eliminating most internal border controls in the barrier-free market that they plan to complete by the end of this year.
But instead of coming into its own as the world's largest and most prosperous market, eclipsing the United States and surging ahead with elan toward ever greater economic and political union, Europe is in a slump.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany might have been the man to lead the way out of the crisis, but he and his country have been too preoccupied with the political and economic difficulties of German unification to know how to do that. One way or another, however, Germany seems fated to define Europe's destiny, which would be much diminished if the Germans decided to go it alone. Mr. Kohl saw European union as the best way to anchor the new, united Germany in the changed strategic environment. At Maastricht, he was one of the principal proponents of monetary union, cooperation in foreign policy and harmonization of social and labor relations among the member states, a principle agreed to in the "social chapter" of the treaty by all of them except Britain.
 
Jitters in Germany
 But since then, many Germans have become increasingly worried not only about how to pay for unification, but also about who will be asked to pay to keep Russia, Ukraine and the rest from utter collapse. They fear that it will be them, and that they can't afford it. Unification proved far more expensive than Mr. Kohl had led his voters to expect in 1990, and government borrowing set off an inflationary spiral that the German central bank, the Bundesbank, has moved to control. Now Germany, no longer in a boom, faces recession.
The Social Democrats, who control the upper house of the German legislature, the Bundesrat, complained that Mr. Kohl had sold out the mark for a nebulous new "European Currency Unit" to be controlled by a European central bank, without insisting in return on new democratic powers for the European Parliament to watch over the financiers. Until this month, they were threatening to block ratification of the treaty. This threat has eased, but the states now want input of their own into community decisions. Both Germany and Mr. Kohl seem to be in an irritable mood, resentful of all efforts to circumscribe their freedom, as shown by Mr. Kohl's insistence Friday on having lunch with the ostracized President of Austria, Kurt Waldheim.
From the start, the axis of the European Community has been French-German cooperation, but France's President, Francois Mitterrand, has been thrown seriously off stride. He and his Socialist Party are deeply unpopular after a decade in office. His strategic vision for Europe, if there is one, is apparently to seek German cooperation in a new European military capability that would shoulder the United States, politically and militarily, out of its strategic position in Europe.
 
Campaigning in Britain
 Britain has always resisted this strongly, and under Prime Minister John Major and his predecessor Margaret Thatcher, it also put a brake on any attempt by the other Europeans to move toward a more federal union. Questions about Europe have had no impact in the British general election campaign, which is preoccupied with arguments about the income tax and proposals to change the National Health Service. But if the opposition Labor Party wins on April 9, its leader, Neil Kinnock, promises to sign onto the "social chapter" on principles of labor relations and fair compensation agreed to by the 11 other states at Maastricht, and to go ahead with monetary union if Britain qualifies and Parliament approves. Still, leading a party that campaigned against British membership in the European Community less than a decade ago, it is doubtful that Mr. Kinnock could emerge as a visionary European leader, any more than the pragmatic and low-key Mr. Major.
At last count, more than 80 percent of the measures necessary to implement a single European market without trade barriers this year had been adopted, leaving mostly petty disputes to be resolved: Spain currently permits bananas to be imported only from the Madeiras, for instance. But in some countries the Maastricht treaty itself has become unexpectedly ensnared in domestic politics.
Ireland negotiated a protocol to the treaty that safeguards the anti-abortion provisions added to its constitution in 1983. But after last month's political crisis over a teen-aged rape victim who was briefly barred from traveling to England for an abortion, Prime Minister Albert Reynolds wants to redraft the protocol to include an affirmation of the general right to freedom of movement between Ireland and other community countries, and the right to "lawful information" on abortion, before submitting the treaty to a referendum. Rejection by Irish voters would kill the treaty altogether.
Spain and Portugal have been disappointed by the failure to make much progress on a fund agreed on at Maastricht that would transfer money from rich northern European countries to their poorer southern cousins. Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community's executive commission, proposed setting up such a $3 billion "cohesion fund" by 1997. But even the Germans were taken aback by another proposal from Mr. Delors -- a plan to raise the community budget over the next five years from $81.9 billion to $107.6 billion, plus inflation. Now, with talk that Mr. Mitterrand may need Mr. Delors to replace Edith Cresson as Prime Minister, the futures of the the expansionary budget and the cohesion fund are in doubt. This leaves the Spaniards, in particular, feeling done in.
 
Differences Over Farms
 In many other important ways, too, momentum has dissipated. A dispute between the United States and the European Community over agricultural policies has snagged negotiations on a new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which President Bush hoped to conclude by April 15. But no European leader seems willing or able to push through the necessary compromises, making a mockery of two years' worth of pious promises by the leaders of the world's biggest industrial democracies to get a GATT accord.
In addition, Germany showed last winter that a common European foreign policy is a sometime thing at best. The Germans steamrollered over their European partners and recognized Croatia and Slovenia unilaterally as independent republics, hoping to press the Serbs into ending the Yugoslav civil war. It worked, but the other Europeans, who followed suit two weeks later, seemed bruised and battered by the experience.
By the end of this decade, the community will be politically even more amorphous, with at least 15 members. Austria and Sweden have applied to join, and Finland is about to. Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, the other European Free Trade Association countries, will be non-voting members, in effect, when a free trade zone agreement with the community goes into effect at the end of the year. After that, the question is what to do with Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, which have association agreements and want to become full members. Ukraine, Russia and the other eastern Europeans all want in as well. But what does "Europe" want, except to prosper? For the moment, nobody seems to know.

HEADLINE: CIRCUIT BREAKER;
The 'Longest of Long Shots' Is Suddenly a Contender

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Where did Jerry Brown come from? What does he stand for? Where, if anywhere, is he going? What's going on around here, anyway?
It is an improbable political year, and not only in the United States. In France, the party structure seems to be fracturing, with the left the big loser. In Britain, the left, meaning the Labor party, seems within reach of a parliamentary majority, which many doubted that it would ever again approach. In the first months of the post-cold war era, electoral politics everywhere is full of doubt and contradiction as voters grope for a way forward. 
 But nowhere has there been anything more startling than the emergence of Edmund G. Brown Jr., a former governor of California, son of another former governor, twice a failure as a national candidate, underfinanced, underorganized and understaffed, as a major contender for the Presidency.
It is said that the news media and the political professionals "missed" his candidacy, in the sense that they noticed it late in the game. Perhaps. But in that sense, they missed the candidacy of Paul E. Tsongas, too, until Mr. Tsongas started moving up in the polls in New Hampshire as Bill Clinton began to falter.
From the start, Mr. Clinton got attention, not always the kind he wanted, because he had the most money, the most big-name backers, the best organization. Such candidates don't always win (Edmund S. Muskie in 1972, is a notable example of one who didn't), but they are always strong contenders, at least for a time. Mr. Tsongas got himself noticed by winning New Hampshire.
Bob Kerrey and Tom Harkin got a little more attention than Mr. Brown, though it didn't help them much, because they were the only senators in the race and senators often end up with Presidential or Vice Presidential nominations -- Kennedy, Nixon, McGovern, Johnson, Humphrey, Quayle, for a few recent examples.
 
Out of the Swim
 Only very, very rarely does someone so far out of the political swim as Jerry Brown, who last held political office almost a decade ago, manage to win the Presidential nomination of a major party. John W. Davis, a Wall Street lawyer who had served a lone term as a member of Congress, emerged from a deadlocked Democratic convention on the 103d ballot in 1924, and Wendell L. Willkie, a charismatic utilities lawyer and executive, won the thankless task of running against Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1940.
So as Mr. Brown wandered through the early primaries, winning less than 10 per cent where the press was watching, in New Hampshire and South Dakota, Georgia and Maryland, winning nothing on Super Tuesday, doing best in the West (Colorado and Utah) while Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Clinton dueled elsewhere, he got short shrift.
He was able to last, when rivals could not, for the same reason he was so little noticed in the early going: the unorthodox nature of his effort. A campaign that uses little or no television advertising, a candidate who sleeps in backers' spare rooms, an entourage limited to a few people, needs little money to keep going.
Mr. Brown's fortunes were transformed by three things: the withdrawal of first Mr. Harkin and then Mr. Tsongas, which left him as the only viable alternative to Mr. Clinton; the shift of the electoral terrain to northern industrial states, where he could capitalize on the fear among industrial workers displaced by a rapid shift toward a service economy and increased foreign competition; and his success in finally amassing enough money (in the $100 increments to which he has limited himself) to get his message on television, albeit not very extensively, in Michigan and Connecticut.
In Michigan, with its crumbling auto industry, he finished second to Mr. Clinton, edging out Mr. Tsongas, who was still an active candidate. Last Tuesday in Connecticut, another economically battered state, which has a habit of backing mavericks, he won his first nationally spotlighted victory. Not until then, the 18th primary of the year, did his vote total exceed 30 percent.
Mr. Brown has had plenty of emotions to play on -- generalized contempt for politicians, dissatisfaction with the quality of the Presidential field and substantial doubts about the trustworthiness and electability of Bill Clinton.
He has done so with skill. Call him a hypocrite or a Johnny-come-lately in his condemnation of big money in politics, recall his years as a champion money-raiser as chairman of the California Democrats, fighting to get contribution limits relaxed, and he makes himself sound like Paul on the road to Damascus, a man who suddenly saw the light. Listening to him work the themes of reform and redemption in New Haven last week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson commented, "We have the Rev. Jerry Brown with us."
That approach makes it difficult to mount an effective challenge to his policies, even though some, like his opposition to fast-track negotiations with Mexico on a free-trade zone, are wildly inconsistent with his earlier positions, and others, like the flat tax, are dismissed by most experts as impractical and undesirable.
By casting himself as the foe of the Establishment, moreover, this scion of a political clan as prominent in California as the Daleys in Chicago, if not the Kennedys in Massachusetts, positions himself to shrug off criticism as the carping of people or institutions threatened by his insurgency. Thus Mr. Clinton and the news media can be portrayed as the voices of corporate interests, lobbyists and out-of-touch officeholders.
 
Getting Ideas
 He is the master of the political gimmick, the catchy idea that sets him apart. The 800 number as a fund-raising tool is one; he used that one in his earlier Presidential efforts in 1976 and 1980. At one time, he favored a balanced budget amendment; now it's the flat tax.
In his role as the fearless teller of truths that others shrink from, he is willing to go well beyond what most politicians will say about members of their own party. In Wisconsin on Friday, for example, he called Mr. Clinton "a Bush look-alike who's mired in conflicts of interest, paid, fueled and financed by the same top 1 percent." In case anyone missed the point, he pressed on: "Clinton is not going to get the nomination. You can put that in your tape recorders and ask me about it in a couple of months."
Most politicians refrain from that kind of slash-and-burn stuff in primary campaigns because they don't want to harm their party or because they know they might need a future favor. After taking a merciless pounding from Mr. Brown in Connecticut for a week, Mr. Clinton called his opponent "my friend Jerry," without sarcasm, in a national television interview.
But Mr. Brown, with nothing to lose, fires away, day after day, despite periodic promises of a more positive tone. Last week, Ron Brown, the party chairman, said he had "crossed the line in terms of inappropriate attacks," but Jerry Brown just picked up that grenade and hurled it back with a crack about a "conspiracy of silence enforced by our political leaders."
If the times were not so unsettled, the temptation would be to say that Mr. Brown, the candidate, cannot possibly win; as it is, he seems "the longest of long shots," as he described himself a week or so ago. But he and his band of guerrilla warriors could certainly do a lot more damage to Mr. Clinton, an already damaged candidate, if they could win in New York or Wisconsin or both on April 7 and in Pennsylvania or Ohio after that. And California's primary, of course, closes the whole extravaganza on June 2.
There are only four options now -- Mr. Clinton, Mr. Brown, a late-starting candidate or a brokered convention. Of the four, the nomination of Mr. Brown, unlikely as the thought may seem, is certainly no less likely than alternatives three and four.

HEADLINE: Selling Out?;
Pushed and Pulled, Environment Inc. Is on the Defensive

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At stake in the Senate last week were six million acres of the nation's last virgin forests, a green arc of pine sweeping across most of western Montana. In less time than it takes lawmakers to eat lunch, the Senate voted overwhelmingly to make at least one million acres of that wilderness eligible to be cut to the ground.
In the finger-pointing afterward, national environmental groups were criticized for being too complacent. The Wilderness Society and the National Audubon Society did not actively oppose the bill until the last few weeks, said Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate. The National Wildlife Federation, the country's largest environmental group, announced that it had no opinion on the legislation, which still faces consideration in the House. 
 "They talk like Rambo in their fund-raising letters but the big national groups are wimps when it comes to dealing with the bad guys," said Tim Hermach, executive director of the Native Forest Council, a regional environmental group in Eugene, Ore., that opposes logging in national forests.
Brock Evans, vice president for national issues in Washington for the National Audubon Society, conceded that the movement is under siege. "What seems to be selling out is trying to get something done in a very rough situation," he said. "It struck me last summer that we're being savaged on the right and attacked on the left and maybe the center cannot hold."
On one side, leaders of hundreds of state and community environmental groups say the national organizations have become soft and are largely absent from battles over such issues as pollution in minority and rural communities. They also complain that the groups have grown so large and desperate for money that they are accepting financial help from some of the very forces whose disregard for the environment led to the movement.
"We can't get funding from the national environmental groups for our work," said Linda Campbell, director of Southern Women Against Toxics, in Livingston, Ala. "They're nowhere to be seen in our fights."
From another direction have come slashing attacks by land owners, timber companies and energy corporations who say the Wildlife Federation and its sister organizations are too rich, too powerful, and so prone to hyperbole about ecological dangers that the economic cost of environmental protection is threatening the American way of life.
"The big environmental groups in a way polluted themselves with power," said Charles S. Cushman, executive director of the National Inholders Association, a group that represents landowners, ranchers and miners who have property within national parks and forests. "Frankly this movement has become a preservation industry that is mainly interested in preserving itself."
Leaders of the big environmental groups say that much of the criticism comes from polluters posing as born-again populists. "Look behind the fancy rhetoric and you realize this is a movement to bash environmental groups that is funded by the oil and gas industry, the mining industry and the development community," said Jay D. Hair, the president of the National Wildlife Federation.
The national groups say that because they are working in a political arena where they have to compromise, they cannot be as aggressive as the new grassroots coalitions that have sprung up by the dozens in militant response to specific problems. These include groups like the Military Production Network, which works on pollution issues that affect the nuclear weapons industry, and the Virginia-based Citizens Clearinghouse for Hazardous Waste, which -- supporters are quick to point out -- is one of the few nationwide environmental groups headed by a woman.
In the case of the bill to open Montana's wilderness to timbering, mining and oil drilling, staff members of the national environmental groups said they did not want to embarrass Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who negotiated the pact with Montana's Republican Senator, Conrad Burns, in what he said was an effort to balance his state's economic needs with environmental concerns. Mr. Baucus, who has been one of the strongest environmentalists in the Senate, received an award from the Sierra Club for helping defeat a proposal by President Bush last year that would have opened the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling and limited citizens from reviewing proposals for new nuclear power plants. The Senate approved the Montana measure 75 to 22, in large part because it is customary to support the position of a state's two Senators on bills primarily affecting their turf.
To a large extent the assault on environmentalism is a result of the movement's political successes in the last 20 years. As much smaller organizations in the 1970's, the national groups helped to bring about the world's first comprehensive laws for clearing the air, cleaning the water, protecting wild habitat and safeguarding people from pollutants.
In the 1980's leading organizations like Greenpeace, The Nature Conservancy, the Environmental Defense Fund, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the World Wildlife Fund doubled in size. The Wildlife Federation, Audubon and the Natural Resources Defense Council built new headquarters in New York and Washington. Staff members introduced a new array of national and worldwide environmental threats like global climate change, depletion of the atmospheric ozone shield, soil erosion, nuclear contamination, ocean pollution, forest destruction, and the accelerating rate of extinction of plants and animals.
But ever since the passage of the Clean Air Act in the fall of 1990, the groups' influence has waned in Washington and across the country. Efforts by Congress this year to rewrite the Clean Water Act and the Endangered Species Act came to a virtual halt after lawmakers sympathetic to environmental goals determined that both bills could be weakened if they were opened to change.
According to some of the White House's top environmental aides, President Bush has been emboldened by the confusion he sees in the national groups. In January he announced a 90-day moratorium on new regulations and a review intended to weaken or eliminate existing rules. Two weeks ago, he dropped a Clean Air Act regulation requiring auto makers to install equipment to capture gasoline fumes. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. sided with the coal industry in a case the industry is pressing to dismantle Government enforcement of strip mining laws. The Environmental Protection Agency proposed rules to weaken Federal hazardous waste laws. Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan wants to limit the ability of environmental groups to stop clear cutting in national forests by barring appeals in the agency's administrative courts.
Environmental groups count as their one significant victory in the last two years the defeat of the President's 1991 proposal to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling. The bill's failure, though, was also the result of active protests from the utilities and auto industries, which opposed some of the energy conservation measures.
The environmental groups' problems come amid a recession that has halted growth and made fund-raising a preoccupation. The National Wildlife Federation, the Wilderness Society, the Sierra Club and Greenpeace have all issued layoff notices in the last year and the Natural Resources Defense Council is considering staff cuts. Staff members meanwhile bristle at the six-figure salaries their directors command. Mr. Hair, the president of the National Wildlife Federation, earns $250,000 a year, according to a spokeswoman.
The financial problems have caused some of the organizations to turn for help to the same industrial polluters they have long criticized. The chairman of Waste Management Inc., which has racked up millions of dollars in environmental fines at its landfills and hazardous waste dumps, is a major contributor and sits on the board of the Wildlife Federation. The National Audubon Society's acclaimed "World of Audubon" television documentaries are financed by the General Electric Company, which has been at the top of the E.P.A.'s list of companies with the most superfund toxic waste sites.
Frances Beinecke, deputy director for programs at the Natural Resources Defense Council in New York, said that though the messengers are under siege their message is as important as ever.
"We haven't taken this as seriously as we should have and we're late in responding," she said. "We're still optimistic that the movement as a whole still reflects the commitment of the people in this country to protect fragile resources. But the anti-environmental movement that's developed around the country is a very serious threat to the gains we have made. We have to face up to it and deal with it."

HEADLINE: THE REGION: Q. & A.: Barry F. Sullivan;
New Deputy Mayor, a Banker, Outlines His Business Plan

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's relations with New York City's business community have often been rocky, but last week he hired a high-powered repairman who won Wall Street's cheers. Barry F. Sullivan, a 61-year-old career banker who retired as chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, is the new deputy mayor for finance and economic development. He succeeds Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, who left to head the city Housing Authority.
Mr. Sullivan will continue to earn $780,000 a year as a consultant to First Chicago -- more than the pay of the next five deputy mayors combined -- and give his $112,000 city salary to charity. "We're frankly all a little scared of him," one senior mayoral aide said. 
 That is clearly how some in the business community, frustrated with the administration's handling of fiscal policy, want City Hall to feel. Mr. Sullivan was recruited by his old boss at Chase Manhattan, David Rockefeller, but says he will not serve the private sector only and knows that broader interests must be weighed. It remains to be seen just how the former Georgetown basketball star, who still speaks in the streetwise accents of his native Bronx, will fit in as the Mayor tries to cope with the recession. Sarah Bartlett and Todd S. Purdum of the Times metropolitan staff discussed his agenda with him last week.
Q. What is your analysis of the city's problems?
A. The key issue as the economy recovers is: will the city be sensitive to the recovery, or will it lag? The four-year plan [the city's projected budget plan] uses about a year's worth of lag to the national recovery. That's a fairly conservative view.
Q. Do you share that view?
A. I don't know. It really depends upon how sensitive the financial community is to the recovery. I think the investment banking side is going to be reasonably sensitive, but the commercial banking side may not be. And the commercial banking side is a big employer. And it's got the Chemical-Manufacturers Hanover merger as part of its digestion process.
Q. How can the city jump start or guide the economy?
A. Well, the first thing is that you've got to retain what you have. But retention tends to be retaining the larger firms. They tend not to be the engines of growth. But if you lose them, you're dead. You can't let the base erode. My suspicion is that by the end of '93 the retention game will be won or lost. But it doesn't cause employment growth, and that gets you into small and medium-sized businesses. And that is a much more difficult game in terms of how you help them grow. Another area that we've got to think about is international business. We're obviously a natural point of attraction.
Q. Do you have any opinions yet on the manufacturing sector and what you'd like to see done to help it?
A. Markets work. And to the extent that certain kinds of activities are able to be better done somewhere else, you watch the pull of the market. Then you watch the city saying, how can we provide some incentives that affect the operation of markets, one of which is tax abatements? And manufacturing just may be a harder one to deal with than some of the other kinds you can deal with. But I wouldn't give up on it.
Q. What did your experience in Chicago teach you?
A. I would say there's two things. One is that the political process really does take more factors into consideration than the business process -- and it ought to. And secondly, the time horizon for the political process is longer. On the whole, government will make a decision 18 months after the business community will make it.
Q. Is it the role of the deputy mayor to make sure there is no additional lag?
A. You also have a deputy mayor for economic development as a recognition that when you're adding up the gross city product, the private sector is the biggest part of that. And you ought to, as a government, pay a lot of attention to that. They're the provider of tax resources and a variety of other things. And it seems to me that one of the things that David Dinkins has done is to take the risk of hiring someone who presumably knows the private sector game and, armed with the right facts, will be an advocate for the private sector -- and do it in a way where the Mayor and the other people will have to at least listen.
Q. Did the Mayor give you any explicit charge?
A. Not as in, "Barry, I wish you'd do the following." But, I would say, a feeling that he certainly wants to have a good relationship with the business community. And I know he expects me to say to him, "This is what I think you have to do to have those relationships." And I think part of it is, "Help me explain to them what we're doing."
Q. Did you ask for any explicit commitments?
A. No, I figure that I know how to figure out what we ought to do, and if I can't persuade him, then I'm the problem.
Q. So, you've made peace with the fact that you'll make recommendations to him that sometimes . . .
A. Sure. He's the C.E.O. I'm not the C.E.O. here. I ought to recommend what I think ought to be done. And from time to time, he's going to turn it down. If he turns me down a lot, he's got the wrong guy.
Q. What's in it for you?
A. Part of the motive in retiring from First Chicago was to get more involved in community service. And this is community service in my hometown. It also had just the sheer intellectual interest and sort of looking at the animal that I had been a part of -- the private sector -- from a totally different point of view.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Oh, for a Chance to Chatter at the White House!

BYLINE: By JAMES ATLAS

 BODY:
As Bill Clinton and Edmund G. Brown fight it out for the Democratic nomination, pollsters and public opinion experts are assessing their strength among the constituencies they need to win. How are they doing with the middle class, labor, blacks, Jews? What no one has troubled to look into is how they are doing among that statistically insignificant but intangibly crucial sector -- intangibly crucial in their own eyes, at least -- the intellectuals.
As a class, American intellectuals have never been more than minor players in electoral politics. Or, indeed, in much of anything else. Isolated in universities, "marginalized" -- to borrow a term from contemporary academic discourse -- by the specialization of literary studies, they're perpetually on the verge of obsolescence. In his influential book, "The Last Intellectuals: American Culture in the Age of Academe," Russell Jacoby lamented the possible disappearance of an "endangered species" from American life: "While the aging industrial plant of America elicits much talk, the aging intellectual plant passes unnoticed." 
 The last two Republican administrations have only exacerbated the intellectuals' sense of isolation. A handful of neo-conservatives -- influential columnists, editors of well-known journals and denizens of think tanks -- may imagine themselves in proximity to power, but Republicans have always been defiant philistines. The golf course is their chosen turf. (How could Mr. Clinton have ignored such obvious symbolism on his ill-advised jaunt to the Country Club of Little Rock?) Ronald Reagan never pretended to have any use for intellectuals, and neither does George Bush.
 
The Glow of Camelot
 The Democrats, on the other hand, have always cultivated intellectuals, and intellectuals have returned the favor. "He thought that if Adlai could beat Ike in the November election, Culture would come into its own in Washington," Saul Bellow wrote of the crazy poet Von Humboldt Fleisher in his novel "Humboldt's Gift." Humboldt, like his real-life model, Delmore Schwartz, was convinced that "if Stevenson is in, literature is in." But Mr. Stevenson was out. "The Republic summons Ike,/ the mausoleum in her heart," as Robert Lowell summed it up in his poem "Inauguration Day: January 1953."
And so it was until the election of John F. Kennedy, who celebrated his inauguration by inviting Robert Frost to read a poem. The nostalgic glow of Camelot is greatly dimmed now, but for intellectuals the Thousand Days was their last great moment. President Kennedy's brain trust "emptied the Harvard faculty," as Hannah Arendt put it. The White House was a virtual salon. The dinner parties were legendary. "We all drank a great deal, and had to sort of be told not to take our champagne into the concert, to put our cigarettes out -- like children -- though nicely," Mr. Lowell remembered.
In a BBC program aired in 1964, the year after the Kennedy assassination, the English writer A. Alvarez went around Manhattan with his tape recorder and gathered eulogies from the New York intellectuals. "Kennedy's style was superb," testified Norman Podhoretz, the editor of Commentary. "He was a man who was post-Freud, post-Marx, post-Einstein." He "thickened things up and gave people a certain sense of our actuality in the social structure," said the critic Lionel Trilling. Norman Mailer called him an "existential hero." Intellectuals revere power as much as any other group, if not more; Kennedy rewarded them with the illusion of it, if not the reality.
It was rough sledding after that. Lyndon Johnson was enraged by the opposition of prominent intellectuals to the war in Vietnam; when Mr. Lowell refused to attend a White House Festival of the Arts in 1965 in protest against Johnson's foreign policy -- and drafted a public statement signed by 20 prominent intellectuals to explain his refusal -- the President was apoplectic. So much for the salon.
There was no one for intellectuals to like until Eugene McCarthy, who wrote poetry (Mr. Lowell tagged around with him on the campaign trail), and Robert Kennedy, who read Camus and was once observed with a copy of Edith Hamilton's "The Greek Way" in his pocket. But they didn't become President. The next Democrat who did was Jimmy Carter, a middle-brow; his favorite poet was Dylan Thomas.
Is Bill Clinton the intellectuals' savior? As long ago as 1988, reporting on their diminished role in American life, U.S. News & World Report compiled a Who's Who of "that endangered modern species" -- and there, between photographs of Robert B. Silvers, the distinguished editor of The New York Review of Books, and Hanna Holborn Gray, president of the University of Chicago, was . . . Gov. Bill Clinton. Why Mr. Clinton? The article didn't explain. Never mind. He was perceived to be on the side of intellectuals. He was there. And success, as Woody Allen said, is largely a matter of showing up.
But what about Jerry Brown? He's also got high-minded friends. In New York, preparing for the primary on April 7, he often stays at the East Side home of Joan Didion and John Gregory Dunne, old friends from California. He's spent time with the radical educator Ivan Illich in Cuernavaca, and among his intellectual cronies is the Mexican novelist Carlos Fuentes. For policy advice he's said to depend on the economist Lester Thurow and on Richard Goodwin, who was a member of Kennedy's inner circle. (Mr. Brown and Mr. Clinton both read Mr. Goodwin's forthcoming book, which is tentatively entitled "Promises to Keep: A Call for a New American Revolution," in manuscript.) Is he a big reader? "He doesn't read as much as he vacuums," Mr. Dunne says. "If he sees a book, he will pick it up, take it back to the bedroom and be ready to discuss it in the morning."
The trouble with Mr. Brown, as far as some intellectuals are concerned, is that he's too New Age. While Mr. Clinton golfs, he hangs out at the Buddhist retreat Tassajara in Big Sur. Also, his chances of winning are slim, and intellectuals like a winner as much as anyone else. As the Democratic front-runner, Mr. Clinton has been eagerly adopted by the Endangered Species -- if you include in that category some of the more literate journalists. In the corridors of mental power, Mr. Clinton is clearly the man, the one to revive intellectuals' perennial hope of sharing in a power they've never had, and probably never will have. "Clinton is about the renaissance of policy," declared the political commentator Sidney Blumenthal in a New Republic cover story last month that featured a caricature of Mr. Clinton as Superman. The cover line read "The Anointed."
Not that Mr. Clinton, despite being a Rhodes scholar, is necessarily an intellectual himself. He's not like Gov. Mario Cuomo, quoting Teilhard de Chardin to every Albany beat reporter who wanders into his office. On the campaign trail in Illinois, Mr. Clinton pulled out a copy of Sara Paretsky's "Guardian Angel" -- she's a mystery writer, but a literary, highbrow mystery writer. His favorite writers, he has said, are Robert Ludlum and P. D. James -- neither likely to top the "10-best" list of subscribers to Partisan Review. (Well, maybe P. D. James.) But Mr. Clinton seems brainy: he graduated from Yale Law School, he's a Rhodes Scholar, he knows -- and is known to know -- intellectuals.
 
The Right Aura?

 He's not, however, a member of the Eastern Establishment. "Kennedy was an insider in that world," notes Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., who still is. "Clinton is an outsider."
What matters is his intellectual aura: Garry Wills publishes an admiring piece about Hillary Clinton in The New York Review of Books, noting her contributions to the Yale Law Journal and the Harvard Educational Review, and describing her as "one of the more important scholar-activists of the last two decades." Arthur Schlesinger detects "an end-of-an-era feeling" that prefigures change -- a kind of Hegelian tide that confirms on the mental plane his theory of a 30-year cycle in American history.
Perhaps even more significantly, Mr. Clinton strikes the right intellectual note -- one of worldliness and self-deprecation, of rueful irony. In the latest issue of The American Oxonian, the journal of the Association of American Rhodes Scholars, his entry in the 1968 Class Letter reports that daughter Chelsea, "age 11, 5 feet 2 inches, size 9 shoes," loves ballet more than politics.
"Accordingly, says Bill" -- in the artful paraphrase of class secretary Robert B. Reich, the policy analyst from Harvard's Kennedy School of Government who is one of Mr. Clinton's chief advisers -- "he and Hillary must have done something right." If Governor Clinton wins, Mr. Reich observes, "Bill will be the very first U.S. President from our Oxford class."

LENGTH: 808 words

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International 3-11

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Could Baker's Grip on Tiller Right Bush Campaign Drift?

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD with THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
George Bush, Jim Baker and Pat Buchanan are in a rowboat that sinks. Who gets saved?
The answer to the joke, now making the rounds in Washington, is: Israel. 
 When the President was told the joke, and asked who gets saved, he reportedly provided his own punch line: "Baker."
It was a natural response. James A. Baker 3d has long been considered a master at saving himself from getting drawn into distasteful political situations, even those involving his old friend George Bush.
 
'Always on the Phone'
 Salvation and sibling rivalry are the threads that have always run through the 35-year relationship of the President and the Secretary of State, who are jokingly referred to in some quarters as Bobby and J. R. Ewing, the brothers of "Dallas" fame. Mr. Bush helped save Mr. Baker from thinking about his first wife's death, back in Houston in 1969, by getting him involved in politics. Mr. Baker reluctantly agreed to give up his job as Treasury Secretary to run the Bush campaign in 1988 and help save his friend's Presidential bid.
Now, with the President wounded and adrift, the question is once again being raised in news reports and political circles: Will Mr. Baker have to come in and save Mr. Bush?
Mr. Baker has been talking more about politics with the President. "The President and Baker are always on the phone, and it doesn't take a genius to figure out that they are talking about other things than foreign policy," said one top White House aide.
White House officials describe the President as "very miserable" and "irritated" by the indecisive and chaotic performance of his political advisers in the White House and in the campaign, and by his inability to get ahead of the political curve.
The President himself shows no sign of craving Mr. Baker's return to the campaign, say aides. Mr. Bush is said not to be frightened about his chances of being re-elected. He is "chagrined," as one Bush intimate put it, about the political advice he has been getting, and the thin-skinned President is upset with the Republican voters who have turned on him when he was expecting a coronation, not a crucifixion from the right and the left.
But whether Mr. Baker's return would provide redemption may not be that simple. In this year when politics trembles with rage and dislocation, when the campaign trail has become the wild earth, when voters are fed up with old boys' clubs and Washington insiders and excessive attention to foreign policy, it is likely to be rough weather for the patrician pals who have relished their years striding the world stage.
"This is a moment in history for the Harris Woffords, the David Dukes, the Jerry Browns, the Pat Buchanans, the Bernie Sanders," said Kevin Phillips, the author and conservative analyst. "George Herbert Walker Bush and James A. Baker 3d don't get called to the colors by this sort of an unhappy populace."
While he would do anything he could to avoid being drawn back into managing another campaign, Mr. Baker understands that his fate is tangled up with Mr. Bush's. So he and friends have been trading calls about what greater role he might play behind the scenes to bring some discipline to the White House and campaign organization.
After Bush campaign officials dealt with the Buchanan threat by "running around like chickens with their heads cut off," in the words of one top White House official, even the generally apolitical Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, suggested to Mr. Baker and the President that Mr. Baker visit the campaign team and try to "settle everyone down." Mr. Baker refused, saying he was the Secretary of State.
"Baker looks over here and is just horrified," said one White House official. "This looks to him like a three-ring circus."
 
Staying Away From What Won't Work?
 Mr. Baker, who is obsessed with shedding his image as a political handler and being remembered as a statesman, dreads the thought of returning to the circus, his friends say. He keeps his public distance from the campaign team of Robert M. Teeter, Frederick Malek and Samuel K. Skinner, the White House chief of staff, who have been criticized inside the White House and in Republican circles for their inability to make decisions and bring consistancy and substance to the campaign.
"You can judge what Baker doesn't think will work by what he stays away from," Mr. Phillips said. "His picture hasn't been seen posing with Skinner, Teeter and Malek. That would be a portrait of Machiavelli and the Three Dwarfs."
There is a division of opinion in the White House about the prospects of the Democrats. Some Bush officials feel confident about the disarray in the Democratic field and predict that Bill Clinton will either self-destruct on the character issues or fall prey to Republican attacks tarring him as a weak executive and a liberal. Others, including the unlikely alliance of Mr. Baker and Vice President Dan Quayle, have a healthy respect for the Arkansas Governor's political skills and an appreciation for the volcanic nature of this political season.
Everyone at the White House these days seems to have an opinion about whether Mr. Baker would ever come back to run the campaign. The overwhelming majority side with the Baker friend who has been talking to the Secretary of State about it and says, "I would bet you $10,000 to $500 it won't happen." Others say, though, that if the campaign goes into "meltdown," as one Administration official put it, in the general election campaign, Mr. Bush will have to swallow his pride and ask Mr. Baker to take the helm.
It is a moment both men dread. The President does not want his biography to read that Mr. Baker was his Svengali, and Mr. Baker does not want his biography to read "that he was a professional campaign manager who took a few stints in other areas of policy," as the political analyst Norman Ornstein put it.
It would be hard for Mr. Baker to save Mr. Bush, since they are both part of the problem: It is their style that has helped give the impression that this Administration is out of touch with the lives and needs and yearnings of ordinary Americans. It is ironic that their shortcomings, foreshadowed early in the Administration, can be seen so clearly in the foreign policy arena where they have focused all their energies and claimed many successes.
When the world all seemed to be coming their way, with Communism crumbling on their watch, they got by with their elitist "we know best" approach, with decisions being made in a very close circle without either man explaining policies to the American people to summon support, or articulating the emotion of a moment for a nation hungry for a voice.
Speaking about the cold war's end, one White House official said, "People don't feel good about what is happening, because they have never been told why they should."
 
Cold-Blooded Eyes, Events of Passion
 In today's world, where ethnic and cultural passions are boiling, and when Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker need to galvanize a broad national constituency to support very unpopular foreign aid for the former Soviet Union or exploit an opportunity for peace in the Middle East that requires getting tough with Israel, their cold-blooded pragmatism and their clubby attitude about world leaders is out of sync.
A lot of this arose from the fact that Mr. Bush was fleeing the shadow of Ronald Reagan, and Mr. Baker, despite his reputation for political savvy and his promise to bring domestic considerations into foreign policy, has sometimes shown a surprising aversion and lack of touch for the politics of his job.
"Bush was so afraid of being handled that he never understood that Reagan properly communicated to the country and set the stage for what he thought was important," said one top Republican. "Bush threw the baby out with the bath water and decided to only talk inside baseball about the new world order."
The truth is that, Mr. Baker, who was a great manager for Mr. Reagan, is unable to complement Mr. Bush in this area: While the President feels no need to explain his policies to the public, the frosty Mr. Baker cannot compensate because he hates politicking and engaging with the public.
For the last three years, Mr. Baker has studiously scaled back the usual hand-holding sessions with American Jewish leaders that his predecessors routinely put up with. This is partly out of his own closed style of management. The fact is, explained one State Department official who insisted on anonymity, "Baker doesn't like meeting with anybody: Jews, Arabs, Palestinians, Japanese, foreign service officers, ambassadors. . . the rest of the State Department."
Mr. Baker rarely gives speeches, never gives in-depth interviews, and has failed to cultivate domestic constituencies for his foreign policy initiatives -- be it for aiding the Russians, dealing with China through a nuanced combination of carrots and sticks, maintaining the special relationship with Japan, or coming down hard on Israel for its settlements in occupied territories.
"For these guys, there is no relationship between politics and policy," argued Michael Mandelbaum, a foreign policy adviser to Mr. Clinton, in a remark that may presage the general election debate. "In the Bush-Baker world view, you do ugly, distasteful things to get elected. You hire people like Lee Atwater and John Sununu to do what has to be done. And then when you get into office, you do what you think is right. The idea that you should have to explain yourself to them is grubby."
When they are pressed by an anxious public to justify a major foreign policy initiative, they tend to reach for the crudest sort of domestic rationale.
When Secretary Baker found that the Administration was having a tough time explaining a possible war with Iraq to Americans who did not want to shed blood for oil, he finally said that the real reason was economic: "Jobs, jobs, jobs," he said.
A year later, when President Bush found himself criticized for too much travel overseas before a state visit to Japan, he finally said the real reason was economic: "Jobs, jobs, jobs."
"Both of those moments revealed their contempt for the public," said Ann Lewis a Democratic consultant from Boston. "It was as though people were yammering at them to do something about the country while they were trying to make great decisions on the international front. When they talked about jobs, it sounded like they were saying, 'Are you satisfied now?' It rings so false."
 
Declining to Explain Their Strong Case
 When some Administration officials suggested to Mr. Baker that on one of his trips to Israel it might be a good idea to go on a popular Friday evening television news show there and give an interview that would explain to the Israeli public exactly what he is doing and why, Mr. Baker rejected the idea. "I won't beg anyone for peace," he said.
The Administration foreign policy has suffered from failing to fashion an understandable framework in the wake of the cold war for its continuing relationship with Israel. Therefore, even though a strong policy case could be made for Mr. Bush's refusal to grant loan guarantees to Israel unless it halted settlement building in the occupied territories, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker did not make the case.
They never really explained publicly why they were imposing the restrictions they did except by citing generalities about advancing the cause of peace. Therefore, the policy was widely interpreted as flowing from Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker's personal antipathy for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel or from their obsession with settlements, rather than a coherent substantive case.
 
Policy Lapse Exacts A Personal Price
 Mr. Baker has paid a personal price for this failure to connect his ideas with the heart of an important constituency. When reports surfaced that he had used a profanity to dismiss Jewish supporters of Israel, which he vehemently denied, not a single American Jewish leader was ready to stand up and defend him, even though he is the first Secretary of State in history who managed to bring the Arabs to the peace table for direct talks with Israel on terms acceptable to Israel.
The Administration is having a very tough time getting Congressional approval for its latest aid package for Russia because officials simply have not developed any domestic support for it. Congress wants the President to go first; the President, gauging the public mood, is reluctant to press a high-profile foreign aid initiative at this time. The result is gridlock. No wonder some State Department officials were quietly applauding when former President Richard M. Nixon chastized Mr. Bush for responding "pathetically" to this historic moment, hoping that it would shame Mr. Bush into action.
"I think the country is crying out for leadership," said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa. "When there is a major issue of our time that is not being addressed, such as the Russian aid question, the alternative party usually steps forward. This time the Democrats have not, which is why in this void the new moral voice in America is Richard Nixon."

HEADLINE: A Siberian Town: Not a Secret and Ready to Deal

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KRASNOYARSK-26, Russia, March 26

 BODY:
At the huge secret heart of the former Soviet military-industrial complex is a place that looks like a well-kept little town in Germany, though it is surrounded by electrified barbed wire and checkpoints.
Unlike most cities throughout the former Soviet empire, the streets here are beautifully paved and maintained; the shops are clean, attractive and well stocked; there are ponds and parks; the apartment buildings are elegant and substantial, and the wooden windows are nicely varnished, rather than covered with flaking layers of badly applied paint. 
 To come here to this town in Siberia, 2,500 miles from Moscow and 80 minutes' drive north of Krasnoyarsk itself, feels a bit like the landing in Oz must have felt for Dorothy and Toto. While hardly Greenwich, Conn., Krasnoyarsk-26 is a vision of what generations of Soviet leaders hoped would be the future for the general population, with Lenin standing tall in Lenin Square, the hammer and sickle everywhere and an engaged, cultured life in pleasant surroundings.
But the seal of this city of 100,000 people -- a place that appears on no map and has only three main employers -- shows a Russian bear handling a ball of radioactive material, while atoms orbit around him. The city is powered by an underground nuclear reactor, and there are radiation-dosage meters posted on public streets.
Founded under Stalin in the late 1940's in the wide expanses north of Krasnoyarsk, Krasnoyarsk-26 was devoted to the mining and production of nuclear materials in the race to make a Soviet atomic bomb. Run by Lavrenti P. Beria, Stalin's security chief, it attracted the country's scientific elite and cossetted them, isolating them entirely from any of the problems of the ordinary civilian economy.
Today, with the Soviet world ruptured and then turned upside down, this secret, secure, privileged world, entirely dependent on the military is also trembling. Krasnoyarsk-26 and the cities like it, named in a utilitarian fashion after their postal codes, suddenly have to earn a living in a more commercial environment. And with some distaste they are setting out at least some of their wares before Western businessmen and governments, looking for investment partners and hard currency.
It is a kind of fire sale at which the United States and other countries are looking to buy high technology at cheap prices, or to farm out dirty jobs like the reprocessing and storage of spent nuclear fuel. But for the proud industrial barons of the towns, who are among the country's best managers and who feel they honorably and patriotically served their country's highest interests, it is also a great humiliation.
"Frankly speaking, the people here supported the August coup" against Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said one of the 11,000 workers at the Scientific Production Association of Applied Mechanics, which makes military and civilian communication and navigation satellites and wants Western customers and investors.
In an office on the shop floor, there is a portrait of Leonid I. Brezhnev, whose long rule is now generally sneered at throughout the nation as the "time of stagnation," but under whom towns like this one still had the best of everything.
"It is only very recently that military-industrial leaders begin to realize that they cannot go back," said Yuri F. Tarasyuk, chairman of the subcommittee on defense and conversion of Russia's Supreme Soviet. "Before, they thought that all this would be temporary, that military orders would shortly return, that the state would finance them and they would have all the privileges they used to have."
 
Business Executives Visit
 Efforts first begun by Mr. Gorbachev to convert part of the gigantic Soviet military-industrial complex to civilian production had only a small effect in cities like this one, whose very existence was revealed by Soviet officials only in 1988 and which has only been open to invited foreigners in the last three weeks. A visit to the city this week by an international group of businessmen specializing in telecommunications was put together by the Paris-based Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development.
With Russia sharply cutting its military spending while moving toward a free market based on world prices, the breakdown of the centralized distribution system and generally wretched state of the real Russian economy have been a considerable material and psychological blow to Krasnoyarsk-26.
The need to make money, to manufacture efficiently, and to take care of the thousands of employees and their dependents in what had been an almost entirely uncompetitive world is a staggering task. So the huge enterprises here are trying to sell some of their products and expertise to Western companies and countries for hard currency.
 
Best Food and Supplies
 Otherwise, the secret towns, which are thought to number about a score, and all of the other 240 or so towns in the former union wholly dependent on military spending, will wither. And their substantial buildings and theaters, museums and concert halls, markets and hospitals, will deteriorate as well, sinking to the level of the economy surrounding them.
"I hate what is happening in this country," said a young woman resident who helped translate for the businessmen, and who found great pleasure in speaking to the first foreigner she had ever met in a language she had studied from books and tape recordings.
She considers herself a good Communist still, and said there were many like her in Krasnoyarsk-26. Without quite blaming the downfall of the Soviet Union on foreign meddling, she kept a polite but careful distance from these foreigners, and asked that her name not be printed. Her mother works in one of the plants at something "extremely secret," she said, involving software; her father works in a distribution center for food supplies.
Previously, the town received the best supplies of meat and vegetables, including tropical fruits like bananas and pineapples the year around, even during the Siberian winter. Krasnoyarsk-26 was still comparatively well provisioned, she said, while admitting she had no clear picture of the way most Russians live.
 
Contact With the Outside
 That is hardly surprising. When the city was begun in the Stalin period and until only recently, foreign travel and contact with foreigners were forbidden. Residents were denied access to ordinary telephones. Travel outside the city was discouraged, and bonuses were paid if annual vacations were taken inside. Close relatives were allowed to visit only once a year, and that at the discretion of the security forces. Russians spoke only of those working "beyond the barbed wire."
The new Mayor of the town, Vladimir Kretov, said the visit of the foreigners was "a very historical event for us." He spoke of the enormous sacrifice made by the nation to support cities like this one and its work.
"But we can no longer be protected from outside events," Mr. Kretov said, or remain dependent on only a few big firms.
They must convert more to civilian production, he said, and the city in the meanwhile was trying to encourage the establishment of smaller commercial enterprises and cooperatives. There was even some talk of changing the name of the town, he said, to make it more ordinary. He favored "Severo-Krasnoyarsk," or North Krasnoyarsk. Others favor Atomgrad or Kosmosgrad -- Atomcity or Spacecity.
 
Nuclear Reprocessing Plant
 Valery A. Lebedev, his silky gray hair cut as well as his dark suit, is the director of the Mining-Chemical Enterprise, which still produces nuclear materials and reprocesses spent nuclear fuel. He said only 79 percent of his firm's work now is military, and the rest civilian, and he is looking to interest Westerners in buying superpure materials like aluminum, gallium and tellurium used in electronics.
He said a new plant to make polycrystalline silicon would be in operation in 1994, with an eventual output of 1,450 tons a year. He was also overseeing a new plant to reprocess nuclear fuel from power plants that could handle between 2,000 and 3,000 tons a year, a huge figure.
"We'll put it out in the Siberian taiga," or forest, he said lightly, implying that the Russian environmental movement had never been Krasnoyarsk-26's biggest concern.
The Western businessmen, for their part, seemed largely unimpressed.
"Some of the materials are good and cheaper, and no one in the West wants to do nuclear reprocessing," said an American businessman from a large telecommunications company. "But their satellite technology is nothing special, and Western satellites carry many more channels and last twice as long."
Still, he said, "they didn't show us much more than a metal-bashing shop," and it was difficult to know the real capabilities of such highly protected enterprises.
A Frenchman was harsher.
"It is a nice place for Russia, but it is doomed," he said. "Even now, it looks like a nice little provincial town in Germany, but only a place you drive through, not somewhere to spend the night."
